HEADLINE: The Winning Thing

BYLINE: By Martin Tolchin; Martin Tolchin is a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times and the author, with Susan J. Tolchin, of "Selling Our Security: The Erosion of America's Assets," to be published this month.

 BODY:

MARCHING IN PLACE
The Status Quo Presidency of George Bush.
By Michael Duffy and Dan Goodgame.
316 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $23. 
 GEORGE BUSH is really a nice guy. A ruthless competitor, perhaps, but a "classy" fellow, "exceptionally well mannered, modest, restrained, generous and considerate of others." So say Michael Duffy and Dan Goodgame, Time magazine's White House correspondents, in their lively, informative book, "Marching in Place: The Status Quo Presidency of George Bush."
From them we learn that the President excels at personal diplomacy, that he is an inveterate writer of thank-you notes and that he calls his 91-year-old mother in Greenwich, Conn., nearly every day. There is no mention, however, of the Clarence Thomas hearings, or of Mr. Bush's cynicism in proclaiming Mr. Thomas the most qualified candidate in the country for the United States Supreme Court, and only passing reference to the savings and loan scandal, with none at all to his son Neil's reprimand by Federal regulators in connection with a failed thrift institution. Nor do the authors comment on the questions raised in the news media about the propriety of some business dealings by his brother Prescott.
Nevertheless, the book is a valuable primer on the Bush Presidency. The theme: George Bush is an elitist who believes in winning at all costs, the better to preserve the status quo.
The authors debunk Mr. Bush's self-portrait of his young adulthood. After Yale, far from striking out in a bold break with "the comfort and connections of his East Coast roots," Mr. Bush was offered a job in Odessa, Tex., with a company whose chairman was one of his father's closest friends. The authors report that "the new red Studebaker station wagon that Bush often describes as the chariot of his independence was bought for him by his family." And the Bush family helped young George along with a $300,000 grubstake.
Mr. Duffy and Mr. Goodgame track the political pragmatism that led Mr. Bush to repudiate his abortion-rights views and embrace the Reagan economic program he had derided in the 1980 Republican primaries as "voodoo economics." Is there a there there? Did Mr. Bush believe in anything besides winning?
To capture the Republican nomination for himself after eight years as Ronald Reagan's Vice President, Mr. Bush unabashedly courted Republican conservatives, who reluctantly joined "his only real base: the roughly 10 million Republicans who identified closely with Bush's background, experience, wealth and breeding." Mr. Bush then successfully wooed Reagan Democrats and suburban independents to gain the Presidency.
In their description of the Bush White House, the authors devote almost an entire chapter (entitled "Color Me Bad") to John Sununu, the former chief of staff, with his penchant for the gratuitous insult. Mr. Sununu lost his temper even with his conservative supporters. Edwin Feulner, the president of the Heritage Foundation, who had been upbraided by Mr. Sununu, warned him that "there's going to come a point, somewhere in your career, when you're going to find that you need somebody broader and deeper in your corner than the one man in the Oval Office." Indeed, when that time finally came, even his conservative allies turned against him.
Mr. Duffy and Mr. Goodgame believe that the President's slow response to the recession underscores his failure to appreciate the concerns of average Americans. They say that Mr. Bush "lacks any fingertip feel for what it is to be a member of the wage-earning middle class in America." Chauffeured to school during the Depression, he has spent his life "surrounded by other white, well-educated, well-connected men with money behind them and bright futures ahead."
The President was angered by this book, although it is evenhanded, down to its title. After all, his critics contend that from his judicial appointments to his positions on a multitude of domestic issues, Mr. Bush has been leading a retreat from social responsibility. That is certainly worse than simply "marching in place."

HEADLINE: The End of Racism, and Other Fables

BYLINE: By Linda Greenhouse; Linda Greenhouse covers the United States Supreme Court for The New York Times.

 BODY:

FACES AT THE BOTTOM OF THE WELL
The Permanence of Racism.
By Derrick Bell.
222 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $20. 
 IN Derrick Bell's view, discourse about race in America is mired in the sugarcoated myth that equality for blacks will be found just around the corner, as soon as the country completes its fitful but inevitably progressive journey toward enlightenment and justice.
The myth is sweet but ultimately disabling and dangerous, he believes, because it denies to both blacks and whites understanding of a truth that is almost exactly the opposite: that racism is not a passing phase but a permanent feature of American life, and that the path is marked not by real progress but by occasional short-lived judicial or legislative victories that serve to obscure the underlying truth even more.
Both in his writing and by his actions, Mr. Bell, one of the country's most prominent scholars of race and the law, has spent years trying to bring this message both to other blacks and to the white-majority institutions in which he has worked. Most notable of these is Harvard Law School, where, more than 20 years ago, he became the first black faculty member to receive tenure. Two years ago he vowed to remain on an unpaid leave until the law school hired a black woman for its tenured faculty. In July, Harvard Law School refused to extend his leave for a third year and informed him that his failure to return meant he had relinquished his position on the faculty, which still includes no tenured black women. He is currently a visiting professor at New York University Law School.
Without directly addressing this episode, Mr. Bell's new book, "Faces at the Bottom of the Well: The Permanence of Racism," nonetheless makes it appear not only understandable but almost inevitable. Like his previous book, "And We Are Not Saved: The Elusive Quest for Racial Justice," this one approaches his theme indirectly, through allegory, fables and dialogues with a fictional "lawyer-prophet," a mordantly wise black woman named Geneva Crenshaw, whose role is to goad and inspire the professor-narrator to confront the truth without the sugarcoating.
These are fables with footnotes as well as irony: Jonathan Swift come to law school. Harvard figures prominently, as does the Supreme Court; most of the stories began as seminar teaching tools to prod students to re-examine old assumptions. There is the "Racial Preference Licensing Act," for example, a new Federal law of Ms. Crenshaw's design under which white business owners could obtain a license that would free them to discriminate openly, rather than covertly as they do at present, against black employees and customers. In return for this privilege, the whites would pay a 3 percent tax into an "equality fund" that would be used to support business opportunities and education for blacks.
When Mr. Bell objects that the Racial Preference Licensing Act is too farfetched even for him, Ms. Crenshaw accuses him of holding on to an outdated faith in "the civil rights ideals that events long ago rendered obsolete." The new law, she says, could be more effective than "those laws that now provide us the promise of protection without either the will or the resources to honor that promise." Ms. Crenshaw sternly reminds Mr. Bell that he himself has written that "whatever the civil rights law or constitutional provision, blacks gain little protection against one or another form of racial discrimination unless granting blacks a measure of relief will serve some interest of importance to whites."
There is the story of Afrolantica, a mysterious lost continent that arises from the ocean. The evidence that, for some unknown reason, only black Americans can breathe the air on the beautiful island leads to a vigorous debate over whether they should move there and claim it as their homeland.
ONE of the most effective fables, and by far the most chilling, is the tale of the Space Traders -- creatures from another planet who offer the United States the solution to all its economic and environmental ills in exchange for one thing: its black population, which would be carried off to an unknown fate in outer space. The story becomes a canvas for Mr. Bell's portraits of the wise, foolish, weak, strong and venal characters of both races who respond to this challenge to the national soul. That the outcome is predictable makes it no less heartbreaking.
Not every fable in "Faces at the Bottom of the Well" -- the title reflects the author's vision of the place of blacks in American society -- has the sure touch of the Space Traders tale. Some wander from their theme, and there is some settling of personal scores. But this book well serves the goal Mr. Bell describes to Geneva Crenshaw, of "attempting to sing a new scholarly song -- even if to some listeners our style is strange, our lyrics unseemly." The stories challenge old assumptions and then linger in the mind in a way that a more conventionally scholarly treatment of the same themes would be unlikely to do.
Mr. Bell does not hold out hope for success in objectively measurable terms. Rather, he says -- putting the words in the mouth of a white female guerrilla fighter for black survival in one of the fables -- "there is satisfaction in the struggle itself," a "salvation through struggle."
In this starkly existentialist vision, a commitment to pressing on in the face of absurdity, Derrick Bell draws as much from Albert Camus as from Martin Luther King. In an epilogue, constructed as a letter to Geneva Crenshaw, he writes: "We yearn that our civil rights work will be crowned with success, but what we really want -- want even more than success -- is meaning. . . . This engagement and commitment is what black people have had to do since slavery: making something out of nothing."
 
 
 
RACIAL REALISM
 Erika looked thoughtful. . . . "We call ourselves White Citizens for Black Survival, or WCBS. Our program has two prongs. First, the policy phase we call 'racial realism.' Then the activist phase, in which we aim to build a nationwide network of secret shelters to house and feed black people in the event of a black holocaust or some other all-out attack on America's historic scapegoats."
"A late-20th-century underground railroad!" I exclaimed. "You can't be serious?"
"You -- and other blacks as well -- need to get serious. What precisely would you do if they came for you? How would you protect your family? Where could you go? How get there? You have money. Could you get access to it if the Government placed a hold on the assets in your checking and savings accounts?" -- From "Faces at the Bottom of the Well."
 
 
 
'THE TRUTH IS NEVER DESPAIRING'
 Derrick Bell says that while he was writing "Faces at the Bottom of the Well," his publisher referred to the book as "unremittingly despairing." It argues that America is a racist country and always will be. Mr. Bell says he responded: "No, you don't understand. For a black person in this society, the truth is never despairing."
In an interview at his office at New York University Law School, Mr. Bell said that when he explains his thoughts on race to black groups these days, he hears the laughter and applause of recognition. "It reaffirms that it is not their fault," he said. "It is an affirmation of themselves and not a basis for despair."
The 61-year-old author said he reached his bleak conclusions over the course of a career in civil rights that he now believes was misdirected. Despite all the change over the years, he said, blacks are worse off and more subjugated than at any time since slavery. The only difference now is that there is "a more effective, more sophisticated means of domination."
But he also believes in the importance of struggling anyway. He has fought many such battles himself, the most recent being his protest against the absence of a black woman on the Harvard Law School faculty. On June 30, his 23-year tenure there was revoked after he refused to end a two-year leave of absence.
He will teach at N.Y.U. this year, but he has no definite plans after that. He is working on two new books. One is a collection of student essays on law and race; the other, drawing from his own experiences, is tentatively entitled "Constructing Character Through Confrontation."
Every time Mr. Bell has quit a job in frustration or protest, he said, things have worked out well. He recognizes that not everyone always gets such good results. "What you can say without reservation is that to stand up when everybody else is sitting down, to leave a job when you think it's intolerable, you feel better," he said. "It may not be long before you can't pay the bills, but there's a sense that you did the right thing." -- JON ELSEN

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Wedges and Bounces

BYLINE: By WIlliam Safire

 BODY:
America is back up on wedgies. Remember those triangulated, high-soled shoes of the 40's that incorporated the heel and turned the fashionable woman into an endangered species? They're back -- not merely in the form of platform soles, but planks in political platforms.
In 1990, as Bush White House aides fought over the degree to which affirmative action guidelines became quotas, the former Carter adviser Stuart E. Eizenstat said with some prescience that the Republicans had "a need to give the Reagan Democrats red meat at a time when the economy is going into the tank, and they see civil rights and quotas as a wedge issue." 
 Recalling this early usage and perhaps coinage, Mr. Eizenstat tells me: "I was looking for a phrase to illustrate the attempt to split the coalition of working-class whites and blacks, the two constituencies Roosevelt unified on economic grounds. The image came to mind of a wedge being driven."
It filled a political-linguistic need for fresh labels. Another Democrat, the Clinton strategist James Carville, charged two years later that President Bush's advisers, bereft of an agenda, had to "dust off the Republican manual, which is to go to wedge issues: 'We can't lead the country so maybe we can divide it.' "
As a phrase, wedge issue is related to the 80's hot-button issue, which was an updating of the 70's polarization. Wedge, with earthy Indo-European roots as both verb and noun, strikes me as an improvement over the Latinate polarize and polarization.
Wedge issue is a political attack locution, usually used by liberals and moderates, aimed at politicians on the right who bring up sensitive cultural and social subjects during political campaigns. The dividing wedge, however, need not be racial: free trade is seen by the right as a wedge issue to use to divide workers and environmentalists on the left.
Here is a synonymy of the issues issue: a switcher issue -- like gun control or abortion -- is a single subject that will cause a minority of voters to change their vote regardless of other patterns, urges or habits (resulting in a bullet vote).
A hot-button issue -- like perks for big shots or global warming -- will cause a potential voter to become agitated, but not necessarily to the point of switching allegiance; touching this button causes audiences to roar or hoot, and is synonymous with red meat, the figure of speech drawn from the excited reaction of carnivorous animals when food is thrown into their cage.
A gut issue has a wider visceral appeal: the intestinal matter on this year's agenda is the slow growth of the economy, expressed in the single word "jobs." This bread-and-butter issue can also be the burning issue if it is dramatized, but if the opposition fails to ignite it, the subject is better described as the paramount issue. As an issue fades, it becomes characterized as a yawner.
 
PEROTIAN ALERT
 I MISS ROSS PEROT. NOT only did he apply the traffic term gridlock to divided-party government, but also the jug-eared, thin-skinned executive generated the most derisive sobriquet of the current campaign, as his betrayed supporters called him "the yellow Ross of Texas."
In Forbes magazine's 75th anniversary issue, Peggy Noonan, the former Reagan-Bush speechwriter who has developed the art of impressionism in political prose, summarized the voters' view of the horseless head man in a poetic trope: "They looked at him and saw a hand grenade with a bad haircut."
<HH>THE WAY THE POLL BOUNCES
 "IT'S PARTLY A convention bounce," Gov. Bill Clinton said after his poll ratings shot up in July.
As August ended and the Republicans had convened in Houston, the Bush-Quayle ratings improved somewhat and The Christian Science Monitor wrote, "It represents a routine convention bounce." Newsweek, in its Conventional Wisdom Watch, asked, "Why does the CW worry about the 'convention  bounce' if the CW also says the bounce dissipates within two weeks?"
The much-discussed convention bounce is a temporary rise in the opinion polls caused by the television exposure and print commentary during a party's national convention. As The Associated Press reported in 1988, "The convention bounce usually settles down as voters focus on the issues of the race."
Bounce has triumphed over the variant bump. Who coined the phrase? In 1980, the Carter Presidential spokesman, Jody Powell, used the term to mean a psychological lift: he said that the increase in President Carter's rating was "the post-convention bounce we hoped for." In a dozen years, the post- prefix has worn off.
 
WORDS OF WISDOM
 PHRASE JUNKIES ARE always on the lookout for political axioms, adages and proverbs.
Bert Lance's "If it ain't broke, don't fix it" has become a source of inspiration to anti-activists. Dwight Morrow's "Any party which takes credit for the rain must not be surprised if its opponents blame it for the drought" is being ruefully repeated by supporters of George Bush. Economists eager to fine-tune the economy turn to the wisdom attributed to the gangster Al Capone: "You can get a lot more done with a kind word and a gun, than with a kind word alone."
A subcategory in this field is "forgiveness, political," headed by the quotation attributed to the Kennedy brothers: "Forgive but don't forget." An addition to this store of sophisticated sagacity has been provided by the newscaster Jim Lehrer, in his new, breezily profound memoir, "A Bus of My Own" (Putnam). He notes in passing that some former associates tried to do him in, and then forgives them, but not completely: "As a prominent Oklahoma politician says a lot," Lehrer writes, " 'Show me somebody who can't tell his friends from his enemies and I'll show you somebody who's going to end up with no friends.' "

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
The Thrill of Outer Space for Earthbound Lives

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
AN ANNIVERSARY IS UPON US, and attention must be paid. It has been 25 years since the opening of Atlanta's Hyatt Regency Hotel, the first of the atrium-style extravaganzas created by the architect and developer John Portman. Is it possibly redundant to celebrate this milestone? After all, the Portman atrium has been a nonstop celebration for the past quarter century. A festive mix of fountains, flapping banners and light-bulb-studded elevators rising to the skies like effervescent bubbles, the Portman atrium is architecture at happy hour. It's a building that's gone out of town to a convention, determined to have a blast.
Still, a toast is in order for a concept that set out to give pleasure and in fact did so. Architects work with space, and few architects of this century have created such drama out of three dimensions. Twenty-three stories tall, set off by balconies carpeted a rich red, the Atlanta atrium presented space as the ultimate luxury. Here, the empty void became a commodity as precious as the marble and gold that adorned the grand hotels of the Edwardian age. 
 Portman's is not a subtle space. With its elevators hurtling into the firmament like space capsules, the enclosed court is less Apollo than Apollo Space Program. It injects into earthbound lives the thrill of America's first ventures into outer space. Portman was our leading scientist of inner space. Psychologically as well as physically introverted, his voids maintained a constant emotional pitch with their suave blend of pleasure and terror, cocktails and vertigo.
In his later hotels, like the Bonaventure in Los Angeles and the Peachtree Center Plaza in Atlanta, the rocket imagery was even more explicit. Towering round cylinders encased in mirrored glass, these buildings evoked silos from which missiles might momentarily erupt. But where were these spaceships headed? For buildings, outer space is the city, and in this realm Portman's space mission sadly fizzled. Indeed, his introverted architecture remains a conspicuous symbol of what went wrong with cities over the past quarter century: the accelerating retreat from the public realm into enclaves of private luxury.
The most glaring example appeared in 1977, with Portman's design for Renaissance Center in Detroit. Though $357 million was poured into the project in the hope of stirring the revival of this economically depressed city, the complex of office buildings, retail shops and a hotel sat isolated from the urban context within a gleaming fortress. Suburban shoppers could drive into the Renaissance without setting foot downtown.
Portman's Marriott Marquis Hotel, in Times Square, also imposes a barrier between the atrium and the city outside. With a lobby lodged eight stories above street level, as though guests should ideally arrive by helicopter, the hotel affronts the street with gloomy overhangs and a midblock driveway. The effect is to turn the sidewalk into a subterranean parking garage.
But the exclusionary thrust of the design is secondary to an eager inclusiveness that coerces people to eat, drink, shop and sleep within the hotel walls. Tourists encounter the city only visually here, through windows of the revolving rooftop cocktail lounge where machinery, rather than visitors' feet, dictates the view. Throughout the hotel, design issues a protective order that makes the city outside a forbidding presence, mercifully kept at bay.
In 1976, with the city planner Jonathan Barnett, Portman co-authored a manifesto, "The Architect as Developer." It is clear from the text that he believed his concept contributed something valuable to urban life. He writes perceptively of the failure of Modern city planning, of the architect's responsibility to re-engage the public. But a Portman atrium is not, of course, a public space. It is a tightly controlled private environment outfitted with the trappings of public space: openness, fountains, trees, bustling crowds. At the Marriott Marquis, there's even a town clock. But this visual dissembling is exploitive, if not sinister, especially considering that Portman received concessions from the public sector in the hope that the hotel would help revive Times Square.
The fact remains, however, that John Portman made a genuine effort to imagine some form of public life at a time when the very concept was in crisis. For by the mid-1960's, America's older industrial cities had witnessed the collapse of two overarching ideas that had governed their design: the historicism of the 19th-century City Beautiful movement and the rationalism of the Modern movement. And the era's most influential minds were opposed to new master-plan approaches. In 1961, Jane Jacobs had argued persuasively that diversity, not unified order, was what made cities live. A decade later, as Portman's second atrium hotel arose at O'Hare Airport in Chicago, Richard Sennett championed "the social uses of disorder."
Given this climate, it is not surprising that architecture turned inward, or that, when Federal support for urban renewal began to wane in the 1970's, projects by private entrepreneurs like Portman and James Rouse were hailed as the answer to the urban crisis. And to an extent the optimism was well founded. Projects like Portman's took a step in the right direction -- toward the city. In doing so, they confronted the problem underlying the urban crisis: the old American tradition of build and move on; leave your messes behind you; there will always be a new place to start over.
By the 1960's there was no new place to start over, except, perhaps, the moon. On Earth, as the urbanist Charles Abrams aptly phrased it, the city was the frontier, and so it remains. Portman made little effort to adapt to frontier life. His atriums shifted the controlled order of the suburban mall to disordered downtown locations. At best, they marked a transition between the old industrial city and some post-industrial metropolis that will not emerge until architects, planners and developers have realized more integrated approaches to urban design. But if Portman did not bring this new city into being, he created glorious space capsules for the voyage to it. So it's Happy Birthday, Dear Atrium -- but hold the happy returns.

HEADLINE: THE PARTY CRASHER

 BODY:
The Republican and Democratic parties offer a big enough tent for everyone who wants to arm-wrestle over abortion, prayer in school, women in combat or, yes, family values. ("The Party Crasher," by Theodore J. Lowi, Aug. 23). But if you are one of those boring people in the center whose main concern is affordable health care, decent schools for the kids, a job and a secure pension, you are out in the political cold.
Theodore Lowi's article marks a turning point. Apparently, it is no longer wacko to yearn for a third party. Used to be, the very term conjured up an image of William Jennings Bryan campaigning for free silver or John Anderson running on a vague platform that no one remembers. 
 But Lowi's third party is about the center, not the fringe; about economic policy and change, not issues and wrangling. The people supporting Tsongas and Perot were releasing a primal scream from the middle class that the way we are conducting our public business is simply not good enough.
 
WILLIAM A. DONLON
Annapolis, Md.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Trammell Crow Thriving on Rental Units

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
WHILE many Connecticut developers have struggled to stay afloat in the recession, Trammell Crow, one of the nation's largest builders, has constructed 2,261 rental apartments in the state since 1986 and is building about 1,300 more.
Projects in Stamford, Hamden, Middletown and Manchester have rented quickly, attracting tenants with reasonable prices, traditional New England architecture, recreational facilities, security personnel and in-house management. Rents range from $589 for a one-bedroom unit at Town Place in Middletown to $1,525 for three bedrooms at Town Glen in Stamford. 
 Town Walk in Hamden is the most ambitious development, a village for young and old, eventually to have some 1,600 rental apartments, condominiums, one-family homes and elderly life-care facilities on 135 acres. Most of the first 430 units have been rented since the opening in March.
Paul Nickeloff, a 24-year-old salesman, took a one-bedroom unit for $650. "I have a fireplace, my deck overlooks a creek, I'm 50 yards from the swimming pool and everybody gets to know everybody else," he said.
Jacqueline Grenier rooms with two other women in a three-bedroom unit for $995. "My parents like it so much they plan to move here when they retire," she said.
Trammell Crow employs focus groups to study the market before embarking on development, a technique widely used by advertising agencies and political parties to mine public opinion. By the time a project opens, it offers what prospective tenants have indicated is their heart's desire in housing.
One of the company's newest ventures and one that would be an innovation for the Northeast, is a proposal for 240 bikini-sized apartments of 270 square feet on Washington Boulevard in downtown Stamford. It would cost $8 million and rents would be around $500 a month, less than the city's low-end average of $750.
"I think this kind of development meets a definite need in the community," said Jon Smith, Stamford's planning director. "We have nothing like it. The alternative is an old apartment or the 'Y,' where there are no vacancies."
The city's zoning board amended its regulations earlier this year to permit up to 304 units, but the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority in Hartford turned the proposal down, in part because it was too big, when Trammell Crow applied for affordable-housing subsidies.
"There were concerns about the size of the project," said Gary King, head of the housing agency, "and its long-term viability."
In addition, state officials appeared to be startled by such an unusual proposal.
"The state has no mechanism for dealing with single-room occupancy housing," said Christopher Cooper, information officer for the State Department of Housing.
Trammell Crow is pushing forward with the project. Charles H. Berman, director of Trammell Crow's Connecticut operations, based in New Canaan, said the company was confident it could find financing.
The concept of a roughly 12- by 22-foot unit with a half-height refrigerator, a small stove, and a shower but no bathtub, harks back to the boarding houses and single-room-occupancy hotels of decades ago. Some still exist, usually in woeful condition.
CONSTRUCTION of new ones is virtually unknown in the Northeast, but thousands have been built or rehabilitated in California. Some 1,200 units of 80 to 300 square feet were built by the San Diego Housing Commission in the 80's and an additional 3,000 have been built by private developers or rebuilt in old downtown San Diego hotels during urban renewal.
"We've averaged 92 percent occupancy since we opened the first project in 1987," said Arnold Fischer of 197 Partnership, San Diego developers, in a telephone interview. The units vary in size from 120 to 320 square feet and in price from $370 to $550. "The demand keeps increasing," he said. "San Francisco has been down here to look, and built its own, and so has St. Louis."
Mr. Berman of Trammell Crow believes that "single-room apartments address a segment of the population that hasn't been serviced in a long time -- people with incomes up to $24,000."
"Women and Social Security retirees in particular want a safe, clean place to come home to," he added. "Stamford is a perfect location because of its extensive numbers of entry-level people."
Amenities planned for the building include air-conditioning, laundries, library, social room, fitness center, 24-hour doorman and parking, contained in a four-story structure resembling a country inn.
Stamford's acceptance of affordable housing is somewhat rare in Connecticut. Ever since the state's Affordable Housing and Use Appeals Law went into effect in 1990, allowing developers to appeal local rejection of affordable housing proposals, the courts have been pelted with dozens of suits.
The law shifts the burden of proof from developers, who formerly had to demonstrate that their projects were within zoning regulations or otherwise not harmful. Now it is the local commissions that must prove such projects are indeed harmful in order to reject them. "It gets to the heart of exclusionary zoning," said Mr. Cooper of the State Department of Housing.
LAST March, Judge Marshall K. Berger Jr. in Superior Court rejected Trumbull's objections to rezoning for a 600-unit Trammell Crow rental project on 40 acres along Old Town Road, where 20 percent, or 120 units, would be affordable. The town, with only 2 percent of its housing affordable, has until Oct. 2 to come up with an alternative or risk having the judge order the complex built.
Last month, zoning was approved in New Canaan for Trammell Crow's $16 million residential-retail project on Elm Street. Twenty percent of the 104 apartments will rent below the state's affordable limit of $1,400, based on incomes in the area.
On a 35-acre tract optioned in Darien, the company wants to build 200 units, of which 40 would be affordable, but a dispute between two landowners must first be resolved.
The 20-percent affordable program, subsidized through various state and Federal agencies, "is not a burden on school systems," said Mr. Berman, addressing a frequently repeated concern. "Low-income developments with two- and three-bedroom units attract a lot of schoolchildren. But with 80 percent market rate units you don't get many children because families able to pay the market rate buy or rent a house."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Town Walk units in Hamden, Conn. The complex, for young and old, will grow to about 1,600 apartments. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Small Uptick In New Housing

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
A MODEST increase in residential construction, mostly impelled by the rebirth of projects that had gone bust, has taken place in parts of the New York metropolitan region.
The activity hardly amounts to a boom. Indeed, home builders, battered by the recession, a tightening of commercial credit and a dearth of consumer confidence, may be suffering through the worst times since World War II. 
 The revival of distressed projects, though, is presenting many developers with what may be their only opportunity to work.
"There is not a lot of construction going on, and this is keeping people alive and staying in the business," said Alec W. Ornstein, the president of Ornstein Leyton Company of Garden City, L.I., which specializes in buying, marketing and selling distressed properties.
The activity is also presenting many people with an opportunity to buy homes at a discount. For example, in July, Carmine L. Fantasia of Lake Hiawatha, N.J., bought an unbuilt two-bedroom town house at Sunrise at Hanover in Whippany, N.J., for $120,000 from K. Hovnanian of Red Bank, N.J. The unit was part of a project that had been taken over by the company the same month following a bank foreclosure. Originally, the units were priced at about $200,000.
"I got great value for the property," said Mr. Fantasia, a 65-year-old retired postal worker who now owns a coffee shop. "There were ones that were already built that were being offered for $89,000, but the newer ones are supposed to be even nicer."
He said that the price and the builder were the big factors for selecting the Hovnanian house. "I didn't want to get involved with a builder who was going to fall into trouble like so many of the others, so I went with a big established one like Hovnanian," he said.
Large developers, such as K. Hovnanian, may be positioned to benefit the most from the revival, because they are not as reliant on outside financing and are more easily able to obtain distressed properties from banks and the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is in charge of liquidating the foreclosed real estate, loans and other assets held by defunct savings and loans.
These developers are also able, thanks to the depressed economy, to buy additional land, if necessary, and complete the projects for less.
"There hasn't been a real strong uptick in construction," said Merle H. Huseth, president of the Northeast Region for K. Hovnanian. "But there has been a smaller one because lenders and the R.T.C. are reaching agreements to build out and close down properties."
For example, when K. Hovnanian opened Sunrise at Hanover in June, buyers snapped up all of its 16 homes in three hours. By the first week in July, the balance of the 86-home final phase had sold out as well.
"DURING the past few years, we've gained control of more than 6,600 value-priced building lots in 32 communities," said Ara Hovnanian, the president of the company, which is the largest buyer and builder of formerly distressed properties in the Northeast. "Value is the prime motivation for today's home buyers. Only clear value sells well in today's skittish market."
He also noted that one property in New Jersey, whose acquisition by K. Hovnanian has not yet publicly announced, was bought at a sheriff's sale in May 1989 for $8.6 million by a second developer after the property's first owner went bankrupt.
The second developer then defaulted and the property was acquired by a bank for $8.8 million. That bank was subsequently taken over by the Resolution Trust Corporation and the property was then sold for $4.5 million to a third developer.
After that developer defaulted, K. Hovnanian bought the property for under $4 million.
"How does affordability happen?" Mr. Huseth asked. "Land prices drop. They have dropped precipitously from their high in 1987. They must have dropped 50 percent since then."
"What is also happening," he added, "is that developers other than the very, very large ones have not been able to get a construction loan because of the credit crunch, so they have to sell the property."
Some smaller developers have also been able to move into the distressed-properties market. For example, in Roslyn, L.I., an abandoned 25-house development that had been left in shambles by vandals has been brought back to life by Bernard Janowitz and Jason Cohen of Roslyn Park, L.I., who acquired the 10.5-acre property and the remains of six houses in July, after foreclosure proceedings against the original developers, Park Ridge at Roslyn.
Three of the six original houses in the development, now called Roslyn Pond Estates and occupying a hillside overlooking Roslyn Park, have been completed. Work is under way on the other three and construction of three more is to begin next month.
Buyers have already signed contracts for three houses and the developers hope to finish the entire project in two years.
The development's original houses, with four bedrooms and 3,600 to 4,700 square feet, were priced from $675,000 to $850,000 when they went on the market in 1988. They are contemporary in design and are now being offered at $499,000 to $599,000. The newer models will be smaller, around 3,000 square feet, and will fall in the same price range.
Another example is Mr. Ornstein's company, which recently was involved with two revived developments, Castle Glen, in North White Plains, N.Y., and New Brookridge Townhomes in Rye Brook, N.Y.
In Castle Glen, which had been by taken over by Union Chelsea National Bank in Manhattan from a bankrupt developer, Ornstein Leyton obtained a project of four completed town houses and eight unbuilt houses, which they sold within six months for $229,990 and $264,990. Nine homes had been built and sold by the previous developer. As recently as 1989, the town houses had been offered at $350,000.
IN New Brookridge, which Ornstein Leyton bought from First Constitution Bank in August, 13 of the planned 46 town houses had already been sold by the original developer for $355,000 to $370,990. Last week, the company began offering 15 partially built and 18 unbuilt homes for $229,990 to $289,990.
The company was able to obtain financing to purchase the properties because it could demonstrate to banks and private investors through a detailed cost analysis and marketing strategy that the homes in the development could become profitable at their new, sharply lower, prices.
Mr. Ornstein and his partner, Scott Leyton, also invested some of their own money in the project. They also believe that marketing is crucial.
"We tried to play up the hook of price in a very direct way," said Chet Halperin & Partners, Cedarhurst, N.J., who handled the company's marketing.
Much of the revival activity has been in New Jersey, and much of it is geared toward first-time buyers and the more affordable end of the market. In June, for example, two condominium developments in eastern Morris County begun in the mid-80's but aborted because of the real estate recession were revived.
The projects -- Eden Lane in Hanover Township and the Village at Convent Station in Morris Township -- were taken over by Baker-Firestone of Pleasantville, N.Y. One former developer defaulted on its loan; the other walked away from the project. Prices at both projects, together totaling 421 apartments and town houses, range from $109,990 to $159,990, about 25 percent lower than the prices the original developer had sought.
Another development, a one-family-home project in Howell Township in Monmouth County that was shelved by its developers after the 1987 stock market crash, was brought back to life last year.
The project, Sunrise Station, still has 120 homes on quarter- to half-acre lots, spread over 65 acres. The homes, however, have been scaled back: to 1,370 to 2,250 square feet from 2,500 to 2,700 square feet, and with three or four bedrooms instead of four or five, all to make them more salable.
The homes are being offered at preconstruction prices of $135,900 to $179,400. The earlier models were priced from $195,000 to $230,000.
"WE have sold 80 out of 120, and have actually moved in 40 families," said Michael Solondz, vice president and secretary of sales for Sunrise Communities. "We feel that the first-time buyer was shut out of the market in the 1980's, and our sales are due to the price structure. My ideas was to bring out a product that a first-time buyer could afford."
The revival of distressed projects isn't occurring everywhere in the region. "I wish there was something going on here, but there is nothing happening," said Herbert Warshavsky, executive director of the Association of Builders and Owners of Greater New York.
In particular, the outlook for home building in Connecticut continues to look bleak. Overall, about 7,500 new homes are expected to be built this year, the same amount as last year but far under the 24,000 built in 1987.
"We have been at the lowest level since 1945 for the last two years and we are staying there," said Michael Lauzier, executive president of the Home Builders Association of Connecticut in Hartford.
Bob Wiebolt, the executive vice president of the New York State Builders' Association, said that in New York there were few housing projects being revived.
"I am aware of projects that are springing back," he said. "But there is a big pall on the whole thing, and that is we can't a lot of front-end financing."
"There is a definite disinvestment pattern out there," he added. "No one is lending much money on construction, preconstruction or acquisitions, and that is a problem that is hampering recovery in the New York metropolitan area and Long Island more than it is upstate."
Even in New Jersey, where K. Hovnanian expects to build 2,500 units this year compared with 1,700 last year and the overall number of homes built is expected to increase from 14,000 in 1991 to 18,000 this year, the optimism is guarded.
"There have been projects that developers have been able to obtain from the R.T.C. and banks," said Joanne Hawkins, the director of land use planning for the New Jersey Builders Association in Plainsboro, N.J. "And there are developers that have been able to bring the projects online at a reduced price.
"But we are still operating at 50-year lows," she added, referring to the number of homes built annually. "These are 1940's-type numbers."

HEADLINE: Far From Old Hat, Headwear Is Back

BYLINE: By RUTH ROBINSON

 BODY:
TIME was when no self-respecting American dared venture into town without a hat. Hats managed to survive the Depression, and even World War II when a large percentage of the population was in uniform and dressing down was considered patriotic. Then, in the 60's, with bouffant hairstyles and a more informal life style, women's hats began to disappear from the sartorial scene. The men's hat industry was dealt a severe blow when in January 1961, President John F. Kennedy appeared bareheaded at his Inauguration on the steps of the Capitol despite freezing temperatures.
Now hats are making a comeback. "Hats are hot," said Casey Bush, executive director of the Millinery Information Bureau in New York, adding that sales of women's hats have been increasing at an annual rate of 10 to 20 percent since the middle of the 80's. 
 "Hats are a necessity, not just a fashion accessory," said Marilyn Malcarne of Deep River, a milliner. Because of the dangers of the depletion of the ozone layer, American men and women, like the Australians, are donning brims and visors to protect their complexions against premature aging and skin cancer.
 
Used as a Sun Barrier
 Darcy Creech of Southport, a hat designer, agreed. "It is beginning to sink in that the sun is not good for you," she said. "When you see a person with a deep tan you don't admire it. You think, 'Oh my gosh, aren't they aware of what they're doing to themselves?' " With impeccable timing, Ms. Creech brought out her first collection in the spring of 1990.
She aims for the classic country look with emphasis on natural materials -- handmade flowers of parchment paper, for example, and leather rather than vinyl bands. Her 600 accounts include major department stores like Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom. She also does custom work and shows up weekends for the polo matches at Conyer Farm in Greenwich with a display of hats.
Ms. Creech's signature hat remains popular. She tells how, unable to find the right straw to wear to a party several years ago, she made one herself, trimming an unblocked Panama with a cotton damask bow, parchment flowers, berries and leaves. The compliments and demands for one like it catapulted her into the millinery business. Rather theatrical, the hat has been described as "Laura Ashley pirate."
Flower-trimmed hats bearing the Darcy Creech label retail from $100 to $450. Men are not forgotten in the fall collection, which includes Western suedes in six colors and baseball caps with corduroy crowns and contrasting suede visors, both considered unisex styles, along with more feminine velours trimmed with flowers and feathers.
 
Fedoras and Bowlers for Fall
 For Dotty Smith of Lakeville, another designer, hats are just one segment of an accessories business with annual retail sales estimated at $10 million, but it is a segment that is growing each year. While the natural straws offered for summer were trimmed with flowers or madras puggrees, the fall collection in felt is more restrained. Included are boaters, fedoras, bowlers, sailors and Stetsons in colors like magenta, plum and goldenrod in addition to standard navy, black, camel and taupe. These retail for about $50 at specialty stores across the nation.
Like many of today's successful milliners, Ms. Malcarne received a certificate in millinery from the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan. She does not have a production line; instead she creates sculptured hats and headpieces that are one of a kind and usually made to order. "If you can imagine it you can make it," is her philosophy.
 
Artists Cross Over
 Her creations, which range in price from $75 to $500, tend to be dressy, a beaded Art Deco headpiece in turquoise and gold, for example, or an exotic brocade turban with Austrian crystal fringe. Ms. Malcarne is often called on to design bridal headpieces as well as period hats for owners of antique cars. She is particularly proud of an elegant tricorner made for the Lord Mayor of London, who she met when in England performing with a fife and drum corps. This model of black felt was set off by a plume fashioned of black lace anchored by an antique black button.
Some of Connecticut's artists are finding hats a creative way of subsidizing their serious work. Alexandre Itin of Stamford, for instance, paints bold colorful designs on straw and felt hats of all varieties and sells them through outlets like the Gayle Willson Gallery in Southampton, L.I., and Julie Artisans' Gallery in New York. Prices range from $130 to $250. Many of the Itin designs are abstract, usually in primary colors, while others relate to landscape painting. They are practical to wear, even in damp weather, because the acrylic paint is sprayed to make it water resistant. Some of the painted hats stem from Mr. Itin's figurative three-dimensional paintings and sport faces built up of modeling paste on the crown. Seen from the front these are innocuous, but from the back they resemble grotesque masks.
Irene Reed of Hartford, a sculptor in fiber and mixed media, tries to give her pieces some function to make buying them justifiable. "I've always been hat and bag oriented," she said. Her first step into the realm of millinery was a practical but funky number resembling an aviator's helmet, complete with goggles. She used her favorite technique, crochet, for these cozy caps of wool or cotton starting out with khaki for a military look, but soon branching out into colors. An immediate success, they were snapped up by people like the actress Mia Farrow.
 
No Comeback for Hatting Capital
 These days Ms. Reed builds her headpieces up like sculptures, and though they can actually be worn, to a costume party perhaps, they are are more likely to show up in a gallery or museum than on someone's head. All kinds of materials are enlisted. Scraps of paper, painted and covered with fiberglass screen, are crocheted together with exotic threads and lavish use is made of found objects -- bones, beads and little plastic objects. Such increasingly elaborate pieces range in price from $700 to $1,200.
Despite the surge in popularity of hats, Danbury -- once known as the Hatter Capital of the world -- today is identified with diverse high-technology companies. The hat industry, which flourished through the turn of the century and came to a halt in the 1960's, has not come back there, or in Norwalk, another city whose economy once depended to some extent on the manufacture of headwear.

Irene Reed sculptures her hats in Hartford. "Dance of the Rooster Warrior," right. (Wayne Fleming)

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

FIBER SCULPTURE DISPLAY
 Fragile and ethereal as Rebecca Medel's fiber sculptures may seem, they are firmly molded into shape with adhesives. An installation of the unusual works may be seen at the Neuberger Museum on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase today through Jan. 24. 
 One of the pieces, called "1,000 Kannons," is a series of mounds shaded from blue to gray to white and made from hand-knotted linen grids. They form what appears to be a repetitious cloud formation from some other universe suspended permanently for all to see.
 Ms. Medel will explain her technique to visitors during a public reception today, when she will give a slide show and lecture at 3 P.M.
Museum hours are Tuesdays through Fridays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Saturdays and Sundays from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission charges are $4; $2 for students and people 62 and older; free on the first Saturday of each month, and free to children 12 and younger. The number to call for more information is 251-6110.
 
FOR RECORDER PLAYERS
 Amateur recorder players looking for a broader outlet for their muse are being sought by the Westchester Recorder Guild, a local branch of the 75-chapter, 50-year-old American Recorder Society. The guild will begin its eighth season tomorrow from 7:45 to 10 P.M. with a session at St. John the Evangelist Church, 148 Hamilton Avenue in White Plains.
Scores will be supplied, and the fee for the evening of music making will be $5, or $32 for a season of eight sessions. Players should take recorders and music stands. Those who would like to audit a session before joining the group will be charged $6.
In addition to the Monday night gatherings, workshops coached by professional teachers and performers are offered on three levels of skill and are held at regular intervals. Fees are $10. The next workshop is scheduled for Oct. 25.
From time to time members perform in small groups in schools, churches and nursing homes. The number to call for more information is 762-2873.
 
IRISH MUSIC PROGRAM
 Cathal McConnell from County Fermanagh, Northern Ireland, has been playing the flute and whistle since he was 11 and can trace the flutists in his family back four generations. He was the All-Ireland Competition Champion on both instruments at the age of 18 in the 1960's.
Len Graham of County Antrim, also Northern Ireland, won an All-Ireland singing competition in the 1970's and is a folk music adviser to Ulster television.
The two men are members of Boys of the Lough and Skylark, respectively, among the best-known traditional Irish music groups, but they will perform separately at the Chappaqua Library on Wednesday at 8 P.M. Admission will be $7. More information is available by calling 238-4779.
 
ECONOMIC SYMPOSIUM
 Derrick D. Cephas, State Superintendent of Banks, and Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, will be the keynote speakers Tuesday at a symposium titled "Rebuilding the Regional Economy."
Mr. Cephas's talk will deal with bank regulation and the need for reform, and Ms. Scanlon's topic will be "Where Is the Economic Recovery in Our Region?"
Organized by the Westchester County Association and the Westchester County Bankers Association in cooperation with the Westchester Business Partnership and the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, Westchester chapter, the symposium will focus on Westchester's role in the regional and global economy. Among others on the panel will be Alfred B. DelBello, former Westchester County Executive and former Lieutenant Governor, and Jeffrey S. Rubin, vice president of the Nynex Corporation.
The symposium is scheduled from 8 A.M. to noon at the Marriott Hotel in Tarrytown. Admission will be $45 and includes Continental breakfast. The number to call for reservations or more information is 948-6444.
 
MOHONK HARVEST THEME
 The weekend theme at Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, Friday through Sunday, is "Hudson Valley Harvest." Drawing on its designation as a National Historic Landmark, the hotel offers a variety of educational events, almost always related to the history and natural aspects of the region.
Daily rates, from $155 to $215 for singles and $245 to $320 for two in a room, include three meals a day and more activities than most visitors can manage. For example, at 4 P.M. Friday newly arrived guests will be served black birch and black currant tea, apple cider and pumpkin bread.
Later in the afternoon Barrie Kavasch, a naturalist and author, and Dale Carson, an artist of Abenake extraction, will lead a nature walk. At 8:45 P.M. the Hudson River Hummingbirds will give a concert of American Indian music, followed by a fireside sing-along.
During the next two days one may rise early for a sunrise harvest ceremony or sleep in until boarding a van for a 9:30 A.M. trip to a winery to watch grape harvesting.
Workshops include one on wreath-making and others on scarecrow- making and cooking American Indian foods in a modern kitchen. Indian handicrafts and blacksmithing are among demonstrations scheduled, and Dr. Laurence Hauptman, professor of history at SUNY New Paltz, will lecture on issues affecting American Indians.
Among other activities are a barbecue, a country dance with Jay Ungar and Molly Mason calling the tunes, walks to find fungi and other wild edibles and slide shows and talks by Bob Grumet, an archeologist with the National Park Service, and Len Tantillo, a painter of historic scenes in the state. The number to call for reservations or more information is 255-4500.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A sculpture on exhibit by Rebecca Medel, "1,000 Kannons." (Neuberger Museum of Art)

HEADLINE: Westchester Community College Expands Its Cultural Horizon

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: VALHALLA

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER Community College is staking its claim as an arts center this season, bringing the famous, the brilliant and the supremely talented to the campus here in a fresh package of events. Lisa Deutsch, the college's new manager of cultural affairs, said she hoped the fourfold increase in programs would attract both students and the public. 
 The arts have long been part of the school's mission, said Dr. Joseph N. Hankin, president of the college. What is new this year, he said, is that "we're presenting programs as a whole instead of willy-nilly."
 
Luminaries, Close Up
 Events featuring such luminaries as Robert MacNeil, co-host of the "MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour"; Ellen Taaffe Zwilich and John Corigliano, two leading American composers, and Julian Bream, the classical guitarist, will take place in small theaters -- the largest holds 400 -- where audiences, especially students, can have a "close-up" experience with performers, Ms. Deutsch said. She added, "We're very interested in having the students directly involved in the arts."
Dr. Hankin said the stronger cultural thrust was meant to broaden the education of students who were typically older than the average college student. Community college students were often busy with jobs and young families and generally less likely than their liberal arts college counterparts to seek out arts experiences, he said. "We as educators feel that for them to have a full education from us, they need to be exposed to activities they won't do on their own," Dr. Hankin said.
Daytime events, such as talks by well-known film makers (an expansion of the college's popular Friday night film series), a poetry series and an American culture series -- which includes the folk singer Pete Seeger and the iconoclastic historian Howard Zinn -- are free to students and the public. Prices for evening and weekend events, featuring dance, music, film and theater, range from $3 to $12, with discounts for series subscriptions. The programs, which Ms. Deutsch said lean toward the nontraditional in content and presentation, are financed with the proceeds from a $5 student activity fee that was initiated last year.
Dr. Hankin said he expected enrollment in the 47-year-old college to break records this year, with 12,000 students taking courses for credit. Even with the recent raise of tuition to $1,750 for a full-time student, the price was still affordable and far lower than at colleges elsewhere, he said. "In a recession economy, people go back for more education," Dr. Hankin said. "It's less of a stigma going to a community college today, and once people have the experience, they know they really have to work hard here."
Long lines snaked through the halls on registration day recently. Anticipating a captive audience, Ms. Deutsch had engaged a guitar duo to play in a nearby lounge as a kind of kickoff of the new cultural season. Most students didn't seem to know what to make of the musicians, but a few smiled as they passed by. Ms. Deutsch, a vivacious, dark-haired woman, said she had many such plans up her sleeve to pique students' interest.
Holding an armful of shiny new brochures, the cultural affairs manager moved down the line of students waiting to register and hawked her goods like a hot dog vendor at a baseball game. "Lots of jazz this year, check it out," she said, handing a flyer to a young man. "Spike Lee's father is coming. There's a lot of free stuff here," she continued, passing out the brochure to all takers.
Although some students looked skeptical, Ms. Deutsch said later that she had received calls for tickets from people who had been in the line. She has immersed herself in her mandate to create excitement on a campus without dormitories, where students go their own ways after classes. She said she watches MTV for new ideas and scours the Manhattan jazz clubs for new talent.
Ms. Deutsch said she filled a gap in the college's musical lineup by adding jazz and, in particular, progressive jazz, to the programming. A new jazz series will get under way on Tuesday with a brown-bag concert by the Jack Wilkins Ensemble. The concert will be held in the Outdoor Amphitheater from noon to 2 P.M. Also on Tuesday the author Helen Barolini will open the Poets and Writers lecture series at 11 A.M. in the Classroom Building.
Orchestral music will be heard in a series devoted to the Camerata, a resident 40-member chamber orchestra, which gives its first concert today at 4 P.M. in the theater of the Academic Arts Building.
The jazz and rock guitarist Larry Coryell begins a new "guitar greats" series on Oct. 2 at 8 P.M. The setting for the guitar concerts is also new; it was Ms. Deutsch's inspiration to turn the Student Center lounge into an intimate theater in the round for special events.
A nine-member cultural arts committee made up of students, faculty members and administrators studies proposals for programs and coordinates them with Ms. Deutsch. Dr. Iris M. Cook, a biology professor who heads the committee, said she was happy that the college had gone big time with the arts. Students need esthetic experiences to round out their classroom ones, she added.
 
Nonstop Phone Calls
 Ms. Deutsch, a mother of two young children who seems to have boundless energy, said a slow response from students would not discourage her, but she expects the opposite. Her "phone is ringing off the hook," she said, with calls from people as far away as Queens and Brooklyn who had received a flyer.
Ms. Deutsch, walking through the college's green and rolling campus, where many a folk concert has been heard and the New York Philharmonic has played, recalled her experiences as the first executive director of the New Orchestra of Westchester, which is celebrating its 10th anniversary, and described her love of "starting things up."
"It's a hectic pace, but I love it," she said. "That's because I love the arts. That's what gets me through the long hours and the trips and falls." There haven't been any falls yet in this job, she added. It is all too new, she said, as the college prepared to play its part as "an alternative cultural center in the community."
The number to call for a brochure of the season's events or for ticket information is 285-6567.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Lisa Schattinger and Alistair Buchan

 BODY:
Elisabeth Myers Schattinger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Schattinger of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Alistair Buchan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Buchan of Edinburgh, Scotland. The Rev. Wilbur Green, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Plymouth Church of Shaker Heights.
Mrs. Buchan, who is 27 years old and is known as Lisa, graduated cum laude from Wellesley College and is a candidate for an M.B.A. at Dartmouth College. Her father is the president of the Pioneer Manufacturing Company, a maker of industrial maintenance products in Cleveland. Her mother, Joan M. Schattinger, is a freelance writer in Shaker Heights. 
 Mr. Buchan, 29, is a senior associate in project finance at Barclays Bank in New York. He graduated from the University of Edinburgh, where he received a master's degree in economics. His father, now retired, was an executive at the Royal Bank of Scotland in Edinburgh.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
European Unity? With Friends Like These . . .

BYLINE: By Steven Greenhouse

 BODY:
It's a pity that European currency markets plunged into crisis because the mayhem could have been avoided -- at least that's what many economists say. All it would have taken was more vision and courage from Europe's governments and central bankers.
In June, President Francois Mitterrand announced today's referendum in France, expecting that voters would approve the next step toward European unity. He never imagined that the uncertainties surrounding the vote would foment a crisis, with speculators ganging up on various currencies. 
 The Italian Government lacked the courage to slash its astronomical budget deficit, which made the lira's devaluation inevitable. And many analysts say Britain's Government might have headed off the pound's devaluation if, a week or two ago, the Bank of England had had the foresight to raise rates to 15 percent. Instead it moved only after speculators savaged the pound.
Germany's central bank might have forestalled the crisis if it had cut its most important interest rate by one or two points last weekend rather than by a quarter point. Once the uncertainty of the vote had passed and markets had calmed, the Bundesbank, to protect its inflation-fighting credibility, could have pushed rates back up. But, alas, central bankers lack the imagination of Balanchine or the agility of ballerinas.
In France, experts say today's vote is too close to call. Some say a no vote would delay and perhaps kill plans to establish a single European central bank and currency. Some analysts say it would make little difference because the markets already think the idea of a single currency is dead. But most agree it would lead to more currency chaos, with the franc coming under fire next.
A no vote could mean more devaluations. This could allow the Bundesbank to cut rates because devaluations help hold down German inflation by making imports cheaper.
For the United States, devaluations and lower interest rates in Europe would mean stronger growth. The reason: faster growth in Europe should mean increased imports of American machine tools and Michael Jackson records. In addition, the devaluations and market chaos fostered by a no vote would strengthen the dollar -- and this could siphon more foreign money into American stock markets.
But a no vote could have a downside. Market chaos in Europe could spill abroad, and hurt equity markets. And a no vote might hurt confidence in Europe. "If it really derailed the momentum and psychology of European unification, it could push us back to Europessimism," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics.
A yes vote in France would be construed as a vote for European unity and for fixed exchange rates. It would probably discourage speculation and raise confidence. With a solid yes vote, said Norbert Walter, chief economist at Deutsche Bank, "there is reason to believe the turbulence would calm down."

HEADLINE: Networking;
Here Comes I.B.M., Embracing Ethernet at Last

BYLINE: By STEPHEN C. MILLER

 BODY:
The International Business Machines Corporation has been trumpeting its latest reorganization, which is supposed to turn it into a lean, mean marketing machine. But last week's announcement of 30 new networking products, due to hit the market in waves starting this month, showed the old as well as the new I.B.M.
Some analysts saw clear signs that the new I.B.M. was struggling to assert itself. "We're seeing an example of the new, agile I.B.M.," said Janet Hyland, director of network strategy research for Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. Others are not so sure. 
 The problem in the past has been that I.B.M. tended to address future markets with conservative technology that quickly got bypassed by other vendors. This time, Ms. Hyland pointed out, I.B.M. is out front with credit-card-sized network adapters for portable computers that adhere to the Personal Computer Memory Card International Association standard meant to insure compatibility between different vendors' machines. The cards themselves set new standards in terms of size, weight and power-saving, getting well ahead of the current portable adapter offerings, which are the size of a pack of cigarettes.
More significant, the cards and full-size adapters, available almost immediately, mark an end to I.B.M.'s disdain for Ethernet. Ethernet is one of several standards that determine both how a LAN is wired and how it passes information around. I.B.M. developed the Token-Ring standard and, until now, has stuck with it despite the fact that everyone else in the LAN industry prefers Ethernet. It's a little like Sony finally offering VHS rather than beta.
New, faster adapters are also available for Token-Ring and can act as a 3270 terminal for use with I.B.M. mainframes.
The cards, for laptops, and a line of full-sized local area network adapters for desktop P.C.'s carry prices ranging from $250 (full-slot Ethernet, available in January) to $845 (Token-Ring, available this week).
"We think that this ends the Token-Ring/ Ethernet stalemate," said Ms. Hyland. She believes that those LAN managers who stuck with Token-Ring because that was all that I.B.M. offered can stay true blue while switching to Ethernet. And with more and more users operating laptops while traveling but still needing network services, the slip-in-your-pocket cards may well prove tempting.
Not everyone is excited about the I.B.M. 30-product announcement, however. Nick Lippis, for one, of Strategic Networks Inc., a consulting firm in Rockland, Mass., still sees too much of the old I.B.M. "While some of it is interesting, much of it is too little too late," he said.
For example, I.B.M.'s new 8250 multiprotocol intelligent hub (a hub connects different networks, like Token-Ring to Ethernet) is not even an all-I.B.M. product. It is a joint development with the Chipcom Corporation of Southborough, Mass. And Chipcom, along with other hub vendors, has been shipping such intelligent hubs for over a year.
