HEADLINE: EUROPE IN TURMOIL;
INDUSTRIAL NATIONS STRIVE TO RESOLVE CRISIS ON CURRENCY

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Finance ministers and central bankers of the leading industrial countries met here for more than seven hours today, searching for a way out of Europe's currency crisis and forging contingency plans in case the financial markets erupt again on Monday.
In a brief communique after the meeting, the officials gave no clear indication of whether Germany had agreed to lower its interest rates further, as many countries have pressed it to do. 
 But eyes were on France as much as Germany as the ministers sequestered themselves at Dunbarton House, a 200-year-old mansion in Georgetown surrounded by a high brick wall that is the headquarters of the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America.
 
Narrow Vote Seen in France
 French citizens will vote on Sunday on a single European currency and other bold steps toward European unity, and the vote is expected to be close. Foreign exchange traders predict that a rejection of the Maastricht Treaty will bring the franc and other European currencies under heavy fire, just as the Italian lira and British pound were driven down in value this week.
In contrast to the harsh words exchanged on Friday by British and German leaders, Norman Lamont, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, took pains after today's meeting not to criticize Germany.
"Everybody is of the view that we would like, including the Germans, that we would like in time to see lower interest rates," he told reporters.
 
Germans Vow to Hold Firm
 German officials continued to insist this evening that they and the nation's central bank, the Bundesbank, would not be swayed by outside pressures. "These decisions have to be taken on the basis of sound economic policy," said Horst Kohler, Under Secretary of Germany's Finance Ministry.
The communique included a clear signal of a preference for lower rates. The group noted that several countries had recently lowered interest rates and said, "These measures will strengthen the global economic recovery and foster greater stability of exchange markets."
By all accounts, this meeting of the Group of Seven, scheduled months before the European currency system exploded this week, was a calm one. American officials said they firmly made their views known about why they favored lower interest rates; German officials said they firmly responded why they did not think that was appropriate.
This afternoon, President Bush invited the ministers and bankers from two dozen industrial and developing countries to a Sunday meeting at the White House, making the most of an opportunity to demonstrate global leadership during his re-election campaign. Administration officials have made clear that they think the United States has much more to fear from European fragmentation than from European consolidation.
 
Problems With the System
 At the center of the talks here was the 11-nation European Monetary System, created in 1979 to link exchange rates in order to eliminate fluctuations and to provide a stability that would encourage trade, investment and growth.
Germany's high interest rates have forced other nations to keep their rates high to prevent their currencies from sliding in value against the mark. But these higher rates hurt investment and growth in Europe. On Monday, the Bundesbank cut its main interest rate by a quarter point, the first such reduction in five years. But the move left intact the large spread between German and American interest rates, and Britain decided on Wednesday to suspend its participation in the monetary system and let the value of its pound be determined by market forces. A day later, Italy dropped out.
For all the criticism of Germany's interest rates, few nations came to the table with clean hands. The United States, for example, faced renewed pressure to cut its $320 billion annual Federal budget deficit, which other nations complain pushes up long-term interest rates around the world.
After the meeting today, Finance Minister Michel Sapin of France said, "The American problem is its budget deficit." He said American officials had said "nothing very precise" about their plans.
As for the United States, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said, "There was broad recognition that measures to strengthen recovery would also further greater exchange-market stability."
Among the contingency plans being discussed here are further devaluations of some currencies, buying of currencies by central banks to bolsterprop up weak currencies, changes in fiscal policies and even a wholesale change in the structure of Europe's system of fixed exchange rates.
American officials said they wanted today's meeting to give new impetus to international economic cooperation. That was the buzzword of the late 1980's as nations agreed to coordinate interest rates and exchange rates, helping to fuel a period of unusual growth and stability. The golden moment of economic cooperation came in the Plaza Accord of 1985, when James A. Baker 3d, then the Treasury Secretary, now the head of President Bush's re-election campaign, orchestrated an international effort to bring down the dollar from its stratospheric heights.
For the last two years, however, cooperation has largely broken down, with the Group of Seven -- the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan -- adopting vastly different and often conflicting economic policies.
While the Americans and British say Germany's high rates are hurting growth, Helmut Schlesinger, the president of Germany's central bank, has repeatedly argued that high rates are needed to reduce German inflation to 2 percent from its current 3.5 percent rate. Germany's large budget deficit, which has fueled inflation there, is mostly a result of the high costs of German unification. The Government is spending $122 billion this year to help rebuild eastern Germany.
 
Up in Germany, Down in U.S.
 To counter inflationary pressures, the Bundesbank has pushed its most important interest rate to 9.5 percent. At the same time, in Washington, the Federal Reserve Board has adhered to easy-money policies, pushing rates down to 3 percent in the hope of stimulating borrowing and investing and reviving the American economy.
"The Group of Seven has been in total disarray for at least a couple of years," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research group.
One concession Germany could be seeking is for the United States to ease its tough stance in the world trade talks in Geneva. The United States has been combatively demanding that the Europeans drastically reduce their subsidies to farmers, an issue that has produced a deadlock in the talks.
The Bundesbank might gain some leeway to cut rates because further devaluations by other nations could be in the offing. When Germany's trading partners devalue their currencies, that helps hold down inflation in Germany because it makes imports cheaper.
A factor behind Germany's large budget deficit is its substantial aid to Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, so Bonn might press its allies to carry more of the load. It might also demand reciprocal deficit-reduction pledges from other big-deficit countries -- the United States, Britain and Italy.
 
Thatcher Backs British Pullout
 Margaret Thatcher, John Major's predecessor as Prime Minister, said at a conference in Washington today that Britain should not re-enter the European Monetary System, and she praised Mr. Major for withdrawing. She argued that the system had a "perverse alchemy" that was strangling growth and was "a grave obstacle to economic progress."
Whatever the results of Sunday's vote in France, several officials predicted that the European Monetary System could be substantially changed.
Finance ministers from the 12 countries of the European Community are scheduled to meet here late Sunday to discuss their next steps.
Some say the Group of Seven might push for a slimmer system that would include just five nations, probably Germany, France, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands.
Countries with high inflation, like Spain and Italy, would not be included, freeing them from the need to raise their rates to keep their currencies from plunging against the mark.

HEADLINE: Life at the Bottom -- America's Poorest County/A special report.;
Sad Distinction for the Sioux: Homeland Is No. 1 in Poverty

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PINE RIDGE, S.D.

 BODY:
The Pine Ridge Reservation is the home of the Oglala branch of the Sioux Indians, descendants of the warrior heroes Crazy Horse and Red Cloud. It is as poor as America gets.
It spreads across nearly two million acres of butte-broken plains and listless creeks, and the oyster-gray cliffs and impervious clay floor of the Badlands. It is a mean and despairing place of 16,000 inhabitants ravaged by isolation, disease, political infighting, and good intentions gone bad. Fewer than 3 in 10 of the adults have jobs, and nearly all the jobs are in government agencies. 
 Most reservations are poor, but this one keeps sinking. The Census Bureau reports that in Shannon County, which covers most of the reservation, 63.1 percent of all residents lived in poverty in 1989 -- the highest rate of the nation's 3,141 counties, up from 44.7 percent (ninth poorest) a decade earlier. By comparison, the national poverty rate was 14.2 percent in 1991.
 
Different Kind of Poverty
 "It's a different kind of poverty here, a more bitter type," said the Rev. Joseph Daniel Sheehan, a Jesuit priest, as he stood outside his little Sacred Heart Catholic Church on a litter-blown knoll overlooking Wounded Knee, site of the United States 7th Cavalry's slaughter of Chief Big Foot and 300 Sioux men, women and children on Dec. 29, 1890.
Father Sheehan once served in India; there, he said, the attitude was, "we're all in this together." Here, he went on, "they feel that anything that comes to them is what's left over. They get angry at one another. It's a kind of poverty that destroys the family. I don't know what I would be if I were an Indian. I think I would be an alcoholic."
In part, the poverty here arises from the circumstances unique to Indian tribes -- their consignment to the remote and resource-poor dregs of the old frontier and the clash of their own values with a dominant white culture. All this is compounded by the arid climate and deep isolation of the Pine Ridge Reservation.
Among the Sioux, generosity is the holiest virtue, and stinginess and greed are reviled. People share their bounty with family and friends, rather than save to build a better house or start a business. In a community with wealth to spread around, everyone wins. Here everyone loses.
The conditions here also show influences that drag people down anywhere: bad nutrition, bad personal habits, high unemployment, racial discrimination, the two-decade-long erosion of American wages and Federal welfare programs that foster dependence.
"We're a fifth- going-on-sixth-generation welfare state," said Leo Vocu, a leader of the tribe. "We have, over these generations, developed some very bad habits."
But in the end, everything comes down to money. "There just ain't any money there," said James G. Abourezk, a former Democratic Senator from South Dakota who practices law in Rapid City and specializes in Indian affairs. "No industry. No jobs. Not much of anything."
 
The People
Families Fall Apart Under the Strain
 People here routinely tell of economic stresses that match the worst of urban ghettos. Alfred Leftwich, 25 years old, married, father of three small children, is tall, agile and vigorous, a former basketball star at Pine Ridge High School.
He prepared for a career, going to college for two years to learn coaching and elementary school teaching and, not finding a job, to vocational school to learn carpentry. He has had two menial jobs off the reservation with the forest service, each lasting eight months, but they were temporary, and he has been unemployed for 18 months.
"Welfare is something I have to do," Mr. Leftwich said. "It's humiliating. I can work. I have all kinds of skills. I have two perfectly good hands." He is five months behind on his $150 monthly mortgage payments on his home, a trailer, and facing foreclosure. The power company has turned off the electricity. The pipes froze last winter and he has not been able to get them fixed. Without toilets or an outhouse, he said, "we just go to the creek."
Carmen Yellow Horse, 34, lived off the reservation, in Rapid City, for 12 years. "That's where the jobs were," she said. In February she returned with her two young daughters to the reservation hamlet of Red Shirt in the Badlands to live with her grandmother, who raised her and needed help. Recently she drove the 70 miles to Pine Ridge to look for a job.
She filled out an application for the only one for which she felt remotely qualified, as a $4.25-an-hour part-time secretary at a Federal Government welfare office. If she gets the job, the gasoline to commute in her 16-year-old Plymouth will cost about $9 a day, more than she would earn for two hours' work.
The poverty here shatters families. Mothers, not just fathers, leave spouses and children behind to try to make a living somewhere else. Many return, complaining of job discrimination and a paucity of jobs and become alcoholics. Antoinette Wince will be among the next to try to break away.
Ms. Wince is 24, the single mother of a 7-year-old girl, a $5.50-an-hour, full-time supervisor at Big Bat's, a convenience store in Pine Ridge, and a part-time student at Oglala Lakota College, near the reservation village of Kyle.
"My major's computer science," she said. "The college will find a place for me off the reservation to do an internship. I want to leave. It's too depressing here." She said she had given her mother, a teacher, legal custody of her daughter, Stefanie -- at her mother's insistence.
"My mom wants me to leave," she said. "She thinks there's nothing here for me. My mom always tells us: 'Be responsible. You're never going to make it in the white man's world if you can't behave like him. Go to work on time. Do your job.' "
 
The Village
Nameless Streets Where Poverty Kills
 Pine Ridge, the reservation's principal settlement, is a prototype of rural poverty, the home of 5,000 people, nearly all Sioux. It is disheveled, potholed and dusty. None of the 15 miles of roads have names, and a third are unpaved.
There is no train, bus, bank, theater, clothing store, drug store, barber shop, restaurant, place to get a car fixed or home delivery of mail. A car is the only way to get around, yet a fifth of all Shannon County households don't have one. With the sole exception of Big Bat's, the new and well-lighted 24-hour store run by Bat and Pat Pourier, the few shops are fortresses against burglary, with boards or heavy metal mesh covering their windows. The sign in front of the Gospel Fellowship church in town offers "Our Only Hope Services."
In the small, white-owned Sioux Nation supermarket, a cooler displays see-through boxes of something chopped up and pink for $1.28 a pound. The label says "meat." The State Data Center at the University of South Dakota Vermillion reports that per-capita in Shannon County fell 23 percent in the 1980's, to $3,417, after adjusting for inflation.
Here, poverty kills. The Indian Health Service says that for every 1,000 children born on the reservation in the late 1980's, 29 died in infancy, almost three times the national average. Death from heart disease, pneumonia, influenza and suicide was twice the national rate; from homicide, more than three times the national rate; from adult diabetes, four times; from alcoholism, 10 times. Alcoholism is showing up among newborn children, victims of fetal alcohol syndrome.
Another measure of poverty is bad and critically scarce housing. "We've got 2,000 families on our waiting list, and those are the ones who haven't given up waiting," said Carmel Richards, finance officer of the tribal housing authority that provides subsidized housing, much of it rent free. As a result, she said, "We see a lot of extended families in one unit. We've come across houses where there's 16 people in three bedrooms."
 
The Prospects
How Some Make It Against the Odds
 Getting things done is difficult in part because the tribal leadership keeps changing. Tribal leaders freely acknowledge that many use their offices to put family and friends in jobs. Then other factions, having been locked out of jobs, run for office and do the same for their people. The tribe also presides over a legal system that favors individuals over businesses, discouraging investors from opening factories and providing jobs.
For a century the Federal Government wielded immense influence over the affairs of the reservation, primarily through the Bureau of Indian Affairs. In recent years it has turned over political authority to the tribe, though it does award contracts and loans to develop things like schools, hospitals and businesses. But Federal aid has not kept pace with inflation, and in the context of the reservation's poverty its contribution is minuscule.
Still, conditions at Pine Ridge could be worse. Welfare programs do provide a crutch, especially for large families. An underground cash economy of poachers, burglars, bootleggers and artisans who make quilts and beaded jewelry is another crutch.
Some people also see hope for a stronger economy. They say alcoholism, the bane and refuge of the permanently unemployed, seems to be abating. Schools are improving, too. Over 20 years, as the tribe has taken over the schools from the churches and the Bureau of Indian Affairs, tribal leaders have placed their top priority on education, and in some of the decrepit-looking villages the schools are the only large and well-kept buildings to be seen.
More young people are finishing high school and going to college than ever, and they are qualifying for the well-paid nursing, teaching and other professional jobs on the reservation that have been going to non-Indians.
John Yellow Bird Steele, chairman of the Oglala Sioux since February, is planning to build up to three gambling casinos, an enterprise that has salvaged some other reservations. Uncommonly for a member of a tribe that has favored a quasi-socialist economy based on tribe-owned business, he preaches free enterprise. "We've got to view economic development for what it is," he said. "It's the private entrepreneur who's going to do it."
But other tribal leaders have had new ideas, too, and are often thrown out of office for espousing them. Tribal chairmen are elected every two years, and none has been re-elected since the mid-1970's. One small faction here, members of the radical American Indian Movement, says gambling will drive Indians deeper into alcoholism and debt. "That's genocide," said Gary Rowland, head of the Wounded Knee chapter of A.I.M.
With or without gambling, there are people who make it even against considerable odds. Bat Pourier, a 40-year-old full-blooded Oglala Sioux, was 14 when his father died. He went to South Dakota State University to play football, injured a knee, dropped out and started drinking. He met Pat, daughter of a white farmer. "We became drinking buddies," Ms. Pourier said.
Back on the reservation, still drinking, Mr. Pourier fell behind in payments on his pickup truck. "I started being honest with everybody," he said. He approached Stockmens Bank for an $11,000 loan so he could keep the truck. "I'm an alcoholic, but I'm going straight," he told the president of the bank. He got the loan.
After three years of sobriety, he was offered a job at the bank. He became a lending officer and stayed six years. While at the bank, he and Ms. Pourier, by then sober and a postmistress on the reservation, made plans to open a convenience store.
They got $1.2 million in loans and a $100,000 grant from the Bureau of Indian Affairs. It took two years to break ground. "The white business owners did not want competition," Mr. Pourier said. "So they contested our lease on the land. We went to court 13 times."
Open two years now, the store is a hive of activity all day. It has 30 employees, all Indian. The Pouriers aggressively tackled a problem that has defeated other Indian-owned businesses on the reservation: A cultural clash over the concept of time. In the Lakota language there is no word for time and few people on the reservation even wear wristwatches. "Late once, you get a written reprimand," Ms. Pourier said. "Late again and you're fired."
Still, the Pouriers have also remained loyal to Sioux traditions. They are sharing the business, giving equal stakes in it to a brother of Mr. Pourier, an adopted brother and a nephew.
"We have people in Washington telling us what funding we need, what our problems are, how to solve them," Mr. Pourier said. "Damn it, let us solve them. We can keep our values and live in a dual culture."

HEADLINE: Senate Race May Focus On Negative Images

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Here's a pop-culture quiz: Which image carries the most negative baggage in 1992 recession-era politics -- the career politician entrenched in the hidebound ways of Washington, or the career businessman enriched by the excesses of 1980's Wall Street?
Both images are to some degree caricatures. But if Connecticut's United States Senate race becomes as mean-spirited as the early signs indicate, voters in November could have just such a choice presented to them. 
 The contest, between Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat seeking his third six-year term, and Brook Johnson, a Republican business executive from Greenwich making his first run for office, will almost certainly present Mr. Dodd's toughest challenge since he was elected to the Senate in 1980, if only because of the amount of money invested in it.
In Mr. Dodd's last race, in 1986, his Republican challenger, Roger W. Eddy, raised and spent $467,000, compared with $2.2 million for the Dodd campaign. Mr. Eddy received 35 percent of the vote, to 65 percent for Mr. Dodd.
 
A Level Field This Time?
 This time around, the financial playing field will be even, and could perhaps even tip toward the challenger. Mr. Johnson, a textile executive who sold and bought back his company during the 1980's in a series of leveraged buyouts, has already spent more than $1 million, mostly his own money. Last Tuesday he won a primary election against Christopher Burnham, a State Representative from Stamford.
Mr. Johnson's campaign will cost at least another $1 million between now and Nov. 3, said a spokesman, Mark Rivers. National Republican party leaders also pledged this week to send advisers and resources to help Mr. Johnson in the campaign, as one of about a dozen selected races around the nation.
Political experts in both parties say that forces beyond the wallet are also at work that could fuel a nasty streak in the campaigns of both candidates -- or, in a gentler interpretation, perhaps provide a genuinely illuminating debate about what sorts of skills people value in their leaders and what cultural symbols resonate most deeply with voters.
 
Dodd Still Popular
 One of Mr. Johnson's main problems is that Mr. Dodd is still a popular politician in Connecticut, even among Republicans (in a poll conducted by the University of Connecticut before Tuesday's Republican primary, 42 percent of the Republican respondents gave him a "favorable" rating). That means Mr. Johnson will have to redefine Mr. Dodd's image to bring the race within reach.
Mr. Dodd will most likely face similar pressure to hit hard, experts say. Leaving Mr. Johnson unchallenged would allow him -- as a political blank slate with no public record -- to present an image that seems perfect. Republican leaders said this week that, even in an optimistic estimate, at least a third of voters still do not recognize Mr. Johnson's name.
Mr. Dodd hinted at his strategy on Tuesday night, with a congratulatory statement to the Republicans saying he agreed with Mr. Johnson's refrain about the need for change in Washington. Without mentioning names, Mr. Dodd went on to specify.
"This election is about change, all right," Mr. Dodd said. "Changing the status quo where the rich got richer during the go-go 1980's, while the middle class has been whittled away."
 
Theme of Disparity
 Of course, Democrats from Gov. Bill Clinton on down are saying much the same thing this year. But Mr. Dodd, as a liberal with solid labor backing, may hope to use the theme of economic disparity to great effect in a state reeling from the effects of the recession, a collapse in housing prices and a bank-lending crisis that economists say has stifled business growth.
Republicans also lost no time is gearing up for a few rounds of Dodd-bashing. On the day after the primary, the state Republican Party chairman, Richard Foley, suggested to reporters that Mr. Dodd did not tell the truth and had "bamboozled" voters for years.
"Chris Dodd has a pretty face and a very ugly record," Mr. Foley said.
But clearly, Mr. Johnson has a record too. If an incumbent's public voting record is fair game in discussing Mr. Dodd's Senate career, how far can Mr. Dodd's forces go in investigating Mr. Johnson's activities in private business without seeming to invade his privacy?
 
Like New Jersey in 1990?
 And will the much-ballyhooed anger in the voting public rebound to Mr. Johnson's benefit? Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, the chairman of the Republican National Senatorial Committee, said this week that Connecticut in 1992 was like New Jersey in 1990.
People are still angry about last year's imposition of a state income tax, Mr. Gramm said, and will take it out this year against Mr. Dodd, just as New Jersey voters did against Senator Bill Bradley. Mr. Bradley, considered a shoo-in for re-election, barely won against a poorly financed and little known Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman.
Mr. Gramm conceded this week that the national organization had dropped the ball by not giving Ms. Whitman enough support. It would not happen again, he said.
"They had a person who had no financing and was not targeted by the Senatorial Committee," he said of Ms. Whitman. "We believe that Connecticut represents a real opportunity for us."
But the issue of voter anger over taxes may not be quite as clear-cut in Connecticut. Mr. Johnson has said he is for repealing the income tax, while Mr. Dodd has said it should be revised to lower the rate for middle-income earners.
Even if voters are still angry, the focus of their anger is difficult to assess. In the primary election races on Tuesday for the State Legislature, for example, there were 17 races in which one candidate supported repealing the tax and the other did not. Only three of those pro-repeal candidates won.

HEADLINE: EUROPE IN TURMOIL;
Aware of Its Own Limits, U.S. Favors Unity Treaty

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
While the Bush Administration has carefully avoided commenting on the French vote on European unity so as not be accused of meddling, Administration officials leave little doubt that they hope the French will vote yes and endorse the Maastricht treaty.
The simple reason, American officials say, is that the United States has much more to fear from European fragmentation and resurgent nationalism than it does from European consolidation. 
 "We are not taking a position on the French vote," said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. "That is an internal affair. But we do feel, and said so at the time, that the Maastricht treaty and European unity was something that was beneficial."
 
Ambivalence in Washington
 Clearly there is ambivalence in Washington about European integration. At one moment officials will point out that a tightly unified Europe would be a formidable economic competitor and a much more potent political force whose interests and opinions would have to be taken into account more than ever before. Something that throws a wrench into those unification plans would not necessarily send Washington into mourning.
There is even a bit of quiet glee in watching the French, who are constantly competing with Washington for regional influence, emerge as the possible agents for the unraveling of European unity.
But these sentiments tend to be overridden by a more powerful instinct: that if French voters reject the Maastricht treaty and the plans for unification unravel, it will damage American economic and strategic interests in the long run. The stakes, American officials say, include gains in international trade talks and Europe's ability to act coherently in the face of outbreaks of nationalist violence like the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
"Our policy has been fairly consistent in support of European integration ever since the Marshall Plan, but we have tended to waver every time it gets close to realization, out of a fear that once they do get unified they will be more competitors than partners," said Stephen F. Szabo, an expert on Germany at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. "But the fact is our longer-term interests are more compatible with a unified Europe.
 
Memory of Wars
 "Several times in this century we have been drawn into Europe as a result of the revival of nationalism and inter-European rivalries," he added. "So it is very much in our broader interest to have some sort of stable post-nationalist structure in place there."
Today Mr. Bush invited financial leaders to meet with him at the White House on Sunday, and aides said he would talk to them about the importance of currency stability and the world trade talks in Geneva.
Still, the United States, with its economic constraints, cannot indefinitely play the stabilizing, balancing role that it has had in Europe since 1945. And no single European nation, including Germany, can substitute for the United States as a neutral balancing power. Only some sort of pan-European structure can do that.
In broader strategic terms, officials say, the United States is gradually withdrawing from responsibilities around the world now that the cold war is over, and, at a time when it wants to do less -- less peacekeeping, less peacemaking -- it needs a cohesive, resolute Europe to do more.
Getting the European Community to act with dispatch and generosity during the Persian Gulf War and in the crisis in the Balkans has been difficult enough, American officials say.
"If you think the Europeans were well orchestrated today when it came to dealing with the crisis in Bosnia," said one senior Administration official, "imagine what they will be like if Maastricht explodes and they go in 10 different directions?"
 
More Yugoslavias?
 There may well be more Yugoslavias down the road, which is why Americans should have no doubt about where their interests lie in the French vote, said Senator Joseph R. Biden, the Delaware Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Europe.
"In the cold war the United States found it convenient to lead an alliance of lessors," Mr. Biden said in a statement. "But today we can achieve none of our major global objectives -- building new institutions of collective security, maintaining open markets, promoting democracy, preventing weapons proliferation or preserving the global environment -- without Europe as a responsible, co-equal partner."
There is also an economic rationale for supporting European economic integration, American officials and analysts say, provided that it evolves in an open, non-protectionist form.
"A self-confident Western Europe is important to continue to act as an economic magnet and example for the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, particularly Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia," said Michael Mandelbaum, a European affairs expert at Johns Hopkins and a foreign policy adviser to the Clinton campaign.
 
Concern for Free Trade
 American officials say they are equally concerned about the impact that the unraveling of the Maastricht treaty would have on negotiations for a new international trade accord known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT.
The six-year-old negotiations, which involve 108 nations, are aimed at adopting rules to expand free-trade rules and reduce tariffs. Progress has been stalled because of a dispute between the United States and the European Community, particularly France, over export subsidies to farmers.
If the Europeans felt too vulnerable before the French vote to make concessions on agriculture in the GATT talks, said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, "they are going to be even more insecure if Maastricht goes down."

HEADLINE: Economic Compromise Is in the Air as Russian Legislators Head to Moscow

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 19

 BODY:
With the Russian Government weakened and the economy slipping out of control, an important session of the legislature opens next week amid signs that President Boris N. Yeltsin is seeking further compromise with forces opposed to Western-style economic reform.
This summer the Russian economy has borne the brunt of an unresolved political and constitutional struggle over the money supply. 
 The executive branch, under Acting Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, has been trying to limit the granting of new credits to former Soviet industrial enterprises so it can keep inflation down and encourage structural changes in the the economy. But the central bank, which is responsible to the legislature, has opened the credit spigot wide in the hope of reviving production and avoiding high levels of unemployment.
The clash, which the central bank and its Acting Director, Viktor V. Gerashchenko, have lately been winning, is in essence about the size of the state's role in controlling the economy. In even broader terms, it is a deeply political struggle about the future direction of Russia. But in narrower terms, as always here, it is an intensely personal struggle for power and perquisites.
 
The Dacha and Other Perks
 "Russian politicians always get their priorities mixed up," a senior Western diplomat said. "They're so involved in their power struggles, which have a lot to do with access to the dacha, the car, trips abroad and access to hard currency, that they really don't see that the economy is on the verge of collapse."
For Mr. Gaidar and his team of Western-oriented ministers, this is a moment of some despair. Mr. Gerashchenko, who took over the central bank in mid-July, issued more than trillion rubles, or some $5 billion, in credit in July and August alone. He did so, Mr. Gaidar's aides say, without consulting the executive branch, and one result will be an inflation rate close to 30 percent this month. They see the possibility of hyperinflation, or a 50 percent monthly rate, in October or November.
Mr. Gerashchenko's policies have also led Mr. Gaidar to acknowledge publicly that the Russian Government cannot meet the financial targets that it negotiated earlier this year with the International Monetary Fund. Russia had originally agreed to aim for a domestically financed budget deficit of 5 percent of gross national product and a monthly inflation rate in single digits by the end of the year.
 
I.M.F. Is Nervous
 Mr. Gaidar has only admitted what everyone already knew. But, despite the air of calm at briefings by I.M.F. officials during the annual meeting of the fund and the World Bank in Washington this week, senior Western diplomats here say that fund officials are "extremely nervous" about the current direction of the Russian economy.
A senior adviser to Mr. Gaidar, Sergei A. Vasilyev, director of the Government Working Center for Economic Reform, went so far as to accuse Mr. Gerashchenko and his allies of "working to discredit the Government and the entire course of the reforms." Some diplomats agree, suggesting that Mr. Gerashchenko is aware of the inflationary implications of his policies and hopes to sink Mr. Gaidar.
But the arguments advanced by Mr. Gerashchenko and powerful industrial lobbyists like Arkady I. Volsky is also about the need for a stronger state hand in the managing of economic reform and a slower transition toward a limited market.
Politically, that is a popular stance for a people accustomed to strong leadership and confused by the rapid economic changes in their lives. It is also a stance that is popular among politicians and bureaucrats, well represented in the Congress, who fear the loss of ties to the institutions and power structures of the old regime.
They also fear the impact of privatization. On Oct. 1, the Government will distribute vouchers worth 10,000 rubles, or $50, to each Russian citizen as his share of state-owned property to invest or sell. No one knows whether the program will be a success, but it will help establish a new political context.
If it is successful, Mr. Yeltsin can tell Russians, "You're the owners now, and Congress stands in the way." If it is a failure, it may strengthen the opposition.
"It will inject a new reality," a Western diplomat said, "and people will be talking about it."
 
Apocalypse Unlikely
 So the issues at stake are significant, even fundamental. But the legislative session, which opens on Tuesday with the smaller Supreme Soviet and may run for two months, including the first session since April of the larger Congress of People's Deputies, may not provide the requisite drama or resolution.
Despite a fondness for apocalyptic language, Russia is also the country of the anticlimax and the messy compromise, where predictions of riots, hunger and chaos rarely quite seem to materialize. Politicians, like their constituents, tend to be patient and resourceful, with a highly developed sense of survival.
Already, Mr. Yeltsin and the speaker of the Russian Parliament, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, have made a public show of their desire for compromise. Mr. Khasbulatov, who was elected from the region of Chechnya, does not want new elections, and Mr. Yeltsin recently promised legislators they could serve for the rest of their five-year terms, through March 1995.
Mr. Yeltsin has also called for a close working relationship with the legislature, a gesture that gives Speaker Khasbulatov, who is feuding with his more liberal deputy, Sergei A. Filatov, more respect. Mr. Yeltsin's base, the badly organized democrats, represent only about a third of the parliament, and they have been calling for the ouster of Mr. Khasbulatov.
Another third of the parliament is made up of hard-line conservatives, ex-Communists who want Mr. Gaidar out and someone like Mr. Volsky or the current Vice President, Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, in. Another third, known as "the marsh in the middle," includes most of Mr. Volsky's followers and tends to lean toward the conservatives.
But the opposition to the Government is incoherent and lacks a political standard bearer. Nor does it have a clear alternative plan in a country where the old command instruments are damaged or gone.
Nonetheless, the opposition objects to the current direction of Western-style, I.M.F.-sanctioned reform, as diluted as it now is, and Mr. Yeltsin needs to give those lawmakers some satisfaction. That may come in new appointments to the Government from the managerial classes, in addition to the three industrialists grafted clumsily onto the Gaidar team in early June.
Or it may come in the form of a more formal acknowledgement of the legislature's powers of oversight, or a more expensive ruble rate for foreign investment in Russia, or an explicit policy of a more gradual transition to the market, with even more state involvement and control.
 
What Yeltsin May Seek
 But it will hardly be a ringing endorsement of the strict monetary policy, fiscal discipline and untrammeled market that are endorsed by the I.M.F. and that Mr. Gaidar tried to introduce in the first half of the year.
In return, Mr. Yeltsin wants a number of things: first, a moratorium on an early challenge to Mr. Gaidar and the Government, including an extension of the President's extraordinary powers to appoint ministers without parliamentary confirmation and to rule by decree.
Second, he would seek the passage of a law on government, to be included in a new constitution, that would allow a strong presidential system. The legislature would have the right under such a law to confirm the President's choice of Prime Minister and lesser officials, but not the rest of the Cabinet or key security officials. Third, at Mr. Gaidar's urging, Mr. Yeltsin would want the central bank subordinated to the President, or at the very least to operate independently of lawmakers.
There is room for compromise and backroom dealing on all of these issues, however, and many diplomats believe the Gaidar Government will survive the congress relatively intact. But it is always possible that both Mr. Gerashchenko and Mr. Gaidar will find themselves serving as trade bait as Mr. Yeltsin and the loose conservative majority in Parliament try to make a deal.
 
Less Support for Yeltsin
 All the main characters have less influence now than they did in April. Mr. Khasbulatov may be unable to carry the legislature with him; Mr. Volsky's own base of state enterprise and farm managers is more interested in rapid reform than he is; and Mr. Yeltsin's own position is not what it was.
"Yeltsin knows his finest hours are over," a senior Western diplomat said. "They occurred when he climbed up on the tank to fight the August coup and when he went to Washington this summer. He'll never be that popular again." That is why Mr. Yeltsin has been picking his battles more carefully, canceling an ill-conceived visit to Japan and trying to come to an arrangement with Mr. Khasbulatov, the diplomat said.
For Western Governments and for the International Monetary Fund, which is their agent, there is simply no alternative to Mr. Yeltsin, who will maneuver as he must. "Whenever he's had to choose, he's chosen the democratic path," the diplomat said. "The alternatives are too awful to contemplate."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congressional Races;
Minority Candidates See Congress as Useful Tool

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Of all the changes coming to Congress, none is more certain than an increase of at least 10 blacks and five Hispanic lawmakers. And these candidates, intent on helping neglected constituencies, conspicuously contradict the anti-government spirit of this year's Congressional elections.
Many candidates this year campaign with a sense that Congress itself is one of the nation's most serious problems, arguing over term limits, committee procedures and staff levels. But the new minority candidates treat getting to Congress as a chance to bring money and programs to constituents who previously had to compete with better-off whites for their lawmakers' attention. 
 Their presence will not make it instantly easier to squeeze money out of tight Federal budgets, or to overcome arguments for keeping military spending near current levels. But their collective savvy and experience are sure to invigorate the forces in Congress who want to make more of an effort to solve domestic social problems.
Eva M. Clayton of Warrenton, N.C., wants to promote rural economic development. Mel Reynolds of Chicago wants to combat mortgage discrimination by banks. Frank Tejeda of San Antonio wants better services for veterans. Lincoln Diaz-Balart of Miami calls post-hurricane reconstruction his first priority.
They are among 15 prospective minority lawmakers who face insignificant opposition or are running unopposed in the November elections. Their candidacies guarantee at least a 40 percent increase in minority membership in Congress, above the current totals of 25 blacks and 10 Hispanic voting members of the House.
The increase will be still larger if candidates with real opposition prevail, like Carol Mosely Braun, a black Senate candidate in Illinois, or Anita Perez Ferguson, an Hispanic House candidate in California. There could easily be 39 black and 17 Hispanic members of the next Congress.
 
'Major Power Shift'
 The impact could be dramatic. Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is the senior black in Congress, said that combined with the retirements of conservatives, the influx of new minority members could amount to "a major power shift in Congress."
Almost all the new minority lawmakers will be Democrats, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, said he had been impressed by all of them he had met. "Many of them have held high public offices in their communities, have been deeply involved in building their communities," he said.
He would not predict just how their influence would be felt, but said the House would benefit simply by having its racial makeup "better represent the American people."
The House would have to have 52 black members before their percentage matched blacks' 12 percent share of the nation's population. Still, the increase is dramatic. During Reconstruction, the number of blacks in Congress who served at any one time peaked at eight. Those numbers dwindled to zero when George Henry White of North Carolina retired in 1901. Afterward, no blacks served in Congress until Oscar De Priest of Illinois took his seat in 1929. It then took 40 more years for the total to reach 10, in 1969, and it was 1983 before there were 20 blacks.
Many of the 1993 class of minority Representatives will come here as a result of redistricting plans, dictated by the 1982 amendments to the Voting Rights Act. The amendments are aimed at maximizing minority representation.
Economic, rather than clearly racial, concerns have dominated their campaigns. Even so, when primary contests pitted black or Hispanic candidates against whites, votes often followed racial lines. But the general election messages focus heavily on the economic needs of their districts.
Mrs. Clayton, a county commissioner for 10 years, says investing in roads, communication systems and education can help the rural economy. Training is important, she told a barbecue supper in Warsaw, N.C., last week, so that prospective employers will not "think of unskilled, low wage jobs" when they think of eastern North Carolina.
Another prospective newcomer, Gloria Roybal-Allard, wants to focus on domestic violence, sexual assault and environmental concerns, issues she has specialized in during five years of representing downtown Los Angeles in the California Assembly.
Louis Gutierrez, whose Chicago district is shaped like a pair of earmuffs, also talks about investing in roads and education but defines it in terms of community policing, better schools and expanded day-care centers. He talks of combating drug problems both in his district and with military force on the country's borders.
Another North Carolinian, Melvin Watt, assails the military budget, pointing out how much more could be done in drug treatment, Head Start programs or college grants by cutting production of B-2 bombers, at $2 billion apiece.
A former state Senator, Mr. Watt has a district that includes black neighborhoods strung along Interstate 85 from Durham to Charlotte. But he argues that even if its map looks funny, the district has common urban problems that will make it easier to represent than a traditional district that combines central cities and suburbs.
 
Some Defeated Incumbents
 Mr. Diaz-Balart, the only Republican among the certain or all but certain new members, hopes to get beyond post-hurricane reconstruction to changes in tax laws that would provide incentives for investment -- a staple of House Republican arguments all year.
While most of the new members will come from new districts, some are succeeding retiring incumbents, and others defeated sitting members in primaries. Mr. Reynolds, a Chicago college professor, defeated Representative Gus Savage. Bobby Rush, a one-time Black Panther, defeated Representative Charles A. Hayes in another Chicago contest.
Besides fighting mortgage discrimination, Mr. Reynolds said he wanted to pursue a larger Federal role in education. A Rhodes Scholar, he said, "Minorities in this country, if they are to have any chance to be free, have to get an education."
Mr. Rush, a Chicago alderman since 1983 and a ward committeeman since 1984, has an agenda that includes creating more jobs, fighting crime, and making health care and housing more affordable. Right now, he complains, "The Federal Government is not engaged in a meaningful way in the day-to-day lives of the people residing in my district."
If there is one national issue that most of the new minority lawmakers bring up consistently, it is the need to improve the nation's health care. Mrs. Clayton called it a "national tragedy that we as an industrialized country do not have adequate health care." She said that she did not have a particular solution that she was committed to, but that changing the insurance industry would not be enough.
Most of the prospective new members are already angling for committee assignments, and they are asking for more than freshmen usually get -- seats on the influential Committees on Ways and Means, Appropriations, and Energy and Commerce.
Mr. Reynolds spoke for their hopes when he said, "All bets are off about what a freshman can and cannot do." Mr. Gephardt agreed that it was likely that those powerful committees that have excluded new members in the past would have to include some in a year when a quarter of the House may be new to Washington.
While many candidates this year are promising sudden change in the House, the prospective minority lawmakers talk more about a long haul. Mr. Watt said: "I'm not into making things happen overnight. I don't mind waiting for a while."
Neither the minority candidates nor their constituents have been attracted to the term-limits movement. Mr. Tejeda said rather than being turned off by Congress, his prospective constituents thought Congress would now be closer to them because they now have a district that they consider their own.
Most of the prospective minority lawmakers are seriously involved in the Presidential race, too. Except for Mr. Diaz-Balart, they are working for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential nominee.
Mr. Rush, schooled in Chicago politics, offers one reason for his efforts to help Mr. Clinton. He said, "I would like to be able to have access to the President of the United States, to pick up the phone and ask him for consideration of matters that affect my Congressional district."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 19; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 877 words

HEADLINE: EX-MAYOR WRITES OF A DEATH PLOT

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Former Mayor W. Wilson Goode, the city's first black mayor, has written a political memoir containing the revelation that he feared that racist Philadelphia police officers were planning to kill him during the fiery confrontation between the police and the radical group Move in 1985.
Mr. Goode says he never alerted his security guards or any other law-enforcement officials but simply stayed home, out of harm's way. 
 Mr. Goode was criticized by the commission that investigated the incident for not being on the scene and for allowing the operation to be run by officials he said he did not trust.
In his book, Mr. Goode shrugs off the whole thing, much the way he ascribes the city's two-year-old financial crisis to forces and people beyond his control. He said in an interview on Thursday that he saw no purpose in making the assassination attempt a major issue at the time, "and I didn't make it a major issue in my book." The former Mayor, who now teaches at Eastern College in suburban St. Davids, completed his second consecutive four-year term in December and was prohibited by the City Charter from seeking a third.
 
One-Paragraph Reference
 Mr. Goode's disclosure raises as many questions as it answers, and some political analysts tend to dismiss the whole book as self-serving. "Goode tries to do a lot of reinventing of history," said Neil Oxman, a Democratic campaign strategist who helped Mr. Goode win his first mayoral election in 1983. "But unfortunately for him, the citizens of Philadelphia have made up their mind that he was one of the worst mayors of all time."
The autobiographical book, entitled "In Goode Faith" and co-written by Joann Stevens of Washington, is being published by Judson Press in Valley Forge, Pa. The company said that 15,000 copies were being distributed nationally and that Mr. Goode was scheduling appearances on national radio and television talk shows.
The book deals with the assassination plot in a single paragraph, but that disclosure has captured more public interest than anything else. . Mr. Goode said the assassination was supposed to occur on May 13, 1985, the day that nearly 500 police officers assembled in west Philadelphia to serve members of the radical group Move with arrest warrants on charges of parole violation and assault. The heavily armed black cult members had fortified their home and had become a threat to the predominantly black neighborhood. The confrontation resulted in the deaths of 11 of the 13 cult members, including five children, and left a neighborhood in ruins when fire swept through it.
 
Why He Stayed Home
 Mr. Goode writes that he stayed home that day because "I feared being killed." He says three people he considered reliable had told him that some renegade police officers were plotting to shoot him, presumably only because he was black and mayor, and that these officers would then portray him as a victim of cross-fire between the police and Move members. Mr. Goode has refused to reveal the three sources.
"I was outraged!" He wrote. "At the same time I battled my instincts to be at the scene of the action."
Mr. Goode might have had reason to fear elements of the police department, which had developed a national reputation for racism and brutality in the 1970's during the tenure of Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, who has since died.
Mr. Goode did not tell any law enforcement officials about the threat. Charles W. Bowser, who was a member of the Philadelphia Special Investigation Commission on the Move confrontation and was once one of Mr. Goode's informal advisers, said: "He should have contacted the F.B.I. or the State Police or some other law enforcement agency to have it investigated. Otherwise, he was leaving individuals on the police force who he believed had the intent to commit assassination, and I just think that's outrageous."
 
'Put the Fire Out!'
 The commission, a panel of civic leaders that Mr. Goode appointed, determined that Mr. Goode had "abdicated his responsibilities as a leader." No criminal charges were ever brought against any officials involved in the incident.
The Mayor watched television as the confrontation grew from an exchange of gunfire into a battle. The police alone fired 10,000 bullets and used water cannons, smoke bombs and tear gas. Eleven hours into the confrontation, Mr. Goode, by telephone, authorized the use of explosives, and a police helicopter dropped a military bomb onto the row house, turning it into an inferno. The Fire Department let the fire burn for 45 minutes before responding, and it consumed 60 houses and left 250 people homeless.
" 'Put the fire out!" I yelled at the screen,' " Mr. Goode writes. "I paced from room to room, banging on desks and talking to the television screens."
Mr. Goode wrote that he accepted responsibility for the disaster because it "happened on my watch," but he says his aides were guilty of misinforming him about the operation. He also blamed racist police for the brutality of the confrontation and, ultimately, for his increasing ineffectiveness over the remaining six and a half years of his administration.
"Sadly," Mr. Goode writes, "I realized that the police had killed two birds with one stone -- Move and me."

HEADLINE: U.S. Anti-Drug Moves Irk Bolivians

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRINIDAD, Bolivia

 BODY:
The United States effort to halt the flow of cocaine is coming under attack in Bolivia, which has opened its doors wider than any other to American drug agents and tolerated heavy political influence from Washington.
Recent miscues by the Bolivian Government and United States officials have stoked strong resentment against the American presence, and a move to restrict United States activities threatens to become a central issue in next June's presidential elections. 
 "Never in our history has there been so much anti-American feeling," said Jorge Lazarte, a political scientist and director of Bolivia's National Electoral Court. "The United States Embassy has acted with such a sense of superiority that it has hurt our national pride. We may be a poor country, but we still have our dignity."
In recent weeks, every major presidential candidate has called either for the removal or a substantial reduction of United States military and drug personnel in Bolivia and a "readjustment" in Bolivian-United States relations.
 
Drug Policy Setback Feared
 "The perception of the people is that we have lost our sovereignty," said Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, the current front-running candidate and head of the National Revolutionary Movement party.
United States officials fear that if a national consensus emerges to throw out the Americans, it could set back drug policy here for years, virtually erasing any recent gains.
Bolivia produces about a third of the world's coca leaves, the raw material for cocaine -- ranking second to Peru, which produces two-thirds. And after Colombia, it is the largest exporter of pure cocaine to Europe and the United States. Drug trafficking brings between $300 million and $500 million into the Bolivian economy each year, compared with legal exports of $1 billion.
More than 100 personnel from the Drug Enforcement Administration, the United States military and the Central Intelligence Agency are involved in the drug war in Bolivia. Of about $200 million in annual American aid to Bolivia, $48 million goes to fighting the traffickers.
 
Few Anti-Drug Victories
 In the more than two years since President Bush met with the leaders of the three Andean nations in Cartagena, Colombia, and declared war against the South American drug trade, there have been few bright spots in United States-Andean anti-drug efforts.
A crackdown in Colombia has hurt the once-dominant Medellin cartel, but the cartel based in Cali has moved in to fill the void, in part by moving operations across the border into Bolivia. And in July the head of the Medellin cartel, Pablo Escobar, escaped from his custom-built prison compound.
In Peru, President Alberto Fujimori's controversial suspension of constitutional rule in April prompted the United States to cut off assistance in anti-drug efforts already hampered by an alliance between traffickers and Shining Path guerrillas.
In Bolivia, however, some progress appears to have been made, although even here officials concede that their victories may be fleeting, producing at best shifts in traffickers' operations.
 
Seizures and Extraditions
 Still, American officials say, the amount of refined cocaine leaving Bolivia has dropped dramatically in recent months. "The organizations are really hurting and they are in disarray," said a United States agent. "We've hit them very hard. But this all could be set back by the current political climate."
The officials cited the seizure in June 1991 of the jungle town of Santa Ana, for decades a wild-west type holdout of traffickers. Within weeks, eight major Bolivian traffickers surrendered. In addition, over the last year, several other traffickers have been extradited to the United States. At least half a dozen corrupt police and Government officials have been removed from their posts.
Finally, counternarcotics teams have begun the largest offensive to date in the coca-producing Chapare region, where Colombian traffickers from the Cali cartel have moved in to replace recently smashed Bolivian distribution networks.
 But recent events have soured the mood of cooperation, underlining the risks to the United States of becoming so deeply enmeshed in the affairs of Bolivia.
In June, residents of this jungle town watched as dozens of American military aircraft, loaded with men and supplies, hopped from here to Santa Ana del Yacuma. Rumors spread quickly. The soldiers were were said to be burying nuclear waste in Bolivia's jungle Beni region or building a huge United States military base similar to the one in Panama. Or they were trafficking in children. Press reports based on the rumors stirred wide outrage.
The soldiers, in fact, were army engineers out of Fort Bragg, N.C., on one of their many goodwill missions, building a school for Santa Ana. The Government of Jaime Paz Zamora, which previously had sought Congressional approval for such an arrival of foreign troops, had failed to notify Congress.
Then in August, an American D.E.A. agent, sitting in a bar at the eastern lowlands city of Santa Cruz de la Sierra, accidently shot and wounded a Bolivian in the shoulder. The next day, as the Government prepared to file charges, the agent was flown out of the country. The incident also received wide publicity and stirred indignation, and Bolivia is now seeking extradition.
 
Where Troops Are Popular
 "Think of it, they can extradite our people for trial, but we cannot put Americans on trial here who commit crimes," said Mr. Lazarte.
The Yankee-go-home sentiment is far from unanimous. In this jungle town and in Santa Ana, many residents have approached the troops, asking them to begin other civic projects.
 
'We Could Win Here'
 But drug officials are worried that either Congress or the Bolivian Government will force them to pull back at a critical juncture.
"We could win here," said a United States official. "Sometimes you can smell it and see it."
Rooting out corruption among Bolivian politicians, military and police is seen by many as the most critical task.
Robert S. Gelbard, the United States Ambassador here until July 1991, frequently used a heavy hand in denouncing officials found to be corrupt, a tactic that now seems to be backfiring. A former Interior Minister was forced to resign after such denunciations.
On a quieter level, D.E.A. officials keep exhaustive data banks on police, military officials and politicians in Bolivia, as well as maintain an extensive network of paid informers. The Bolivian Government routinely sends lists of suggested police appointees in drug trafficking regions to the D.E.A. for its review. Names on those lists are frequently rejected.
"In Bolivia we are at a rare historical moment in which there is a significant cadre of clean people who are hanging by their fingernails," said an American official. "We have to support these people. We are not going to win this war by going to diplomatic cocktail parties."

HEADLINE: Hungarian's Attack on Opponents Sets Off Storm

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Sept. 19

 BODY:
A leader of Hungary's center-right governing party has touched off a storm with a report asserting that the political opposition, liberals, Jews, Western financiers and the press are sabotaging the Government's work.
The political leader, Istvan Csurka, a vice president of the Hungarian Democratic Forum, published his analysis last month in the party weekly. The 57-year-old playwright was one of Hungary's most popular writers in the 1970's and 80's and an important figure in the opposition in the Communist era. 
 Mr. Csurka (pronounced CHOOR-kuh) cited instances of what he considered Jewish and foreign influence over Hungarian affairs, deception by opposition members and wavering by his own party. Referring to the Communist elite that used to rule, he said, "Consensus is the nomenklatura's newest slogan to stay in power."
Many Hungarians interpreted a reference to "genetic reasons for deterioration" of the country as an allusion to gypsies, but Mr. Csurka denied this.
Some members of Mr. Csurka's own party quickly condemned his work, with one member likening its message to Nazi ideology.
Prime Minister Jozsef Antall, who is also president of the Democratic Forum, told Parliament that he had to distance himself from some ideas in the publication. "Istvan Csurka's political pamphlet," he said, "offers politically harmful and wrong answers, with which neither the Government nor I can agree."
He singled out Mr. Csurka's comparison of the International Monetary Fund's presence in Hungary to the postwar Soviet Army presence.
Opposition members were more blunt. "Forces within the governing party who want to take the country in the direction of Balkan chaos have begun to dictate," Laszlo Kover, a member of the Federation of Young Democrats, told Parliament.
No one can say how much support Mr. Csurka has in his party. The Democratic Forum is to hold a congress in November to determine its course, and until then Mr. Csurka and his rivals will be courting members.
Foreign politicians have warned of the publication's potentially negative effect on Hungary's image abroad. Representative Tom Lantos, Democrat of California, who was born in Hungary, said he would raise the publication in Congress next week.
While there does not appear to be much popular support for a far-right political surge in Hungary now, many commentators have said the Csurka study hit a chord of anger in society, appealing in particular to embittered, poor, elderly Hungarians who feel they have gained nothing from the end of Communism but rising prices.
But many Hungarians said it also reached out to the middle class, especially those who feel they have been denied economic opportunity and are sinking into poverty.
"A lot of people are dissatisfied, because we had promised that they would live better, not that only those who had previously collected the capital could become entrepreneurs," said Istvan Elek, a member of the Democratic Forum's liberal wing.
Mr. Csurka reminded his readers that while the Communist Party's political network had been broken, its members' economic might had not. The Communist-era elite remains largely in place as factory managers, bank executives and business owners, he said, preventing the formation of a new middle class.
"My study was intended to throw a spotlight on this," Mr. Csurka said.
He said he had been alarmed by a discussion in the Democratic Forum last spring in which several leaders called for keeping the old economic leaders in place to get the economy moving. "What if America were a land of opportunity where only descendants of the Mayflower had the right to prosper?" he asked in an interview.
Mr. Csurka also appeared to tap a widespread disappointment with the West's unwillingness to provide large amounts of aid. "There's always a Western examiner coming along, and we're always failing the exam he sets, so there is some real anger about this," said Laszlo Lengyel, director of the Financial Research Institute.

HEADLINE: Shrinking Tax Base Means Higher Long Island Taxes

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 19

 BODY:
For the first time in its history, the total assessed value of property on Long Island is going down -- which means the average taxpayer now faces a property-tax increase to make up for lost revenues.
Officials say lower home-sale prices, a wave of challenges to assessments and new rules removing some property from the tax rolls have shrunk the total value of taxable property. To compensate, county officials say they must raise tax rates, resulting in higher tax bills for a majority of taxpayers whose assessments have not changed. 
 Compounding the revenue problem is an increase in delinquent taxes, arising in part from recession-driven bankruptcies and foreclosures.
Suffolk County property owners, already paying among the highest property taxes in the country, are threatened with a 20 percent tax increase, nearly half of it to cover losses resulting from lower property values. County officials attribute the other half of the tax rise to increases in the cost of state-mandated programs administered by the county, like social welfare and child care.
 
'Ugly, but Honest' Budget
 The additional tax dollars would be needed to help balance a $1.5 billion budget for 1993, proposed Friday by Suffolk County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, who described his fiscal plan as "ugly, but honest."
Mr. Gaffney, in presenting his budget, said the county was greatly concerned that assessed valuation in Suffolk had fallen by approximately $120 million this year.
He said that even if no additional money were needed for mandated costs, the reduction in total assessed valuation would require increases averaging $123 a taxpayer, just for the county's share of a homeowner's total property-tax bill.
The county's share accounts for only 16 percent of the taxes paid by homeowners in Suffolk and neighboring Nassau County. The largest share, 60 percent, goes to school districts. The rest goes to local towns and villages and special library, fire and sewer districts.
 
Drop in Nassau, but Less
 In Nassau, County Executive Thomas Gulotta is also struggling to hold down county expenses in the face of a lingering recession and lower property values, as he prepares his budget for 1993, when he will also be seeking re-election.
In Nassau, the Department of Assessment has reported a decline of $27 million in the taxable value of commercial and residential property. Nassau officials say that since the decline is smaller than Suffolk's, it should have less impact on next year's budget.
Officials in both counties attribute the decline in property values to the ailing economy on Long Island, a weak real-estate market and a wave of successful assessment challenges by taxpayers. They also cite legislation approved by Albany that removes some utility property from the tax rolls, like the Shoreham nuclear power plant, which is being decommissioned by a state agency.
There is also a rising tide of tax delinquencies in both counties, further crimping cash flow and increasing the cost of tax collections.
 
If Everyone Paid Tax Due
 According to budget procedures, the counties can only record property-tax revenues when the payments have actually been received. Suffolk County has about $35 million in property taxes that have not been paid so far this year.
"And that creates a budgetary deficit of $35 million," said Charles K. Stein, Deputy Suffolk County Executive for Budget and Finance. "If everybody would pay their taxes, we'd be in great shape."
That amount is equal to the sum the county will have to borrow to cover the deficit left over from the 1991 budget Mr. Gaffney inherited from his predecessor, Patrick J. Halpin.
Nassau County is due to release its 1992 tax delinquency figures in the next few weeks. Officials say that from 1989 to 1991, total unpaid property taxes went from $59.7 million to $86.6 million, a 45 percent rise.
 
Delays by Bankruptcies
 The slowdown in tax payments coincided with an increase in bankruptcy petitions, which have the effect of delaying tax payments for as long as three years, officials said.
If owners do not make payments on vacant or commercial property within one year, or on residential property within three years, Suffolk County takes title to the land and can sell it at auction. During the entire period, however, the county is without tax income from the property. In Nassau, the county sells liens on the property to private investors to recover most or part of the lost tax revenues.
By state law, all property taxes on Long Island are collected by the county, which distributes them to towns, school districts and other special districts. If there are not enough tax dollars to go around, the county ends up on the short end and must borrow the difference until the delinquent taxes are recovered. The costs of the borrowing and the dunning of delinquent taxpayers are paid by the county, which in turn passes them to property owners in the next tax bill.
