HEADLINE: What's Good for Daily News Means Different Things for Other Papers

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
On the muddy battlefield of New York City's longstanding newspaper war, a revived Daily News with a wealthy new owner like Mortimer B. Zuckerman would clearly affect the other combatants: The New York Times, The New York Post and New York Newsday. One would be helped; the others, hurt, newspaper and labor leaders say.
Mr. Zuckerman, the New York real-estate developer and the owner of U.S. News & World Report, will almost certainly acquire the bankrupt Daily News, having won the support of eight of the paper's nine unions and the endorsement of The News's board of directors. 
 The deal has yet to clear bankruptcy court, and Mr. Zuckerman must still reach agreement with the paper's creditors and the Newspaper Guild. But even Peter S. Kalikow, the owner of The Post, who only last week was predicting he would be The News's eventual buyer, said on Friday that he expected Mr. Zuckerman to take the prize.
In broad terms, say the industry and labor officials, a Zuckerman-owned Daily News would seem to be good for The Times, bad for The Post and even worse for New York Newsday.
 
Consequences for Competitors
 In the short term, The Times hopes to use Mr. Zuckerman's deal with the pressmen's union to reach its own pact with that union, enabling the paper to open its new color printing plant at Edison, N.J., with all craft-union issues settled until 2000.
In the long term, the continued publication of The News, whoever owns it, would help The Times because both Newsday and The Post would face an even more competitive tabloid war. Had The News died, Newsday would have been a more direct competitor to The Times. Because Newsday had the most to gain, it now has the most to lose.
Officials of both The Times and the pressmen said that if Mr. Zuckerman acquires The News, The Times would use that as an opportunity to reduce staffing by offering enhanced severance to some of its pressmen and then filling the vacancies that are created with pressmen who leave The News. In exchange, The Times would win lower staffing levels than those in the current contract and would eventually achieve those levels through attrition.
 
Possible Sale of Plant
 That would satisfy The Times's goal of shifting the bulk of its printing operation to the Edison plant and closing a plant in Carlstadt, N.J., with all of its craft-union contracts settled. John M. O'Brien, the paper's deputy general manager, said that The Times plans to complete the move by April 1993.
Mr. Zuckerman has said that he has already had some discussions with The Times about acquiring the abandoned Carlstadt plant and refitting the black and white presses there to print in color.
Should Mr. Zuckerman and The Times reach agreement, The Times would eliminate an idle plant and Mr. Zuckerman might be able to achieve his labor savings by the end of next year. Of course, Mr. Zuckerman has other options, like taking over another empty plant or building one, and he said he had not yet made a decision.
 
Effects on Newsday
 In addition to helping The Times achieve its short-term labor goals, continued existence of The News would help The Times by forcing New York Newsday into a competitive battle that it had hoped it to avoid, newspaper leaders say.
During the strike at The News two years ago, the paper's circulation dropped to 300,000 from 1.2 million, its advertising all but disappeared and its death seemed likely. Had The News ceased publication, New York Newsday would have been the primary beneficiary and, like a hurricane gathering force, would probably have mounted an all-out assault on the high-demographic audience of The New York Times.
Though a tabloid like The News, New York Newsday's market niche is somewhere between the blue-collar and immigrant audience of The News and The Times's white-collar audience, which is generally wealthier. From The Times's perspective, The News is not a competitor, but New York Newsday is, and a revived News could effectively distract New York Newsday by going after its audience in Brooklyn and Queens, traditional News strongholds.
Ultimately, of course, a strong News would also be a competitor to The Times for retail and classified advertising, but from The Times's perspective that is a small price to pay for keeping New York Newsday at bay.
"From the perspective of The New York Times, the revival of The News is positive for the newspaper business and the city," said Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The Times, who declined to discuss the competitive situation in detail.
New York Newsday has consistently dismissed any suggestion that anything The News did would affect its overall plan, which has been slow and steady expansion from the paper's Long Island base into Brooklyn, Queens and, to some extent, Manhattan.
 
Potential Financial Problems
 Certainly New York Newsday would be unlikely to change its plan before waiting to see whether Mr. Zuckerman can weather the difficult financial times ahead and restore significant profitability, which The News has not had for decades. Should he fail, New York Newsday, once again, would stand to benefit the most.
Because most of Mr. Zuckerman's labor savings are pegged to a new plant, he may face huge financial problems in the next two years, especially if newsprint prices rise dramatically and the already depressed advertising climate should worsen.
Fred Drasner, who is president of U.S. News & World Report and who Mr. Zuckerman has said will be the publisher of The News if the deal goes through, declined to discuss The News's marketing plans or its financial situation.
But Michael M. Connery, a lawyer advising the newspaper unions, said that Mr. Zuckerman has realized small immediate labor savings from all the unions and stands to gain significant savings from an immediate reduction of nonunion employees and from the guild, which represents news, advertising and clerical workers.
 
Deep Pockets
 Although The News is losing money, it is nearly breaking even, and Mr. Connery said that he believes the paper would have little difficulty weathering the two years until the new plant is completed.
Presumably, Mr. Zuckerman, who Forbes magazine estimates to be worth more than $265 million, could finance any losses, but business executives are generally not inclined to do so for very long. From New York Newsday's perspective, the strategy would probably be to hold on and hope that Mr. Zuckerman fails.
For two decades the conventional wisdom of the newspaper business has been that The New York Post could not survive because it is perceived to be the weakest of four competing newspapers in a world where few cities have even two competitors.
But The Post has managed to hang on by cutting its expenses to the bone and by attracting an audience that, in many cases, also reads one of the city's other newspapers. The Post's combination of gossip, sports, crime and scandal has won an audience that allows Mr. Kalikow to operate it at what he terms "close to break even or a little profit."
Even with a revived News, Mr. Kalikow said, The Post could survive as it has. But Mr. Kalikow is in personal bankruptcy and his own financial situation could be a greater threat to The Post than a revived News.
 
Impact of Newsprint Prices
 Mr. Kalikow has said that he believes a new owner of The News would be wise to try to buy The Post because The News could probably add about 150,000 to its daily circulation if The Post were not competing. And without The Post, Mr. Kalikow said, The News would have more flexibility to raise its advertising rates, even beyond what the added circulation would justify.
But Mr. Zuckerman has said he is not interested in buying The Post.
While added circulation from The Post might help attract new advertising, the additional papers could actually cost The News money if newsprint prices rise, as is expected.
The News and The Post both sell on newsstands for 40 cents, The Times is 50 cents and New York Newsday is 35 cents. If newsprint prices increase, Mr. Kalikow said, he will raise his newsstand price, which would make it easier for The News to do so.
But without The Post, The News would be head-to-head with New York Newsday, which has traditionally made a cheaper price part of its appeal. Conceivably, with a steep rise in the price of paper, The News could find itself with more circulation but losing money on every extra sale, because the competition with New York Newsday would preclude raising the newsstand price.
And as for The Post's absence giving The News more flexibility in advertising pricing, the competition for advertising is now so fierce in a weak economy that The News would probably get little if any advantage.

HEADLINE: CARE Headquarters To Move to Atlanta From Manhattan

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
CARE, the international relief group, announced yesterday that it would move its national headquarters from New York to Atlanta next year, a move it said was caused by high operating and housing costs.
CARE, which was established in New York 46 years ago, will be given a five-story building in downtown Atlanta, to be bought and remodeled by an Atlanta charitable group, the Robert Woodruff Foundation. Atlanta civic and business leaders also arranged to cover part of the group's $6 million relocation costs and to give the group free and discounted legal, accounting and travel services. 
 "Obviously, we're disappointed to see CARE leave," Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said yesterday. "We're in a situation where other cities that don't have the variety and number of national and international organizations that we do will go to extraordinary lengths to get one or two or three."
Judith Webb, a vice president of the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, said CARE's presence would bring added "international recognition" to the city, as well as 200 new jobs.
 
Hard to Find Housing
 Jack McBride, a CARE vice president, said that New York had worked with the agency to keep it here, but that little could be done to offset the city's high operating costs and cost of living, particularly housing. He said it was difficult to find homes for overseas employees who were on temporary stints in the New York office.
CARE estimated that the move would save it more than $10 million in expenses over the next 10 years and would let it rotate more of its international staff through headquarters.
CARE will keep a regional office with about 15 people in New York. Its current headquarters is at 660 First Avenue, near 37th Street.

HEADLINE: A CENSUS DISPARITY FOR ASIANS IN U.S.

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Americans with roots in Asian countries and the Pacific Islands continue to stand out in educational achievement, but this advantage does not translate into higher per capita income, according to newly released Census Bureau data.
The latest data from a periodic survey of American families reveal that Asian-Americans complete more years of school than whites, on average, and are as likely as whites to be in professional occupations, but are still underrepresented in skilled crafts and in executive suites. As a result, median salaries of Asian-American workers lag behind those of whites. 
 And the report highlighted one other nuance: Because Asian-American families tend to have more wage earners than white families, their median household incomes surpass those of white households.
Slightly more than seven million residents of the United States trace their ancestry to Asian countries like China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and India or to Pacific Island nations like the Philippines. They now represent about 3 percent of the total American population.
The survey, taken in March 1991, showed that 4.1 million Asians, or about 60 percent of the total Asian-American population, lived in the West -- the vast majority of them in California.
 
Educational Success
 The report tracks earlier accounts of the relative educational successes of Asians 25 years of age and older, 82 percent of whom have completed high school (compared with 80 percent of whites), 39 percent of whom have completed four years of college (compared with 22 percent of whites) and 16 percent of whom have had at least one year of graduate study (as opposed to 9 percent of whites.)
But it also indicates that the overall educational success of Asians does not always translate into overall economic advantage.
For instance, according to the report, written by a Census Bureau demographer, Claudette E. Bennett, Asian high school graduates earned 79 percent of what their white counterparts made, $21,060 compared with $26,530, while the median salary of Asian male college graduates, $37,550, was about 90 percent of the median salary of white men, $41,660.
But earnings of Asian-American women equaled or slightly exceeded those of their white counterparts. Among college graduates, the median salary for Asian-American women was $29,150, compared with $29,110 for white women.
All the median income calculations are based on a sampling of adults 25 years old or older who were working full-time. No comparisons were made with other racial or ethnic groups.
 
Asian Blue-Collar Workers
 The differences between the incomes of Asian-American and white workers offer a window on the complex economic patterns among Asian-American wage earners. While great attention has been focused on the academic achievements of Asian-Americans, less notice has been given to Asian blue-collar workers.
"Asian and Pacific Islander males with a high school education were considerably less likely to be employed in precision production, craft and repair occupations (18 percent) than were white males (29 percent)," the report said.
"The lower percentage of Asian and Pacific Islander male high school graduates who worked in high-paying precision production, craft and repair occupations, as well as their lower median earnings in these occupational groups, ($22,770 compared to 27,600 for white males) contributed to the lower median earnings they received," it said.
In 1990, the poverty rate for Asian and Pacific Islander families, 11 percent, far outstripped that of white families, 8 percent.
But despite those elevated poverty rates, Asian households are still more likely than whites to have multiple wage earners. As a result, the overall median income of Asian families, $42,250, significantly exceeded that of white families, $36,920.
This was true even though the per capita income of the Asian and Pacific Islander population, $13,420, trailed that of the white population, $15,260.

HEADLINE: New York Fears Impact of U.N. Cuts

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
From his 37th-floor windows at the United Nations, Vladimir F. Petrovsky, the former Deputy Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, surveyed the Chrysler Building, Citicorp Center and other corporate monoliths as he described the deep financial problems at the world body, one of New York City's biggest employers.
"The United Nations has played a critical role in peacekeeping around the world," said Mr. Petrovsky. In February, he and Richard L. Thornburgh, the former United States Attorney General, were appointed by Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the Secretary General of the United Nations, as Under Secretaries General charged with streamlining the United Nations in ways that resemble the reorganization of a large American corporation. 
 "Now," Mr. Petrovsky said, "we must clean our own house."
The economic fallout could be harsh for New York City, where the United Nations has for decades been the equivalent of an international economic mother lode on the East Side of Manhattan. City records show that it supports a diplomatic corps and staff of over 50,000, and pays $1 billion a year for apartments, offices and other services.
 
Budget Talk in Many Tongues
 On Tuesday, the United Nations General Assembly opened its 47th annual session amid assurances by Mr. Boutros-Ghali to the staff that it was committed to remaining in its home on the East River. But throughout the week, its polyglot corridors were filled with anxious talk of spending cuts, reorganization and lost jobs.
And while the General Assembly is rooted in Manhattan, the vast international relief agencies of the United Nations are not. Two of the largest, the United Nations Children's Fund and the United Nations Development Program, are considering new headquarters sites.
The agencies' search for new quarters has drawn them into a bruising competition between New York City and the Government of Germany, which has already offered the Development Program free rent and reimbursement for moving expenses if it relocates to Bonn. A similar German offer is expected to the Children's Fund, also known as Unicef.
But the pressure on the United Nations to cut its spending remains intense. The chief problem is that member nations, particularly the United States, have fallen far behind in their dues to the world body.
 
'New York Is Fiercely Committed'
 Even accounting for the cost cutting already this year, the United Nations estimates that it will have a $81 million deficit for the year ending Dec. 31.
Last week, as thousands of diplomats, delegates and staff members converged on Manhattan, the United Nations emerged as a cause celebre among city, state and Federal officials trying to shore up New York City's battered economy.
"New York is fiercely committed to the United Nations," Barry F. Sullivan, Mayor David N. Dinkins's deputy for finance and economic development, said in a speech to international bankers on Monday, the day before the General Assembly's opening.
It came amid a frenzy of arm twisting, civic seduction and promises of financial aid. On Monday night, Mayor Dinkins held a reception for Secretary General Boutros-Ghali; it was the largest gathering of top city and United Nations officials in a decade. While city officials are trying to lure Unicef to development sites in Brooklyn and Queens, members of Congress from New York are pressing bills in Washington to allow the sale of tax-free municipal bonds, which would make it cheaper for the United Nations agencies to stay in the city. Such bond sales are now used by many government and nonprofit organizations to lower interest charges, but since the sweeping Federal tax revision in 1986, the United Nations has not qualified for such aid.
 
Getting What They Want
 More immediate relief may come from the United Nations Development Corporation, a city and state agency that owns the East Side offices of some United Nations departments, and the office buildings that house most of its agencies. Thomas Appleby, the agency's president, said last week it would consider lower rents on new United Nations leases.
"My sense is we'll get whatever we want, at least within reason," said one senior United Nations staff member, who, invoking the subtleties of international diplomacy, insisted that his name not be used.
The stakes for New York City are huge. Although the international prestige of the world body cannot be measured, its employment rolls can. City records show that it has 10,000 staff members in Manhattan, and that the assorted missions, consulates and relief agencies that serve it employ 45,000 more in the city.
Its muscle goes beyond routine employment figures. It is a magnet for international conferences, and many of its diplomats are dispatched to Manhattan with rich expense accounts for apartments, hotel rooms, restaurants, clothing, and limousines.
 
'They Don't Go to McDonald's'
 "This is an industry unto itself," J. Richard Foran, the United Nations Assistant Secretary General for General Services, said on Friday as he and other senior United Nations officials prepared for the arrival of President Bush, who is to address the General Assembly tomorrow. "When these people come to New York they go out to eat. And they don't go to McDonald's or Blimpie's."
But a new sense of austerity has begun to take hold and seems certain to spread. Diplomats and member governments have criticized the management of the United Nations for years, angrily accusing it of excessive spending and sometimes calling it the pork barrel of the world.
"The compelling rationale for the United Nations is not the bottom line, but to ignore sound management would be a tragic mistake," said Mr. Thornburgh. "This organization had become much too top-heavy."
Now, as the United Nations Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, he has taken on the role of chief cost-cutter, and asked McKinsey & Company, Price-Waterhouse, and other New York City corporate consultants for advice.
 
Attrition by Peacekeeping
 The first reductions were ordered by Mr. Boutros-Ghali almost immediately after his election as Secretary General in January. A total of 13 departments and 22 of the United Nations' 30 highest posts, including those of several assistant secretaries general, were eliminated.
Mr. Thornburgh said the consolidation was accomplished largely by leaving vacancies unfilled and reassigning officials and staff members, many of them to jobs more closely tied to the United Nations' growing peacekeeping duties in Bosnia-Herzegovina, Cambodia and elsewhere.
But Mr. Thornburgh has cut more deeply in recent months. More than 50 jobs in his own department are gone, and he said he had asked other department heads to impose similar reductions, resulting in several hundred fewer jobs.
So far, he said, nearly all of the staff cuts have been accomplished through attrition and by offering workers alternative posts in the organization. At an anxiously awaited "Staff Day" meeting on Sept. 11 -- an annual gathering of thousands of workers in the General Assembly hall -- Mr. Boutros-Ghali announced that no workers would be dismissed this year as a result of the revamping.
 
U.S. Owes the Most
 In a report last week, Mr. Thornburgh said the member nations were behind $1.6 billion in payments. The most recalcitrant nations are the United States, which owes $733.2 million, and Russia, which owes $420.4 million. Twelve others, including South Africa, Japan and France, each owe more than $10 million.
The huge unpaid bills have piled up largely because of world politics. The United States began falling far behind in the mid-1980's, when Congress assailed the United Nations repeatedly for its mandates related to Isreal and Lebanon, and criticized it for financial waste.
Now, with the United Nations' stature on the rise, the United States is in the second year of a five-year payment schedule, ordered by Congress, that it says will make good on all its outstanding bills to the world body by the end of 1995.
Still, Mr. Thornburgh said, there is no assurance other members will pay off their debts. That means no one can be sure that more cost reductions and job cuts can be avoided.
 
Relief Agencies Growing
 The United Nations Children's Fund, with 950 employees in Manhattan, and the United Nations Development Program, with 1,200, face different pressures. Because they are financed by voluntary donations, they have been spared the fiscal squeeze resulting from unpaid contributions to the United Nations itself.
But both relief agencies have grown in employment and worldwide commitments. They need more space than they now occupy in the United Nations Plaza, a complex of three buildings built by the United Nations Development Corporation between 1975 and 1985 across First Avenue from the General Assembly building.
International analysts said that Germany's offer of free rent and moving expenses to the Development Program was prompted by a desire to enhance its international stature and bolster the economy of Bonn, the former capital of West Germany. National unification and the planned movement of several German Government agencies to Berlin are expected to leave a glut of office buildings in Bonn.
 
Lure to Unicef Expected
 Soren Syssegaard, a spokesman for the Development Program, said the German offer had been extended until the end of 1996, and that directors of the relief agency would not decide whether to accept it at least until their annual meeting in June.
Mr. Appleby, whose job as president of the Development Corporation makes him the landlord to both the Development Program and the Childrens Fund, said last week that "we fully expect" the German Government to make a similar offer of free rent and travel expenses to Unicef.
But in a recent letter, he said, officials of the Children's Fund wrote that they would prefer to remain in their Manhattan offices if the city could find additional space nearby.
At City Hall, development officials are known to be courting the Children's Fund with an array of alternatives in Brooklyn and Queens, including new offices in a Hilton hotel complex that is planned in downtown Brooklyn, and in buildings that are planned in Hunters Point, Queens, directly across the East River from the General Assembly building. Unicef is also considering a proposed 20-story office tower in New Rochelle.

HEADLINE: When a Baby Is So Unaffordable It Is Abandoned

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 19

 BODY:
About 3 o'clock on a warm August morning in one of San Diego's rougher neighborhoods, a woman was awakened by the sound of a crying baby. She put on a robe, went downstairs and, on her front porch, found a plump baby boy wearing a diaper and a T-shirt. He had two front teeth and a robust pair of lungs.
Since the discovery of the 9-month-old boy -- the sixth child abandoned this year in San Diego County -- the police and social service agencies have stepped up a publicity campaign to find the family. 
 Two weeks ago officials held a televised news conference about the baby boy. Now, in stores and at other public areas where the forsaken children were found, the authorities have begun putting up posters displaying all the children's pictures. The families of two of them have been found; county officials have not yet decided whether to press charges against them.
 
Economic Explanations
 To explain the abandonments some look to the area's stuggling economy, one that has produced growing homelessness and unemployment.
"The general consensus is, with the economy the way it is right now, a lot of people just can't afford to raise a child," said Ron Hall, the police officer in charge of the 9-month-old boy's case.
There are no available statistics on the number of children left in hospitals, churches or on street corners in cities around the country. A recent informal survey by the Child Welfare League of America, a national organization of social service agencies, found a sharp increase this year in "boarder babies," newborns who are healthy enough to go home but who remain in hospitals because their parents have either abandoned them or are homeless and cannot care for them.
With California's unemployment rate near 10 percent, two points above the national average, the police here worry that they will be handling even more cases of abandoned children.
Like Tom Jones, the raucous character in Henry Fielding's novel, these children appear to have been abandoned out of love, by parents who believed the children would be better off without them. But unlike Tom, who is raised by a wealthy landowner, these children generally end up in foster homes.
 
Looking for a Mercedes
 "In the cases that I've worked on, economics was the primary reason," said Tim Drum, a police detective who located the families of two abandoned children. "It was out of a great deal of caring that these women did this."
One child was just a couple of hours old when Mr. Drum found her in the back of a pickup truck in the parking lot of a shopping center.
"When we found the mother, she told us she went to the shopping center and looked for an expensive car, like a BMW or a Mercedes, to put the baby in," Mr. Drum said. When she was unable to find an unlocked car, she put the baby in the bed of a new truck.
The woman and her husband had other children at home, were unemployed and, she told the police, could not afford another child. The baby girl was returned to the family. Officials have not decided whether to press charges against the woman.
In most cases of abandonment the parent or child's caretaker feels isolated and, with nowhere else to turn, seeks a caring and comfortable place to leave the child, the police and social-service providers say. Often domestic violence contributes to the parents despair.
Another of Mr. Drum's cases was that of a 2-year-old boy who was being reared by his grandmother when they were evicted from their apartment last spring. The grandmother took the child to a day-care center, asked if she could leave the boy there for a couple of hours and then left and did not return.
The grandmother later told the police that she had been beaten by her boyfriend and worried that the boyfriend would begin to abuse the child. The child's mother had moved to Las Vegas, Nev., to search for a job.
The grandmother, Mr. Drum said, did what she thought was best for the child. "Like any parent, she just wanted him to be in a safe environment," he said.

HEADLINE: White-Collar Recession: Shifting Perceptions and Politics

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: METUCHEN, N.J., Sept. 18

 BODY:
The Mazda is five years old now, but running fine, so Ed and Donna Huntress will wait another year or two to replace it. Mr. Huntress is remodeling the kitchen himself, instead of hiring a contractor. Vacation this year was a camping trip instead of the usual journey to the Virgin Islands, but Michael is 5 years old now, and likes camping better.
At the Huntresses' bungalow here, as in most homes across the vast archipelago of comfortable middle-income suburbs outside New York City, the recession has not taken much of a visible toll, but it is changing the way that many families live and the way they view their future. 
 Now in its fourth year nationally, the recession has given many people their first introduction to a sense of economic stagnation. But New Jersey's unemployment rate among white-collar workers like Mr. Huntress, at 2.2 percent, is lower than in both New York, 4.1 percent, and Connecticut, at 2.5 percent, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"There's the perception and then there is the reality," Mr. Huntress said. "The reality is not bad at all; we are doing fine. But the perception is that there is a problem, and it is making me a little bit uncomfortable and concerned about the long range."
These are not the problems of blue-collar workers, for whom factory closings and wrenching layoffs have pushed jobless rates well over 10 percent in most job categories in New Jersey. For them, the recession has come as a sharper blow. Mr. Huntress, who is 44 years old, writes advertising copy for a small group of machine-tool manufacturers.
He said he earns between $50,000 and $100,000 a year. After spending as much as a quarter of that for health insurance and his home-office expenses, he said what remains places him squarely in financial company with his neighbors, a lawyer and the president of a small company in New York. Mrs. Huntress, 43 years old, was a fashion buyer for stores like Sterns and Macy's before Michael was born. She quit work to stay home with him in 1987.
"We're more careful now," she said of their household budget. "I've seen our grocery spending go up steadily. I never used to clip coupons, but now I do. I joined Price Club and I did it to save money, not because I like shopping in a warehouse."
Her husband added: "We watch small expenses, like movies, that we never used to worry about. It's not that we're miserly, we're just being rational."
Watching the dimes and quarters is not what bothers the Huntresses. What troubles them is that they did not expect to have to be this careful at this point in their lives. The recession, they say, has put their lives on hold.
"I must say we are not where I thought we would be at this point in time," Mrs. Huntress explained. "I thought we would have moved to a larger house, for one thing. I really thought things would be easier for us at this point. I know if I were still working we really would have these things, but that was a sacrifice we are willing to make.'
 
Remodeling, Not Moving
 When he left his last employer 12 years ago to begin free-lance advertising work, Mr. Huntress had hoped that, by now, there might be two or three employees to help with the clerical and research work, but he has postponed such an expansion in favor of increasing his savings during the recession.
Both he and his wife want a house larger than their 1,200-square-foot, two-bedroom bungalow, perhaps one across the Pennsylvania border, where it is less crowded but still easy to travel to New York City. But instead of househunting they are remodeling their kitchen and planning to add another room next year.
And in a stronger economy, Mr. Huntress said, that Mazda would have been replaced by now. As they speak of dreams deferred, the Huntresses could be speaking for countless others who are not buying that new house or car, and so leaving the housing and automobile industries depressed, or not hiring to expand their businesses, as reflected in stubbornly high jobless rates. Even their doubts about the future are reflected in the Business Round Table index of consumer confidence, which stands at nearly half its 1985 level.
Mrs. Huntress thought for a moment and seized the note of optimism that had brought her and her husband this far, from their first meeting as classmates at Michigan State more than 20 years ago.
"We are planning to have all the things we wanted," she said. "It just isn't happening as quickly as we thought it would."
When will it happen?
"During the 80's," Mr. Huntress said, "I thought we were back in the kind of cycle we were in in the 60's, short-term recessions followed by recovery. That kind of cycle doesn't upset me. What upsets me are the signs that the underlying problems are permanent, that it's not just another cycle we're in. That we really are going to the dogs."
The first sign of permanent distress is the hardship that factory workers and laborers are having, he said.
 
'Look Pretty Expendable'
 "When the economy is percolating it means that a guy with no skills can get a job that supports a non-income-producing wife, a house, two cars and college for the kids," he said. "Those are the people that the rest of us in the service economy depend on. If the part of the economy that makes those jobs, and values our services, isn't cooking, we start to look pretty expendable. And we are."
This line of analysis brings up politics, and Mr. Huntress calls himself a "Reagan Democrat" who may return to his roots for this election. Since he first voted in 1972, his choices for President have been George McGovern, Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, Ronald Reagan and George Bush. This time, he is not so sure.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas says he is campaigning on behalf of "the forgotten middle class." And while the Huntresses were speaking, President Bush was making his third visit to the New Jersey suburbs, pledging that his policies will improve the economy.
"I'm a typical conservative suburbanite," Mr. Huntress said. "When things are going well, I want the Government to leave things alone. When the economy is bad, I get scared and want a more activist administration. So I think I'm going to hold my nose and vote for Clinton."
Mrs. Huntress, the daughter of rock-ribbed Illinois Republicans, voted for Mr. Bush last time, but is still undecided.
"I'd like to vote for Bush, but I'm really upset about the attacks on gays and the abortion issue and the whole viciousness of it," she said. "For some reason, they strike home for me more than the economy. Anyway, I don't know what Bush or Clinton can do about the economy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ed and Donna Huntress, with their son, Michael, at home in Metuchen, N.J. The Huntresses are one of many families living in comfortable middle-income suburbs who, while not visibly affected by the recession, are changing the way they live and how they view their future. (Najlah Feanny for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: It's a Whole New Campaign as Senator and Attorney General Go One on One;
D'Amato Virtually Severs Ties to Bush And Attacks Opponent as 'Incumbent'

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
His best friend is not just Jewish, but Ed Koch. He barely knows George Bush. He has wheeled all kinds of bargains for middle-class New Yorkers, but God forbid people should think of him as part of the entrenched Washington Establishment. And Al D'Amato is shocked, shocked, shocked by the "vicious, anti-Italian" campaign his Democratic opponent, Robert Abrams has led -- almost as shocked as he is by Bob Abrams's "fund-raising shakedown."
At least, that is the portrait Alfonse M. D'Amato is painting of himself as he seeks a third term in the United States Senate. In the first volley of television advertisements, the D'Amato campaign has taken the offensive, defining his opponent as "hopelessly liberal," with claims that Mr. Abrams's health plan and defense cuts would raise taxes and eliminate jobs. But the Senator has decided to redefine himself as well. 
 At a time when many voters consider incumbency a character flaw, in a state where the top of the Republican ticket is trailing in the polls, and against an Attorney General who is making ethics a central issue, Mr. D'Amato's 1992 strategy includes a make-over.
President Bush is expected to travel to New York tomorrow, but Mr. D'Amato said he had no plans to campaign at his side. Keiran Mahoney, his campaign manager, said that unless the White House changes plans, Mr. D'Amato will only see Mr. Bush at an evening fund-raiser in New York City that is closed to the press.
 
Distancing Himself
 Though the White House calculates that the New York Senator has voted 78 percent of the time with Mr. Bush, Mr. D'Amato has lately been stressing the occasions on which he has voted against the Republican President. Most of his ads, in fact, prominently feature a Democrat. And lest any viewers forget Mr. Koch's religious affiliation, Mr. Koch was filmed at an office desk, a menorah on the ledge behind him.
"Koch is New York, George Bush isn't," is how Anthony W. Marsh -- a media consultant whose firm, Marsh & Russo, created Mr. D'Amato's ads -- explained the heavy reliance on the former Mayor. "We don't want to become apologists for the Bush Administration."
But Mr. D'Amato has borrowed some of the President's campaign rhetoric, saying he will seek to portray his opponent as a "tax-and-spend" liberal, someone who, as Mr. D'Amato put it, "will cost New York hundreds and thousands of jobs."
 
Courting Jewish Vote
 And in stressing the endorsement of Mr. Koch, the campaign is hoping Mr. D'Amato, a longtime supporter of Israel, will be able to get votes from conservative and Orthodox Jews, despite the fact that Mr. Abrams, who is Jewish, expects to do very well among Jewish voters. He has attacked Mr. Abrams for not being supportive enough of the President's decision to send troops to the Persian Gulf. And he reminds voters that when it comes to Saddam Hussein, "I took on the Administration, I didn't wait until the war started or public opinion changed to call him the Butcher of Bagdad."
Mr. D'Amato opposes abortion and supports the death penalty, unlike a majority of New York voters. But as an Italian-American he is likely to do well with Italian-American voters, who are the largest single ethnic group in New York State. He has begun portraying himself as Geraldine A. Ferraro's defender, dismissing Mr. Abrams's questions about her possible ties to organized crime as "a brutal, vicious campaign of smear and innuendo" against Italian-Americans.
Mr. D'Amato, however, was the first candidate to suggest that Ms. Ferraro had dealings with criminals (his campaign issued a statement in August noting that Nicholas Sands "a.k.a. Dominick Santiago" a convicted labor racketeer, had raised money for the former Congresswoman's early campaigns).
 
Ethnic Loyalty a Factor
 Mr. D'Amato said that the main issue in the Senate race was the economy, but ethnic loyalty is also a factor. Forty-four percent of voters in the general election Nov. 3 are Catholic, 14 percent are Jewish. Besides Mr. Koch, a conservative Democrat, the Senator expects to rely heavily on Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and a former Congressman from Buffalo who scores well with Democratic voters. Mr. Kemp, once a quarterback with the Buffalo Bills, could help Mr. D'Amato appeal to blue-collar Democrats upstate.
Mr. D'Amato cannot afford to cede any portion of the voting population, said Lawrence Mandelker, a former official in the Koch administration. "A large part of the voting population is uncomfortable with Mr. D'Amato on ethics, and his position on 'choice,' " Mr. Mandelker said.
The Senator has not yet volunteered his anti-abortion stance in his TV ads, but he does address the issue of ethics. Mr. D'Amato, who was scolded by the Senate Ethics Committee for allowing his brother to use the Senator's office stationery for lobbying purposes, is trying to turn the tables on Mr. Abrams, railing in an interview about a 1989 commission that criticized the Attorney General and other state officials for taking campaign contributions from people who did business with the state.
 
Sees Himself as Fighter
 Hank Morris, a Democratic consultant, argues that Mr. D'Amato's complaints about his opponent's negative campaign attacks could strike some voters as, "he doth protest too much."
"Some of D'Amato's arguments ring completely untrue to people -- he has an image as a rough-and-tough negative campaigner," Mr. Morris added. (In his 1980, primary campaign against the ailing Jacob Javits, who was suffering from Lou Gehrig's disease, Mr. D'Amato ran ads that vividly depicted his opponent's illness.)
Mr. D'Amato bridles at the word incumbent, preferring to refer to himself as the fighter. At times, he even traded identities with Mr. Abrams, calling his challenger, "a classic political insider" and "an incumbent." Mr. D'Amato said, "I'm the one who takes on the causes of his constituency." Taking on a mock tone of grandiloquence, he called Mr. Abrams, "a business-as-usual incumbent who is into the pomp and circumstance of the office -- Senatorial, oh so Senatorial."
There is one perk of incumbency that Mr. D'Amato is unlikely to forgo: fund-raising. As of the end of August, his campaign had raised more than $8 million. It currently has $3.7 million. And their spending strategy is simple. Zenia Mucha, the deputy campaign manager and press secretary explained, "We plan to stay on the air statewide from now all the way through the election."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Salvation Is at Hand: Lindros Makes Debut

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The National Hockey League, which survived 75 seasons without him, presented its first Eric Lindros Show this afternoon in an exhibition match between the team he rejected and the team he accepted after forcing a trade.
Lindros scored one goal and set up Mark Recchi's game-winner in leading the Flyers to a 4-3 victory over the Quebec Nordiques before 17,226 fans at the Spectrum. 
 It was an impressive debut for a high-salaried teen-ager who is seen by many in the hockey business as the rising star who will lead the struggling league into a new era of American television exposure and international consciousness.
"I've never seen as many people at an exhibition game," Lindros said. "I hope they enjoyed themselves. I know I did."
 
Is This Trip Necessary?
 It was a twist of fate that Lindros began his career against Quebec, the team that originally drafted him. He refused to play for the Nordiques for reasons that included economics, culture and language. But it was calculation that will keep him home Sunday when the Flyers play a return match against the Nordiques in Quebec City at le Colisee.
Lindros is expected to get a rude greeting from the fans on his first trip there, so Flyer management decided to postpone that until the teams meet there in the regular season on Oct. 13.
The player left open the possibility that he would persuade team management to let him play in Quebec on Sunday night. "Yeah, I'd like to get up there," he said. "I do what I'm told. The bus leaves at 7:30. Maybe I'll be on it. Maybe I won't."
A spokesman for the Flyers repeated after the news conference that Lindros wouldn't play Sunday.
Lindros took a regular shift today, killed penalties and worked the power play. He got about 25 minutes of ice time in part because Kerry Fraser, the referee, called 32 penalties as the officials tested the interpretation of tougher new rules against high-sticking and other fouls.
He set up several scoring chances and drew gasps and cheers late in the first period for a rush that gave the customers hope for the future of a once-successful franchise that has sagged badly in recent seasons.
With the teams playing four aside, Lindros cradled the puck at his own blue line, fought off a holding attempt by Valery Kamensky and charged up ice. He bulled through three other Nordiques and zeroed in on the goalie, Jacques Cloutier. Lindros fired a hard, rising wrist shot that missed the corner of the net but cracked off the glass with a loud bang. The fans roared as a penalty was called on Kamensky.
In the second period, Lindros showed the checking advantages that come with his size -- 6 feet 5 inches and 235 pounds. A collision with Bill Lindsay left the latter on the seat of his pants. He also collided, accidentally, with Recchi.
"He just smiled at me," Recchi said, referring to Lindros. "He almost knocked me out."
At 18 minutes 17 seconds of the second period, Lindros scored his first goal of the N.H.L. exhibition season, with the Flyers holding a two-man edge. When Recchi's pass across the crease was tipped by a defenseman, Lindros glided in on the left side and swatted the loose puck past Stephane Fiset, Quebec's second goalie.
Lindros celebrated by slapping the hands of teammates on the bench and accidentally collided with a Nordique when he turned from the bench and skated back toward center ice. At 8:12 of the third period, with the Flyers on another two-man power play, Lindros passed across the crease to Recchi, who finished off the play.
Lindros, 19 years old, joined the league and the Flyers this fall after a year of controversy. Selected by the Nordiques first over all in the 1991 draft, he refused to report and played for the Canadian Olympic team in order to force a trade.
The Nordiques traded him last June at the draft in Montreal, but both the Flyers and the Rangers claimed they had a deal with Quebec. The Nordiques sided with the Rangers, but an arbitrator ruled in favor of Philadelphia.
Lindros is earning an estimated $3.5 million per season, the largest salary in professional hockey.
When someone asked if the Quebec players said negative things to him, Lindros smiled and replied that they didn't.
"They're there," he said, "and I'm not sure they're all that excited to be there. So, what are they going to do?"

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Every Day's Crunch Time For Handley

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 19

 BODY:
Many Giants fans are looking for a lynching, and the neck they want belongs to Ray Handley, the team's beleaguered coach.
They blame him for the Giants' 8-8 record last year, one season after a Super Bowl championship. They blame him for the Giants' 0-2 start this year, a record that could easily slip to 0-3 Monday night against the Bears in Chicago. They blame him for everything except low interest rates on savings accounts. They dislike him intensely. 
 They say Handley is over his head and messing up a pro football team that can win. In 1983, they were saying that Bill Parcells, the Giants' new head coach, was over his head and messing up a team that could win.
Parcells survived his 3-12-1 rookie season and led the Giants to two Super Bowl victories. When Parcells suddenly resigned in May 1991, the job was thrust on Handley, who had been ready to abandon coaching for law school.
The public is angry that Handley is not Parcells. The dissenters cry that Handley is an intellectual who does not understand motivation, that he cannot communicate, that he picked the wrong quarterback last year and ended up alienating both of his veteran quarterbacks, that he has confused his players, that he plays a boring offense, that he tried to mess up a sound offensive line, that he is making a stable defense complicated and angering the veterans who have to play it, that he is a cold, emotionless fish. And on and on.
In a frank interview last week, Handley said he had heard it all. He said he did not care what the public thought about his performance as long as he was satisfying the people who hired him.
"I don't regret taking the job," he said. "I enjoy the job. Winning always makes it more enjoyable. I regret I haven't been able to put together a winning record, not yet. The only pressure is self-inflicted. The people in the organization have been extremely supportive."
The people in the stands have not. When the Giants give up a touchdown or fail to score one or break down in any way, the chant arises: "Ray Must Go."
If chants are not enough, T-shirts are available for $8 with the same message: "Ray Must Go."
Ray is not going. This is the second year of his three-year contract, and General Manager George Young of the Giants, who hired him, is not about to fire him, at least not during the season.
"The coach is not the issue," Young said. "I've said that over and over. We've played two games. You think anybody can recognize positives when you lose? With Bill Parcells, we didn't go to the playoffs the two years after our first Super Bowl."
The Giants are not going to the Super Bowl this season, either, not with their inconsistency. They may struggle to be 8-8 again.
Handley said his image had been created unfairly by the news media.
"I don't know why the media perceives me the way it does," he said. "I don't think I've hit it off with any part of the media. Sure, I walked out of a press conference last year and I've been sharp with people a few times, but I haven't been uncooperative."
Sometimes, he has not been cooperative -- like the time he walked out of that news conference last year because he was angered by persistent questions whether Jeff Hostetler would get his quarterback job back from Phil Simms when healthy. Reporters there were upset because they considered the question valid.
Another incident happened nine days ago. Hostetler, recovered from another back injury, said Handley had just told him that Simms would continue to start. Hostetler was distraught because Handley had said publicly that Hostetler would regain the job when healthy.
Twenty minutes after Hoststler spoke, Handley met with the media at his daily news conference. Handley talked as if he had not decided who his quarterback would be.
 
Too Much Quarterback Talk
 Handley seems irritated at the constant questions about quarterback. He says quarterback is just another position on the team, although it is seldom that on any team, certainly not on these Giants.
The news media, for better or for worse, made a hero of Parcells. He was brassy and witty, a self-styled Jersey guy. He manipulated players, and some felt he demeaned them in his attempt to motivate them. But he also helped them win two Super Bowl rings.
The players played hard for Parcells because they knew there would be success. Some may not be playing that hard for Handley.
"I think Ray is a good coach," said linebacker Lawrence Taylor, who had a strong relationship with Parcells. "But like anyone else, just like Bill Parcells when he came in, he has to show us he knows what's going on. I think he has to take more control this year, which is good. I think he can be a winner. It's always up to the players. Are they doing what it takes to play for the man? A coach is only as good as his players."
The idea that a coach must prove himself to players seems novel. But Taylor said that having a new coach, and Handley is still new, is like having a substitute teacher in school. Everyone tries to find out how much he can get away with. That stage may have ended, but the Giants still seem uncertain at times. Some critics say they appear unmotivated.
Since childhood, football players have had coaches who try to motivate them loudly, frenetically and endlessly. Handley believes that professional football players should motivate themselves, that coaches should be teachers rather than motivators. Taylor agrees to a point.
"We are all professionals," he said. "We're grown men who get paid a lot to play the sport. Should there be motivation from the coaches at all? But I think it's up to the head coach to get everybody in the right frame of mind. It all boils down to trust. If you trust the guy, if he shows he knows what he's talking about, it's O.K."
Some players like Handley, some do not and most seem indifferent to whoever coaches them.
"We can play for Ray Handley," one veteran player said. "We have to make up our minds to play. It's his team."
Another veteran said: "A coach can't take the blame for dropped balls and fumbles and offsides and interceptions. It's our job to make plays and not mistakes."
A third player said Handley was making more mistakes than any coach should.
"He mishandled the quarterback controversy last year and got both guys upset," this player said. "He gives us a good game plan, but he doesn't kick guys in the rear when they need it. Some of these guys don't even know it's their responsibility to get ready for a game."
There is another side of the argument. Handley does not show emotion, but neither did Tom Landry, a winning coach with Dallas. Handley is changing a winning defense, but Parcells changed a winning offense after one Super Bowl and won another. Handley was perceived as the villain in last year's quarterback controversy, but two people on the team said Hostetler became the starter then only because Simms told Handley he did not think his injured foot had healed sufficiently. Simms denies he said that, and Handley will not talk about it.
Harry Carson, a former Giants inside linebacker and now a television personality, said the Giants' problems came not from Handley but from the players.
"It's not so much that the Giants are bad," he said, "but that their play is bad. Fans don't want to see lousy football. If you go out and play and get beat by a superior team, fans can see that and appreciate that. But if you don't make tackles, you don't catch balls that are catchable and you don't block for the quarterback, people don't accept that and they shouldn't. You're going to get booed.
"The coach shouldn't have to scream and shout. They're professional football players. They make a lot of money. That should be incentive to go out and play hard. When you're booed in your own house, shouldn't you play hard? I think Parcells got too much credit and Handley gets too much blame. It's the players' problem now, and I think they need Handley."

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
Mum's the Word but Tulips Are on the Mind

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
THIS is a reminder. If the bulbs to bloom next spring have not been ordered from catalogues, get busy. Domestic orders must be in as the mail-order houses will soon begin shipping.
Spring-blooming bulbs will be planted this fall, usually October, so that they will be ready to put on their displays when the weather settles. Bulbs are dormant when planted, but will soon start to develop roots. Depending on the soil temperature, these young roots will continue to grow but will stop developing when the soil chills. 
 By next spring the roots will resume their function and be ready to push up foliage, buds and eventually the flowers. Roots anchor the bulbs and absorb moisture. When foliage starts to appear next spring and there is a sudden cold snap or even a snowstorm, gardeners often become alarmed and fear that their bulbs will be killed. Not to worry. This is a natural phenomenon. The foliage and the flowers will be safe in such weather. In fact, many a crocus has been photographed in snow.
More important now is making the decisions of what bulbs to plant and where, and to mail the bulb orders promptly before it is too late. For the largest floral displays, the Big Three -- daffodils, tulips and hyacinths -- are counted on. The daffodils can stay in place for many, many years before they will need dividing. (Daffodil bulbs multiply underground and eventually become a thick mass.) For this reason, daffodils are often selected for naturalizing in woodsy locations. Also, squirrels seem to leave them alone. Tulips do not last for years. The old bulb dies each year and a new one forms above it. Eventually, in two years or so, the tulip display becomes disappointing. Gardeners usually have best results by planting new tulip bulbs every year. Hyacinths may last a bit longer, but they are usually replaced every few years, too.
When buying daffodil bulbs, some gardeners believe that bigger is better. A helpful clarification on daffodil "noses" appears in the catalogue of McClure and Zimmerman, bulb brokers in Friesland, Wis. "All daffodil bulbs have at least one 'nose' from which the stem, leaves and flowers emerge," the catalogue explains. "Some daffodils regularly produce bulbs with one, two, three or more noses. These bulbs are usually sized by weight of the bulb not the number of noses. A 'double-nose' bulb may not be the largest; the term only describes what the bulb looks like, not its size. Some daffodils, especially species and miniatures, practically never produce bulbs with multiple noses. For these bulbs, the term 'double nose' is inappropriate."
By ordering bulbs by mail it will be possible to obtain some of the rarer species and especially the little bulbs that may not be sold at the local garden centers. The species bulbs are the ones often used for small gardens, rock gardens and tuck-in spots where a touch of color is needed. Most of these smaller, beguiling flowers are under a foot tall.
But certain species have been under stress because they were being dug from the wild in their native lands. Many of them bloom naturally in Mediterranean countries where digging the bulbs for sale is part of the local economy. The species that have been of particular concern are cyclamen, snowdrops (galanthus) and the fall daffodil (sternbergia).
An international agreement between the Dutch bulb growers and bulb importers, many of them in the United States, requires that bulbs be labeled according to their sources, whether they were commercially propagated from seed, propagules, or collected from the wild. One of the watchdogs of this agreement has been the Natural Resources Defense Council. In an analysis of the 1991 permits for cyclamen, galanthus and sternbergia, the council reported that imports of bulbs of wild origin were down from last year.
Total imports of galanthus were 2.14 million in 1991, down from 3.78 million in 1990. Bulbs said to be galanthis elwesii or of Turkish origin fell from between 710,000 and 960,000 in 1990 to 387,000 in 1991. Sternbergia fell by 67 percent.
But all was not as rosy for cyclamen. The council found that imports of wild-dug cyclamen increased to nearly 128,000 from 70,000 and it noted that these figures returned the United States imports of this critically decimated wild plant to past levels of 100,000 to 150,000 a year. It is essential for gardeners to check their sources for any cyclamen to be sure they are buying cyclamens that have been propagated commercially. They are quite easy to grow from seed.
Most mail-order nurseries comply and many are now identifying the sources or origins of the bulbs they sell.
All bulbs, large or small, can help to turn spring into a glorious display: big bulbs for big displays, little bulbs for special places. These little bulbs were once the wildflowers of their native lands so they should be placed where they can be seen and appreciated.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Love Lombard Rates

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
While European politicians and financial gnomes panicked during last week's currency convulsions, the Swedes displayed uncharacteristic humor. They raised their interest rates 500 percent. "You shall not pass!" they shouted to the monetary barbarians at the gates of their precious krona.
This Swedish excess seemed the only sensible response to European behavior that made the U.S. appear, if only fleetingly, a well-governed country. Hegel opined that to be sane in a world of madmen is itself a form of insanity. Europeans are once again taking his advice to heart. 
 European leaders tossed out exotica like "Lombard rates," but what they were actually talking about last week was money. Or more precisely, the fact that no one has very much of it. Or more exactly still, that the Germans are the only Europeans who have any and are paying high interest rates to borrow what they do not have.
If you add what the Germans are borrowing to pay their debts to what Americans are soaking up to pay theirs, and tie that to the fact that Japan is spending more on itself and lending less, there is little money left for others.
But the problem is, as economists let you know, far, far more complex. It runs deep down to the inconvenient factoid that presidents and prime ministers borrow money to pay their bills because they refuse to raise taxes and reduce spending. If they did so, they would have every expectation of soon becoming former presidents and prime ministers. Such is the gratitude of free peoples everywhere.
Free peoples have a point, however, as other economists explain. For if leaders actually behaved responsibly and increased taxes and cut outlays -- but did it too quickly -- the effects would be devastating, even irresponsible. For instead of pumping money into their economies, they would be taking it out. The result would be a catastrophic loss of jobs. And as jobless rates grew, leaders would soon find themselves unemployed. (Unless they happened to be economists, in which case they would always be needed to explain Lombard rates -- central bank interest rates for overnight borrowing -- currency exchange rates, the float and why the Maastricht treaty is more a political document than an economic one.)
I note these ironies and paradoxes not to make light of economists, who must possess the analytical horsepower of nuclear physicists to generate such elegant ironies and paradoxes. I do so, rather, to rejoice in the simpler dilemmas of foreign policy and to contemplate the coming effects of economics on world politics.
I start from last week's central message: Westerners are running out of money; or to put it another way, mighty nations cannot afford to pay their bills.
This means that world leaders will think poor. They will be less disposed toward distractions like civil wars in Bosnia and the former Soviet Union. Ever more, the meek and weak shall be left to their fates. President Bush, it will be remembered, compared himself to Columbus. People laughed, then realized the common bond: both sailed around the world and finally discovered America. Increasingly, exploration and statesmanship will be seen as Old World extravagance.
Already-diminishing military establishments will shrink more quickly still. Soon enough, arms and warriors will be easier to eliminate than any other budget item. Thus, on those few occasions statesmen find the will to intervene, they will begin to lack the means.
Nations with arms to sell will sell them willy-nilly to any renegade with cash. Russia has little else to export. Britain, France and the U.S. will find weapons exports to be the only way to maintain defense industries. To nations with idling aircraft and missile factories, even Iranians will come to look like misunderstood spiritualists.
Germany and Japan, by virtue of their economic muscle, will gradually come to play greater military roles. But their emergence will occur even more slowly than expected -- unless ignited by dormant demons.
The most politically correct leaders will shrink before towering resistance to financing necessary causes like protecting rain forests and harboring refugees.
A world without money will be nasty and messy. But worry not, for with another quarter-point drop in the Lombard rate, it will all work out.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: More Issues Than Israel Concern Jewish Voters

 BODY:
I take exception to Abe Seldin, chairman of the Nassau County Board of Assessors, when he says, "Jews are more comfortable in the Republican Party these days" ["For L.I. Delegates, Touches of Glitter," Aug. 23]. Mr. Seldin cites a 2 percent rise in the number of delegates this year over the last convention and attributes the increase, albeit a skimpy one, to the Republican Party's Israel platform.
Unfortunately, Mr. Seldin's statement gives the false impression that politically Jewish-Americans care only about the Israel issue. Sure, most of us care deeply about the future of Israel. It's the issue that coalesces us. But it doesn't define us. Jews, like most other Americans, care about issues such as quality education, affordable and accessible health care and revitalizing our economy. Surveys show this to be true. 
 Perhaps that's why more than 400 Jewish-Americans were delegates at this year's Democratic convention, some four times the number that Mr. Seldin states were at the Republican convention.
 
MARK J. GROSSMAN
East Patchogue

HEADLINE: Why We're in a Slump and Not Creating Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Looking for Work: America Isn't Creating Enough Jobs, and No One Seems to Know Why," the lead article in the Sept. 6 Week in Review tells us. Anyone who reads your newspaper knows there are at least seven reasons why America is in a slump with not enough jobs to go around: 
 (1) The interest on the national debt, already 15 percent of the national budget, not counting the bonds issued to cover what has been borrowed from the Social Security trust fund, consumes money that could otherwise go toward Federal projects.
(2) Excessive regulation, mostly environmental, puts a lid on all new works. It is estimated to cost every household more than $4,000 a year. This curtails industrial projects.
(3) Inflation, now running at 3 percent a year, devalues money and erodes capital.
(4) The impossible goal of 100 percent purity and safety makes the cost of anything new too high to attract investment.
(5) Prisons eat up a large chunk of our tax money. Every year we jail six times as many people as Australia or Denmark, in proportion to population, and 10 times as many as Japan or the Netherlands -- even 50 percent more than South Africa. Jail sentences have increased 30 percent for sexual assault, but 1,600 percent for drug cases! Prisoners are parasites we cannot afford.
(6) Waste disposal is consuming an increasing share of everyone's income, as the price of advertising and convenience packaging rises.
(7) We learn less and less from the experience of our elders. Unlike the Japanese, who continue to employ and respect theirs, we say goodbye to ours, and conduct expensive meetings and seminars, mostly run by ambitious managers, seeking to recover what we have thrown away.
There are many more useless burdens that the ship of state is trying to tow, like dragging anchors, each of them a pet of the 500-odd freeloading members of the crew in the fo'c's'le, the 100 lookouts in the rigging or the 9 pilots in the deckhouse, preventing the captain from cutting them loose. What we need are drydocking and overhaul!
 
EUGENE H. HARLOW
Houston, Sept. 6, 1992

HEADLINE: Why We're in a Slump and Not Creating Jobs;
The Right Education

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Sept. 6 Week in Review report on the failure of the American economy to create jobs begins with the now popular concept of work-force training and education. Yes, our work force is at least as well educated as its Japanese and German counterparts. But, unlike those examples, American education mismatches its products to the demands of the market. It is not more college education, but higher quality education at all levels, plus diversified alternative education, that we need. 
 Our emphasis on college education has had two negative effects on our work-force training: first, it degrades any type of blue-collar work to a nonhonorific status, making any apprenticeship system by definition fit only for the intellectually less endowed, the dropouts, the inner-city unreachables. With this de-emphasis also comes an abandonment of craft codes, which acted as quality controls and a source of personal pride.
In their place came a deprecation of labor in general, as expressed in such bumper stickers as "A good day's fishing is better than a week's hard work" -- clearly not an expression of the old American work ethic.
The unbalanced supply made it more expensive to replace skills in the industrial sector. American corporations have always had a bias towards labor-saving policies because the United States has been a high-cost labor market. The successful post-World War II drive to liberate international trade, along with newly portable technology, made it possible to relocate production to low-cost markets and to lower consumer prices at home. At the same time the industrial base eroded, lessening in turn the need for skilled labor.
The problem will not be easily solved. However, foreign companies do profitably produce in this country with American labor. The failure to create jobs may therefore rest mostly with American management. It has attempted to remedy glaring educational deficiencies, but beyond that, as you report, has little interest in on-the-job training.
American corporations may need incentives to reverse this pattern. Surveys show that a large percentage of jobs in the future, as in the past, will not need a college education. We ought to de-emphasize college as a cure-all and upgrade alternative educational choices.
 
RICHARD HYSE
Oswego, N.Y., Sept. 6, 1992
 
The writer is an emeritus professor of economics at SUNY.

HEADLINE: Sept. 13-19: Hawaiian Crunch;
Rebuilding in the Wake Of Hurricane Iniki

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

 BODY:
After Hurricane Iniki flattened their crops, toppled utility poles and ripped the roofs off their houses, some residents of the island of Kauai were able to take showers and make phone calls last week as basic services were restored. But officials said it could take six months or longer to return electricity to all 55,000 inhabitants of the sparsely settled island.
The hurricane, with winds of 160 miles per hour or more, roared across Kauai Sept. 11, killing three people and causing at least $1 billion in damage, destroying sugar cane fields and fledgling macadamia nut orchards. 
 It seemed almost a cruel joke when economists told The Honolulu Advertiser last week that, with the storm coming late in the year and with 10,000 homes damaged, an anticipated boom in the construction industry was likely to give the island record growth figures for the year.

HEADLINE: Sept. 13-19: Improve or Die;
New York's Chancellor Lets Students Pick Any School

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
The national movement to let students choose their schools enlisted a mighty player last week: New York City, with its almost 1 million students.
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said that, starting next year, he will let parents send their children to any of the city's 32 school districts, not just to their neighborhood schools. While he is still working out details, his plan will mean that parents of elementary and junior high school youngsters can scour the city for good schools and arrange to get their children there. 
 The plan, however, has holes that make it something less than a bonanza for parents. There is no money for transportation; many parents would balk at sending children to an ideal school by subway. Also, many of the best schools already have long waiting lists.
Gary Orfield, a Harvard University education professor who advised St. Louis on a choice plan, worries that without free transportation and money spent on recruitment, "you're creating schools which serve the most selective social and economic group" while schools with poor and less educated parents deteriorate.
Still, some Manhattan districts have been experimenting, producing programs in the sciences, performing arts and other fields. The freedom -- and money -- to create distinctive schools is pivotal, says Joe Nathan, another adviser.
"If you have two blue shirts made out of the same material, what kind of choice is that?" he asked.
