HEADLINE: A Conflict Over Havens That Advise and Shelter

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
In the Bronx, in a fortresslike complex that lies at the end of the route that homeless families sometimes traverse through the city's complex and often frightening maze of shelters, there is a locked gate, an enforced curfew system and a prominently posted set of rules.
Residents must sign in and out. They must behave according to community standards. Miscreants are punished with expulsion, and their discharge, mostly, means a slide away from hope. 
 To those willing to follow the rules, the HELP Bronx apartments, run by the nonprofit Homeless Enterprise for the Less Privileged is a haven after weeks and sometimes years of battling the bureaucracy and the crowding of New York City's chronically overstretched shelter system. More important, it is a final stop in the system for most residents fortunate enough to win one of the places. The next move is usually to permanent housing and, presumably, a second start at life.
This week, the city's overcrowded shelter system was caught in a budget battle with the state. One of the main points of contention is a disagreement over whether the system known as Tier II, which provides transistional apartments for families at the relatively high cost of $3,000 a month per family, should continue to grow, or if money for that program should be shifted toward permanent relocations. The city had announced plans to open 1,000 more Tier II apartments.
 
Crowding and Controversy
 The controversy has sputtered for weeks. The city's shelter system is so overcrowded that more than a hundred families a night are sleeping on chairs and tables in city offices, waiting to be placed in shelters. On Sept. 10, state officials informed the city that it would have to improve conditions or face the loss of reimbursements. This week, State Social Services Commissioner Mary Jo Bane complained in a letter to the city that the shelter program could not continue to grow at the expense of permanent housing.
In the last six years, 65 new Tier II shelters, providing apartments for 4,000 families, like the HELP Bronx apartments, intended to provide a mix of social services and basic, relatively traditional, efficiency-apartment-style housing, have been built at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars as the city worked to help homeless families move into the mainstream. Structured around the theory that families need counseling, and basic advice before getting their own apartments, the complexes are a last stop on the return to independence.
Many advocates for the homeless agreed with that conclusion, noting that shelters siphon money that could otherwise go toward permanent housing. And they note, too, that shelters intended to provide temporary housing are sometimes used by residents for more than a year because they can not find permanent homes.
Advocates of the Tier II programs, however, say more such apartments are needed to prevent families from being shoved, unprepared, into difficult environments of crime, drugs and unemployment -- some of the very problems that drove many to the streets in the first place. "One of our biggest problems," said Frederick Shack, the executive director of the HELP Bronx program's two apartment complexes at 785 Corona Park North and 285 East 171st Street, "is that we need more and more room."
HELP Bronx is run with prisonlike discipline and round-the-clock security. The two compounds include day-care centers, counseling offices, playgrounds and other amenities, all kept nearly immaculate and with a few finishing touches like artwork and potted plants.
 
Fostering Hope
 Grace Lugo, who moved into the Corona Park HELP Bronx with her three children just a month ago, said on Friday that the Tier II shelter has given her hope. One of two families selected by Mr. Shack to describe the system's merits and organization, she said she had moved to the shelter after spending time at several temporary shelters in the city.
Ms. Lugo said she became homeless after a deteriorating relationship with her sister forced her to decide to move her family out of the woman's apartment. But her own journey into the system started earlier. A native of the Bronx, Ms. Lugo spent the last eight years in Puerto Rico, she said, and returned to the mainland the day before New Year's to escape her abusive husband.
Without a place to live, she moved in with her sister. But the overcrowding and the juggling of two families in a small space wore on everyone. "There is an expression in Spanish," she said. "You stink after awhile. So I felt I had to leave."
She had no money and nowhere to go. The next steps in her search for housing were "the worst experience of my life."
Thrust into the New York City shelter system, for three days Ms. Lugo scrambled just to find chairs in a shelter for her children to sleep on. Finally, the family was moved to a more accommodating shelter, but there, everything was open. "Everyone is right there," she said. "They put such a fear in you. I really got sick. I got high blood pressure."
The move to HELP Bronx, she said, has improved her health and her hopes for the future. She said she was receiving psychiatric help for the anxieties she suffered from the beatings at her husband's hands. She said she looked forward to finding an apartment "within three months" and looking for a job as well.
"I find it comfortable here," she said. "It's small. But it's safe. This is a blessing." Staff members at HELP Bronx were helping the family to look for government-subsidized housing, she said. And her daughter, Damaris Perez, a quiet 13-year-old who is an A student, is settling into a new school.
Diana Garcia moved to HELP Bronx with her two daughters and one son at the start of the summer. Her family became homeless after a fire in their building, at 1208 Southern Boulevard in the Bronx. Their first stop was a hotel near LaGuardia Airport in Queens, she said, a place she described as a haven for drugs where unemployed teen-agers lounged around all day long. "Not only were you homeless," she said, "you were degraded at the same time."
Like Ms. Lugo, Ms. Garcia said the HELP Bronx complex was her first step toward a more normal life. "When we came here," she said, "We were like, Oh, God! This is like an apartment complex. It's a little small, but the things you normally find in the Bronx like drugs and crime you don't find in here."
Soon, Ms. Garcia and her children will have to return to the harder world of life outside the shelter. She has found a government-subsidized apartment not far away and expects to move in several weeks. It will be a move into a world with plenty of problems. But it will also provide a place to once again call home.

An article last Sunday about a shelter for homeless families in the Bronx gave an incorrect address for one complex of the Help Bronx apartments. It is at 785 Crotona Park North.

HEADLINE: In the Land of Genghis Khan

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF is head of the Beijing
bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
OUT on the steppes, where the prairies stretch endlessly until they melt into mountain crags on the horizon, there's not much sign of the last few million years of human civilization. At most, one sees an occasional rutted dirt road or a shepherd's tent exhaling a plume of white smoke from a cooking fire made of cow chips.
 Mongolia, after all, has been in a funk for the last seven centuries. 
To be sure, Genghis Khan did pretty well for himself in the 1200's, establishing the largest continuous land empire the world has ever known. The Mongols controlled everything from Korea to Hungary, and they were poised to continue west when in 1242 their commander, Prince Batu, was abruptly summoned back to the Mongol capital for an important meeting. Otherwise, he would have swept through Western Europe facing little resistance, and today we might all be speaking Mongolian.
 Batu did return for the meeting, however, and Western Europe was saved. Then Genghis's grandson, Kublai Khan, moved the capital of the Mongol empire to Beijing, and ever since Mongolia has been a quiet kind of place.
 Leaders and ideologies come and go, but few tourists do, and the United States did not get around to establishing diplomatic relations until 1987. Last year only 282 American tourists visited the entire country.
 The lack of tourists, though, is simply another advantage of a nation that is rich in history, hospitality and unspoiled scenery. On the outskirts of the capital of Ulan Bator, at the Palace of the Bogd Gegeen, Mongolia's former god-king, there is no jostling as you wander alone through the gardens and admire the bright Buddhist sculptures and embroidery hanging on the walls.
 At Dashchoylin Monastery, in the center of Ulan Bator, the 120 monks look up from their prayers when foreigners walk in, and their chanting falters for a moment as they lose their concentration.
 In the countryside, drop in on any nomadic herdsman and he'll immediately invite you into his round white felt tent, or ger.
 Custom dictates that you sit on the left side, and that you accept a whiff of the snuff bottle that he may share. He's also likely to offer you a bowl of yogurt or ariq, fermented mare's milk. The friendliness leaves you with a warm feeling, even if the ariq tastes awful.
 Mongolia was the second country to become Communist, after the Soviet Union, when in 1921 it staged a small revolution that led to secession from China and the eradication of Buddhism.
 Mongolia was closely linked to the Soviet Union for the next 70 years, and it was difficult for Westerners to arrange visits. Then in 1990 a 27-year-old professor of Marxism named Zorig led a peaceful uprising that introduced democracy and capitalism. These days Mongolians are enormous fans of the United States, and tourism has never been easier.
 That is not to say that tourism is easy. Food is scarce and often atrocious, English-speakers are hard to find, hotels are poor, telecommunications difficult and visas difficult to obtain except for organized tours.
 When I visited the head of the national tourism agency, Zuulchin (or Juulchin), I found him besieged in his office by two women, an American and a Briton, who seemed ready to throttle him. They had been trying for days to arrange a trip out of the capital, a challenge that appeared insurmountable. He seemed grateful and relieved when I gave them the name of a translator who could arrange a private car for them.
 The starting point for almost all visitors to Mongolia is Ulan Bator, the capital, which is also spelled Ulaan Baatar and various other ways. There is no agreed-upon system for transliterating Mongolian names into English, and the proliferation of different spellings adds to the sense of cheerful chaos.
 About half of Ulan Bator is made up of the tired gray concrete buildings that are the legacy of Communism from East Berlin to Vladivostok.
 The streets are broad, suitable for military parades, and most people get around by foot or by bus. Public bus rides are a bargain, less than half a cent a ride, and they are a good way to explore the city.
 (All prices have been converted at an unofficial exchange rate of about 250 tugriks to the dollar. In theory, there is an official exchange rate of 40 tugriks to the dollar, but despite valiant efforts I was never able to convert dollars at that rate. The post office insists on paying the black market rate, and so does the Ulan Bator Hotel, even when traveler's checks are involved. There seems to be no penalty for black market exchanges, and in fact United States dollars are a second currency in Mongolia.)
 The focal point of the city is Suhbataar Square, a Mongolian version of Red Square in Moscow. It is a vast plaza with a central statue of Suhbataar, the architect of Mongolia's 1921 revolution. Herdsmen come from all over the country to have their photo taken on the square, as a souvenir of their visit to the big city. On the south end of the square is Government Palace, where the president has his offices on the third floor; on the east end is a pink building that houses the newly established Mongolian Stock Exchange. Shares are traded every Tuesday, and there is a public gallery for visitors to watch the show.
 Even in Ulan Bator, some 45 percent of the population lives in gers, often set up permanently with electricity as a year-round residence. You can stroll among the gers as you make your way to Ganden Monastery, the most famous in Mongolia.
 GANDEN is said to have once had 100,000 monks, but this is probably a wild exaggeration, since the entire population of Mongolia was only 600,000 at the time of the 1921 revolution. The country as a whole may have had about 80,000 to 100,000 monks then -- as many as one male in three -- and many thousands of them were at Ganden.
 Even when all the other monasteries in Mongolia were closed down by the rulers in the 1930's, Ganden survived and today it is very much a living monastery rather than a museum. There has been a resurgence of Buddhism since the collapse of communism in 1990, and today the number of monks at Ganden has risen from about 70 under Communism to more than 200.
 "A lot more boys want to be monks now, so the numbers will continue to rise," says Dorj, a weather-beaten caretaker in a green del, a cloak that is the national dress for both men and women. Ganden is being renovated, and the monks are making a special effort to recover a 90-foot high Buddhist statue, the Janraisig, that apparently was carted off to Russia half a century ago. If the Mongolians can find it, they want it back.
 In the courtyards of the monastery, old men and women in dels prostrate themselves before statues of the gods. They rise and pray, and then prostrate themselves once more. Younger people seem to have less enthusiasm for prostrations, but they join their parents in gleefully spinning the prayer wheels outside the temples. Visitors are welcome, and the best time to go to Ganden is in the mornings, because the odds are better that the monks will be in the middle of prayers.
 At Ganden and at other monasteries as well, it is quite a sight: the red-robed monks sit and chant in rows, facing each other, surrounded by spectacular painted Buddhist statues and embroidered hangings. There is none of the austerity of a Romanesque cathedral: rather, everything is colorful and every bit of space taken up with pillars and carvings and silk.
 More typical than Ganden, and nearly as impressive, is Dashchoylin Monastery, which reopened in 1990 and already has 120 monks. Daschoylin, which used to have 40 temples and 5,000 monks, is trying to rebuild itself and is very much a part of the community. Old people sit on benches outside, and children play on the grounds, which were used for a circus in the Communist days.
 Another spectacular monastery was converted by the Communists into the Religious Museum in Ulan Bator.
 Admission is about 5 cents, and the museum contains pleasant overgrown gardens and several temples with 17th-century bronze Buddhas, ornate ceilings and silk embroideries of humans being disemboweled and suffering other tortures.
 The former palace of the Bogd Gegeen, Mongolia's god king who died in 1924, is also a museum these days.
 But, in accordance with Buddhist beliefs, a man who is said to be a reincarnation of the Bogd Gegeen has been found in India and has been confirmed by the Dalai Lama. It is possible that he will return to Mongolia and reclaim his palace.
 The palace is a 30-minute walk from the center of Ulan Bator, so it is simplest to go by car. Taxis are extremely scarce, and expensive when found, so normally the procedure is simply to stand at the side of the road and flag down any car coming along.
 About half of all passenger cars moonlight as taxis, and if the car stops that means it's a gypsy cab. Fares are based on mileage and the apparent wealth of the passenger, but they are unlikely to exceed 25 cents.
 THE Bogd Gegeen's Palace contains dozens of stuffed animals -- including giraffes and polar bears -- that he collected, and also his ceremonial thrones and stagecoach. Best of all is his ger, which is about as lavish a tent as one could make, strewn with leopard skins and entered through a red and gold wooden door.
 The national museum, a dilapidated cement monolith in the center of the capital, charges 5 cents' admission. It has a fine collection of fossils (abysmally labeled) as well as several dinosoar skeletons from the Gobi desert.
 The museum also displays an extensive collection of stuffed wolves, panthers, bears and other animals; it is a better place to get a sense of Mongolian wildlife than the zoo, which has only a few animals -- and those are officially acknowledged to be suffering from malnutrition because of the country's financial crisis.
 From Ulan Bator there are three important destinations in the countryside. Karakorum, the ancient capital, is the most important historically and culturally and also the easiest to reach. It is less than a day's journey by hired car.
The Gobi Desert, reachable by plane, offers camel riding with the nomads and rich fossil hunting; only now are Western experts able to explore it systematically for dinosoar remains.
 The Altai mountains in the far west offer perhaps the most majestic scenery and lure occasional American hunters who pay up to $25,000 for the chance to bag a trophy argali mountain ram or even a rare (and supposedly protected) snow leopard. It is possible to drive up into the Altai mountains from the city of Hovd, which in theory has air connections to Ulan Bator.
 Several organized tours include visits to these destinations, and it may also be possible to arrange trips independently if you have a flexible schedule and considerable reservoirs of patience. One problem is that domestic air links in Mongolia are very unreliable, because of the economic crisis and fuel shortage.
 Even if flights are scheduled, there is no guarantee they will take off.
 And while buying an air ticket outside of Ulan Bator is relatively easy and cheap, beware: returning to the capital may not be so easy. You cannot book the return flight until you have landed at your destination, and you may find that all flights back are booked for weeks.
THE GLORY THAT WAS KARAKORUM
IN the grasslands of central Mongolia, miles and miles from nowhere, a stone turtle weighing several tons quietly contemplates the horses and occasional monks who wander the prairies. The turtle was erected in the 13th century to protect the site, which at that time was arguably the world's most important city.
 This is Karakorum, once the capital of the Mongol Empire, now returned to grassland. Genghis Khan apparently founded Karakorum as a military camp, but it was his son and heir, Ogedei, who presided over the construction and built the city walls in the year 1235.
 The pride of the city was the Palace of Universal Peace, surrounded by 64 columns and looking down on a fountain designed as a tree of silver by a master craftsman from Paris.
 These days not much remains of the old Mongol capital, which was destroyed in wars after the Mongols moved their headquarters to Beijing in the late 13th century. Then, after Buddhism arrived in Mongolia in the 16th century, some pious monks used the rubble as a quarry to build the nearby Erdenezuu Monastery beginning in 1586.
 The monastery survives, magnificently, and today is more of a reason to visit Karakorum than the stone turtle and faint ruins of the old Mongol capital. Surrounded by a brick wall with 108 stupas -- a figure that is reflected in the 108 worry beads that the monks carry -- the monastery complex stretches a quarter-mile in each direction. Some 1,000 monks lived and worshiped there until the Communists tried to eradicate religion in the late 1930's.
 Most of the monks were slaughtered in 1938, and virtually all of the temples in the complex were knocked down. Fortunately, one was spared and survives as a museum. Admission is 8 cents; it is open on Monday from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M., closed on Tuesday, and open Wednesday through Sunday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.
 Davaadorj, the director of the museum, is a historian who seems delighted to answer questions. He is the only one who offers reliable information, but you will probably need an interpreter, available from the tourist agency, as he speaks no English. Each year about 400 to 500 foreigners visit Karakorum, but until recently the great majority were Russians. The monks detest Mr. Davaadorj, because he wants to keep the temple as a museum. He, in turn, rails at the monks for moving in on the Erdenezuu Monastery and reclaiming parts of it without paying attention to their cultural and historical importance.
 "The monks are sitting on this place and destroying it," Mr. Davaadorj fulminated. "They should build their own monastery. On the third floor of the temple that they've taken over, priceless treasures are being destroyed by their oil lamps."
 The museum, built at the end of the 16th century, was put up without any nails -- and that apparently saved it, because the troops who tried to destroy it in 1938 couldn't figure out how to dismantle it and finally gave up. Set in a pleasant if overgrown garden, the museum is divided into three small buildings.
 In the building on the left is an eight-foot tall seated Buddha in gold, dominating the room. The Buddha is guarded by dragons, carved as if they were clambering the columns at the entrance.
 The risks of defying the gods are graphically illustrated in the entrance to the central temple, where a wooden guard, also eight feet tall, carries spears and swords and wears a helmet of skulls. He resembles something out of a Mongolian Stephen King novel, and the flayed carcass of a human sinner lies beneath his feet.
 A short walk from the museum is another small temple crammed with ancient religious scrolls, silks -- and, more gruesome, a bugle made of the leg bone of an 18-year-old woman. Mr. Davaadorj explained that it was good luck to appropriate the bones of a young woman. He hurriedly added that the luck held only if the woman died naturally, during childbirth.
 On the other side of the Erdenezuu Monastery is a large Tibetan-style monastery, the one that the monks have taken over without permission. Rebuilt in the 1950's, the monastery reflects the close links between Mongolian and Tibetan Buddhism: the Dalai Lama is the most revered figure for Mongols as well as Tibetans.
 The monks pray in the monastery but do not live there -- at least until the dispute over ownership is resolved -- so the best time to find them is the morning. They seem delighted to chat with visitors, if you have an interpreter, and range in age from about 12 to the late 80's; the older ones were monks here in the 1930's and survived the purges, returning to Erdenezuu in the last year or two.
 The monastery's interior is a festival of color, particularly the red of the monastic robes, but the monks' spirituality does not preclude entrepreneurship: They charge $5 a minute to take photographs inside, but this is relaxed Mongolian time and the single minute that I purchased covered five minutes on my watch.
 There is now a beautiful place to stay nearby, beside a river just a 15-minute drive from the monastery and the small modern town of Karakorum. The Orkhon Hotel is owned by the Bureau of Prisons and used to be a country retreat for the nation's top prison officials, but since 1990 it has accepted tourists as well. A big country manor with comfortable furniture and huge balconies, it looks out over the grasslands and the gers of herdsmen.
 A room is $25 per night per person, and on most nights the place is empty. But about twice a month it fills up with prison officials, so you might get a Mongolian to struggle with the telephones and try to make a reservation. The phone number is 131. The best thing about the hotel is that it has food available -- even imported soft drinks and French wine. The food is typically Mongolian, which is to say fatty and unappetizing to Western palates, but the meat comes from a nearby prison farm and therefore a steady supply is guaranteed. There is no choice on the meals, which run about $5 a person.
HEADING OFF FOR ULAN BATOR Getting There
 Visas are supposed to be obtained before leaving and are avilable from the Mongolian Embassy in Washington (2833 M Street N.W., Washington D.C. 20007; [202] 333 7117). In fact, airlines do not always check for a visa before allowing you to board a plane to Ulan Bator, and once you have landed you are unlikely to be expelled for lack of a visa.
 Tourists are supposed to make arrangements with Juulchin, the tourism corporation (addresses for all companies mentioned here are simply: Ulan Bator, Mongolia). The managing director, who has only one name, is Delgersuren, and his telephone number is 20163 (the country code for Mongolia is 976, the city code for Ulan Bator is 1). Juulchin charges a minimum of about $80 a day and is often inefficient, so it may be wise to try to get a visa without going through Juulchin.
 The only air connections are with cities in China and Russia, and it's important to book a round-trip ticket to avoid being stuck in Mongolia. If flights are full between Beijing and Ulan Bator, as they often are, try going through Hohhot, the capital of Chinese Inner Mongolia. The trans-Siberian railroad from Moscow to Beijing passes through Mongolia, but it is now mostly booked up for months.
Where to Stay
 The hotels are all likely to be clean, but not particularly comfortable or charming.
 The best place is Ulan Bator Hotel, a concrete box in the center of town; telex 79315. If you send enough telexes they may confirm a reservation. A single without bath is $32 a night; with bath $60; double with bath is $80. All with breakfast. Don't phone unless you speak Mongolian.
 The other place to stay is the Bayangol Hotel, not quite so central but a bit friendlier than the Ulan Bator. The phone number (no telex) is 28632 and there is a chance of getting an English-speaker. Room rates are about $2 cheaper per room than the Ulan. Some tiny private hotels have now opened for about $15 a night; ask at the train station.
What to Eat
 Because of the food shortage, almost the only place to eat is in the hotels, and even there the meals tend to be bad with no variety. It is common for hotels to offer only one dish (such as lamb schnitzel and rice) for weeks at a time. The food is loaded with fatty meat, mostly pork and lamb. There is no Mongolian word in popular usage for cholesterol, and a Mongolian friend answered my query about what happens to visiting vegetarians with a laconic, "They starve to death."
 You are unlikely to see a fruit the whole time you are in Mongolia. Wine, beer and some soft drinks are available in Ulan Bator, and the local vodka is ubiquitous. Health problems are not as much of a concern to travelers as in many developing countries, but it is still best to drink only boiled water or bottled drinks and to be careful about what you eat. (One exception: when visiting a ger, you must out of politeness drink fermented mare's milk from an old bowl that may look as if it has not been thoroughly cleaned since the days of the Mongol empire.)
 The hotel restaurants charge in tugrik, with a meal about 30 cents each; the same meal, served more quickly and still warm when it reaches you, is $4 a person in the hard-currency restaurant of the Ulan Bator Hotel. You are unlikely to see fruit in Mongolia.
What to Take
 Take absolutely everything you might need: sunscreen and chapstick (because of the fierce sun and high altitudes), any medications, a canteen, toiletries, film and food, if you like variety. Summer can be chilly in the evenings, but winter isn't nearly as bad as people expect (not counting the times when the electricity goes off, as it regularly does in winter).
 Credit cards are virtually useless, but traveler's checks can be exchanged for tugrik -- and, at hotels, even converted into American cash, which is much more useful. Dollars come in very handy in Mongolia, but no one has change, so take a bundle of 100 one-dollar bills as well as larger bills. American coins are also useful, because unless you pay exact prices you get your change in bubble gum or postcards. At the Ulan Bator Hotel, for example, a can of soda pop is costs $1.10; unless you have a dollar bill and a dime, you must surrender at least $2.
Getting a Guide
 If you are not part of a tour, I strongly recommend hiring a guide, largely because of the language difficulties. The Bureau of Translators, 28089 (a Spanish-speaker answers the phone and can summon an English speaker), can arrange an interpreter-guide for $25 a day plus any expenses. The interpreter, in turn, can probably arrange for a car to go on a trip outside Ulan Bator. Hiring a car and driver for a two-day round-trip excursion to Karakorum would cost about $50 if done this way; officially, through the tourism agency, it would cost about $400 in a Japanese vehicle. The drive to Karakorum takes five hours in a good car, and up to twice as long in the wrecks that are still common on the roads in Mongolia. Try to get a driver who knows the route and has some sense of how he is going to refill the gas tank for the return journey. Most gas stations in Mongolia say they are out of gas, although bribes can accomplish wonders.
ARRANGING TO MAKE A VISIT
 The following can help with either individual or group travel arrangements:
 Academic Travel Abroad, 3210 Grace Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20007; (202) 333-3355. Organizes one or two groups a year. This year a three-week trip to Mongolia and the Siberian Far East, including three days on the Trans-Siberian Express, cost $6,480. A trip for next year is scheduled from Aug. 29 to Sept. 19; no price has been determined.
 Australia Mongolia Society, Box 1091, Collingwood, Victoria 3066, Australia (61-3) 578-2533, takes bookings from all over the world and offers an excellent itinerary.
 Gabriel Lafitte, president of the society, knows Mongolia well and often leads the tours.
 Chinasmith, 324 West 42d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; (212) 239-2410 or (800) 872-4462. Individual and custom arrangements; has been organizing trips to Mongolia for about seven years.
 General Tours, 245 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016; (212) 685-1800 or (800) 221-2216. "The Exotica" visits Russia, Kazakhstan, Siberia and Mongolia (six days, with visits to Ulan Bator, Karakorum and the Gobi). This year the 22-day tour cost from $4,599 to $4,799, depending on the time of year. A similar tour is planned for next year.
 Inner Asia Expeditions, 2627 Lombard Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94123; (415) 922-0448 or (800) 777-8183. The company, which caters to individuals and groups, organizes about five trips a year. One of this year's main offerings, "Courts of the Khans," started in Beijing, then went to Ulan Bator, Khujirt and Karakorum, to yurt camps in the south Gobi, then to Russia and back to Beijing. The 20-day tour cost $4,250.
 Japan and Orient Tours, 3131 Camino del Rio North, San Diego, Calif. 92108; (619) 282 3131. Has been packaging tours to Mongolia for individuals for three years.
 Klineburger Worldwide Travel, 3627 First Avenue South, Seattle, Wash. 98134; (206) 343-9699. Sending groups and individuals to Mongolia since the late 1960's, the organization has dozens of programs a year. A two-week tour, with a week in China, costs from $3,900 with air fare from the West Coast. A 14-day hunting trip for elk is $5,400.
 Russian Travel Bureau, 225 East 44th Street, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 986-1500 or (800) 847-1800 outside New York State. This year the company sent out five groups on its 19-day Trans-Siberian Railroad Plus Mongolia Adventure ($3,900), including three to four nights in Mongolia. No dates or prices have been set for next year.

PUB-DATE: September 20, 1992

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 2; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1859 words

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Susan Levy;
Why a Woman Became a Contractor

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
FOR a woman who grew up in in Baldwin Harbor with five brothers who played baseball and football instead of with dolls and at the age of 18 joined the Army, a career in a traditionally male-dominated industry was logical.
When the woman, Susan Levy, started her subcontracting business 12 years ago, she was one of a few women in the construction industry. Her saw-cutting company, Femi-9, opened with a small capital investment and one employee in an office in Lindenhurst. It has grown into a business specializing in saw cutting, milling and grooving, processes that are used to repave or resurface roads and bridges, with more than $1 million worth of equipment. Ms. Levy now employs seven full-time operating engineers, including her husband, as well as seasonal workers from March through November. 
 After a difficult 1991, Ms. Levy has won bids for work on the Tappan Zee Bridge and at several sites throughout Nassau County.
She is also the treasurer of the National Association for Women in Construction and was one founder of its Long Island chapter in 1983. She is the lone woman to be elected to the board of the Nassau-Suffolk Contractors Association.
Last week at the convention of the National Association for Women in Construction in Orlando, Fla., Bridgestone Tires honored Ms. Levy with its first Race to the Top award, a program to recognize businesswomen's achievements.
Q. How did you become interested in the construction industry?
A. After graduating from high school in 1967, I decided to join the Army. The truth was I wanted to get away from home and was unaware of any financial aid that would have helped me go to college. At first I wanted to join the Navy. But they told me I had to know how to swim, and I didn't. So I decided on the Army.
After I came home in 1969 I worked at a few different jobs and finally took a job with an equipment-leasing company. It was there I first learned about construction equipment. I began to notice that often people who would call to request certain types of rental equipment would also ask if we did that kind of work. I saw that there was especially a need for people to do saw cutting, cutting out an area on a road or bridge in order to replace it with a patch or filler before resurfacing.
I started calling manufacturers of saws, toured a diamond-blade manufacturing plant in Texas, did a lot of reading and asked a lot of questions. I had contacts from working at the leasing company.
So when I found a qualified person who could run a concrete saw I decided it was the right time to start my own company. I made up business cards and sent them to everyone I could think of with a note asking for an opportunity to bid on their next job.
Q. What is the significance of your company's name?
A. I wanted a name that would let people know there was a female at the helm. First I thought of the name Ms. Construction, but that name was taken. Then my attorney suggested the name Feminine, and I liked the play on words, spelling it with a hyphen, Femi-9. It has been the best conversation starter that I could have ever dreamed of.
Q. Have you faced any barriers to success as a women in the construction industry?
A. The biggest barrier to success in the construction field was not being taken seriously. The stereotypical attitude of my male counterparts that women belonged in the home or in "girl" jobs like teaching and nursing -- anywhere but in the construction industry -- required a great deal of patience on my part. Many people assumed I was a front for someone else. The realization that their attitudes were many years in the making and would not be changed overnight, gave me the patience and strength to persevere. I knew I needed to get a foot in the door in order to prove my capabilities, and that meant I had to develop a business strategy and be patient, if I wanted to succeed.
Sometimes my selling point was having the lowest prices, but my performance followed to develop my reputation in the field.
Q. Have you experienced or witnessed any incident involving sexual harassment on the job?
A. I personally have never experienced it, but I do know that it exists. I've seen other women subjected to inappropriate comments and sensitive situations. I think the way to put an end to some of it is not to make a big deal of it. Of course if someone is blatantly sexually harassed, you can't ignore it. There's a time and place to put a stop to it. But there are some lines that should be drawn. When you're working on a job site and you're one female out of maybe 50 men, common slang is to be expected and is better to be ignored unless personally directed.
I've seen two instances that were almost identical but were handled very differently. One women was climbing up onto a piece of equipment, and the man behind her patted her on the backside. She turned around and gave him a look, and he said innocently, "I'm just helping." To which she answered, "Thanks a lot," and proceeded on. The other woman who was pushed from behind turned around and said: "I'm going to have you brought up on charges. You can't touch me like that." The situation escalated into a major incident, and in this case the man probably didn't mean anything. The woman's reaction was most likely precipitated by other unpleasant experiences. I think that the appropriate response in a sensitive situation really depends on the people involved and the manner in which it occurs.
Q. How did a woman who didn't know what "milling" was, become a specialist in the field?
A. Most of my initial knowledge came from equipment manufacturers. When I first thought about expanding my company to including milling and not being a mechanic, I really had no idea what milling actually was. Milling and grooving are extensions of saw cutting, just done with different kinds of machines.
There are no books that can teach you how to become a milling contractor. I've learned most of the details as I went along, making a lot of mistakes, as everybody does. When I started out I was so anxious to get a job that sometimes I forgot to include a price in my bid that should have been incorporated and I ended up barely making ends meet instead of making a profit. Most of my learning has been by trial and error.
Q. What does it take to be a successful entrepreneur?
A. The most important thing is to have a belief in yourself that you can do it. But if that was all it took you'd see a lot more entrepreneurs and fewer failures. It also takes a game plan. You need to do your homework, to build a network of supports for contacts, to have sources you can go to for all your needs. You must do a lot of research and know your product or service, and I mean know it well. And in today's economy it's also important that an entrepreneur be able to deal with a lot of stress!
Q. How has the recession affected the construction industry, and Femi-9?
A. In the Northeast we've been especially hard hit by the recession; 1991 was the first year since I went into business that I didn't show any growth. The work just wasn't there. I was able to keep my full-time employees but had to cut back on seasonal workers. This year I've been trying to operate with fewer people, without compromising on the work, in order to try to get a little ahead of the game.
Q. What is the outlook for the construction industry on Long Island and in the New York metropolitan region?
A. Despite current economic trends, the construction industry is predicted to grow at a rate of 200,000 jobs annually over the next decade. Other parts of the country haven't experienced a decline like we have in the Northeast. But economists say that it will pick up. I've seen it already over the last few months in the New York area, so I believe that the prognosis is hopeful.
Some experts say that construction is the backbone of the economy, because everything relates to it and construction touches everything in some way. We're all looking forward to better times.
Q. How will the role of women in the industry change?
A. According to the United States Census Bureau 42 percent of the new jobs in construction will be held by women. Women entrepreneurs are behind many of the new businesses responsible for this growth. With women entering the construction field at all levels, it is women who will play a major role in the shape and scope of this industry, gaining more power with each increase of women's participation. The Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 paved the way for change with the establishment of the National Women's Business Council, which submits annual policy recommendations to the White House and Congress for supporting women-owned businesses, including construction businesses.
Q. What does the Race to the Top award mean to you?
A. I'm extremely proud of this national award given by a major corporation that sees the need to recognize the achievements of women. That in itself is commendable. Women have had a tough time in business fields, and there's been a lot of gender discrimination. We have accomplished so much in recent years, and I'd like to think of myself as representing all of the women achievers in construction.
Q. You have also been active in charitable causes. What motivated you to become so involved in those efforts?
A. I think everybody has to give something back. Since I don't have a lot of spare time, this is one way I can do something to give of myself. I've done a great deal of fund raising for the American Cancer Society, the Red Cross and the American Heart Association. As an Army veteran, my time went to the Red Cross as an active volunteer during the Desert Storm conflict, doing whatever I could.
Often it is the smaller organizations that require more active participation, because they are less well known. I've found that to be the case with my latest priority, the Brighter Tomorrows Shelter in Suffolk County, for battered and abused women and children. As an adult survivor of an abusive childhood environment, it has meant a lot to me that there is a safe place where women and children can go. Years ago women didn't know of these alternatives.
I've spent time making repairs on the shelter home and property, collecting toys and clothes, raising money from dinner-dances and auctions. Last year I made arrangements for Santa Claus to visit the shelter at Christmas to distribute gifts to the women and children.
Q. What are your plans and goals for the future?
A. I would like to expand my firm's operations to include airport-runway grooving, which would require a major purchase of additional specialty equipment. I'd also like to develop more cost-effective and innovative methods to improve my grooving and milling operations.
My long-term goal is to expand the scope of our market to include many or all of the Eastern Seaboard states. My personal goal is to become the president of the National Association for Women in Construction within the next five years. As more women enter the construction industry, the need for a support group is growing.

HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
Neither Plain Nor Simple

BYLINE: By A. G. Mojtabai; A. G. Mojtabai is writer in residence at the University of Tulsa and the author of several books, including "Blessed Assurance: At Home With the Bomb in Amarillo, Texas" and the novel "Ordinary Time."

 BODY:

AFTER THE FIRE
The Destruction of the Lancaster County Amish.
By Randy-Michael Testa.
Illustrated by Susie Riehl.
187 pp. Hanover, N.H.:
University Press of New England. $19.95. 
 CONSIDER this: A visitor to Lancaster County, Pennsylvania, complains to the state police about an Amish farmer who refuses to halt his plowing to pose for a photograph standing next to her husband. The woman is unable to conceive of the farmer in his quaint costume, plying his antiquated farm implements, as anything but part of some sort of historical reconstruction rigged up for the benefit of tourists like herself. Her indignation, so rich with cultural presumption, would be funny -- if the joke weren't on us.
This episode is but one of many telling interactions between Amish and "English" (the Amish name for non-Amish Americans) recounted in Randy-Michael Testa's provocative first book, "After the Fire." The author is a teacher, writer and editor in Cambridge, Mass. What started out as field notes for his Harvard University doctoral dissertation (concerning education in a moral community) has emerged as quite another -- quite its own -- thing. His story of a summer spent living and helping out on the farm of an Old Order Amish family in 1988 has provided the occasion for a concomitant critique of mainstream American society.
The book is a testimonial, the narrative of a young man's journey to a place only 40 miles from his parental home, "across a galaxy of custom and sensibility where nothing I know is apt or fitting," there to learn, and unlearn, many things. It is also a call to reflection and action, for it is Mr. Testa's contention that the Amish in Lancaster County "are being squeezed out one family at a time by a changing infrastructure mobilizing regulation, ordinance, money and callousness disguised as concern for the economy." The threat is not only external. "Some Amish," the author says, "have chosen to squeeze themselves out of their society."
Today, managed and unmanaged economic growth, in the form of strip housing, shopping centers, industrial parks and factory outlets, constitutes a growing blight on what the Amish have helped make one of the leading dairy farming counties in the nation and one of the prime garden spots of the world. Of particular, currently pressing interest is a proposal to turn 80 acres of Amish homeland into a 100-home development called the Meadows in an area the Amish have farmed for more than two centuries. It is worth noting that land developers are not solely responsible for the Meadows project; the instigator, and owner of the land, is himself Mennonite, formerly Amish.
The Amish way of life, as Mr. Testa emphasizes, is not a historical curiosity but a vibrant, if endangered, present reality. Living without electricity, traveling in horse-drawn buggies at 12 miles an hour, the Old Order Amish are, and mean to be, confounding witnesses to a life of simplicity and deliberate limitation. Theirs is not a "life style" to be bought into, and shed, at whim. It is a faith commitment that integrates every aspect of life. In the author's words: "The way they eat is the way they farm is the way they think is the way they behave with their neighbors. . . . Faith is the glue that joins these things, the blessed tie that binds."
The story of Mr. Testa's journey to the Amish opens with a backward glance at his experience teaching third grade at a private school in Denver. The incoherence of much contemporary secular education is sharply recalled: "I had taught over 120 children how to multiply up to nine, to read paperback accounts of flying saucers and the Loch Ness monster, and to sing 'O Tannenbaum' " for the Christmas pageant. (Meanwhile, the family lives of his students were disintegrating with downturns in the oil economy.) Subsequent experience as a teaching assistant for a course in moral reasoning at Harvard supplied more evidence of fragmentation: elegant reasoners often acted shabbily. The author also noticed this disparity in himself.
Given such a background, Mr. Testa's attraction to the seamless integration of piety and practice in Amish life is readily understandable. It is the author's conviction, sharpening as the summer wears on, that if the Amish are driven out, "if [their] way of life falters, we all fall down. We need [them] to point out how far we have strayed."
"After the Fire" does not purport to be a full or balanced portrait of Amish life. Even so, a brief mention of the history of the Amish, tracing their spiritual ancestry from the 16th-century Ana baptist movement, would not have been amiss. The story of the separation of Amish from Mennonite would have cast helpful illumination on the character of both communities. The emphasis on purity is more extreme in the Amish fellowship, a purity reinforced through painful, embittering practices of excommunication and social shunning. The boundaries within which gentleness, harmony and peace prevail are defined by fierce exclusions. There is a price to be paid for purity.
Separation from worldly entanglements carried out with the typically rigorous consistency of the Amish means that there is often no pathway for effecting needed change beyond the enclave of their own faith community, even when their way of life is threatened. Faced with protracted conflict, the Amish pull up stakes and move out. The author notes this tendency but does not reflect on it. A fuller reflection would not diminish the vital lessons the Amish have to teach us (in social cohesion, land stewardship, moral economy and more), but it would deepen their credibility for readers whose lives are not plain and simple.
"After the Fire" is several shades darker than Sue Bender's 1989 account of a similar sojourn, the best-selling "Plain and Simple: A Woman's Journey to the Amish." In retrospect, that earlier portrait of two contrasting ways of life let us off lightly; Ms. Bender's narrative was charming and comfortable throughout. "After the Fire" is neither. There's no way it could be. Mr. Testa is focused on our urgent need for reform. His book is driven not simply by his own spiritual hunger but by his vision -- a compelling one -- of widespread spiritual famine in a land of material glut.

HEADLINE: The Flight of the Raptors

BYLINE: By DYAN ZASLOWSKY; DYAN ZASLOWSKY is writing a biography of the conservationist Rosalie Edge.

 BODY:
HAWKS and eagles have been migrating for eons along the stony spine of the Kittatinny Ridge in northeastern Pennsylvania. But it is only since 1934, when a section of the rocks became a bird refuge, that people have gone there to marvel.
Every year more than 50,000 people are drawn to Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, a 2,200-acre private nature preserve in a dot of a town called Kempton, about an hour north of Allentown. The sanctuary is on a thickly wooded 1,300-foot-high promontory above the farmlands of the Pennsylvania Dutch. 
 This coming autumnal migration, which runs Aug. 15 to Dec. 15, is particularly notable because sometime during the season, the sacntuary will count its millionth bird of prey since it started keeping records in 1934. Birds arrive in their greatest numbers when the foliage turns, offering two excuses for a visit in the fall. Hawk watchers typically head for the exposed sandstone spine of the sanctuary's North or South Lookouts, and settle for the day on the jumbled, stony couches with their binoculars, books, sketch pads, picnics and blankets. An impromptu assembly can number 1,000 on a bright, warm weekend in October. All face the stage, which is what the sky becomes when the birds are flying.
On my first visit to Hawk Mountain I was struck by the crowd's reverence for the birds as much as by the birds themselves. North Lookout was positively serene despite the number of people who had gathered. The crowd -- many of them Mennonites from the nearby farming communities, judging by their apparel -- talked in whispers if at all.
Throughout the day one of the Hawk Mountain guides, or "counters" as they are known, calmly narrated the changing scene. "Sharpie coming up on the right!" one counter announced, pivoting in the direction of the sharp-shinned hawk. The counter acknowledged the arrival of a chimney swift -- "a cigar with wings," as she called it. At the same moment an osprey rose higher in our sphere of vision, backlit by the sun. Binoculars tilted upward, and the congregants murmured approval.
Such worshipful human behavior is one remarkable indication of how the attitude towards hawks and eagles has changed; it was hunters, at the end of the 19th century, who first discovered the advantages of Hawk Mountain's location. With their pump guns and automatics they blasted hawks and eagles out of the sky as they flew into firing range. It was a civic duty to do this. Wishing to eradicate predatory birds from the face of the Keystone State if not the earth, the Pennsylvania Game Commission at one point even paid a $5 bounty for each dead goshawk.
Hawks of all kinds were despised because they preyed upon smaller birds and, now and then, hens and chicks. Popular folk wisdom held that bald eagles attacked lambs and untended infants and carried them off to their aeries to devour. Thousands of birds both wounded and dead were left to rot where they dropped.
The rocks on this section of the Kittatinny Ridge fell silent in the autumn of 1934, when an ardent bird lover named Rosalie Edge wrested the high killing ground from a failing tombstone company and established the first hawk sanctuary in the world.
Edge, who earlier in life had been a New York suffragist and socialite, was hailed in her middle age as "the only woman in conservation." Her one-woman Emergency Conservation Committee successfully agitated for numerous environmental reforms. Edge did manage to change the local conduct toward hawks; she hired an armed caretaker named Maurice Broun, who felt about hawk protection as she did, and together they rigorously enforced the new Kitattinny code: watch, don't shoot. Edge became the birds' outspoken champion, and led national efforts to educate the public about their right to exist. The ridge was transformed into what Edge called "a citadel of peace." The transformation was an economic one as well. Hawk-related tourism has replaced hawk hunting as a prime source of Schuykill (pronounced SKOOL-kil) County's income.
The land Edge optioned to buy for her sanctuary had been skinned of its timber, but she let nature resume its course, and today Hawk Mountain is dense with second-growth chestnut oaks, and an understory of red maples, sassafras, sweet gums and witch hazel, brilliant in autumn.
Hawk Mountain is known as one of the best natural vantage points in the world from which to see large numbers of birds of prey. From the sanctuary's North and South Lookouts visitors can see 20 of North America's 30 raptorial species, including bald eagles, golden eagles, osprey, peregrine falcons, broad-winged hawks and kestrels.
During my two-day visit in early October, 11 species were sighted -- 10 peregrine falcons and more than 120 osprey and 20 vultures. October is a month of quantity as well as diversity; a week after my visit Cooper's hawks, sharp-shins, kestrels and others were streaking by at a rate of 150 an hour, riding the brisk currents of west-northwest winds that presage good hawk watching.
Hawk Mountain's counters (both volunteers and paid staff) assiduously track the number and species of birds and the weather conditions -- there is even a phone line to find out about the preceding day's highlights. Since Hawk Mountain's inception not a single day has passed when birds -- raptors and others -- were not tallied, and as a result the sanctuary supplies ornithologists with the longest-running record of raptor migration patterns in the world.
Rachel Carson found Hawk Mountain's data extremely useful when she was conducting her research for "Silent Spring," and she frequented the lookouts.
The counters are a blessing to fledgling bird watchers. Their friendly expertise is dispensed to anyone who doesn't know a peregrine from a pigeon, and as one of the nation's top bird education centers, Hawk Mountain is a good place to start learning the difference.
Ornithologists believe that hawks migrating from Eastern Canada and New England fly over the Kittatinny Ridge because they are trying to conserve their energy by supplementing their wing power with the updrafts from the ridge, oriented in the same direction the birds are heading on their trip to South America.
Broad-winged hawks take advantage of thermals, which are bubbles of warm air that rise as cooler mountain air mixes in from below. Flying at a speed of 40 miles an hour the hawks can cover about 250 miles on a good day.
At Hawk Mountain flocks of broad-winged hawks typically arrive in September, when they can be seen churning within a single thermal, looking as though the birds are boiling in a kettle. In fact, when hawks appear in this sort of configuration they are said to be kettling. Even for nonbirders, hawks are thrilling to watch because of their dramatic flights. The chance to see sky-kettles boiling with hundreds of hawks is something watchers hope for when they spend a day at the lookouts. And yet, sighting a solitary immature bald eagle, as I did, can be quite exhilarating as well.
Hawk Mountain Sanctuary includes about eight miles of hiking trails that wind through the woods up toward lush brows of rhodedendrons at several scenic outcrops. A few minutes from the parking lot, one trail up to the Lookout is accessible to the handicapped. All other trails, some of which connect with the Appalachian Trail, are rocky but easy enough for children to negotiate.
From the South Lookout you can see a curious geologic formation called the River of Rocks, a milelong gash of boulders left by the last ice age. Those who get restless just sitting at the lookout can always hike down to it.
Outside the Visitors Center is an outdoor exhibit of how to landscape to encourage wildlife and a sculpture of a golden eagle, once thought to be extinct in the region. The center itself features a bookstore, murals explaining the relationship between birds and winds and the predator-prey cycle and two windows from which visitors can see birds at feeding areas .
The sanctuary has a staff of 14, and is supported by an association of 8,500 members nationwide.
While Hawk Mountain's efforts concentrate on birds of prey, it has also preserved a remnant of Colonial history, in the form of a white stone cottage called Schaumboch's, today a private residence for sanctuary staff members. Built shortly before the Revolutionary War as an unprotected outpost in hostile Delaware Indian country, the cottage stood practically at the edge of the world as then known by the settlers. In the mid-1800's Schaumboch's became an important stop for wayfarers on the rough mountain road between Drehersville and Eckville. The building is named for its most sinister occupant, a man reputed to have murdered and robbed at least 20 travelers after plying them with his homemade whisky. Residents attest to so many paranormal incidents that the notion that the house and maybe the ridge is haunted is very much alive.
The possibility of ghosts impressed me one moonless midnight when I was working alone in the sanctuary's archives. As I stumbled through the black woods to my car I heard a long, low, lugubrious wail.
It might have been the spirit of one of Schaumboch's victims. I prefer to believe it was a great horned owl, proclaiming this place his own.
 
 
 
STOPS FOR HAWK WATCHERS
Although mid-October is the best time to visit Hawk Mountain to see hawks and autumn foliage, the sanctuary is open year round. If you are interested in seeing a specific species, contact the sanctuary to find out when its arrival is expected: Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, Route 2, Box 191, Kempton, Pa. 19529; (215) 756-6961. The nearest exit from I-78 is Lenhartsville for those traveling east and Route 61 North for those traveling west. Binoculars are essential. The visitors center is open daily 9 to 5; trails are open dawn to dusk. Admission is $3, $1.50 for children 6 to 12.
 
Where to Stay
 All accommodations mentioned are within a short drive of Hawk Mountain. They are simple, clean, and offer few amenities. Particularly on autumn weekends, reservations are necessary. Allentown, an hour away from Hawk Mountain, offers greater selection of lodgings. You can request a list of accommodations from Hawk Mountain Sanctuary.
Union House Bed & Breakfast, Broad and Central Streets, Port Clinton, Pa. 19549, (215) 562-4076, is about five miles to the southwest of the sanctuary. Its seven bedrooms are furnished with antiques, rope beds and handmade quilts, share two bathrooms. A room is $95 a night for two, full breakfast included. Dinner and lunch are also served, featuring steak, lobster, home-made crabcakes; meals are $7.95 to $23.95.
Glasbern, Pack House Road, RD 1, Box 250, Fogelsville, Pa. 18051, (215)285-4723), about 20 miles southeast of the sanctuary, is a restored barn, with 23 rooms with private baths, and, in some, whirlpool and fireplace. Better rooms are in separate buildings. Doubles are $100 to $200 on weekends, and $95 and $145 on weekdays, full breakfast included. Dinner is $35 to $40, with wine.
The Hawk Mountain Inn, Box 186, Kempton, Pa. 19529, (215) 756-4224) 10 miles east of the sanctuary, is a bed and breakfast establishment. Eight rooms with private bath breakfast, $65 to $95 a night. Dinner entrees are $16-$19.
Fort Motel, Route 61, Orwigsburg, Pa. 17961, (717) 366-2091, is about a 10-minute drive to the west. The 12 rooms, $42 for two, all have private baths.
Top Motel, 1030 Krumsville Road, Lenhartsville, Pa. 19534, (215) 756-6021, is also about 12 miles to the southeast. Eleven rooms, private baths, $32 a night for two.
 
Where to Eat
 There are no restaurants or snack bars at Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, so visitors must bring their own provisions or drive about 20 minutes to a restaurant. Local fare tends to be good, inexpensive and never exotic.
Clauser's Mini Market, (717) 366-1628, intersection of Routes 895 and 61 in Molino, prepares sandwiches visitors can take to sanctuary lookouts.
Smith's Country Inn, (717) 943-2785, near the intersection of Routes 443 and 895 in New Ringgold, is a large stone house originally built as a stagecoach stop in 1769, now popular for steaks and fish. Meals are $8 to 20.
Villa Montagna, Route 61, in Orwigsburg, (717) 366-1914, serves Italian specialities. Entrees are $12 and up.
