HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN EUROPE;
British Leader Faces Revolt on Europe Union Policy in Own Party

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
With the treaty on European union having won a narrow endorsement from French voters today, a new battlefront seems certain to open in Britain, where Prime Minister John Major's Government is facing a spreading rebellion over European policy in the ranks of his Conservative Party.
Spurred on by last week's financial turmoil in Britain, which sent the value of the pound tumbling, those skeptical of European integration here say it is now up to them to derail the movement toward European union and drive a British stake through the heart of the treaty, which is awaiting ratification in the House of Commons.
 
Summit Meeting Called
 
 "We in Britain have got our own choice to make," Michael Spicer, a Conservative Party critic of the treaty, said tonight. "We cannot rely on the French to make the choice for us."
Critics of European union in both the Conservative and the rival Labor parties also pressed the Government tonight to put their case for the treaty before voters in a referendum, just as in France.
Speaking tonight, Mr. Major repeated his support for the treaty as good for Britain and Europe. Mr. Major, now serving as President of the European Commission, a revolving post, also called a summit meeting of European Community leaders for early next month, presumably in London.
The debate over the treaty will be joined in earnest on Thursday, when Parliament reconvenes in a special session for an emergency debate on the economy. It is not clear, however, when the treaty will come before the House of Commons for ratification.
Mr. Major also said tonight that he was uncertain when he would reopen debate in Parliament, because he is waiting to see if European leaders can persuade Denmark to reconsider its rejection of the treaty. Danes voted it down in a referendum last spring.
All 12 member nations of the European Community must ratify the treaty, a blueprint for closer political and economic cooperation, if it is to take effect.
The rebellion over Europe could further imperil the political leadership of Mr. Major, who is already under fire for his embarrassing reversal of policy last week, when he abandoned efforts to preserve the value of the struggling British pound in the European monetary system. The pound has since dropped sharply in value.
Treaty opponents say about 100 backbenchers - nearly a third of the party's strength in Commons - will join their movement.
Opponents of European integration in Britain were emboldened over the weekend by what they described as growing signs of public doubt here.
A poll of 1,063 voters appearing today in The Independent on Sunday, a British newspaper, showed a 2-to-1 margin against the treaty. Forty-seven percent said they would vote against the treaty, if given the chance in a referendum, and only 24 percent said they would vote yes. Twenty-nine percent were undecided.
Critics were also cheered Saturday by the return to the battlefield of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, a longtime skeptic on European integration.
On Saturday, in a speech delivered in Washington, Mrs. Thatcher called for a halt to what she described as the "European gravy train," and restated her explicit opposition to the treaty, which Mr. Major and other European leaders signed this year in Maastricht, the Netherlands.
Trying to exploit the growing rift in Conservative ranks, Gordon Brown, the Labor Party spokesman on economic affairs, warned darkly that the Tories were "lurching into a new anti-Europeanism."
But the Labor leadership faces a rebellion of its own. Bryan Gould, one of the party's top officials, has urged the Labor leadership to let the British people decide for themselves about European union in a referendum.
There was some good news today for Mr. Major and Norman Lamont, the Chancellor of the Exchequer. Two public opinion samplings published in London newspapers showed that two-thirds of British voters favored the Prime Minister's staying in office. Slightly more voters were in favor of Mr. Lamont's staying on than favored his resigning.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
Day of Brawling for Presidential Camps

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
On a day of testy partisan squabbling, Gov. Bill Clinton televised the first negative commercial of the fall Presidential campaign today, painting President Bush as an unrealistic leader who talked about prosperity while the economy tumbled into recession.
Vice President Dan Quayle found himself answering new questions about his military record and trying to avoid discussing the Republican Party's anti-abortion stand and Mr. Bush's agreement to the 1990 tax increase, as the campaigns traded accusations on the draft, the economy and taxes. 
 The two camps also remained locked in a circular argument over debates. Each side is insisting on holding Presidential and Vice-Presidential debates on its own terms and accusing the other of being afraid of what both call a "man-to-man" confrontation.
 
Attacks on Credibility
 Both Presidential camps sought to use the day to undermine their opponent's credibility. The Democrats told Americans that Mr. Bush, who has insisted for at least two years that the economy is on the verge of recovery and still has not acknowledged how sluggish it really is, can no longer be trusted.
"If George Bush doesn't understand the problem, how can he solve it?" the Clinton commercial said, using film clips of Mr. Bush sounding upbeat about the economy. Some of the clips were presented out of sequence to the events they were intended to illustrate.
The Republicans, signaling that they intended to respond to Mr. Clinton's commercial with advertisements of their own criticizing the Arkansas Governor, continued to pound away at his draft record, which White House strategists have made the center of their assault on the Democratic nominee's character.
But Mr. Quayle also found himself on the defensive on the draft issue in an extraordinary, hourlong appearance on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
Mr. Quayle dismissed an article in The New York Times today about his service in the National Guard as a "rehash." The article repeated Mr. Quayle's assertion that he sought the advice of relatives before joining the Guard. But it also disclosed that the unit in which he enlisted was holding slots for people of influence at a time when Washington had ordered all National Guard units to accept enlistees on a first-come, first-served basis.
Mr. Quayle has said his decision to join the Indiana National Guard 23 years ago "wasn't to avoid going to Vietnam." But he acknowledged today that he knew there was far less chance of going to war if he was in the Guard. He said that he sought no special favors and that "no rules were broken, no regulations broken."
The Vice President tried to steer away from the specific question of service in Vietnam, on which he is as vulnerable to criticism as Mr. Clinton, and to stay on the Republicans' designated target: the question of whether Mr. Clinton has been completely forthcoming on how he avoided the draft.
"I don't think that military service one way or another is a definitive character issue on whether you can be a good Commander in Chief or not," he said. Mr. Quayle said Mr. Clinton had "not told the truth" and added, "That is the issue that qualifies him or disqualifies him in my judgment from being Commander in Chief."
Mr. Bush himself stayed out of the campaign fray. But he took advantage of a meeting in Washington of the International Monetary Fund to appear before television cameras at the White House as host to an international group of finance ministers and state bank officials.
 
'Do-Nothing Administration'
 Mr. Clinton was out on the trail courting Democrats who voted for Mr. Bush in 1988 in mostly white suburban Detroit and helping to register voters at a mostly black rally in the South Side of Chicago.
Mr. Clinton urged the Chicago audience to register to vote and to show up at the polls to end the "12 years of trickle-down economics" he said had left Americans "working harder for less."
In Macomb County, Mich., where he was greeted by a boisterous crowd of people, many of them carrying signs declaring their affiliation with labor unions, Mr. Clinton said those who voted for Mr. Bush in 1988 were "betrayed" by a President who broke his promise not to raise taxes and sought a cut in the capital gains tax rate that would benefit the wealthy.
"They talk about traditional values, but they punish people who work hard and play by the rules and reward people who cut corners and cut deals," he said, adding: "This is a do-nothing Administration that will do nothing for four more years if we are foolish enough to give it to them. And I don't think we are."
Mr. Clinton's oratory followed the track of the two commercials that his campaign began broadcasting today, one of them focusing exclusively on criticisms of Mr. Bush, with emphasis on his economic performance.
Torie Clarke, Mr. Bush's campaign press secretary, said: "Nobody disputes the fact that the economy has not grown as fast as we would like or that not enough good jobs have been created. We're saying that the most important issue in this election is not just the state of the economy, but what do you do about it."
She called the commercial a "diversionary tactic to get away from answering any questions about the draft issue" and said of Mr. Bush's opponent, "He is slowly bleeding to death on this one as lie after lie after lie by Bill Clinton is revealed."
The Bush team itself was clearly more intent on changing the subject, talking about Mr. Clinton and the draft rather than the current state of the economy.
In his appearance on NBC this morning, Mr. Quayle tried to deflect questions about the tax increase of 1990, asserting that Mr. Bush had been forced to agree to the increase in October of that year because of the Persian Gulf crisis.
"He had an international crisis," Mr. Quayle said. "He could ill afford another crisis at home, which probably would have happened by him not going along with that negotiated deal."
But Mr. Bush first agreed to raise taxes in June 1990, and Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was in August. Other accounts also dispute Mr. Quayle's assertion. A senior official who was present during the Administration's deliberations on the war and the Federal budget has said Mr. Bush never drew a connection between the two issues.
Mr. Quayle, who has been trying to strike a more middle-of-the-road position on abortion than he has taken in the past, also grew evidently uncomfortable when asked about it. Although Mr. Quayle said he remained personally opposeed to abortion, he refused to say whether it should be banned outright, as the Republican platform, Mr. Bush's own stated position and Mr. Quayle himself have demanded.
Instead, Mr. Quayle tried to focus on laws, like one in Pennsylvania, that limit access to abortions. "I'm trying to change attitudes," he said. "I'm trying to change behavior."

LENGTH: 1283 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Pulse -- Colorado;
Anti-Bush Sentiment Could Break Colorado's Tradition of Loyalty to G.O.P.

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The last time Colorado voted for a Democrat for President was back in 1964, when Lyndon B. Johnson was the candidate. The next time could be this November.
President Bush is trailing Gov. Bill Clinton in this Rocky Mountain state, according to the most recent polls, and although there is still time for Mr. Bush to catch up, it will not be easy. He is widely seen here, even by some Republicans, as "a failed President, out of ideas and out of steam," said Thomas Cronin, a professor at Colorado College and a leading authority on the Presidency. 
 Colorado counts. Not because of its electoral votes (it has only eight), and not because it is a bellwether. It counts because it epitomizes a perilous problem for Mr. Bush: with only six weeks left until Election Day, he has still not secured many of the states that ought to constitute his base. And it counts because it shows that even in states where the economy is on the upswing, as it is here after a painful recession in the mid-1980's, doubts about the nation's economic future are working against the President.
 
The President as Quarterback
 Mr. Bush has already made two trips here this month. He spoke in the Denver suburbs on Tuesday, comparing himself not to Harry S. Truman but to another come-from-behind specialist, John Elway, the Denver Broncos' quarterback, and depicting his Democratic opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, as a dyed-in-the-wool liberal who favors "more government intrusion, more regulation and more spending."
It was a high-risk attempt to capitalize on this region's mistrust of government. Colorado, the only state in the Union with a term-limitation law applicable to Congress, has long harbored suspicions toward Washington, but so far this year the President has been the main focus of what one Republican here calls "a storm of cynicism and disillusionment."
The Democrats are also pressing unusually hard in Colorado, with separate visits scheduled this week by Mr. Clinton; his wife, Hillary; his running-mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, and the party's national chairman, Ronald H. Brown.
 
Very Independent State
 "People here are saying, 'Well, it's certainly not morning in America any more,' " acknowledged Howard (Bo) Callaway, a former Army Secretary and one-time state Republican chairman. "But they don't trust Clinton. That's why the draft issue matters. The President has said he isn't perfect, that he's made mistakes, that the economy's bad. What we have to do now is convince people it will get worse -- a whole lot worse -- if the Democrats win."
That approach, Mr. Callaway said, gave the Conservatives in Britain a surprise victory earlier this year and could do the same for Mr. Bush in Colorado and in the nation.
Senator Hank Brown, a Republican moderate, describes Colorado as "one of the most independent states in the country" with no deep-seated allegiances to either party. It has a Republican Senator and a Democratic Senator, a Republican-dominated Legislature and a Democratic Governor. Its House delegation is evenly split. It has long been viewed as a bastion of abortion rights, yet it has cut off all state financing for abortions.
Chock full of young, well-educated and technologically sophisticated people, many of whom came here because of the mountains and the fresh air, the state has propelled onto the national stage such figures as former Senator Gary Hart and retiring Senator Tim Wirth, both new-breed Democrats.
Colorado's habit of voting Republican for President is ingrained; Robert Ewegen, a Denver Post columnist, said, "A lot of people think it's in our state Constitution that we go Republican in Presidential elections."
But Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, a weak candidate nationally, lost to Mr. Bush by less than 10 percentage points four years ago. And moderate Democrats like Gov. Roy Romer and Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell are now the state's most popular breed of politician, which should augur well for Governor Clinton.
 
Conscious of the Environment
 "Democrats here are changing," Mr. Romer said in an interview the other day, pulling from his briefcase a thoroughly annotated study of strategies to cut spending. "We used to be identified with the safety net and redistribution of wealth, but we've become involved with growth and budget control. There's no point in arguing about how to cut up the economic pie when the pie is shrinking so fast that it won't even feed everybody.
"Clinton understands that, and it is helping him in this state."
In addition, Colorado's baby boomers are intensely conscious of the environment, and Mr. Wirth argued that the presence of Mr. Gore on the ticket, with his credentials as one of the Senate's leading environmentalists, was helping Mr. Clinton to "hammer the President on that issue." Earlier this week Mr. Bush vowed to block renewal of the Endangered Species Act unless it took jobs into account, a position that widened the gap between himself and the Democrats.
But the Republican National Convention may have made Mr. Bush and his party look unacceptably extreme to swing voters in the Denver suburbs.
The attacks on homosexuals and on Mrs. Clinton, and the absolutist opposition to abortion that marked the Houston convention, Mr. Romer said, haven't gone down very well with "our pro-choice, two-job yuppies, who tend to be conservative on fiscal issues but libertarian on social questions."
 
Oppressive on Family Values
 Former Senator Bill Armstrong, a fiscally conservative Republican who thinks Mr. Bush has a chance to carry Colorado if he can articulate his program, agreed with the Governor on the party's convention. "For my taste the family values stuff was pretty heavy-handed," Mr. Armstrong said. "In terms of style, it went too far for most people in this state."
But it suited the religious right perfectly, and the religious right has come to play a powerful role within the Republican Party. Representative David E. Skaggs, a Democrat who represents the Boulder area, faces a challenge this fall from Bryan Day, a fundamentalist minister who won a tight primary race. Foes of abortion also ousted several prominent Republican supporters of abortion rights, including State Senator Bonnie Allison, in the primaries.
But in the end, said Mr. Cronin, the Colorado College professor, neither the religious right nor the environmentalists will decide the election. With memories of hard times four and five years ago still fresh, he said, "out of 10 factors that are going to influence this election, the economy is 1, 2, 3 and 4."
The attacks on the President's economic stewardship by Patrick J. Buchanan in the early primaries and by Ross Perot after that, Mr. Cronin added, "hurt Bush more than most people realize, by peeling off supporters who have found it very difficult since then to return to the fold."
Mr. Perot had the backing of close to a quarter of Colorado voters when he pulled out of the race in July, and he retains a highly visible campaign office in downtown Denver. If he reactivates his campaign, he may tip the result here one way or the other.
Even if he does not, his erstwhile backers may hold the key. A poll for The Denver Post, taken Aug. 21 to Sept. 1, showed an eight-point lead for Mr. Clinton, 45 percent to 37 percent, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four points. But 11 percent of the 618 respondents said they were undecided and 7 percent declined to respond, and politicians of both parties suspect that many of them were former Perot supporters who dislike the President but still find themselves loath to give Mr. Clinton a chance at the job.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Doubts about the nation's economic future are weakening support for President Bush in Colorado, even among traditional Republicans. Dr. R. D. Graphs: "A Mind of Its Own"
 Colorado goes its own way. It has term limits for its politicans, but it has elected liberals like Gary Hart and Tim Wirth to the Senate. Now Ben Highthorse Campbell, the only American Indian in Congress, who angers environmentalists with his emphasis on jobs, is the Democratic Senate nominee.

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal;
Where Tourists Rummage in Communism's Attic

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The Arbat, Moscow's half-mile pedestrian mall, is Russia's capital of "poshlost," but amid the dross are scattered treasures and a glimpse of how the new market economy, bribe ridden, actually functions.
Vladimir Nabokov, who should have known, declared "poshlost" untranslatable. It encompasses banality, triviality and kitsch, with a crucial added dash of vulgarity. 
 Poshlost is the 975th set of matryoshki, the one-inside-the-other wooden dolls, shaped like bowling pins, with a vacant "happy face" on each. It is the imitation Palekh box, the black-lacquered papier-mache knickknack with a fairy tale painted on the top. It is the "McLenin" T-shirt, with the Soviet patriarch's face imposed on the Golden Arches, or the Lenin candle, a carved wax bust with a wick coming out of its glistening dome, perfectly precious for just the wrong dinner party.
Every society sells junk to foreign tourists for whatever price can be had. But Arbat poshlost has a special poignancy. In the market for a Soviet colonel-general's dress uniform with all the trimmings, including a used white shirt? Bought from a needy widow, it can be yours for 10,000 rubles ($49), subject to bargaining. The seller, Dmitri, said the widow, if she were lucky, got 2,000 rubles for it.
 
'Generals Cost More'
 "It's just old fabric," Dmitri said. "We've got kids and wives and I haven't been paid my salary for two months." A factory worker, he wore a N.F.L. windbreaker intended for a St. Louis (now Phoenix) Cardinals fan. And how much did that cost? "Six thousand rubles," he said proudly.
Aleksei Sarokin, 20 years old, sells uniforms from any service, including the K.G.B., with its cornflower-blue lapel flashes. A colonel's uniform is about $50, a dress uniform $80. "Generals cost more," Mr. Sarokin said.
Soldiers' greatcoats are common, only $15, and ordinary winter hats, of fake fur, $7. Officers' winter hats, of gray rabbit, are $15. A MIG pilot's helmet, Steve Canyon-style, is $120 with oxygen mask, $100 without.
"Some officers bring these uniforms themselves," Mr. Sarokin said, "but mainly it's their wives." Unsurprisingly here, where tour buses come, he sells almost exclusively to foreigners, especially young Americans.
Asked if he felt any shame, he and his colleagues shrugged. "Sometimes people yell at us," he said. "Sometimes they ask if we've served in the army." Have they? They laughed, shaking their heads.
"We don't think it's something sacred," said a burly blond in aviator sunglasses. "After all, our state is selling secrets abroad, and the officers themselves come and sell these clothes." What bothers him is the sale of icons nearby. "These are purely Russian and have artistic value," he said. "And we're sorry for it."
Another colleague, a student, wore a Buffalo Bills sweatshirt and a New York Giants jacket. "Mostly students sell here," he said. They get a monthly government stipend of 1,000 rubles ($4.88). "Who can live on that?"
In three years on the Arbat, he has found the highest profit in uniforms: "If you pay 3,000 rubles for a matryoshka, you can sell it for only 6,000. But for every 100 invested in uniforms you get 1,000 to 2,000 back."
Mr. Sarokin hires a student to sell on weekdays. "So you have an employee?" He laughed. "I suppose so." Students get 25 percent of the fixed price and any extra.
 
Militias Muscle In
 The Arbat is ruled by two gangs, one Russian and one from the Caucasus, who have split the street. Mr. Sarokin and his friends pay the gang members from the Caucasus $20 to $40 a month for each small folding table at their prime spot near the Prague Restaurant.
"We pay to get a sort of protection, so people leave us alone," one said. They are also supposed to pay 5,000 rubles a month to the city, and say they earn $400 to $500 a month in net profit per table.
Olga, 17, sells papier-mache boxes. Her best, a numbered one from Palekh (a village famous for its painters), is a minimum of $150. Her boss has fixed a $125 price, "and if I sell it for less than $25 profit for me, it's not worth it." Poorer boxes sell for $30.
Lately the sellers have also had to cope with a feud between the city and state militias, who want to control the Arbat and its riches. Last week, the city militia tried to close the street down, but failed. Now, like the gangs, they share it with their state colleagues.
 
$5,000 for a Banner
 Russia is still a country where people have the right to buy for hard currency, but not to sell for it. If the militiamen see a hard-currency sale, they can confiscate the proceeds. "They can't stop you on the street and turn out your pockets," said Aleksei, 22. "But if they see a sale, they can."
Sometimes the militiamen take the entire sum, sometimes half; sometimes they can be placated with a 250-ruble bottle of vodka.
Most students clear about 2,500 rubles ($12.20) a day, Olga said, though matryoshki sellers can make 5,000.
Sergei I. Suvorov, a businessman turned amateur historian, has the best Soviet memorabilia on the Arbat. He calls his store "a political antique shop of the socialist realism period." If he thinks you're serious, he'll invite you upstairs to his museum for tea.
On the street, he has pins, medals and banners of velvet, silk and nylon, usually praising Lenin and urging the workers of the world to unite, ranging from $5 to $200. One silk banner of Stalin and Lenin is $1,000; velvet ones worked in gold from the 1930's can cost $5,000.
Mr. Suvorov, 26, has started to take himself more seriously as a collector. Upstairs, he has banners from the first years of the Soviet Union. One from the first five-year plan shows a richly embroidered Lenin with the golden injunction, "Five years in four!
He has numerous portraits and statues of Stalin and the young Lenin, poring over a book. There are carpets given to the leadership, depicting rarer figures, like Rosa Luxemburg and Richard Sorge, a famed Soviet spy.
Mr. Suvorov hopes to start a real museum. "This is not all junk," he said. "This is history, and people come from all over the world to see it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Souvenirs of the Communist era are offered for sale on the Arbat, a pedestrian mall in Moscow that offers foreigners a glimpse of one part of Russia's new market economy. A MIG pilot's helmet is offered for $120. (Bill Swersey for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section B; Page 6; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1194 words

HEADLINE: Against Odds, Revival For Troubled College

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 16

 BODY:
When Robert E. Karsten took over as president of Upsala College here in 1988, he was often told that he faced one insurmountable hurdle in trying to revive a rapidly failing institution.
Since the 1967 riots in Newark, East Orange, Upsala's home, once a quiet, white suburb, had become a largely black city with a reputation similar to Newark's as a dangerous place. People were not sending their children here to college, and the common wisdom went that people would never send them here again. 
 Upsala had rapidly been losing enrollment, from a peak of 1,400 full-time day students in 1969 to 475 in 1990. What's more, the college had accumulated a $10 million deficit. Projections made in August 1990 showed that by June 1992 there would be no more money and Upsala College would have to close.
But Dr. Karsten, the former provost of Capital University in Columbus, Ohio, was brought in to turn Upsala around, and he promptly began to do just that -- partly by considering East Orange an advantage, not a disadvantage. Last year there were 674 full-time students; this year there are 882, many of them members of minority groups or foreign students.
A major fund-raising effort increased gift-giving by $1 million in the first six months of 1992, and an unusual consortium of lenders from church, private and public interests assembled a $4 million deal to provide the college with working capital.
 
Finding Strengths
 While much still needs to be done to assure Upsala's future, at a time when many colleges and universities nationwide are facing financial difficulty, Upsala's story is one example of how a college can buck the odds.
"It's all a matter of recognizing what your strengths are and taking advantage of them," said Dr. Karsten, a 62-year-old Lutheran minister who has also been a vice president, dean and professor of religion at Gustavus Adolphus College in St. Peter, Minn., and the pastor of Wittenberg University in Springfield, Ohio. "But our strengths had changed over the years, and the college had not found a way to make an accurate assessment of where its strengths were."
 
Lutheran Affiliation
 Upsala (pronounced Up-SAH-la, after the Swedish university with which it maintains ties) is an independent, four-year liberal arts college affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, the largest Lutheran group in the United States. Its campus, a 46-acre expanse of red-brick buildings and spacious lawns, is in a residential neighborhood just off the Garden State Parkway. The school has 22 programs leading to the bachelor's degree, plus master's and continuing education programs.
For many years the college had depended on Lutheran churches along the Eastern seaboard to recruit students.
But in recent decades those recruiting efforts waned, Dr. Karsten said, and Upsala did not react quickly enough to fill the void. When he arrived, Dr. Karsten increased recruiting efforts across the board.
 
Diversity as a Strategy
 "Diversity has become a centerpiece of our strategy," Dr. Karsten said. "And not just in terms of black and white. It's what a college should be these days anyway." The student body of Upsala in 1992, he said, is about 35 percent white, 35 percent black and 30 percent foreign students.
"We have a program in which 15 Jewish students from the states of the former Soviet Union come here," he said. "We have a continuing exchange program with Uppsala University in Sweden. We have students from South Korea, Japan, China, Namibia -- a largely Lutheran country -- France, Jamaica. The ebb and flow of cultural differences is richer than anything I've ever seen."
 
High Retention Rate
 Upsala also participates in programs for disadvantaged students with low Scholastic Aptitude Test scores. Among the programs are the publicly financed New Jersey Educational Opportunity Fund, which this year is helping to provide an education for 121 youngsters at Upsala.
The retention rate for the program in the last year and a half has been more than 90 percent, Dr. Karsten said. "Our experience shows that most of the urban youngsters who we tend to think of as not being college material are indeed good learners," he said.
The college also runs a satellite program for 300 students on a rural campus in Sussex County.
At a time when many town-gown relationships are badly frayed, East Orange and Upsala have combined to form what appears to be a mutually beneficial admiration society.
"A community that has a college within its borders can maximize that relationship," said Mayor Cardell Cooper. "It gives the city a positive image, and it adds flavor to the city."
 
Bond Issue Planned
 Mayor Cooper said that he and other East Orange and Essex County officials had tentatively agreed to guarantee a bond issue that would provide $3.5 million for Upsala for capital improvements and the purchase of new equipment. Both Dr. Karsten and Mr. Cooper said that prospects for final approval this fall were good.
But Upsala needed money right away. So Dr. Karsten organized a consortium of church, private and public interests to provide loans to the school and to restructure Upsala's debt for working capital and capital improvements. The amount involved totals $4 million.
The consortium includes St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn.; Gustavus Adolphus College in St. Peter, Minn.; Concordia College in Moorhead, Minn.; California Lutheran University in Thousand Oaks, Calif.; the Campus Ministry and Mission Development Funds of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America; the Marriott Corporation and the ServiceMaster Corporation, two of the college's creditors; the college's Calman Trust, and Midlantic National Bank and First Fidelity Bank.
After years of deficits, Dr. Karsten said, "We are now in a fiscal year in which we will show an operating gain." Tuition at the school for the 1991-92 academic year was $9,800.
 
Expanding Faculty
 And, at a time when many colleges and universities are cutting the size of their faculty, Upsala has added five positions to its teaching staff.
Students at Upsala this week said they enjoyed the campus. "What I like most is the ethnic diversity," said Karen Gayle, a 23-year-old junior from Ewarton, Jamaica. The allure for Michael Chechelnitsky, a 20-year-old senior from Moscow, was that "you can talk to the professors as long as you want, and they always will respond to you."
Bobbie Johnson, 35, a sophomore from East Orange, praised the instructors. "If you have any problems, even outside of your schoolwork, they have an open ear to listen and help you through," she said.
Faculty members, even those who said they did not support everything Dr. Karsten was doing, said Upsala had improved. Bassam Abed, an associate professor of anthropology, said, however, that he would like to see more emphasis on faculty development and improved salaries. And Bill Olson, an associate professor of economics, said that Upsala needed to increase enrollment even further.
Dr. Karsten said he knew that much more needed to be done. "But the perils are now standard perils," he said. "Our future is in our hands."

HEADLINE: Choosing Schools Through Fakery;
New York Parents Use Many Schemes for False Enrollment

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Clara Woodson is a school guidance supervisor in Brooklyn but, she told a Jamaican mother and her little boy sitting edgily in her office last week, in an earlier life she was a detective.
So when the Jamaican woman insisted that she had recently returned to New York City from California and was living with a friend two blocks from a popular public school in Canarsie where she demanded to have her son enrolled, Mrs. Woodson made no secret of her skepticism.
"Look at me," commanded the 65-year-old grandmother, 
 removing her glasses. "Do I have this job because I'm beautiful?" The tension eased and Mrs. Woodson zeroed in. "I have a hard time believing you," she said. "Just tell me the truth and I'll help you."
Such scenes have long been familiar around the start of each school year as frenzied parents cajole and harangue school officials, pull strings with politicians and often resort to imaginative schemes to place their children in the better New York City public schools outside their districts.
They give the addresses of friends or relatives, often even faking a lease on a form bought at the stationery store, or having a telephone installed in someone else's apartment to create the fiction of residency.
It was partly to curb this trickery that Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez decided to allow parents to send their children to any school in the city that has space available, after the children in the immediate area and then the surrounding district are accommodated.
"We don't want a system for people who know how to work it to their advantage, nor do we want a system where people have to lie in order to go to the school of their choice," James Vlasto, a spokesman for Mr. Fernandez, said last week.
The Board of Education does not keep track of how many students officially attend elementary and junior high schools outside their districts, and many of the 32 semi-autonomous districts, which do keep such figures, are reluctant to disclose them, some out of embarrassment about the eagerness to go elsewhere.
 
Thousands of Transfers
 But the number of such transfers is clearly in the thousands. In two Manhattan districts alone, District 3 counted 620 variances, or official exceptions, signed for pupils coming in and 22 for those going out, and District 2 reported 323 coming in and 3 going out. Variances are often given to ease overcrowding, for example, or if siblings already attend the school out of district, or if a parent's job requires the child to attend a school near the work site.
Officials say there is no way to even estimate the additional number of children who attend schools outside their district by subterfuge. Within the districts, moreover, others have found ways to attend a school other than their designated home school.
After word of the new choice policy was disclosed, so many parents called one of the top-ranked Manhattan schools, Public School 6, on Madison Avenue at 81st Street, that the principal, Carmen Farina, finally had to take her telephone off the hook, a district official said.
"This is a black-market economy," said Anthony J. Alvarado, the former Schools Chancellor who is superintendent of District 2 in Manhattan. "When there is a commodity needed, people will do what they have to to obtain it."
"There will have to be a lot of good schools and a lot of space to accommodate movement," he said of the new citywide policy. "It won't solve the black-market economy, but it will decrease the amount of finagling."
 
Trying to Surrender Custody
 With private school tuition running as high as $15,000 a year, the lengths to which parents will go to place a child in a top-ranked -- and free -- public school outside their home zone often startle school administrators.
Some families even surrendered custody of their children to relatives near a desirable school, said Dr. Harvey Garner, superintendent of Brooklyn's District 18, who recalled going to court to contest such attempts.
Inez Fonti is a guidance supervisor in District 26, covering Bayside and Douglaston in Queens, where the public schools have long ranked among the city's highest in reading scores.
"They fake addresses," she said. "They say they're living with someone else. They bring in a notarized statement from someone saying they're living with them. I'll ask: 'Did you drive here? Where is your driver's license?' It will list another address. They'll say, 'Oh, I didn't change that yet.' I ask them, 'Where do you vote?' They say, 'I haven't decided yet.' I ask, 'Do you have utility receipts?' They say, 'No, the people I live with pay the bills.' "
So many parents have conspired over the years to install telephones in other people's homes, Ms. Fonti said, that the district no longer accepts a phone bill as a proof of residence.
 
Once In, Home Free
 A spokesman for New York Telephone, Bob Varettoni, said last week that the company had never been informed of such practices, and that customers were free to have phones installed wherever they wished and billed to whomever they wanted.
At another sought-after school, P.S. 87 on West 78th Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues in Manhattan, the principal, Jane Hand, said that despite visits to suspicious addresses by an attendance teacher, children from outside the "catchment zone" had slipped in. But once a child is in, she said, "our hands are tied -- the child has become part of us."
There is no citywide policy, but most school officials interviewed agreed that a child, once in, would not be summarily expelled even if the address proved false. Some said the child would be not be permitted to return the next year, while others said they would let the child stay through all the grades of that school.
The ability to sniff out a parent's suspicious story has clearly become a specialty. Ms. Woodson, District 18's assistant superintendent for guidance, is one such expert. She has spent 45 years in the school system, the last 28 years in the district.
 
A Month to Prove Residency
 One morning last week, she questioned a new immigrant from St. Thomas, Debra Williams, who said she was living with her mother in the district and wanted to send her 11-year-old son, Michael, to fifth grade at P.S. 276.
Mrs. Williams had no residence records, which gave Ms. Woodson pause. Michael stumbled over his grandmother's phone number, stirring further suspicions. But by questioning the boy further, Ms. Woodson satisfied herself that he knew the neighborhood. She gave the woman a month to produce proof of residency.
"If we find out later that's not your real address," she said, "I'm going to send you to the closest school, understand?" The boy and his mother nodded happily and left.
Her next visitor, the Jamaican woman from California, was trying to get her 9-year-old son into third grade in P.S. 219, which was full. She said they were living nearby with a friend. The mother said she was homeless.
 
Homeless, With a Beeper
 "For a homeless person you look great," said Ms. Woodson, appraising her modish fluorescent mesh top and patterned leggings. Besides, she said, if she was living with her friend, she wasn't homeless.
Next Ms. Woodson asked if the mother could be reached by phone. Oh yes, she said: on her beeper.
"You have a beeper?" asked Mrs. Woodson, rolling her eyes.
"It's my girlfriend's beeper," the woman said hurriedly, "but I'm using it because I'm moving around."
Ms. Woodson said, "You're certainly making me earn my money today." She said she would admit the boy only if the mother returned within three months with documentation of her true residence.
"I have a direct telephone to God," said Ms. Woodson, who is about to retire to become a minister of the Reformed Church in America. "If He tells me it's true, I don't give you a hard time."

HEADLINE: With Day Care or Bonus, Hospitals Entice Hard-to-Find Workers

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
To 4-year-old Jenny Liu, the new day-care center at the Woodhull Hospital Center in Brooklyn is a place full of toys and books and playmates.
To her father, Zi Yang Liu, who is a laboratory technician at Woodhull, it is a safe, affordable child-care alternative that allows him to visit at noontime and take his daughter to the cafeteria for lunch. 
 To the hospital's administrators, the $140,000 center, which opened earlier this month, is a way to keep Mr. Liu and other employees in their jobs. Even in the recession there are positions that hospitals cannot fill, and financially struggling institutions have learned to be creative with the enticements they offer workers trained for such "hard to recruit" slots.
At Woodhull, for instance, priority at the day-care center is given to the children of nurses, occupational therapists, social workers, physician's assistants and a variety of other jobs with high vacancy rates.
 
Greater Demand for Care
 "We want to persuade them to work here," said Selena Griffin-Mahon, the associate director for human resources, "and, more important, once they're here we want to keep them. You're less likely to move your job if that means moving your child away from familiar day care, too."
The shortages, particularly of nurses, are being felt by hospitals nationwide, and nearly all are using similar methods to recruit and keep nurses and other professionals who are in short supply.
Studies have found that the shortage is a result of increased demand for nursing care, rather than a decrease in supply. The population of the United States is growing older and, therefore, sicker; the number of AIDS patients is rising, and medical technology can keep people alive longer. All these factors create a need for more health-care workers.
In New York City, the need for creativity in hospital recruitment is a lesson learned during the height of the nursing shortage in 1989, when as many as 30 percent of nursing jobs were vacant at some medical centers. Hospitals found themselves offering signing bonuses, subsidizing apartments, creating do-it-yourself work schedules and repaying employees' student loans.
And in recent months, hospitals have begun applying the methods of the nursing crisis to other professions where vacancies are growing. Across the city, 18 percent of occupational therapy jobs are vacant, as are 15 percent of respiratory therapy jobs, 16 percent of jobs for radiation therapy technicians and 11 percent of jobs for ultrasonographers, according to a survey in May by the Greater New York Hospital Association.
 
Effective Incentives
 The city's 11 financially strapped municipal hospitals have long been at a disadvantage in the benefits bazaar. The day-care center at Woodhull, for instance, is the first at any municipal hospital. In contrast, the hospital group's survey found that more than 20 percent of private hospitals and nursing homes in the area have on-site day care, though not all give preference to workers in hard-to-fill positions.
The nursing crisis showed that incentives can work. Across the city, the percentage of vacant nursing jobs was 18 percent in 1989; by the spring of 1992 the rate was 6 percent.
"It's much better than it was," said Thomas G. Doherty, vice-president of corporate affairs for the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which oversees the city's municipal hospitals. "We are still in need but it isn't a crisis."
There is evidence, however, that staffing at the public hospitals is worse than at private hospitals. The annual nursing turnover rate, for instance, is 17 percent at municipal hospitals, compared with 6.6 percent percent at the city's private hospitals.
 
Matching Private Hospitals
 One reason the municipal hospitals have more staffing problems is that they can offer fewer incentives to recruit and retain employees. Begining in 1988, the corporation began to match the nursing salaries at private hospitals, a response to the fact that nurses at municipal hospitals earned 15 percent less than their private counterparts. There is, however, no matching program for other employee salaries, which still lag.
The hospitals corporation has also tried to match other incentive programs, like subsidies for employees who wish to retrain for hard-to-fill jobs, and flexible scheduling options.
Nearly half of the city's private hospitals give a referral bonus to nurses who recruit other nurses. Two of the city's public hospitals -- Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx and Harlem Hospital in Manhattan -- give such bonuses, which amount to about $1,000, said Mary Gold, a corporation spokeswoman.
On the other hand, 14 percent of private hospitals give new employees a "signing bonus" of the kind -- though not the size -- that ballplayers often receive. Norman Katz, a spokesman for the hospitals corporation, said the municipal hospitals do not offer such bonuses.
About 30 percent of the private hospitals own apartments that their nurses can use, and half of those rent them at a subsidized rate. Ms. Gold said the only housing that the hospitals corporation provides are temporary quarters for nurses brought from overseas to relieve the shortage.
The corporation would like to provide incentive programs equal to those of the private hospitals, Ms. Gold said, but "everyone knows why we can't -- the money isn't there."
The feeling that their bag of enticements is smaller is one reason why Woodhull officials have such hopes for the new day-care center.
"This is important, and it's something not a lot of other places do," Ms. Griffin-Mahon said.
 
$120 a Week
 The $100,000 construction costs, she said, included a new entrance so children do not have to walk through wards to get to the playground, and one-way mirrors to allow parents to watch their children without interrupting their play. In addition, $40,000 was spent to equip and furnish the center with toys and decorations.
The fee for the center -- $120 a week for infants and toddlers, $95 a week for pre-schoolers -- will just cover the cost of the salaries of the six teachers and two teacher's aides, Ms. Griffin-Mahon said. And that is only if the 33 spaces are filled. At the moment, only five children are enrolled. Ms. Griffin-Mahon believes many employees are waiting until the center has been running for a time before enrolling their children.
Those who were among the first to sign up said the center does what hospital officials hoped -- it makes them feel better about Woodhull.
Mr. Liu, who has worked in the histology lab for three years, was paying $400 a month for child care before enrolling Jenny in the Woodhull center. His wife has a sales job in a department store and the couple would regularly struggle to pick Jenny up on time. Now he travels down an elevator and a hallway to get his daughter and he can drop in during the day, too.
"This is a good thing," said Mr. Liu. "Now it's a better place to work."

HEADLINE: Bills and Notes to Be Sold By U.S. Treasury This Week

 BODY:
Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill and note markets, beginning with today's regular auction of three- and six-month bills. Tomorrow, the agency will conduct a two-year note auction, followed on Wednesday by a five-year note auction.
By late in the day Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 2.86 percent, and on the six-month bill 2.89 percent. In when-issued trading, the new two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 3.86 percent, while the five-year note was at 5.41 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Revived Harper's Takes Its Next Step

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Harper's Magazine is feeling confident. Even flush.
Ten years ago, Harper's was losing almost $2.5 million a year. "Now we are balancing on the point of breaking even," the magazine's editor, Lewis H. Lapham, said. 
 Seizing the moment, the 142-year-old Harper's is introducing its first big change since the overhaul that brought the magazine back from near-death in 1984. Beginning with the October issue, it will publish a long essay or piece of fiction four times a year. Titled Harper's Folio, these pieces of up to 20,000 words will be printed on different-colored, heavier paper and separately bound into the middle of the magazine. It will enable Harper's to showcase writers and to offer its advertisers a premium position in the center spread.
 
Trying to Lure Advertisers
 The Folio section will provide a counterpoint to the shorter, snappier features that have characterized the magazine for the last eight years. It represents an investment of $150,000, with the hope, of course, that it will lure new readers and advertisers.
The first Folio piece, "Pafko at the Wall," is a novella by Don DeLillo. It takes place during the 1951 playoff game between the old Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Giants when Bobby Thomson clinched the pennant for the Giants with what is known as "the shot that was heard around the world." The game is attended by J. Edgar Hoover, Toots Shor, Frank Sinatra and Jackie Gleason, who sit together.
John R. MacArthur, president and publisher, called the new format that he and Mr. Lapham devised in 1984 an "unqualified success." The grand old general-interest magazine became faster-paced and wittier while continuing to publish essays and criticism, like its piece by Tom Wolfe on the state of American fiction.
Mr. MacArthur confirmed that Harper's is nearing the break-even point. In 1992, he said, the monthly magazine expects to lose $60,000 on revenues of $4.6 million.
 
Financing a Rescue
 That is a far cry from 1980 when the Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company, which then owned Harper's, decided to shut the magazine because it was losing so much money. Mr. MacArthur, then a young reporter at The Chicago Sun-Times, went to his father, J. Roderick MacArthur, and asked him to persuade the board of the family's MacArthur foundation to finance a rescue.
As a result, the Harper's Magazine Foundation was set up to acquire the magazine with a $3 million investment -- half of it from the John D. and Catherine MacArthur Foundation and half from the Atlantic Richfield Foundation. The magazine was able to continue publishing without missing an issue. Mr. Lapham, who had been the editor since 1976, was dismissed by the board in 1981 and brought back by Mr. MacArthur in 1983.
Determined to liven up the fusty periodical, which calls itself the oldest continuously published monthly, Mr. Lapham and Mr. MacArthur then introduced the highly successful Harper's Index, a puckish compilation of odd facts and statistics.
(Samples: Number of the 28 millionaires in the United States Senate who are Democrats: 21. Amount the Department of Defense will spend on softballs this year: $1 million. )
Another section introduced at the time was Readings, a selection of essays, letters, memos and writings from other publications. Compilations of the Index and two other new sections called Forum and Annotation have been published as books.
Not only did the shorter pieces turn out to appeal to younger readers, but the quality of the longer pieces also improved sharply.
"If you only publish one or two magazine pieces an issue, you can take the best," Mr. Lapham said. "Before that, I had had to publish 8 to 10 pieces of 2,000 to 3,000 words and that was unmanageable."
Mr. MacArthur has also pared the circulation, eliminating marginal readers.
In the mid-1980's, Harper's was sending out 2.7 million direct mailings a year, a very expensive way to acquire subscribers. This year Harper's will send out only 346,000 direct mailings because longtime readers are renewing at the relatively high rate of 78 percent, Mr. MacArthur said. And since 1984, the age of the average reader has dropped to 43 years old from 50.
David Verklin, senior vice president and corporate media director at Hal Riney & Partners, said his ad agency analyzed circulation in detail to determine how well a publication performed for its clients.
"The circulation of Harper's is very clean and very pure," said Mr. Verklin, who has placed ads in Harper's for the Saturn automobile. "And the more a magazine is reaching and appealing to its readers, the better for its advertisers."
 
Circulation Growth
 For the six-month period that ended June 30, Harper's reported a circulation of 202,076, virtually flat with the year before, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Still, this is an increase of about 80,000 since 1983, Mr. MacArthur said. The magazine's main competitor is The Atlantic, which has a circulation of 465,173.
Like most other magazines, Harper's has seen its advertising decline because of the recession. Ad pages are down 12.7 percent through August, as reported to the Publishers Information Bureau. The magazine derives 64 percent of its revenues from circulation and the rest from advertising.
Tom Benelli, associate media director for the Wunderman Cato Johnson agency, said he had placed ads for BASF and Baileys Irish Cream in the magazine because it "targets leaders and people concerned about issues and influence."
"It's just an editorial product that you don't get anywhere else," he said. "There is just not another publication like it."

SECTION: Section C; Page 11; Column 1; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 2812 words

HEADLINE: Shakespeare Festival Is on a Different Path Without Joseph Papp

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
As the New York Shakespeare Festival, for years the pre-eminent nonprofit theater in the United States, begins its first full season without its founder, Joseph Papp, who died on Oct. 31 last year, it is significantly different from the institution Mr. Papp presided over with ebullience in its glory days. In the last two years the staff has been cut in half, to 60 from 120, and the budget has been reduced by more than a third, to just under $10 million from $15 million.
The festival's stages at the Joseph Papp Public Theater on Lafayette Street, which in the theater's heyday saw the first performances of such celebrated works as "A Chorus Line," "The Normal Heart" and "That Championship Season," are increasingly being filled with a mix of films, literary readings, solo performances and community events. While plenty of plays are still being presented, a majority of the productions in the new season originated at regional theaters instead of at the Public. 
 In his 31 years of running the festival he founded, the legendary Mr. Papp produced more than 400 plays and musical works, which won 28 Tony Awards, 3 Pulitzer Prizes and nearly 100 Obies. Though anyone replacing him would doubtless become the focus of unflattering comparison, JoAnne Akalaitis, whom Mr. Papp named as his successor as artistic director in August 1991, has become a lightning rod for controversy. She has alienated some artists who have said she is difficult to work with, and she has made slighting remarks about subscription audiences, though the festival greatly needs to expand its subscriber base, currently 2,000, down from 3,500 two years ago. In comparison, the Roundabout Theater Company has 22,000 subscribers, and the Manhattan Theater Club has 15,000.
Ms. Akalaitis appears to be risking further wrath by omitting any work by Shakespeare in the coming season at the Public Theater, the first time in memory that he will not be represented there.
 
A Strong Defense
 For all of this, however, the Shakespeare Festival is strongly defended by partisans, both inside and out, who feel it is unfair to make judgments on the basis of one year without Mr. Papp. They say that Ms. Akalaitis, who is 55 years old, did well to mount a season at all in the face of severe budget cuts and the sense of drift that had pervaded the institution during Mr. Papp's long illness. Furthermore, even Mr. Papp had his good years and his bad years, and many theater people are suspending judgment on Ms. Akalaitis until she has had several seasons to a develop a record. (Ms. Akalaitis has a three-year contract that expires in the spring of 1994.)
They also point out that the festival won enthusiastic reviews for several productions last season and that Ms. Akalaitis tried to keep the building active with readings, film series, concerts and community events. Ms. Akalaitis commissioned 21 new plays in late August and two weeks later expanded the festival's group of theater artists in residence to 21 from 3. And if the new season at the Public includes no work of Shakespeare, they say, there are such eagerly anticipated productions as Tony Kushner's AIDS drama "Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes" and Jose Rivera's dark urban play, "Marisol."
Robin Wagner, the scenic designer of "Crazy for You," who has been on the festival's 25-member board since last year, said there was dissension on the board about the status of the festival, but "that's always what happens when a parent dies and the heir apparent takes over."
"Whatever disagreement there is," he said, "the feeling is that we must get behind JoAnne and this institution, and that the Public Theater must sail on."
Several theater executives praised Ms. Akalaitis's efforts. Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, said of her work last season, "I would definitely give JoAnne an A minus because she was not afraid to make the bold choice."
But others, while agreeing that Mr. Papp's shoes may be impossible to fill, assert that, as the playwright Larry Kramer said, "This doesn't mean you just have to settle for so much less." Mr. Kramer, the author of "The Normal Heart," the longest-running production at the Public, is among the most vocal of the festival's critics and one of the few writers, directors, producers and other theater people interviewed for this article who were willing to be quoted by name.
Although the Public's stages have been alive this month with work and sold-out audiences in the Puppetry at the Public series, this was hardly the case for much of last season. "I live in the neighborhood," Mr. Kramer said, "and you only had to walk by that empty building this season to feel a great sadness that all the vitality that Joe spent so many years creating there is completely dissipated. The place has been a ghost town."
 
The Finances
Staff and Budget Have Been Slashed
 While New York City owns the Shakespeare Festival's landmark theater complex, which last spring was renamed in honor of Mr. Papp, the city contributes less than 10 percent of the institution's budget. Its other public and private support has eroded so sharply that in July the festival was forced to let seven more people go and, three months earlier, requested an emergency donation of $200,000 from the city to put on its summer Shakespeare productions at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, says Barbara J. Fife, New York City's Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development. The city came through with the money.
For the first time since 1990, the festival will again receive money from the National Endowment for the Arts, estimated at $225,000 by Jason Steven Cohen, the festival's producing director. Two years ago Mr. Papp turned down a grant of more than $370,000 rather than agree to the endowment's "decency standard," which has since been struck down in Federal court.
In discussing its finances, Bernard Gersten, the executive producer of the Lincoln Center Theater, who worked with Mr. Papp from 1960 to 1978, said the biggest problem was that the festival "makes no economic sense and never did."
"It depends on successful shows like 'A Chorus Line' to pay the rent," he said. "And 'Chorus Line' is unlikely to be matched in a lifetime."
 
New Role for Board
 Officials of several other nonprofit theaters said they doubted the festival could succeed in the long run unless its board became more aggressive in raising money -- a matter that was left primarily to the persuasive Mr. Papp in the past -- and that Ms. Akalaitis had to lead the way. Larry E. Condon, the incoming chairman of the festival board, agreed. "The future now depends on a board that is actively engaged in a way it has not been in the past."
Ms. Akalaitis admitted that she did not have Mr. Papp's fund-raising charisma. "There is no way I can ever be like Joe, but I have my own way," she said, adding that she had been doing her own fund-raising but declining to give specifics. "But Joe said money follows the work, and it is all about the work."
The festival's S O S to the city particularly angered several other recession-starved nonprofit companies in New York because the festival also has a reserve fund, which Mr. Condon, the president of the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, puts at "$15 or $16 million," consisting mainly of profits left from "A Chorus Line," which earned $38.8 million before it closed in 1990 after a 15-year Broadway run. "It's a cushion we can rely on," Mr. Condon said. "But if we eat it up at $2 million a year, it would bail us out for six more years or so and then we'd be out of business."
Administrators at several other nonprofit theaters view the festival's comparatively large budget and the reserve fund with envy. And they say the festival should be making more of an impact. "Forget about their money," said the artistic director of another nonprofit company. "Wouldn't it be wonderful to have a couple of their darkened theaters?"
 
The Productions
Outside Talent Dominates Plays
 Last season the festival put on eight major productions, three of which received general critical praise: " 'Tis Pity She's a Whore," directed by Ms. Akalaitis; "Fires in the Mirror," Anna Deavere Smith's one-woman show, which was the smash hit of the festival's season, and "As You Like It." "Blood Wedding," directed by Melia Bensussen, received mixed reviews. "As You Like It," one of two free Shakespeare productions at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, drew consistently full houses despite a rainy summer, and some nights 1,000 would-be playgoers had to be turned away for lack of seats.
 
The Coming Season
 A majority of the plays scheduled this season at the Public are co-productions and plays brought in from other theaters. Mr. Kushner's "Angels in America," which is to open Feb. 2, comprises two full-length plays about AIDS, "Part 1: Millennium Approaches" and "Part 2: Perestroika." "Millennium Approaches" was staged this year at the Royal National Theater in London, to widespread acclaim; the Public is bringing in a different version, however, a co-production with the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles in association with New York Theater Workshop. It will have a run at the Taper before being seen at the Public. Mr. Rivera's "Marisol" has been produced in Louisville, Ky., and will play at the Hartford Stage in the winter before arriving at the Public in May.
Other scheduled productions include Steve Tesich's "On the Open Road," which has been staged at the Goodman Theater in Chicago; "Woyzeck" by Georg Buchner, which Ms. Akalaitis will direct; "Texts for Nothing," a one-man show constructed from texts by Samuel Beckett, to be directed by Joseph Chaikin and starring Bill Irwin, and Ann Magnuson's one-woman show "You Could Be Home Now," which the festival will co-produce with the Women's Project. In March, Ms. Akalaitis will direct "Prisoner of Love," a performance piece taken from the words of Jean Genet's last book about his experiences living with Palestinians and Black Panthers.
Puppetry at the Public, the popular and critically praised series that opened the new season on Sept. 7, was originated by the Jim Henson Foundation.
 
A 'Fact of Life'
 Mr. Wagner, the board member, defends the new schedule. "Co-productions are now a fact of life, and holding down costs, that's the major issue for all nonprofits right now," he said. "It's not a lack of leadership or new material. It's just simply hard to finance all these things."
Skeptics say some co-productions are more collaborative than others. A true co-production, said the director of another nonprofit theater, occurs when both companies have equal artistic involvement. This director said the Public was increasingly booking works conceived entirely by other theaters and putting its imprimatur on them.
By comparison, some of these critics point out that at Playwrights Horizons, which also had a change of leaders (Don Scardino replaced Andre Bishop as artistic director in January), only two of the six plays in the new season have been done in other theaters, and none are co-productions.
"The Public will never be a rental house," Ms. Akalaitis said. "But there is nothing wrong with renting out space if it can bring in great work." She said, "Joe also gave the theater to many other groups." Indeed, a few of Mr. Papp's successes came from other theaters, including "For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf."
Perhaps the most surprising aspect of the new season's schedule, though, is the absence of any work by Shakespeare at the Public, where 1,800 subscribers have paid to see the Shakespeare Marathon that began in 1987, when Mr. Papp promised to present all of Shakespeare. "I find that shocking," Mr. Kramer said, "because Joe believed that Shakespeare was more dear to him than anything in the world."
Ms. Akalaitis said that a planned production of "Timon of Athens" at the Public this winter had fallen through. "We love Shakespeare and my commitment to Shakespeare is as fervent as ever," said Ms. Akalaitis, who produced "Pericles" at the Public last season and two Shakespeare comedies in the Delacorte Theater over the summer. She promises more Shakespeare next summer, possibly "All's Well That Ends Well" and another play, and says that raising money for the summer will have a high priority.
Ms. Akalaitis's public style as artistic director became an issue at a symposium in June on "Critics and Criticism" in Cambridge, Mass. In discussing Mr. Papp's attempts to mount a subscription campaign two years ago, she told the symposium that this situation "made some directors, including myself, very miserable because we didn't like the subscription audiences."
"We didn't like them," she said, according to the transcript. "I mean, we felt, some of us felt, they didn't understand the work, that they were essentially dull people."
In an interview about her remarks, Ms. Akalaitis said that the quote was taken out of context, and she did clarify her remarks later in the symposium, saying, "I really believe in subscription," and adding, "I have been in theaters where I've been inspired by the response of a subscription audience."
 
The Outlook
With a New Vision Comes Criticism
 The creative success of the festival under Mr. Papp derived from his often stormy but highly productive relationships with playwrights and directors, whose contributions he often emphasized.
Board members like Mr. Wagner feel "that JoAnne has worked hard to create an ambiance of creativity at the theater," he said. But some playwrights don't see it that way. "She may be very genuinely trying to find plays, but it's not something you do from Monday to Tuesday," said Albert Innaurato, whose "Coming of Age in SoHo" was produced by Mr. Papp in 1985. "New work comes from longstanding relationships."
Ms. Akalaitis presided over a rambling invitational meeting for playwrights last fall at the Public, remembered most for its confusion and for the walkout of Jon Robin Baitz, the author of "The Substance of Fire." He was reported to have said he didn't want to belong to a writing community, adding, "I write alone."
"I suppose it was a gesture toward the so-called creative community, but it didn't seem terribly effective," Mr. Innaurato said of the meeting. "She's worked a lot with classical plays, but I have a sense that working with playwrights is not what she does, that she doesn't know playwrights and their reality."
Ms. Akalaitis denied this and in late August commissioned 21 new plays and adaptations from playwrights ranging from Connie Congdon ("Casanova") to Jose Rivera ("Marisol"), spending from $500 to $10,000 for individual plays, she said. "We hope that this will lead to new work, workshops and plays that will pay off during the next two years," she said.
Early this month, Ms. Akalaitis expanded the festival's group of "artistic associates" to 21 from 3. They include writer-performers like Eric Bogosian and Anna Deavere Smith, the playwrights Craig Lucas and Ms. Congdon, and the directors Robert Woodruff and Melia Bensussen, as well as costume and lighting designers. "They will be gadflies, scouts, philosophers and project directors who will be loosely in residence," Ms. Akalaitis said.
These associates will receive "varying degrees of compensation," she said, ranging from full health insurance, to travel stipends, to the use of a telephone. The total budget for the associates program, she said, is $100,000. Different artists will have different contracts with the festival under the loosely structured arrangement, and some of the associates will have an artistic base at other theaters, like Mr. Lucas, who is a member of the Circle Repertory Company and will continue to create work for that group.
 
A Question of Manner
 Though Ms. Akalaitis said her goal was to reach out to talented theater people, there are some who say her manner, which they describe as distant, may hinder that effort. "No one disputes that JoAnne has taste or says she's unskilled as a director," Mr. Kramer said. "But she does not radiate friendship in any way. I can't tell you how many people don't want to work there."
Mr. Papp was known to engage in high-decibel arguments with some of his theatrical collaborators, and they continued to work with him. And such defenders of Ms. Akalaitis's as Mr. Landesman say, in fact, that rapport with artists is a strong suit because of her work as a director.
For her part, Ms. Akalaitis commented: "I'm portrayed as this naughty person. But I feel I have terrific relations with the theater community and with the staff." She said she hoped that her work, in conjunction with the theater's new artistic associates and the newly commissioned plays, "will speak for itself."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Ad Campaign;
Clinton: Criticizing the President

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
 The only picture of Mr. Clinton is a small photo of him grinning at the end of the ad.
TELEVISION SCRIPT -- Narrator: "1988."
Bush: "30 million jobs in the next eight years."
Narrator: "1990. America's jobless rate hits a three-year high."
Bush: "I'm not prepared to say we are in recession.
Narrator: "March 1992. Jobless rate hits six-year high."
Bush: "The economy is strengthening."
Narrator: "George Bush vetoes unemployment compensation."
Bush: "The economy continues to grow."
Narrator: "July 1992. Unemployment is the highest in eight years.
"If George Bush doesn't understand the problem, How can he solve it? We can't afford four more years."
ACCURACY -- The statements are accurate, but the ad juxtaposes images of Mr. Bush with events that are not directly related in time to what he is saying. For example, Mr. Bush is shown on Nov. 8, 1991, saying the nation is not in a recession, and the next image is words saying the jobless rate hit a six-year high in March 1992. The Bush campaign accuses the Clinton organization of exploiting the hardship of Americans in the ad.
SCORECARD -- In its first negative commercial, the Clinton campaign seeks to avoid being accused of gutter tactics by letting the President hang himself with his own words. The topic is the one that polls show is foremost on the minds of voters: the economy. The Clinton forces are trying to steer the debate in that direction.
 
On the Economy
ON THE SCREEN -- Mr. Clinton at a desk in shirt sleeves, tie loose, American flag and old-fashioned radio behind him. Throughout the commercial, the camera cuts from Mr. Clinton talking about his economic prescriptions to words bolstering his remarks: "Income is down," "Higher unemployment," and "What it takes: New Jobs . . . Cut health care costs . . ."
TELEVISION SCRIPT -- Mr. Clinton: "We've been under trickle down economics for 12 years -- just keep taxes low on the wealthy and see what happens. Well, I'll tell you what happens. Most Americans are working harder for less money, unemployment's up, health care costs are exploding, we are not doing what it takes to compete and win.
"I've worked hard on a different plan. Let's give incentives to invest in new jobs. Let's spend more on education and training. Let's provide basic health care to all Americans. Putting our people first. Rebuilding this economy. Making us competitive. If we do those things, we'll compete and win. And we'll bring this country back."
ACCURACY -- There are no factual inaccuracies, although Mr. Clinton's assertion that "we'll compete and win" is, of course, speculative. Republicans argue that the tax burden of Mr. Clinton's programs would ultimately fall on everyone, not just the wealthy, who the Governor says are not paying their fair share.
SCORECARD -- The two new Clinton ads complement each other, one criticizing Mr. Bush, the other portraying Mr. Clinton as the more capable. In once again inviting viewers to call an (800) number to obtain a copy of its proposals, the Clinton organization seeks to give the impression it has a meaty, workable plan.

HEADLINE: Don't Blame the Owl

 BODY:
The northern spotted owl -- once described by President Bush as "that little furry-feathery guy" -- is not a particularly popular little guy among timber workers in the Pacific Northwest. Listed as an endangered species in 1990, the owl triggered a series of court cases that halted logging in millions of acres of old-growth forests.
Timber workers are furious. They also vote. Which is why Mr. Bush went to Washington State last week and pledged to mend the Endangered Species Act to give "greater consideration to jobs, families and communities." It is time, he declared, "to put people ahead of owls." 
 Reasonable people may disagree on whether the Endangered Species Act, one of the nation's toughest environmental laws, gives sufficient weight to the economic costs of preserving biodiversity. But to suggest to frightened loggers that changing the act and sacrificing the owl will save their jobs for very long is disingenuous.
The logging industry is undergoing such radical changes that further clear-cutting can only be a stopgap remedy. Mr. Bush correctly noted, for example, that many milling jobs are lost because raw logs are exported to Japan, not sent to local mills.
There are two other powerful forces he did not mention. One is a major shift in investment capital to the South by the big timber companies. The other is automation. In short, business decisions and market forces have done far more to undermine the workers than the owl.
Blaming the owl trivializes the environmental stakes and diverts attention from the Administration's failures. The issue is not just the owl but the owl's habitat -- magnificent old-growth forests that environmentalists wish to save for future generations and loggers wish to cut for today's generation.
Yet the Administration has done virtually nothing to devise a sensible protection plan for the owl, as mandated by the act. Nor has it proposed measures to retrain displaced workers or help distressed communities. With a concerted effort, the Administration might conceivably save most of the forest and more than a few jobs. But nobody, including Congress, seems to have the stomach for such a task in a political year.
The old-growth forests could disappear completely in 15 years if cutting resumed at pre-1990 levels. What would happen to the loggers then? And what would happen to tourism and recreation -- industries that can create sustainable jobs as long as the forests last?
These questions require a political perspective that extends beyond Election Day. To his credit, Governor Clinton has talked, albeit vaguely, about a government-business partnership to reconcile environmental and economic needs. For Mr. Bush, who campaigned in the Pacific Northwest four years ago as the next "environment President," the answer is much simpler: get on with the cutting.
That approach will sacrifice not just the "little furry-feathery guy" but an extraordinary environmental resource with its own job potential.
