HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Two Faces of George

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Have we ever had two political campaigns so different in style and content? I mean the two campaigns being waged by George Bush.
In one there is the President, reassuring authority figure, reaching out to all Americans, promising to help them in their economic distress. This campaign, positive in tone, offers an "Agenda for American Renewal." 
 In the other there is Pork Rind George, knee-fighter and scourge of un-American values. This campaign, entirely negative, attacks Bill Clinton as a dangerous leftist in the grip of alien ideology.
The negative campaign began in Houston. The convention there featured speakers from the paranoid right, such as Pat Robertson. (He has called George Bush's "new world order" a plan plotted by Satan, but that didn't keep him off the speakers' list.) The convention theme was attacks on "the other" -- working women, gays, the unwed, the un-Christian.
Mr. Bush embraced the extreme right in Houston in order to secure his base among conservatives, especially the increasingly powerful Christian right. He also had a particular strategic purpose: to shore up his support in the South.
When James Baker took over the Bush re-election drive this month, he changed direction. The convention attacks on Hillary Clinton and others, and the general tone of hate, had repelled many Americans. And Mr. Baker understood that to win Mr. Bush had to target voters at the center of the political spectrum.
Accordingly, some of the most strident messages from the convention were toned down. Vice President Quayle, the inventor of "family values," announced that his grandmother had been a single mother and his sister was divorced. He and Mr. Bush seemed to back away from the platform's demand that all abortions be made criminal, even when the pregnancy resulted from rape or incest.
President Bush had been scheduled for weeks to go down to Virginia Beach, Va., and speak to a meeting of Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition. But reading the polls, Mr. Baker decided that dramatizing the Bush-Robertson connection would be bad news.
The solution was to have Mr. Bush speak to the Robertson meeting at 7:40 P.M. on a Friday night, Sept. 11, after the last television network news broadcast. And Mr. Baker rushed through plans for sale of F-15 jets to Saudi Arabia so the President could announce them to a crowd of airplane workers earlier in the day, dominating the news.
The jet sale reflected another aspect of the new, positive campaign: George Bush as Santa Claus. He announced so many sudden benefits that a Lorenz cartoon in The New Yorker showed a woman opening a letter and telling her husband: "My goodness! It's a check from George Bush for $150,000 to fix the screen door."
But Jim Baker has evidently decided that the positive campaign is not working well enough.
In Enid, Okla., last week Mr. Bush said Governor Clinton believed in "social engineering" and an "elite central government." Those were old European ideas, Mr. Bush said, and Mr. Clinton was for them because "he and a number of his advisers studied them at Oxford in the 1960's."
Why did President Bush go in for such crude nativism? Because he is running behind in the South, and even in Oklahoma, and because the latest Baker strategy is to smear Governor Clinton.
A Bush campaign official, asked by John Aloysius Farrell of The Boston Globe why they were so interested in Mr. Clinton's time as a Rhodes Scholar, said jokingly, "You mean Red Willie?" It was not a joke when Floyd Brown, who put out the supposedly "independent" Willie Horton advertising in 1988, wrote last week that Bill Clinton's opposition to the Vietnam War while he was at Oxford was "under the aegis and support of one of the most notorious Communist front organizations in Europe."
Surrogates are doing much of the dirty work in the negative campaign. Newt Gingrich says that the Democrats have Woody Allen's family values; the Bush people disavow the crack, but the sting remains.
Watch the target, and you can tell which Bush campaign it is. There is one for the North and one for the South, one for the center and one for the right.

HEADLINE: Don't Confuse China Trade and Human Rights

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"One-Fisted Strength on China" (editorial, Aug. 29) is right to state that the Bush Administration has been soft on human rights issues in China. However, I would suggest that it is better not to use the same weapon to fight two different battles: promoting free trade and improving human rights in China. 
 The United States, by threatening to impose retaliatory tariffs and pressure for freer trade relations with its trading partner, is likely to achieve its goal, an outcome beneficial for both countries. However, pressuring for human rights by using tariff penalties will not work.
Under United States pressure for a more open market, China is likely to yield. Last year, China made a concession to United States pressure in a trade conflict over intellectual property rights. Taiwan and Hong Kong business groups played a role in defusing the conflict because they are joint venturers in many of China's exports, particularly in the southern part of China. They and other private sector groups persuaded the Chinese Government not to confront the United States publicly on trade. Their interests and efforts apparently influenced the negotiation.
Moreover, pressing China to open its market will help its fast-growing private sector further integrate into the world market. The more China's economy is integrated into the world economy, the more likely its reform will succeed. Therefore the reformers will benefit by increased foreign competition in China.
Although the United States has vast trade leverage with China, when the tariff weapon is applied to human rights, the directly affected groups, such as political prisoners and others sympathetic to politically repressed people in China, will not have much leverage in changing Government policy. Business groups from overseas and domestic reformers will not have much influence if China decides to stand up against the United States on this issue.
A penalty would hurt China's export sector, which is closely linked to the economic and political power bases of the reformers. Therefore, threatening with a protectionist tariff is a wrong weapon in the human rights fight. It would hurt reformers much more than some symbolic gains, if any. We need a different fist to create pressure for better human rights in China.
 
CHI-CHU CHOU
 Asst. Prof., Economics, Rutgers U.
 Newark, Sept. 1, 1992

HEADLINE: Don't Confuse China Trade and Human Rights;
Next Prime Minister?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Aug. 25 Beijing Journal on China's new economic strongman, Zhu Rongji, is illuminating. While Mr. Zhu's replacement of Li Peng as China's Prime Minister requires the final approval of the Chinese Communist Party's 14th Party Congress, recent developments in China suggest this appointment is imminent. 
 Last June 11, the State Council established the Economic and Trade Office, with Mr. Zhu as director. This organization has been authorized to take broad charge of production and circulation affairs. It will soon become the State Commission on Economics and Trade, the No. 1 superministry, surpassing the State Planning Commission.
Last July 24, the State Council inaugurated a 54-article regulation on the transfer of management mechanism for the State Industrial Enterprises. The regulation, generally considered the most innovative plan in recent years, provides concrete procedures for transferring the Chinese economy from a Stalinist central planning system to a market-oriented system. Mr. Zhu supervised the drafting.
In mid-August, information gathered from Beijing by Taiwan's newspapers showed the new set-up of leadership agreed to by Deng Xiaoping and his octogenarian comrades. Mr. Zhu was reportedly selected as the new Prime Minister to replace Li Peng, who will become chairman. The new standing committee of the party political bureau will be composed of seven members: Jiang Zemin, Qiao Shi, Li Peng, Zhu Rongji, Li Ruihuan, Tian Jiyun and Li Tieying, with Yang Beibing replacing his brother Yang Shangkun as first vice chairman of the party's central military committee.
While Mr. Zhu's role as the new champion of Mr. Deng's reform seems definite, he has nevertheless encountered numerous hurdles, notably the resistance of the bureaucracy. As China's bureaucracy has reached a staggering figure of 31 million, the change of state enterprise management would deprive power to millions of officials whose economic interests may be adversely affected. Mr. Zhu must overcome resistance from this group to implement the regulation.
Equally important are 30 million superfluous employees in state enterprises and 23 million retirees, whose subsistence depends on support from the state enterprises. Eradicating this enormous burden is another thorny task. Mr. Zhu's solution is to develop tertiary industry (service) by allowing state enterprises to diversify their operations.
As you point out, one of Mr. Zhu's great strengths is his willingness to accept criticism, a sign of self-confidence. In a private audience in Zhongnanhai in mid-July, he not only listened patiently to my blunt criticisms of China's state enterprises and price reform, but he also sincerely sought follow-up comments.
Should Zhu Rongji become the Prime Minister, China may be able to break the zigzag pattern of economic reform of the last decade and accelerate the pace of economic transformation.
 
CHU-YUAN CHENG
Prof. of Economics & Chmn., Asian
Studies Committee, Ball State U.
Muncie, Ind., Sept. 2, 1992

HEADLINE: Diamond Industry Loses Little Luster

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Sept. 4 Business Day article on the American diamond industry and New York City's 47th Street diamond district paints an incomplete portrait. The industry, like virtually every other, has been hit by the recession. But Department of Commerce data do not support your assertion that "sullen economic times have treated few industries as meanly." 
 While there are fewer cutters and workers in the diamond district than a decade ago, this is due less to the economic slowdown than to a shift in manufacturing pattern: we are no longer cutting large quantities of smaller sized goods, but smaller quantities of larger and better stones.
The American diamond industry remains strong, certainly compared with other industries affected by the recession. Last year, American diamond industry exports exceeded $1 billion for the fourth straight year.
We believe that rents have dropped far less on 47th Street than in many, if not most, other sections of New York City.
 
LLOYD JAFFE
Chairman
American Diamond Industry Assn.
New York, Sept. 9, 1992

HEADLINE: Regulations March On, Despite a Moratorium

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
After more than seven months, the moratorium that George Bush imposed on most new Federal regulations has had little visible effect in reversing the sharp growth of regulation during the first three years of his Presidency, many policy analysts say.
At the same time, however, both supporters and critics of the moratorium contend that it has helped chill the regulatory climate, particularly involving rules covering the environment, where much current attention is focused. 
 "I'm not sure the concrete results are there just yet," said Phillip Mink, general counsel for Citizens for a Sound Economy, a conservative-oriented group seeking a rollback in the Federal regulatory presence, which now employs a record 125,000 people in drafting and enforcement. "But it's still a very sound concept. What it needs is significant long-term execution."
The moratorium, which was initially for 90 days and subsequently extended for 120 days, is now scheduled to remain in place until August 1993, assuming Mr. Bush's re-election.
 
 
Federal Register's Growth
 One measure of the extent of regulatory growth is the number of pages found each year in the Federal Register, in which Government rules are published. In 1988, before Mr. Bush took office, there were 53,376 pages. By 1991, there were 67,716, the third- highest total. By Sept. 1, 40,070 pages had been published for 1992, compared with 43,687 at that time last year.
The Administration's Council on Competitiveness, headed by Vice President Dan Quayle, now estimates that 1992 savings will total $35 billion. The council disputes those who contend that headway has been harder to achieve than officials expected, thereby forcing them to give the issue less political prominence.
"The regulatory moratorium has been a huge success by any estimate," said Jeff Nesbit, a spokesman for the Vice President.
He said nearly 1,000 regulations have been reviewed -- perhaps three-quarters of those in the pipeline when the moratorium began in late January -- and that in about 300 of these cases there has been at least some favorable result.
A vast majority of cases, Mr. Nesbit said, have involved pro-growth or deregulation measures, some of which have been amended to make them even more so.
The rest were suspended indefinitely, withdrawn or returned to the agency proposing them for further work.
This latter group consists of "dozens of obsolete regulations that have been desexed forever," Mr. Nesbit said.
 
No Specific Examples
 But when asked for specific examples, Mr. Nesbit said he could not point to any since departments and agencies are generally unwilling to provide lists of such actions because they often harbor "some hope" of one day reviving the rules, Mr. Nesbit said.
Public Citizen, a group associated with Ralph Nader that is one of the Administration's severest regulatory critics, charged recently that the moratorium has been used to hold up regulations improperly. The White House specified that the moratorium would not apply to rules developed under statutory or judicial deadlines or those that involved "imminent danger" to human safety or health.
The moratorium "is costing the nation dearly in human life and a damaged environment," the group, along with an executive-branch monitor called O.M.B. Watch, asserted. "Dozens of crucial public health and environmental safeguards have fallen under the guillotine." As examples, they pointed to the issues of food labeling and protecting workers from toxic chemicals.
Even so, the groups called the Administration's cost savings of up to $20 billion "pure voodoo accounting."
Quite apart from differing interpretations of what can be legitimately deferred, the near-term impact of the moratorium is hard to measure because, unlike budgetary matters, there is no real yardstick, no way of telling what would have happened without it.
 
 
'No Regulatory Baseline'
 "I don't think you can tell" what effect the moratorium is having, declared William Niskanen, head of the Cato Institute and once an official in the Reagan Administration. "There's no regulatory baseline."
Conservative hopes are tempered by the fact that Mr. Bush has presided over a substantial expansion of Government regulation, signing among other things the Clean Air Act amendments and Americans With Disabilities Act, both of which required extensive rule-writing.
It is generally agreed that it is harder to undo a measure than to prevent it from becoming law in the first place.
Moreover, noted William G. Laffer 3d, a regulatory specialist for the Heritage Foundation, and other analysts, Mr. Bush has himself appointed some regulation-minded officials, in particular William Reilly at the Environmental Protection Agency and David Kessler at the Food and Drug Administration.
Doubts about the Bush Administration's commitment are also fueled by the fact that it has failed to install anyone to head the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, the body in charge of reviewing rules and other paperwork. With its only candidate failing to win Senate confirmation, the post has been in the hands of an acting chief since late 1989.
The 60-day moratorium imposed by President Reagan in 1981 provided few lessons since it was aimed at preventing a host of last-minute Carter Administration rules from taking effect. Mr. Bush, by contrast, seeks to counter his own handiwork.
In many eyes, the main virtue of the Bush moratorium is that in addition to deferring new rules, the departments and agencies are instructed to review all existing ones with the goal of perhaps abolishing those failing the cost-benefit test.
In a recent report on the broad sweep of regulatory reform since the mid-1970's, Mr. Quayle's office held that some changes had been counterproductive, citing as a notable example the 1986 expansion of Government insurance on bank deposits to $100,000 for each account from $40,000. Many believe that by exposing itself to greater risk, the Government contributed to the financial havoc among savings and loan institutions in the late 1980's, requiring a huge Federal bailout.
The report mentioned transportation, energy, telecommunications and financial services for particular attention during a second Bush term.

HEADLINE: Trading Set in U.S. Mutual Fund With an Israeli Portfolio

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The first American mutual fund invested in Israeli companies is scheduled to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange next month.
Seventy percent of the First Israel Fund Inc. will be invested in publicly traded securities on the Tel Aviv stock exchange, according to Ze'ev Holtzman, director of Giza, one of two Israeli companies acting as advisers to the United States managing firm, BEA Associates. Analyst, Israel's largest managing firm for private funds, is the other adviser. 
 The remaining 30 percent of the fund will be invested in higher-risk unlisted private companies, particularly those in high-technology fields, Mr. Holtzman said.
Merrill Lynch, Prudential Securities and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette will serve as underwriters.
Mr. Holtzman said the fund planned to raise $60 million to $100 million. That would be welcome news for an Israeli financial community long starved for investments from foreigners, who have been wary because of Israel's war-torn past.
But recent political and economic events, including the energetic approach to the peace process by Israel's new Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, have raised confidence in the market and prompted sponsors to go ahead with the fund. Original plans to float it in 1990 were canceled when Iraq invaded Kuwait.
Much of the rising interest in the market here can be traced to the privatization policy begun by the previous Likud Government, including changes in currency laws and tax rulings favorable to foreign investors.
 
Loan Guarantee a Factor
 Also a factor was President Bush's granting Israel $10 billion in loan guarantees for absorbing new immigrants from the former Soviet Union. This could help lower the unemployment rate, now about 11 percent.
The volatile Tel Aviv stock exchange rose 65 percent last year and the injection of tens of millions of dollars of capital through the new fund could have a considerable impact. The market had a capitalization of $24.9 billion in August, but only about $7.5 billion was regularly traded on the exchange.
About 70 percent of the 360 companies on the exchange are held by majority shareholders, which accounts for the large difference between the market's overall capitalization and the scope of the trading.
Mr. Ross of the Tel Aviv stock exchange acknowleged that the Israeli economy was not well understood abroad. But he and others pointed to a huge increase in visits by potential investors lately.
"Getting in now is getting in on the ground floor," said Mark Meiras of Pacific Mediterranean Investments.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yankees Make First Of Their Many Lists

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
The Yankee hierarchy spent most of yesterday in Tampa, Fla., debating the future. The National League's expansion draft was the topic, and the executives exchanged lists touting the 15 players they deemed most desirable for the organization to protect.
Because the Yankees have one of the deepest farm systems in the major leagues, yesterday's dialogue was sure to be laced with dissenting opinions. Both major and minor league players can be chosen in the expansion draft. The arguing among the Yanks will likely continue and the names will likely change until the club submits its final list before Nov. 17, the day of the draft. 
 Eight A.L. teams will lose three players apiece, and six will surrender two each to the Colorado Rockies and Florida Marlins. The minor league rich Yankees are almost assured of waving goodbye to three players.
After the Yankees lose a player in the first round of the three-round draft, they will add four players to their protected list, one more than National League teams can. When a second player is chosen, they will protect four more.
 
'We Have to Lose Some'
 "There is no such thing as a perfect list," said Manager Buck Showalter. "We are probably going to lose one or two players who someone in the organization did not want to lose. But we have to lose some. There is no way to prevent it."
Because they are not expected to contend next season, the Yankees will probably choose to sacrifice a bona fide major leaguer like Randy Velarde or John Habyan rather than lose a future talent like third baseman Russ Davis (.285, 22 homers and 71 runs batted in for Class AA Albany) or pitcher Mark Hutton (13-7, 3.57 e.r.a. at Albany).
It is a sound philosophy because the Yankees already know what a Velarde or Habyan can achieve, but they would be perturbed if a minor leaguer slipped away and became a .300 hitter or 20-game winner.
Employing this approach, the Yankees would have a safety net. For example, if they lost Habyan, they would be able to add Rich Monteleone to the protected list for the next round so they would not lose two right-handed relievers. If they lost Velarde, they would then protect utilityman Andy Stankiewicz.
"This is extremely important for the future of the Yankees," Joseph Molloy, the managing partner, said recently. "You could lose a player and have it affect the team for years."
The Yankees will likely take a slight gamble by not protecting Danny Tartabull, their leading run producer. Eight months after they signed him to a five-year, $25.5 million contract, the Yanks seem certain to leave him off the protected list because they claim his price tag will frighten the new teams, who inherit existing contracts of their players.
 
Unahppy With Tartabull
 But there could be more to the Tartabull scenario than what the Yankees concede publicly. Despite his 23 homers and 80 r.b.i., there are team officials who are irritated by Tartabull's chronic injuries and who would prefer to see the Marlins or Rockies snatch away what they consider a $5.1 million-a-year headache.
How disastrous would it be for the Yankees to lose their marquee free agent after one season? They could sway any negative feelings by grabbing the $20 million they save, add another $10 million or so and and put on the full-court press to sign Barry Bonds. Does that sound like a George Steinbrenner design to anyone?
Tartabull has heard that the Marlins might be interested in him because he was born in Miami, but the talk doesn't bothered him.
"They're doing it from a business standpoint," he said. "It doesn't have anything to do with me."
Other notables not likely to be on the protected list are Matt Nokes, the bewildered catcher with decent power but a $5 million contract over the next two years; Kevin Maas, whose homer potential is attractive, but whose erratic defense is not; Steve Farr, the dependable 35-year-old closer whose economical $1.1 million salary next season could land him a new address, and Mike Gallego, the Yankees' other 1992 free agent.
 
Taylor Is Safe
 Brien Taylor, the fastball prospect and former No. 1 draft choice, is exempt from the draft because he has no major league experience and fewer than three years in the minors.
Each Yankee official is known to have about 10 "locks" on his list, but the last five choices are what will cause the lengthy squabbles. Ideally, the Yankees would not mind losing the Class AAA standouts Hensley Meulens (26 homers, 100 r.b.i.) and Jeff Johnson (2-1, 2.17 e.r.a.) because there are no spots for them in New York.

HEADLINE: Forward With Europe

 BODY:
For Americans, the news from France is close but clear. European unity lives, and that is in the best interests of the United States, the 12 members of the European Community and global trade. France's 51-to-49 percent "yes" vote on the Maastricht treaty does not guarantee ultimate triumph. But it averts what could have become a slide into nationalist discord.
The road ahead is pitted with rocks and craters: the thinness of the margin, monetary tension and skepticism in countries that have yet to vote. Community leaders will have to find ways to make rolling reassessments. Yet for the moment they can keep rolling forward. 
 France's referendum on the Maastricht treaty started out as a judgment on debatable details of monetary and political union. By the time of the vote on Sunday it had become a test of the viability of the European Community. Now, with Europe's narrow victory, attention quickly turns to the next set of obstacles, and the next.
The most difficult is how to respond to last week's currency crisis. Fixed exchange rates could not forever bridge the gulf of divergent national goals. The system unraveled because Germany refused to compromise its low-inflation policy for the sake of its partners. Unless Europe's governments are now prepared to sacrifice domestic goals for the sake of wider harmony, plans for a single European currency in this decade will have to be scaled back.
Communism's collapse in East Germany helped detonate the monetary crisis. Communism's collapse elsewhere in Europe demands new trade links, coordination on refugees and a workable collective security system. Europe needs to overcome the apathy, appeasement and obsolete imperial rivalries that have doomed its approach to Yugoslavia. And it needs to relieve Germany of its disproportionate refugee burden.
Eight Community members, including Denmark, still have to ratify the treaty before it can go into effect. That will require addressing grass-roots misgivings about, for instance, loss of sovereignty. Undoing Denmark's negative vote will also require some substantive change.
The close call in France highlights the need for wider citizen involvement in shaping a new Europe. People complain about "Brussels bureaucrats." But that's an oversimplification. Without Brussels functionaries to standardize the rules, there could be no Common Market. The problem does not lie with the bureaucrats but with the elected leaders who negotiated the treaty and arrogantly took their constituents for granted.
As the ratification process moves forward, those leaders, now chastened, will have to make midcourse adjustments on the way to a unified Europe, a reassured America and a more prosperous world.

HEADLINE: Boy, 15, Is Fatally Stabbed at School in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
A 15-year-old sophomore and varsity football star at South Shore High School in Brooklyn was fatally stabbed yesterday by a classmate wielding a dagger in a hallway fight, the police said. Moments later, a dean and a security guard at the school seized and disarmed a 16-year-old suspect.
The victim, Damion Ennis, of 670 East 82d Street, Brooklyn, was stabbed once in the chest at 1:35 P.M. in a struggle that spilled from a third-floor hallway into a stairwell of the sprawling, white-brick school at 6565 Flatlands Avenue in Canarsie, the police said. He died an hour later at Brookdale Hospital. 
 The police said the suspect, Michael Bubb, of 412 East 93d Street, Brooklyn, was charged as an adult with second-degree murder and possession of a deadly weapon. Detectives said they did not know the cause of the fight, but that the 7 1/2-inch dagger used in the stabbing "most likely" belonged to the suspect.
The slaying -- the first in the academic year that began two weeks ago in a school system that saw three students killed in the 1991-92 year, all at Thomas Jefferson High in Brooklyn -- occurred in a high school that the Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, yesterday called "one of the most stable in the entire school system."
School officials said South Shore High -- with 3,200 students whose racial balance of whites and blacks in almost equal numbers has changed little in recent years -- had relatively high reading and Regents' examination scores and no recent record of violence: only 40 of the school system's 4,952 reported "incidents" occurred there last year.
Because South Shore High was regarded as relatively safe, it was not one of the 40 high schools that are either now, or soon to be, equipped with metal detectors, a program intended to stem the tide of weapons that flow daily in and out of the schools. Some students at South Shore said, however, that many students there carried knives.
A student at the school, Louis Brown, 16, said that before the slaying yesterday, he saw Michael Bubb draw a knife on someone other than Damion Ennis. "I saw him pull a knife on a student in class earlier this day," the student said. "He pulled it out and threatened him, and the kid ran out of the classroom."
 
'He's Not a Fighter'
 But the suspect's mother, Gracelyn Harris, said the police had told her that Damion had attacked her son with a knife, and that her son had wrested the weapon away and stabbed the other boy in self-defense. "He's not a fighter," she said of her son, recalling that he had been beaten up by another teen-ager last year. "He's very nice, very sweet."
The victim and the suspect both were members of families that had migrated to New York from the Caribbean. Neither had a criminal record, according to the police, and school officials said both had learning disabilities and were enrolled in special education classes.
The slaying stunned the families of the victim and the suspect, as well as the students, faculty members and administrators at South Shore High, a four-story school built in 1971.
"He wasn't doing anything bad and he was a good kid," said Damion Ennis's mother, Joyce Smith, 34, an unemployed nurse's aide, who brought her son to New York from Kingston, Jamaica, three years ago. She said he had attended a football camp in Pennsylvania over the summer. "He played real good," she said.
The South Shore High football coach, Marty Senall, called Damion "a fine young man who had tremendous potential in football, as a student and as a human being." He said Damion played fullback on offense and nose guard on defense and had scored his team's first touchdown of the season in a 38-14 loss to Curtis High School last Saturday.
 
Called Quick to Anger
 Friends said Damion also was a member of the Down Low Posse, a group of students and neighborhood youths. "The posse is a family that looks out for each other," said Abel Etienne, 20, a member and former South Shore student. "We are not a gang. You can be in school and have respect. We deal with strictly positive vibes." The police said they knew nothing about the group.
Acquaintances of Michael Bubb said he had come to New York from Grenada two years ago and had been a second-string goalkeeper on the school soccer team last year. They called him a temperamental youth who teased others, but was quick to anger. But a 14-year-old girl said he was "nice" and "a friend," and was not known to carry a knife.
His mother, who said she works 70 hours a week at two jobs to raise five children, said Michael, the oldest of her four boys, was a stay-at-home who did not hang out with young toughs. "I have to run him from my bedroom," Mrs. Harris sobbed. "He's always on my shoulder. He always has girls calling him here. He never had boys around."
The nature of the dispute was not immediately determined, but investigators said the two youths knew each other.
Detective Capt. Richard Ward, commander of the 12th Division of Brooklyn South detectives, said the fight began in a third-floor hallway immediately after a seventh-period class, which ended at 1:30 P.M.
As other students ran for help, he said, the struggle spilled into a stairwell near the rotunda, Michael got Damion in a headlock with his left arm and, with his right, stabbed the youth once in the left side of the chest.
As Damion fell wounded and the assailant moved away, Neil Rosen, the school's dean of special education, who had been summoned by witnesses, ran up with a security guard. "It was a matter of seconds before Mr. Rosen entered the stairwell," Captain Ward said, "but it was too late."
The security guard disarmed and handcuffed Michael. Some students said it took a long time for medical aid to arrive, but the Emergency Medical Service said an ambulance was called at 1:39 P.M., arrived at 1:44 and rushed the victim to Brookdale, where he died at 2:40.
"Damion was part of us, part of all of us," his friend Abel Etienne said. "He was just talking about how he was going to make it in professional football. He had a great future."

HEADLINE: THE U.N. ASSEMBLY;
Bush, in Address to U.N., Urges More Vigor in Keeping the Peace

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21

 BODY:
President Bush told United Nations members today that Washington was ready to support a greatly expanded role for peacekeeping missions and to adapt the United States military to better assist in such operations.
But despite his stated willingness to promote the United Nations' role in preserving the peace, Mr. Bush did not offer ground troops for the 12 peacekeeping operations under way. Nor did he offer any new money for such tasks, or promise to pay the $733.1 million in dues and arrears that Washington owes to the United Nations. 
 Mr. Bush also did not agree to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's suggestion that all members keep troops on standby for emergency peacekeeping needs. "Member states, as always, must retain the final decision on the use of their troops," he said. [Excerpts, page A14.]
 
An Expanding Need
 In his remarks, which received polite applause as the General Assembly opened its 47th session, Mr. Bush provided backing, however, for other proposals in what Secretary General Boutros-Ghali calls his Agenda for Peace, a plan published in June to expand peacekeeping operations to deal with the mounting inter-ethnic battles and other crises.
Noting that "peacekeepers are stretched to the limit, while demands for their services increase by the day," Mr. Bush said he would discuss with other United Nations members convening a Security Council summit meeting to discuss Mr. Boutros-Ghali's proposals.
The Agenda for Peace proposed a $50 million peacekeeping start-up fund and a $1 billion peacekeeping endowment fund. Mr. Bush himself made no commitments on these suggestions, but said he was prepared to "review how we fund peacekeeping and explore new ways to ensure adequate American financial support for United Nations peacekeeping."
Mr. Boutros-Ghali has suggested that member states include their United Nations contributions in their defense budgets, which usually get passed much more easily than foreign aid or special supplements for United Nations dues.
Getting to what the United States was prepared to do now as an example to others, Mr. Bush said he was directing Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to make United States military bases, intelligence agencies and engineering units better able to take part in peacekeeping operations. He is also to establish a peacekeeping curriculum in military academies, something that already exists in Scandinavia.
"Because of peacekeeping's growing importance as a mission for the United States military, we will emphasize training of combat, engineering and logistical units for the full range of peacekeeping and humanitarian activities," Mr. Bush said.
"And we will work with the United Nations to best employ our considerable lift, logistics, communications and intelligence capabilities to support peacekeeping operations. And we will offer our capabilities for joint simulations and exercises to strengthen our ability to undertake joint peacekeeping operations."
Mr. Bush also said United Nations members must transform their defense institutions and foreign policies to better cope with the new economic and military challenges of the post-cold-war world.
 
No New Money
 His address was in keeping with the overall approach of the Administration in this election season: It has sought to adapt American policy to the challenges of the post-cold-war world without having to ask voters to spend more money or risk American lives.
While the President's speech contained various proposals, he provided few details. Several of the proposals would require the approval of Congress.
Mr. Bush told the General Assembly that he would order changes in the Agency for International Development and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. A.I.D. is to be recast to better assist emerging democracies in former Communist lands in the transformation to free markets. The arms control agency, which used to focus on Soviet-American arms control, is to concentrate on limiting missile proliferation.
The President also said he would propose to Congress the creation of a $1 billion fund of grants and credits for United States businesses investing in the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. This would come from the existing foreign aid budget, but Mr. Bush did not say which aid recipients would have to give up grants as a result.
 
Offers Few Details
 "We face the political challenge of keeping today's peace and preventing tomorrow's wars," said Mr. Bush. "We face the strategic challenge of the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. We face the common economic challenge of promoting prosperity for all. Meeting these challenges will require us . . . to transform our collective institutions and look seriously at our own governments and how we conduct our international affairs."
Senator David Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma and chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said many of the ideas in Mr. Bush's speech -- including expanded peacekeeping training for troops and using the foreign-aid funds to promote trade with emerging democracies -- had been suggested by him and other Senate Democrats months ago, and initially resisted by the Administration. For example, the Senate voted last week to allow the Defense Department to spend up to $300 million a year to help with United Nations peacekeeping operations, in an amendment sponsored by Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan.
The President opened his address with what seemed like a political shot at Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, his opponent in the Presidential election, who has been criticized, especially by Republicans, for having avoided the draft during the Vietnam war.
The first words of Mr. Bush's address were: "Forty-seven years ago I was a young man of 21, and like thousands of others of my generation, I'd gone off to war to help keep freedom alive."
Mr. Bush has been trying to draw a contrast between himself and Governor Clinton in almost every speech.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Profile;
A Primer: How the White House Budget Czar Not Only Survives, but Thrives

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
So how does Richard G. Darman do it?
In every society, in every age, there are courtiers who possess many enemies, but also bewitching powers that allow them to stay close to the throne. 
 At the Republican convention in Houston, there was pressure on President Bush to sacrifice his budget director, a principal figure behind Mr. Bush's hands-off economic policy and tax-raising budget deal, to win conservative support.
Some college Young Republicans in Orange County, Calif., got so exercised about the matter that they drew up a (presumably mock) resolution to find Mr. Darman on the floor of the convention and beat him "within an inch of his life."
 
Machiavelli Plays Elvis
 But while President Bush has been repenting his economic mistakes on the campaign trail -- "Raising taxes won't cut the deficit," he assures audiences -- Mr. Darman has been sidling even closer to the center of power.
The Machiavellian budget czar said he would reprise his 1988 role of playing the Democratic candidate in debate rehearsals with Mr. Bush. Four years ago, he showed up to play Gov. Michael S. Dukakis with a tank helmet and a box on which to stand.
For this year's costume, he said, "I'm torn between Elvis with a white scarf or the Arsenio Hall look, with shades and a saxophone." Asked whether he would be the old Elvis or the young Elvis, the pudgy budget director with the slicked-back dark hair and the unlimited confidence replied, "I think I'm stuck with the old Elvis now, though there was a time. . ."
 
An Exclusive Group
 If Mr. Darman seems to be strutting, maybe it is because his mentor, James A. Baker 3d, just swept into the White House and pulled the budget director into his exclusive core group of transplanted State Department aides.
Mr. Darman polished his chameleon skills and bureaucratic bank shots as an aide to Mr. Baker in the Reagan White House when Mr. Baker was chief of staff, and then followed him to the Treasury Department.
While Mr. Darman may act a lot more like "a choir boy" around Mr. Baker, as one Bush official put it, he has not given up his devilish delight in the black arts of backstabbing, infighting, leaking and turf building.
"There are not too many people who have survived five Presidencies," the official mused.
Taking the reminiscences of those who have worked closely with him, as well as some commentary from Mr. Darman himself, it is possible to deduce the five secrets of how to succeed in the bureaucracy by really trying.
RULE NO. 1. Work harder than anyone else, be more prepared and add a dash of psychological intimidation.
As a boy, Mr. Darman once queried a teacher about a final question on a test, as a way of intimidating the other students into thinking he was almost finished. As an adult, Mr. Darman sometimes managed to convey the impression that he was the last one working in the Reagan White House by leaving his suit coat on his chair and his office light burning after he left for home.
Mr. Darman claims that he was motivated only by sartorial convenience: "The truth is, I'd go home and leave my jacket on the chair and I'd put on the same jacket the next morning."
He tries to know more than anyone else in the room on any issue, and he always reads all the abstruse paragraphs in briefing papers that others, to their peril, skip.
Edward J. Rollins recalled that during the 1984 Reagan re-election campaign, Mr. Darman wanted to know what books he could read on how to run a campaign and was nettled when Mr. Rollins, the campaign manager, replied that he had to learn by experience. Mr. Darman did not accept that.
He began reading war strategy books provided by Lee Atwater, a campaign aide and who would become an architect of Mr. Bush's 1988 victory, and he stayed up one night studying Gary Hart's book on public policy. When the Reagan team began speculating about what direction Mr. Hart might take, Mr. Darman produced underlined passages in the Hart book.
Bush officials who have studied this Master of the Bureaucratic Universe say he swiftly establishes primacy in relationships with subordinates by asking a question on a subject he is certain he knows more about, then correcting the subordinate's answer, even if it is only a tad off.
In the days when he and the former chief of staff, John H. Sununu, were dominating domestic policy with what one Bush aide describes as "Torquemada-like glee," Mr. Darman was asked by a conservative columnist why the Bush speech writers had no fresh ideas. "That's the way we want it," Mr. Darman replied, smiling.
Certainly, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press spokesman, who has seen Mr. Darman yell and throw papers on the floor on occasion, was too intimidated to talk about the budget chief.
"Too dangerous," he said. "Too scary."
RULE NO. 2. Flatter up.
While some subordinates complain Mr. Darman can be rude, and some rivals call him remorseless, he can be charming and witty to those he would capture. Some rivals say Mr. Darman even changes the tone of his voice when he addresses President Bush, to make it more respectful and soothing.
"Over time, Dick has figured out the psychology of the Presidents he's working with, what they need," said David Gergen, an editor at U.S. News and World Report who worked with him in the Reagan White House. "He is one of the few people who thinks about this in a consistent way and watches in a close way how to act so that he will become indispensable."
In the beginning, Mr. Darman passed on too much paper to President Ronald Reagan. But over time, Mr. Gergen said, Mr. Darman came to understand "the importance of anecdote" and the way "to send him the critical papers without sending him 5,000 pieces of paper."
President Bush, after an initial period of chariness because he believed Mr. Darman was a source of negative commentary about him in the Reagan era, has grown comfortable with the former Harvard professor. Despite Mr. Bush's snide references to "intellectuals out there in the Harvard schools" who are advising Gov. Bill Clinton, the Connecticut Yalie prefers wealthy Ivy League types like himself. And both the President and Mr. Darman are pragmatists and creatures of Washington.
Mr. Darman reinforced the President's feeling that there is not much the Government can do to fix a sick economy except wait, and he has played up to Mr. Bush's wacky sense of humor, donning a gorilla suit for the President's birthday in 1989. (Although even Mr. Bush looked a bit taken aback by that.)
Vice President Dan Quayle is just the sort of winging-it, homework-resistant type that Mr. Darman would be likely to chew up if Mr. Quayle were a subordinate. But Mr. Darman has formed a surprisingly close relationship with the Vice President. The budget chief was one of the guests at Marilyn Quayle's intimate birthday party at the trendy Southwestern restaurant Red Sage, and he was featured in the acknowledgements of her novel, "Embrace the Serpent," for reading an early draft and offering some advice.
RULE NO. 3. Get control of the paper.
While critics have complained that he has occasionally played shell games with budget numbers, and while Bush aides say that Mr. Darman's political instincts are erratic, he is one of the rare Republicans who has mastered the arcane subject of how the Government works.
As Mr. Darman has pointed out, if you control the first draft, you control history.
When he first started in the Reagan Administration, he happily took the low-level job of staff secretary, with an office in the White House basement, because it allowed him to control what papers went to the desk of the President and other top officials.
Mr. Darman's associates say he has never confused public visibility with true influence. He is known for gaining the upper hand by pulling out a sheet of paper at a pivotal point in a meeting, near the start or the end, "just a few thoughts," so that his paper becomes the one that is marked up, "the beginning document."
This trick particularly flummoxed Samuel K. Skinner, the indecisive chief of staff who came in telling people he would curb, and perhaps banish, Mr. Darman. But the budget chief knew instantly that Mr. Skinner was no match for him and privately held the chief of staff in contempt for not trying to form an alliance with him. Rather, Mr. Skinner started off by telling The National Journal that the 49-year-old Mr. Darman was "a talented young man" with waning influence.
"Poor Skinner," one White House official said. "Darman made sure he got blamed for everything, even on the rare occasions when he wasn't at fault."
RULE NO. 4. Even if you believe in the power of the few, or the one, keep some proletarian touches.
He cuts his own hair. Badly.
He eats breakfast and lunch at the staff table in the White House mess on most days, picking up gossip and expounding on why this or that idea will or will not work, based on his more than two decades in Washington.
His social life is limited, and his preferred restaurant is McDonald's, where he orders either Special No. 3 -- a Quarterpounder and fries -- or No. 4 -- a grilled McChicken. "Occasionally," he confessed, "I veer off to nine McNuggets."
RULE NO. 5. Dare to be petty.
To the amusement of White House aides, Mr. Darman has stopped attending morning senior staff meetings, where he once reigned with the panache of a cat toying with a rubber mouse. The ostensible reason is that he no longer needs to, now that he is in the Baker clique. But Darman-watchers suggest that he no longer goes because the meetings are now run by someone he considers a respected junior: Robert Zoellick, who was Mr. Darman's aide at the Treasury Department.
Although he claims he has mellowed, Mr. Darman has been known to get upset over exceedingly small things. After an otherwise favorable article about him once, he was angry that he was described as "portly," and he can be picky on everything from camera angles to picture captions. During the Reagan years, he was always so furious about being referred to in the press as a "Baker aide," that his colleagues presented him with a license plate with that moniker.
Although he grants audiences to favored reporters, he often sets elaborate rules in return for his cooperation, rarely allows himself to be quoted by name and freezes out those who displease him. He prefers live television to print because he feels he has more control, and especially likes David Brinkley's Sunday morning program because he is allowed to be last, so he gets the last word.
With reporters, he also aims for the psychological edge.
"You went to Radcliffe, didn't you?" he interrupts an interviewer who did not. He told another young reporter, after excusing himself to take a phone call from his good friend, the famed investigative reporter at The Washington Post: "That was your colleague, Bob Woodward."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard G. Darman, the budget director, has earned his own Washington adjective -- Darmanesque -- for his hard work and preparation coupled with a dash of psychological intimidation. Mr. Darman listened to testimony at a House budget hearing in July. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

 Interests: Work.

HEADLINE: Sudan Worker for U.S. Is Believed Executed

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The Sudanese Government is believed to have executed a United States Government employee on charges of treason despite strong objections from Washington, the State Department said today.
A department spokesman, Joseph Snyder, said the United States had expressed its "gravest concern" to the Sudanese Government. 
 The authorities are thought to have executed Andrew Tombe, a 34-year-old Sudanese employee of the Agency for International Development in the southern city of Juba. The city is a stronghold of a rebel movement that has been at war with the Muslim Arab-dominated government in Khartoum. The southern part of the Sudan is mainly Christian and animist.
"Based on our own knowledge of Mr. Tombe, we do not think he was guilty of these charges," Mr. Snyder said.
The Sudanese Ambassador in Washington did not immediately comment on the execution or the American response.

HEADLINE: THE U.N. ASSEMBLY;
With U.S. the Biggest Debtor, President Finds U.N. Skeptical

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21

 BODY:
President Bush's words of support for United Nations peacekeeping in his speech to the General Assembly today, coupled with a vague promise to "insure adequate American financial support," was greeted with skepticism by United Nations budget officials who last week issued figures showing that the United States remains the organization's largest debtor.
What is new this year about the United Nations' perennial financial crisis is not how much money America owes, but the additional burden from the lands of the former Soviet Union, which, beset by deepening economic woes, have been unable to contribute anything toward the organization's costs so far, officials say. 
 As a result, the United Nations finds itself caught up in a double financial squeeze -- despite its increased prestige and usefulness in the post-cold-war world. It is borrowing money from peacekeeping accounts to meet its monthly payroll and then shuffling cash from one peacekeeping operation to another to meet those obligations.
The United States is by far the largest debtor, owing a total of $733.1 million in regular budget and peacekeeping dues, the latest figures show.
Russia is the second-biggest debtor, owing $420.3 million to the regular budget and for peacekeeping, while two other former Soviet republics, Ukraine and Belarus, owe $45.8 million and $12.5 million, respectively.
Together, the 179 United Nations members are more than $1.5 billion behind in their payments, owing $831.2 million in regular budget dues and $735.2 million more for peacekeeping.
The United States is the organization's second-largest debtor for the peacekeeping operations, owing $208.7 million, largely for the efforts in southern Lebanon and Cambodia. Russia is the largest in this category, with unpaid obligations of $282.2 million.
 
U.S. Alters Its Bill
 Far larger than its peacekeeping debts are America's unpaid regular budget dues, which now stand at $524.4 million. For this year, the United Nations set Washington's regular contribution at $298.6 million. Congress is offering $282 million, subtracting about $16 million for a dispute over income-tax payments by Americans working for the organization and for activities it refuses to finance, like help for the Palestine Liberation Organization.
The United States never pays its regular assessment before October, though it is due at the start of the calendar year. The Bush Administration has promised to pay $225 million in October and $57 million by year's end.
Meanwhile, the United States' back dues for regular budgets, dating to the years when it deliberately underfunded the United Nations to show disapproval of its actions, are being wound down under a program approved by Congress in 1991. This provides for the balance to be paid off over five years.
Under this program, the United States paid off $46 million in back regular dues last year and $40 million more this year.
Congress is moving to establish a peacekeeping contingency fund to help finance the American share of start-up costs so that peace operations can get going faster. Mr. Bush requested $700 million for this, but Congress appears likely to appropriate a smaller amount, perhaps in the $500 million range.
Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, has proposed legislation that would charge peacekeeping bills to the Defense Department, as part of the cost of maintaining national security.
The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, has proposed that all countries take a similar approach, charging their peacekeeping bills to defense budgets -- which Parliaments tend to approve more quickly than United Nations assessments.
At Senate hearings on Mr. Simon's proposal earlier this summer, Defense and State Department officials indicated that they were opposed to the idea.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Says Economy Is Not as Bad as People Think

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Hours after his Democratic rival began broadcasting a television commercial accusing him of misjudging Americans' economic pain, President Bush told a national radio audience today that the economy was not nearly as bad as people believed.
In an interview with Rush Limbaugh, the conservative radio talk-show host, Mr. Bush said that the economy was "poised for a dramatic recovery" and maintained that most people believed otherwise because they paid too much heed to the news media. 
 "I think they're feeling negative about the economy because they hear 92 percent of the coverage on the television -- where a lot of people get their news from -- on the economy has been negative," he said. "There are some good things. Interest rates are down. People aren't being robbed by inflation anymore. Inventories are down."
 
Bush Attacks Clinton on Draft
 He added: "A lot of people think we're in a deep recession in this country. The irony is we are growing and we've grown for five quarters. Now, don't tell that to a guy that's worrying about his job tomorrow, but I am telling you, the fact that they've had hammered into them that things are a total disaster is influencing people's judgments."
The President's comments came the day after Gov. Bill Clinton's campaign broadcast its first television attack on Mr. Bush. The advertisement alternates film clips of Mr. Bush making cheery economic pronouncements with bleak statements about rising joblessness. "If George Bush doesn't understand the problem, how can he solve it?" the commercial says at the end.
Mr. Bush also spoke harshly about Mr. Clinton's explanation of his efforts to avoid the draft during the Vietnam War, saying his rival was guilty of a "total failure to come clean with the American people" on the issue.
Responding today in Chicago, Mr. Clinton said he had been straightforward on the draft matter, and cited an endorsement last weekend by Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., the retired head of the Joints Chiefs of Staff, as evidence that the issue should now be forgotten.
"Admiral Crowe has more credibility on truth-telling than George Bush," Mr. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: DECISION FOR EUROPE;
Continent Weighs Hopes and Fears About Having One Big Central Bank

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Like squabbling parents anxious not to disturb the children, European officials unhinged by Europe's sudden currency crisis have lowered their voices. But soothing words calculated to calm edgy voters and edgier financial markets will not soon repair the trauma of a week that began with the fracturing of the European currency system and ended with French voters approving by the narrowest of margins a single currency for Europe.
The delay may not be entirely a bad thing. For while the financial follies undermined prospects for a speedy transition to a common currency controlled by a common central bank, the crisis itself was precipitated by the model for that vision -- Germany's very independent Bundesbank. And skeptics are now in a better position to force an open debate on whether democratic Europe can afford to surrender its economic fate to the hands of a few unelected central bankers -- or, indeed, whether it can afford not to.
 
Controlling the Flow
 Central banks, like the Bank of France and the Bank of Japan, are in charge of their national supplies of money. They may not actually print it: in the modern world, money largely consists of deposits in checking accounts. But they can effectively control how much is available to borrow, and at what interest rate. And that in turn has enormous influence on the demand for everything from refrigerators to shopping malls. 
 In most countries the central banks take their marching orders from the president or prime minister. In fact, the whole tradition of central banking evolved from the symbiosis of private financiers and their government patrons. The bankers raised capital, informally policed the practices of less-well-connected banks and shuffled documents for governments, in return receiving monopolies over lucrative commercial banking services. The Bank of England, incidentally, only lost its status as a private institution in 1946.
There was, however, one giant exception: the United States Federal Reserve, chartered in 1914. The Fed's enormous potential to influence output and employment by dictating interest rates was not initially understood; the idea was, more simply, to create a public lender of last resort that would deter periodic bank runs, like the one in "It's a Wonderful Life."
 
A Hybrid Creature
 But the Fed's independence from daily politics -- governors are appointed to 14-year terms that overlap Presidential elections -- survived its gradual accretion of power. And the Fed was seen as so successful a hybrid that it was used as a model for the Bundesbank after the restoration of democracy in Germany.
The appeal is understandable, especially in an era in which governments are routinely expected to do everything from cleaning the air to paying the pensions of the retired. Elected officials are subject to enormous pressures to spend more and tax less -- hence Washington's $300-billion-plus budget deficit. An independent central bank, with its power to raise interest rates, can trim private spending to offset a government's inclination to profligacy. The result: stabler prices.
What works in the United States seems to work elsewhere. Some countries, notably Japan and the Netherlands, managed to avoid inflation in the 1970's and 1980's without shielding their banks from parliamentary arm-twisting. But these are exceptions. Alberto Alesina, an economist at Harvard, found that as a rule independence has been closely linked to low inflation: Germany and Switzerland, the industrialized democracies with the stablest prices, have the most independent central banks.
Indeed, the idea is so attractive that it served as the catalyst for European monetary union. While many of the leaders who signed the Maastricht accord last December dreamt of ultimately converting the European Community into a true United States of Europe, a common currency run by a single central bank was widely touted for its potential to bring the discipline imposed by the Bundesbank to the rest of Europe. It may seem ironic, then, that the Bundesbank has had a hand -- indeed, the leading role -- in knocking Maastricht off track.
 
Fighting Inflation
 Two years ago the Bundesbank warned that the German Government's policy of supporting high wages in eastern Germany before the wages were earned through high productivity would be inflationary. The bankers repeated the warning when Chancellor Helmut Kohl decided to pay for reunification by borrowing, and Germany's unions responded by demanding wage increases to cover the likely rise in the cost of living. And they did more than warn: The Bundesbank has jacked up interest rates by three percentage points since 1990, even as interest rates were falling sharply in recession-mired America.
The result was a surge of foreign investment in German bank deposits that drove up the value of the mark against the dollar, and forced other European countries to raise interest rates to maintain a fixed exchange with German currency.
The fixed exchange-rate system within Europe finally broke down last week when the Bundesbank made only a token gesture at diluting its anti-inflation medicine. Too many people with deep pockets decided that the sluggish British economy simply could not -- and therefore would not -- pay German-level interest rates much longer.
The very independent Bundesbank has disabled the Maastricht juggernaut, perhaps putting it out of commission for good. Does that mean a united Europe would be worse off with a German-style central bank?
Not exactly. The Bundesbank's first priority -- by all accounts supported by the German electorate -- is to stop inflation in Germany. A European central bank would presumably defend broader European interests. Indeed, supporters of the Maastricht treaty in France argued, apparently to some effect, that a European central bank was needed to prevent the Bundesbank from putting German interests ahead of Europe's.
 
Bearing the Burdens
 But there are still reasons for Europeans to be uneasy about the proposed superbank. The heterogeneity of the greater European economy almost guarantees that the best monetary policy this month for, say, Spain, will not be the best policy for the Netherlands. That means Europe would generally either have a monetary policy that is a compromise, or one that forces regions in recession to bear a disproportionate cost of keeping prices stable in booming parts of the community.
Richard Cooper, an economist at Harvard, believes this inherent tension would be magnified by a lack of oversight. While the Bundesbank is indeed independent from direct interference, Mr. Cooper points out that it still must retain the confidence of the governed. After all, the same legislature that created the Bundesbank could always abolish it or limit its powers.
But the Maastricht design effectively requires a change in the treaty to change the bank. That would transform the decision makers into what Mr. Cooper calls "Platonic central bankers" -- philosopher-kings answerable to no one, once they are appointed.

HEADLINE: DECISION FOR EUROPE;
Text of Europeans' Statement at the U.N.

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement issued today by the foreign ministers of the members of the European Community, convened as the General Affairs Council:
The General Affairs Council met in extraordinary session in New York on Sept. 21. 
 The council warmly welcomed the positive result of the French referendum on the Treaty on European Union signed in Maastricht on Feb. 7.
The council noted with satisfaction that certain member states have already ratified the draft treaty, and that ratification procedures were well advanced in most other member states. They attached high priority to the speedy and successful conclusion of the process, without reopening the present text, on the timing foreseen in Article R of the treaty.
[Article R states: "1. The Treaty shall be ratified by the High Contracting Parties in accordance with their respective constitutional requirements. The instruments of ratification shall be deposited with the government of the Italian Republic. 2. The Treaty shall enter into force on 1 January 1993, provided that all the instruments of ratification have been deposited, or failing that, on the first day of the month following the deposit of the instrument of ratification by the last signatory State to take this step. ]
The council also welcomed the statement issued on Sept. 20 by economic and finance ministers meeting in Washington, in which they expressed the view that the French referendum result will ease tension in the foreign-exchange markets and reiterated their commitment to the European Monetary System as a key factor for economic stability and prosperity in Europe.
The council welcomed at the same time the wide debate which has taken place in all the member states over recent months with regard to the future development of the European construction. They pledged their determination to ensure that the preoccupations which had been brought to the forefront in this public discussion will find specific responses in the future development of Europe internally and externally.
The council welcomed the presidency's decision to convene an early, special European Council to consider these issues. [Britain holds the rotating presidency of the community.]
The council also welcomed the determination of the presidency to press ahead quickly with urgent business, including the completion of the single market by the end of 1992 and the negotiations on the community's finances, in accordance with the timetables and priorities set by the European Council in Lisbon.

HEADLINE: 2 Big Banks Set Plans To Expand

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Continuing the industry trend toward fewer but larger banks, the BankAmerica Corporation announced plans yesterday to acquire $7.5 billion of deposits from First Gibraltar Savings, a Dallas-based savings and loan, and the First Union Corporation said it would buy Dominion Bankshares, a $9.4 billion banking company based in Roanoke, Va.
Both BankAmerica, which operates large banks in seven states, and First Union, which will now have large banks in six states, are old hands at acquiring other companies. Analysts expect them to move quickly to improve the profits of their new acquisitions by cutting costs. Each bank has smaller operations in other states as well. 
 BankAmerica, which already has about $4 billion of deposits and 130 branches in Texas, mostly from its acquisition this year of Sunbelt Savings, faces the daunting task of converting those deposit-rich but loan-poor offices into more conventional bank offices with more lending and more checking account customers.
 
 
Product of 'Southwest Plan'
 First Gibraltar is the descendant of five failed Texas savings and loans that Federal regulators sold in 1988 to Ronald O. Perelman for $315 million. Mr. Perelman, who was given $900 million in Federal tax breaks, bought the company as part of the "Southwest plan," under which Federal regulators were trying to stave off the collapse of the savings and loan deposit insurance fund by hurriedly selling failed savings institutions on favorable terms to private investors.
Mr. Perelman, who also controls Revlon Inc. through his investment company, MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, which also owns First Gibraltar, was never expected to be a long-term owner of the bank. He has been negotiating the sale of various parts of the company for months.
The BankAmerica purchase does not include four of First Gibraltar's branches in Plano, Tex., or its mortgage-banking subsidiary.
For First Union, of Charlotte, N.C., the new acquisition is an important move into markets where it had little presence, in Virginia, Tennessee and the District of Columbia. First Union, whose appetite for acquisitions in the 1980's gave its chairman, Edward A. Crutchfield Jr., the nickname Fast Eddy, felt it was now able to handle a large new purchase because it had completed its acquisition of the Southeast Banking Corporation, a failed Miami-based company it acquired a year ago.
 Many investors were unhappy with First Union because it paid high prices for acquisitions in the mid-1980's. But the company recently pledged to limit itself to purchases that will be quickly profitable, and yesterday it forecast earnings of $487.5 million for this year, 70 percent higher than in 1991.
Dominion has been hit hard by losses on commercial real estate loans in the last two years. But its financial condition is not so weak that it is considered a candidate for takeover by Government regulators.
The opportunities to cut costs after mergers have been the catalyst for American banks to announce, thus far this year, the acquisition of $98.9 billion of deposits from other banks, plus an additional $67.2 billion from savings institutions, according to SNL Securities of Charlottesville, Va.
The pace of bank mergers is slower this year than in 1991, when $253.7 billion of bank deposits and $89.5 billion of savings institution deposits changed hands. But the pace of bank mergers and acquistions remains at a near-record pace.
 
Rich Banks Getting Richer
 The most acquisitive banks are generally those like BankAmerica and First Union that retained their financial strength through the recent downturn in real estate prices and the economy. In banking, the rich are getting richer, as acquisitions of weaker institutions lead to higher profits and greater financial strength, which in turn makes it easier to arrange the next acquisition.
"The process of merger and acquisition among banks can feed on itself," said Ronald Mandle, a banking analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "Once a bank is established in a market, additional acquisitions become more likely, since they would be part of the bank's existing market and have the potential for large cost savings."
At First Union, for example, executives have already said the acquisition of Dominion will sharpen their appetite for some of the other banks in the Washington market, particularly First American Bankshares.
First American's executives, who are now breaking the company's legal ties to Arab investors associated with the failed Bank of Credit and Commerce International, have said they expect First American to be acquired eventually by another bnaking company.
The stock of First Union, which agreed to pay 0.58 of its shares for each Dominion share, closed yesterday at $37 a share, down $1, making its offer worth $855 million. Dominion's stock rose $3.25 a share, to $19.625.
First Union expects to cut costs at Dominion by about $100 million a year. Although the two companies do not have overlapping branches, First Union expects savings to come from eliminating more than 1,000 jobs and sharing computer systems.
 
Need to Provide More Loans
 BankAmerica did not disclose the total cost of its First Gibraltar acquisition, but told analysts that it paid about $110 million for the 130 branches and their deposits. BankAmerica also bought most of First Gibraltar's loans, including $225 million of commercial loans and $640 million of consumer loans. BankAmerica stock was unchanged yesterday at $47 a share.
"To turn a reasonable profit on its investment, BankAmerica has to revitalize the savings and loan branches to offer more kinds of deposits and to generate more loans," said Lawrence Cohn, an analyst at Paine Webber. Although the purchase gives BankAmerica the second-largest branch system in Texas, "they have virtually no ability to generate loans or other assets," he added.
David Berry, chairman of Bank America's Texas subsidiary, noted that the state's ban on home-equity loans makes it harder for banks to issue new loans. Initially, he said BankAmerica was concentrating on selling checking accounts to customers who have certificates of deposit by offering no-fee checking for a year. He said BankAmerica should be earning a "reasonable" profit in Texas within two years.
