HEADLINE: With Office Space Glut, Philadelphia Is Sour on Proposed Federal Building

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Five years ago, when new office buildings seemed to be rising on every downtown corner here, business leaders cheered the Federal Government's proposal to build a huge office tower that would consolidate Federal workers now scattered in different buildings and, in the process, create construction jobs and spruce up a dreary part of town.
But as the local economy has soured, so has the enthusiasm for the project. With a 17.5 percent vacancy rate in the city's downtown office buildings, real estate experts and urban specialists now say that the last thing Philadelphia needs is a new Federal office building. The city and taxpayers would be better served, they say, by Government leasing of some of the surplus space available at deeply discounted prices. 
 "It looks stupid for the Government to build new buildings when you have buildings vacant all over the place," said Claude M. Ballade, a real estate expert and partner with Goldman, Sachs & Company, an investment bank in New York. "Why build when you can buy office buildings all over America for 60 or 70 cents on the dollar?"
 
Adding to Economic Woes
 Nor is Philadelphia's situation unique. The Government is proposing an office building in Atlanta and is building one in New York, two cities also hard hit by the real estate slump. And while the projects would initially create hundreds of construction jobs, the real estate experts say these buildings would house Federal agencies already in those cities, drawing thousands of workers, and rental income, from existing office buildings and adding to the cities' economic woes.
But officials from the General Services Administration, which is building the project in Philadelphia, say there is no available office building in the city that is big enough to accommodate the Government's regional offices for the Departments of Health and Human Services and Housing and Urban Development, among others. The proposed $256 million building, they say, would help streamline the agencies' operations and reduce duplication of things like conference rooms, auditoriums and parking.
With the encouragement of Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, the Senate has approved $37 million to start the project, and a House-Senate conference committee plans to negotiate a final bill on the matter next week. Mr. Specter, who is in a tight race for re-election, has won the endorsement of normally Democratic construction trade and other unions because of his 11-year record in the Senate for bringing projects like this proposed office building to Pennsylvania.
 
Planned in Better Times
 Mr. Specter said in a recent interview that he had talked to President Bush about the project and had begun shepherding it through the Senate only after having been advised of a great need for the new building by Federal office managers and local elected officials, including Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia.
"My job is to work on the funding when a decision has been made on the merits," Mr. Specter said.
Some of the Federal projects were planned in better economic climates. For example, in 1988 Congress approved a $517 million Federal complex in the Foley Square of lower Manhattan that includes a 975,000-square-foot office building for Federal agencies like the Internal Revenue Service and the Environmental Protection Agency.
"I cannot see the Government building office space during this time of glut," said John H. K. Belt, president of the Building Owners and Managers Association of New York, the local chapter of a national trade association. The vacancy rate in Manhattan's downtown financial district is 22 percent.
Mr. Belt said there had not been much organized opposition to the new building in Manhattan, largely because it represented a tiny addition to the office market of 350 million square feet of space.
In Atlanta, where the downtown office vacancy rate is 28 percent, the Government is considering a new office tower with 1.9 million square feet of space. Here again, the building's major purpose is to consolidate some Federal agencies in the city under a single roof. But building owners question such a purpose.
"I don't see any reason why they all have to consolidate, especially when it increases their cost of operations," said Stewart M. Huey, executive vice president of the Building Owners and Managers Association of Atlanta.
The Atlanta proposal is expected to move ahead in the approvals process on Tuesday when the House Public Buildings and Grounds Subcommittee is scheduled to vote on the development plan.
In Philadelphia, the proposed 12-story building would be at 30th and Walnut Streets on the west bank of the Schuylkill River, near a 14-acre site owned by the United States Postal Service. With one million square feet of space, the proposed building would represent about 2.5 percent of Philadelphia's current office market of 38 million square feet, a market that has six million square feet of empty office space.
"The commercial real estate market in Philadelphia is in a total free fall," said Jay Lamont, director of the Real Estate Institute at Temple University. "I am appalled that the Government would consider building space at $260 a foot when landlords are offering unheard of concessions and you can own modern footage for $50 a foot. Banks are literally giving buildings away. There is a noxious political odor that is emanating from this project."
Federal officials who manage Government property say they are not aware of any bargains in Philadelphia that meet the Government's needs or space requirements. "If the bargains are there, I haven't seen them yet," said Gordon P. Cordes, the regional administrator in Philadelphia for the General Services Administration.
In 1989 the United States Postal Service, which has the authority to develop its property for profit, announced plans to build a Federal office building on its riverfront property. The General Services Administration agreed to lease the space. Because this was an agreement between two Federal agencies, the Government had no obligation to seek competitive bids for space from building owners, and did not do so, said Wolfgang J. Zoellner, the deputy commissioner of public buildings at the General Services Administration in Washington.
 
Building vs. Buying
 Mr. Zoellner predicted that the Government would save money by building instead of buying or continuing to lease private buildings. But he and Postal Service officials refused to disclose any financial information about the project, until later this month, when the agency is scheduled to give Congress a prospectus on the project.
A General Services Administration memorandum on the building, released recently by the subcommittee, estimates the Postal Service would spend $255.8 million for constructing it. The memo estimates that the General Services Administration would pay "at a minimum" $33.5 million, or $33.50 a square foot, in 1996, the first year of the lease. That rate would gradually increase over 30 years to $46 million, or $46 a square foot.
Commercial real estate brokers in Philadelphia say that space currently rents for $12 to $32 a square foot per year, and that the Government now leases large blocks of renovated space at $15.50.
In Philadelphia, business leaders have mixed feelings on the Federal project, said Charles P. Pizzi, president of the Greater Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce. "Some folks say additional office space isn't needed now, while others see Federal investment in center city as important," he said. The Building Owners and Managers Association of Philadelphia is opposed to the project.
Charles F. Seymour, chairman of Jackson-Cross Company, a commercial real estate brokerage here, said: "Normally, the community would say, 'Great! A new office tower!' Now if they build another tower, it's going to be dumped into a market that is overbuilt and cause everybody to hurt even more than they are now."

HEADLINE: Weaker Currencies Fall Again

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Europe's weaker currencies continued to erode in value today in a clear sign that France's narrow approval of the European unification treaty on Sunday has not ended the economic upheaval of the last week.
The French franc, the British pound, the Italian lira and the Spanish peseta all dropped relative to the German mark. 
 Financial markets bet that with the pace and scope of attempts to create a single currency and a unified monetary policy still uncertain, the franc, the lira, the peseta and other currencies might still have to be devalued -- some of them further -- before order can be restored to Europe's economic coordination system.
 
Franc Almost Hits the Floor
 The franc, after rising in value against the German mark in the hours immediately after the French referendum on Sunday night, fell again today, nearly to the lowest level allowed under the exchange-rate agreement. By the end of trading in Europe, the franc stood at 3.4240 to the mark, just slightly above its allowable floor of 3.4305 to the mark. Traders said the French central bank tried to support the currency by purchasing francs and selling marks.
[After the completion of most currency trading in New York on Monday afternoon, the European Community's foreign ministers said at the United Nations headquarters that there was scant chance that the European unity treaty would take effect at the beginning of next year, as they had once hoped. They also acknowledged the need for further measures to quell the widespread disquiet over the treaty throughout Europe.]
Unlike Britain and Italy, France is in good economic condition, with lower inflation and higher economic growth than Germany. "You could argue that France has the best economic fundamentals in Europe, but that won't necessarily stop the speculators from having a go at it," said Ian Harwood, an economist at S. G. Warburg & Company in London.
The ability of the franc to hold up against speculative pressure in coming days will foretell the future of the Exchange Rate Mechanism, said Robin Hubbard, an economist at Paribas Capital Markets, the investment arm of Banque Paribas, the French banking company. The mechanism is the system by which the European Community nations pledged to keep their currency values stable as a precursor to the establishment of a single currency,
"It's a matter of whether the markets pluck up the courage to take on the franc," Mr. Hubbard said. "It will be a game of cat and mouse. But I don't think the markets will take it on, and if they do, they will probably run into a coordinated response, with France raising interest rates and the Germans perhaps willing to cut rates."
Traders are also watching the lira closely. Italy had said last week that it wanted to rejoin the Exchange Rate Mechanism on Tuesday, but was forced to back off today and acknowledge that a return was not imminent. Traders and economists said the weakening of the currency against the mark today suggested that Italy would not be able to rejoin any time soon without accepting a further devaluation of the lira, which had already been devalued by 7 percent last week.
The lira closed in Europe at 846 to the mark, down from 836.1 at the close on Friday.
 
Pound Falls Further
 With British officials signaling that they would cut interest rates to stimulate the domestic economy rather than try to bring the pound back into the monetary system soon, sterling continued its long slide in value. The pound closed in European trading at 2.5390 marks, down from 2.5579 in trading on Sunday night and 2.61 on Friday.
The Irish punt, the Spanish peseta and the Portuguese escudo also remained in danger of falling below their minimum values in the exchange rate system, traders said.
Trading in foreign currencies was considerably less frantic today than last week. But traders said there continued to be buying and selling based on the same strains that led Britain and Italy to withdraw from the European monetary system last week: Germany's policy of keeping its interest rates higher than its European neighbors want, and the resulting flow of speculative and investment funds out of weak currencies and into the German mark.
"The tensions have not completely gone out of the markets," Mr. Hubbard of Paribas said "They're not as intense as they had been, but clearly the speculators continue to feel that there is a problem with German interest rates and therefore some vulnerability on the part of the authorities in trying to defend the weaker currencies."
European officials have been hoping to avoid a broad-based devaluation of the currencies within the Exchange Rate Mechanism. Devaluations, in addition to undermining the credibility of a stable exchange-rate system, tend to lead to inflation by increasing the cost of imports. They also tend to force up interest rates in the long run because investors, fearing that a nation that has devalued once will be willing to do it again, require a higher rate of return to offset the additional risk of putting their funds into that country.
Britain and Italy last week pulled out of the European monetary system, at least for the time being, effectively allowing their currencies to be devalued. They pulled out after being unable to defend the values of their currencies against intense selling pressure from speculators, despite raising interest rates sharply and spending billions of dollars worth of reserves to buy pounds and lire.
It is the same type of speculation that is now buffeting the franc, the lira, the peseta and the Irish punt.

HEADLINE: DECISION FOR EUROPE;
U.S. Also Guilty In Money Crisis, Europeans Say

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
After a week of hearing American officials complain about high German interest rates, European officials struck back today, saying the weak dollar and low American rates also contributed heavily to the crisis in world currency markets.
"Interest rates in Germany are too high, and U.S. rates are too low," said Spain's Finance Minister, Carlos Solchaga. Mr. Solchaga made his assertion that the Federal Reserve should raise interest rates at a news conference this morning in his capacity as chairman of the chief policy-making committee of the International Monetary Fund. 
 Bush Administration officials, who have for much of this year pressed the Fed to lower rates to help end the stubborn United States economic slowdown, were clearly irritated.
 
U.S. Blames German Rates
 "We obviously don't think our rates being too low are the problem," said a Treasury official. "We obviously think that Germany needs to lower theirs." Administration officials assert that Germany's high rates slow borrowing and lending and hurt economic recovery not only in Europe but also throughout the world.
The wide gap between the Federal Reserve's 3 percent short-term rates and the German central bank's rates of 9 percent or more means that many investors have shunned low-yield American investments in favor of high-yield German ones. This has made the German mark so strong that last week Britain, Italy and Spain had to devalue their currencies, at great embarrassment to their Governments.
Even as the Europeans lobby for higher rates, many economists predict that because the American economy remains in such bad shape, the Federal Reserve will cut rates yet again over the next few weeks to help end the slump. That could weaken the dollar, strengthen the mark and, European officials fear, serve as a spark thrown into Europe's currency tinderbox.
The European officials, in Washington for the joint annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, spent much of the day after France's narrow vote in favor of further steps toward European unity trying to reassure Europe's nervous currency markets.
"The general view is that we're now over the worst," said Henning Christophersen, the European Community's Commissioner for Economic Affairs. "I think after two or three days we will see the markets begin to work in a more orderly fashion."
The Europeans also showed little sympathy for the suggestion President Bush made Sunday to tie world currency rates to a basket of commodities, including gold, that would help governments detect inflationary pressures and adjust their policies.
 
Action in Currency Markets
 Currency traders said the central banks of France, Ireland and Germany intervened in the foreign exchange markets today, buying and selling currencies to keep the French franc and the Irish punt from falling below their official floor in the European monetary system, an 11-nation system of linked exchange rates. The franc and the punt were weak today in foreign exchange markets but did not face huge attacks the way British, Italian and Spanish currencies did last week.
Asserting that the pressures the French franc faced today were nothing out of the ordinary, Finance Minister Michel Sapin of France said, "Business is normal on the markets today."
The open criticism of America's low interest rates was in sharp constrast to the exchanges at Saturday's meeting of the finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrial nations, which includes the United States. Ministers then said they understood America's need for faster growth. At such meetings, the ministers do not try to anger the others.
But Europeans who do not belong to the Group of Seven did not feel similarly inhibited. "The weakness of the dollar was at the origin of Europe's currency crisis," said Philippe Maystadt, Belgium's Finance Minister.
Spain's Mr. Solchaga, whose country's currency was swept up and badly battered in the financial markets' turmoil last week, complained that other industrial nations were trapped "between the benign neglect of American monetary authorities" regarding the weak dollar and "the monetarist doctrines of the Bundesbank," Germany's central bank. The Bundesbank has used extremely high interest rates to squeeze down inflation, and this has forced Germany's partners to jack up their rates to keep their currencies from sliding against the German mark.
 
Denial That Dollar Is the Culprit
 Treasury Under Secretary David C. Mulford has repeatedly bristled at suggestions that Washington blithely let the dollar slide to record lows last month without worrying about its effects on other countries.
"We've felt that the dollar is competitive at its present levels," he said. "And as you know, we have not sought to depreciate the dollar, nor have we followed a policy of benign neglect."
Denying that the dollar is the culprit, American officials assert that Germany's high interest rates have caused the dollar's weakness and Europe's currency tensions.
Michel Camdessus, the International Monetary Fund's managing director, who said last week that the Fed should not lower rates further, threw his lot in with Washington's critics today, saying that once a recovery gathered steam the Federal Reserve should be "prompt to accompany the recovery with moderate and progressive increases of interest rates."
In light of the sharp policy differences between Germany and the United States, the monetary fund's key policy-making unit, the Interim Committee, said in its communique today: "The recent currency turmoil forcefully illustrates the importance of reinforced policy coordination."
Administration officials said the President's suggestion to link a basket of commodities was not a return to the gold standard, under which the value of the dollar was tied to the price of gold. They said that the proposal would help industrial nations assess whether their currencies were properly valued against a basket of commodities, which might include wheat and oil in addition to gold. When a country's inflation rate was less than the price increases for the basket, the country would have leeway to ease its monetary policy to spur growth.
Some officials criticized the plan as clumsy or unclear. "There are many disadvantages to such a currency construction,' said Helmut Schlesinger, president of the Bundesbank.
Mr. Sapin, France's Finance Minister, did not seem to take the proposal seriously, saying, "It isn't exactly new."
James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, made the same proposal in September 1987 when he was Treasury Secretary, but it did not get anywhere.
Mr. Camdessus of the I.M.F., who is eager to study new proposals to stabilize the world's monetary system, had kind words for the President's proposal. He said it "is timely and can play a useful role along with other economic indicators in assessing the stances of economic policies that underlie exchange market development."

"Interest rates in Germany are too high, and U.S. rates are too low," he said. At left was Michel Camdessus, managing director of the I.M.F. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Many Risky Bargains in European Stocks

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Like one-bedroom condos in Manhattan, European stocks can be had at bargain prices. But buyers should question some of the bargains unless they are planning to stick around a long time, analysts say.
France's half-hearted approval Sunday of the European unity treaty hardly lessened the risk that declining currencies will leave American investors with losses even if European stocks themselves rise. And with Britain stuck in a recession, France barely growing and Germany slowing down, higher stock prices are no sure bet. 
 Those Americans with the patience and steady nerves to test the European markets should choose their countries, stocks and mutual funds as carefully as they might shop for an Italian sports car or French couture.
Many strategists recommend stocks likely to benefit from lower interest rates and a stronger dollar: banks, for example, and companies with substantial American operations or exports. Mutual fund buyers might consider those funds that hedge some of their currency risk.
The temptation of European stocks comes from their moderate prices. Japanese stocks still trade for nearly 40 times earnings and American stocks nearly 25. In Europe, a franc, pound or mark of annual earnings can be bought for a multiple of just 10 to 16. European cash flow and book value also come relatively cheap.
What is more, European interest rates have plenty of room to fall from short-term levels now about six percentage points higher than in the United States. Germany's Bundesbank might hesitate every step of the way, but as Thomas R. Robinson, the chief international strategist at Merrill Lynch, put it, "Over all, the direction of interest rates is down."
But lower European interest rates, while making European currencies less attractive, would also increase the value of the dollar. Add the risk of sudden currency devaluations -- most recently, the lira and the pound -- and even strong gains in European stocks could vanish when translated into dollars.
European stocks rose smartly last week; the British market, Europe's largest, gained about 8 percent. But only four of 19 European stock funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. reported gains.
John R. Hickling, manager of Fidelity's International Growth and Income Fund, with assets of $70 million, said that investors should approach Europe "with caution and at their own peril." With 35 to 40 percent of his money in Europe, Mr. Hickling's fund finished last week off just 10 cents a share, to $13.99. But the fund lost another 6 cents a share yesterday.
Mr. Hickling sometimes wishes company policy allowed him to hedge his currency risks. "There are some times it's pretty obvious the dollar is going to go up," he said.
To protect himself, Mr. Hickling favors the stocks of companies that would benefit from a stronger dollar. Several British companies -- Glaxo, Cadbury Schweppes, Smithkline Beecham, Grand Metropolitan -- have extensive operations in the United States, he noted.
Since oil is priced in dollars, Mr. Hickling is also looking at European oil companies. He is buying Royal Dutch/Shell for its strong balance sheet and dividend prospects.
Mr. Hickling sees banking stocks as the best way to take advantage of declining European interest rates. "The U.S. lesson has not been lost on us," he said, referring to the fall in American rates. "There's no reason why interest rates in Europe can't do what interest rates have done in the U.S. over the last two years." He lists ABN Amro of the Netherlands and Union Bank of Switzerland as being among the likely beneficiaries.
Picking the right countries might also shield against currency risk. David C. Roche, Morgan Stanley's global strategist, leans toward the so-called core countries, including Germany, the Netherlands and France, that appear to have the greatest commitment to maintaining the value of their currencies.
Yesterday, however, he saw speculators turn their attack to the French franc, "like a bunch of wolves starting to attack a group of trappers crossing the snow." He recommended that clients reduce their European stock holdings by about 17 percent and shift that money to the United States.
But when it comes to recommending countries, unanimity among analysts and money managers is fracturing as quickly as the European Monetary System.
France has many friends: Mr. Robinson of Merrill Lynch boasts of its low price/earnings ratios and inflation lower than Germany's. But others, pointing to a French Government weakened by the close vote on Sunday, prefer to buy British, saying that declining interest rates will pull Britain out of recession. French stocks fell more than 3 percent yesterday, while British stocks fell only a quarter point.
For individuals, however, betting on a single country often requires buying a closed-end mutual fund that sells for less than the value of the stocks it contains.
Considering the currency risks, Nancy R. Lazar, an economist at International Strategy and Investment, a consulting firm, sees little reason for investors to look abroad. "We are closer to a pickup in our economy than they are in Europe," she said. "They should stay home."

HEADLINE: DECISION FOR EUROPE;
Russia Balking at Liability for the Entire Former Soviet Debt

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The issue of how and when the former Soviet Union's $70 billion foreign debt will be repaid became further tangled today as Russian officials said their Government was not willing to be liable for the entire debt.
Roughly half the debt is owed to Germany and a German Government official expressed surprise and dismay this evening, saying he thought the question had been settled. "It seems to me as if the Russian side was raising additional issues," he said. 
 Roughly $19 billion in interest and principal payments will fall due next year on the former Soviet Union's debt, and no one can agree on who should pay. The question has become an obstacle to further aid to the former Soviet republics, as Western officials try to figure out how much of their assistance should be used for debt repayment and how much to help the republics' economies.
 
Repayments Postponed
 The Group of Seven industrial democracies agreed on Oct. 28, 1991, when the Soviet Union was heading toward a breakup, to postpone some interest and principal repayments this year in exchange for pledges from each of the republics to accept full responsibility for the debt.
All 12 of the remaining Soviet republics then signed a tentative agreement to make payments on the Soviet debt in rough proportion to the sizes of their economies. But under the principle of "joint and several" responsibility, they also agreed that if five republics stopped making payments, for example, then the remaining seven republics would be liable for their payments also. And if all but one republic dropped out, the remaining republic would be liable for the entire debt.
But the final agreement on debt repayment, signed a month later, included only eight republics, and in practice every republic except Russia has stopped making payments. Russia is unhappy now about being held liable for the entire debt. German officials are trying to maintain the principle of "joint and several" responsibility in the formal rescheduling now being negotiated, but Russian officials want to water it down and American officials are backing them.
Aleksei V. Mozhin, a top Russian debt negotiator who is here in Washington for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, told reporters today that Russia was still trying to persuade the other republics to start contributing to the debt payments. Meanwhile, he said, no agreement has been reached on whether Russia will assume responsibility for all of the Soviet debt or whether it will be liable for only 61 percent, under the formula approved by the 12 republics.
Mr. Mozhin said, and an American official confirmed, that Russia and the United States did not want Russia to take full responsibility, but that other countries opposed such a solution.
As a result, Mr. Mozhin said at a news conference today at the World Bank, detailed negotiations of the amounts to be postponed have not begun.
Petr O. Aven, Russia's minister for foreign economic relations, repeated recent Russian assertions that it could only afford to pay $2.5 billion next year in interest and principal.
But the German Government official said that the $2.5 billion figure had not been accepted by Russia's creditors. "This has been a figure that has been given to us without much economic reasoning," he said.
German officials also want any postponement to be much shorter than American officials want.
The German official said that Mr. Aven had told officials from creditor governments last week that Russia was willing to manage the repayment of all of the former Soviet Union's debts provided that the other republics also allowed Russia to manage all of the former Soviet Union's assets. Germany assumed that Russia was also prepared to be liable for the entire debt if it were managing it, the German official said.
But Mr. Mozhin said Russia was not willing to accept full liability and that American officials had supported this position.
Ukraine and other republics have criticized Russia's takeover of many assets that used to belong to the Soviet Union, such as overseas embassies.
The Russian economy is already stumbling, and many factories have closed because of a lack of foreign exchange for imports. A staff official of the International Monetary Fund estimated on Sunday that Russia's net debt payments, purchases of imports and outflows of investment money would exceed export revenues and foreign investment by $18 billion this year and another $18 billion next year. Closing this gap has been a crucial objective of Western assistance.
This year the gap is being closed with $2 billion from international organizations like the International Monetary Fund, $6 billion in assistance from individual foreign governments, and $10 billion from the postponement of principal and interest repayments. Western officials also plan separately to set up a $6 billion fund to stabilize the value of the ruble.
American officials include this fund in their calculations that assistance totals $24 billion. Russian officials sometimes say that assistance only totals $1 billion because they only count grants and do not include loans that must eventually be repaid.
The big issue in aid to the former republics now lies in how much of next year's shortfall will be covered by the postponement of interest and principal payments and how much will be covered by foreign governments and international institutions. Because roughly half of the debt is owed to Germany, German officials want the postponed portion to be as small as possible.
At their summit meeting in Munich in July, the Group of Seven said that they would help Russia cope with the debt. The German Government officials said today that Germany stood by that commitment, but that with so much money involved, "It's true that we are particularly wary, careful and diligent to the entire matter."

HEADLINE: THE U.N. ASSEMBLY;
Excerpts From Address By President to the U.N.

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech by President Bush before the General Assembly today: 
 Across the globe we all looked forward to a future free of war, a world where we might raise our children in peace and freedom. And this institution, the United Nations, born amidst the ashes of war, embodied those hopes and dreams like no other.
But the hopes and dreams of 1945 remained unfulfilled. Communist imperialism divided the world in two. Our hopes for peace and our dreams for freedom were frozen in the grip of cold war. . . .
And instead of uniting the nations, this body became a forum for distrust and division among nations. And in a cruel irony, the United Nations, created to free the world of conflict, became itself conflict's captive.
And now, 47 years later, we stand at the end of another war, the cold war, and our hopes and dreams have awakened again. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
'Three Critical Challenges'
 [T]he community of nations and the United Nations face three critical, interrelated challenges as we enter the 21st century.
First, we face the political challenge of keeping today's peace and preventing tomorrow's wars. As we see daily in Bosnia and Somalia and Cambodia, everywhere conflict claims innocent lives, the need for enhanced peacekeeping capabilities has never been greater, the conflicts we must deal with more intractable, the costs of conflict higher.
And second, we face the strategic challenge of the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, truly the fastest-growing security challenge. . . .
And third, we face the common economic challenge of promoting prosperity for all, of strengthening an open growth-oriented free-market international economic order, while safeguarding the environment. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
'To Prevent Conflict'
 Let me begin with peacekeeping. . . . Peacekeepers are stretched to the limit, while demands for their services increase by the day. The need for monitoring and preventive peacekeeping, putting people on the ground before the fighting starts, may become especially critical in volatile regions.
This is especially the case because of the rapid and turbulent change that continues to shake Eastern Europe and Eurasia. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	I welcome the Secretary-General's call for a new agenda to strengthen the United Nations ability to prevent, contain and resolve conflict across the globe. And today, I call upon all members to join me in taking bold steps to advance that agenda. I therefore will be discussing with my colleagues the merits of a special meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss the Secretary General's proposals, and to develop concrete responses in five key areas.
One, robust peacekeeping requires men and equipment that only member states can provide. . . . Two, if multinational units are to work together, they must train together. . . . And three, we also need to provide adequate logistical support for peacekeeping and humanitarian operations. . . . And four, we will need to develop planning, crisis management and intelligence capabilities for peacekeeping and humanitarian operations. And five, we must ensure adequate, equitable financing for United Nations and associated peacekeeping efforts. . . .
 
'We Will Emphasize Training'
 I have directed the United States Secretary of Defense to place a new emphasis on peacekeeping. Because of peacekeeping's growing importance as a mission for the United States military, we will emphasize training of combat, engineering and logistical units for the full range of peacekeeping and humanitarian activities. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	I have further directed the establishment of a permanent peacekeeping curriculum in United States military schools. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
'To Refocus' Arms Monitoring

 I want to announce my intention today to work with the United States Congress to redirect the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency . . . to refocus its talents on providing technical support for nonproliferation, weapons monitoring and destruction, and global defense conversion. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
'Overhaul' of Foreign Aid
 Since World War II, foreign assistance often served as a weapon in the cold war. . . . But foreign aid, as we've known it, needs to be transformed.

 	 	 		. . .	 	[W]orking with our Congress, I will propose a top-to-bottom overhaul of our institutions that plan and administer foreign assistance, drastically reducing the bureaucracy, . . . streamlining our delivery systems and strengthening support for private-sector development and economic reform.
The Agency for International Development, A.I.D., another institution born during the cold war, needs to be fundamentally and radically overhauled. Promoting economic security, opportunity and competitiveness will become a primary mission of the State Department.
Our assistance efforts should not be charity. On the contrary, they should promote mutual prosperity. Therefore, using existing foreign affairs resources, I will propose creating a $1 billion growth fund. The fund will provide grants and credits to support United States businesses in providing expertise, goods and services desperately needed in countries undertaking economic restructuring.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Media;
More News Also Good News For Bush: He Surges on TV

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
George Bush's stock may still be low in the polls. But in the secondary market of television, it is more than holding its own.
For the last few weeks, President Bush has succeeded in dominating the news with far more regularity than his opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton. Since the Republican convention, not only has the President received substantially more television coverage than the Arkansas Governor, but the tone of his coverage has improved, while the tone of Mr. Clinton's has declined.
 
Source of Consolation
 Analysts attribute Mr. Bush's new air strength to a more aggressive campaign that has put the power of incumbency to good use -- one week producing hurricane aid for Florida, the next saving military jobs in Texas. At the same time, though, they say, Mr. Clinton has helped the President to command the cameras by adopting a play-it-safe media strategy. 
 "The President has become much more active and takes a lot more air time," said Marvin Kalb, director of the Shorenstein Barone Center on Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University. "There's nothing Clinton can do about that. But Clinton is leading, and as the candidate who has managed to maintain a 10-point differential in the polls, it may not be to his advantage to be too adventurous in the way he puts himself forward."
The emergence of a "coverage gap" between Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton is one of the few legacies of the Republican convention from which the President's team can take real consolation.
According to the Center for Media and Public Affairs in Washington, between the California primary on June 2 and the start of the Republican convention Aug. 17 -- a period that included the Democratic convention in July -- Mr. Clinton held the lead in coverage on the network news shows: 454 minutes versus 400 minutes for the President.
During the Republican convention, Mr. Bush, not surprisingly, surged ahead, and since then he has maintained a comfortable advantage. Figures from the center show that in the weeks between the end of the convention and Labor Day, the President received 131 minutes of network news coverage to Mr. Clinton's 84. For Mr. Bush, this translated into an average of 2.6 minutes a night on each network, for Mr. Clinton an average of 1.6 minutes.
"Clinton's coverage per night has dropped since mid-August," Robert Lichter, co-director of the center, said. "He has not really recovered since the Republican convention."
After having been accused for weeks of favoring Mr. Clinton, news executives do not seem concerned about the recent upturn in Mr. Bush's coverage. "It seems like sort of the normal course of things," one network executive said.
The tactics the Bush campaign has used to dominate the news have been well tested by incumbents over the years: dispensing Federal goodies, attacking the challenger's fitness for higher office and making "major" Presidential addresses. These tactics do not seem to have lost their usefulness despite frequent repetition.
Twelve days ago, for example, when Mr. Bush gave an economic speech in Detroit, his address led the newscasts even though it contained little that was actually new. And last week, even the possibility that the President would attack Mr. Clinton before the National Guard Association -- he did not, in fact, do so -- was enough to prompt the networks to devote the top of their newscasts to a discussion of the Governor's draft record.
To be sure, at a time when so much of the news about the candidates is negative, getting too much attention, like getting too much sun, can produce unflattering results. The President's announcement earlier this month that he would save jobs in Texas by selling fighter jets to Taiwan, for instance, attracted widespread coverage, much of it unfavorable.
"It is a sign of the political trouble the President is in that he is adjusting foreign policy to help himself in Texas, his home state," ABC's Brit Hume said.
For the President, though, the tone of the television coverage, while often negative, has at least been improving. For Mr. Clinton, it has been getting worse.
August, according to the Center for Media and Public Affairs, marked the first month of the campaign in which people interviewed on the network news -- both average citizens and professional politicians -- gave Mr. Clinton a smaller proportion of positive reviews than they gave Mr. Bush. During that month, only 32 percent of those interviewed made favorable comments about Mr. Clinton, while 43 percent made positive remarks about the President, at least as the center interpreted those remarks. While such interpretations are partly subjective, there are a number of key words and phrases that are classified by the center as either positive or negative.
On several occasions, the President has been able to deprive Mr. Clinton of potentially favorable coverage simply by declining to participate himself. One such occasion came last night, when the Public Broadcasting Service televised an election special on minority voters; remarks by Mr. Clinton were eliminated from the broadcast because the President would not address the program. Similarly, when the President refused to participate in the debate scheduled for tonight, he insured that Mr. Clinton, too, would not be appearing.
 
Victim of Own Caution?
 The Clinton campaign has expressed some unhappiness about the fall-off in its coverage; last week, for example, campaign officials complained bitterly when an an endorsement of the Governor by chief executives in California went virtually unnoticed. But in addition to fighting a President in full campaign mode, the Clinton campaign, it seems, is also losing coverage to its own deliberately cautious strategy.
Over the last month, Mr. Clinton has consistently hewn to his by-now-familiar economic message, abandoning it only long enough to accept some endorsements or answer questions about the draft. Such consistency, while perhaps advisable for a man who is leading in the polls, does not often produce what could be called news.
"He has not been saying anything interesting, so there's been little to cover," Andrew Tyndall, publisher of a weekly newsletter on television and the election, said of Mr. Clinton. "It looks as if he's sitting on his lead."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

 BODY:

PRESIDENT BUSH
In an interview yesterday the the radio personality Rush Limbaugh in New York City.
"You asked me why people are upset. The deficits have been big under me. Why? Because we paid in this savings and loan mess for excesses. People -- private businesses did too much. They went out and loaned money that they shouldn't have loaned. And the taxpayer ends up getting burned, except I vowed we must protect every single depositor, and we've done that. Not a bailout from some institution. Protect the depositor. 
 We've protected him, but that adds to the deficit. So I have to bear some responsibility for that. I keep blaming Congress for certain things while accepting blame myself, because Congress has frustrated my economic growth program that I put before the American people in January. They didn't want to see the economy get better because they knew very well the politics worked against them. "
 
GOV. BILL CLINTON
At a news conference yesterday in Chicago.
"Keep in mind that most Americans according to the census are working harder today than they were 20 years ago for incomes, which, adjusted for inflation, are lower than they were 10 years ago. That is in spite of the fact of dramatic increases in productivity by some of the companies represented here and many companies in this country.
Why is that? It's because we have stubbornly refused to develop the kind of partnership for growth and opportunity in this country that the global economy requires, a partnership which will require us, in my judgment, to adopt an across-the-board investment tax credit for new plant and equipment so that we can continually have incentives to reinvest and modernize our plants here and our small businesses; a partnership that requires, in my judgment, the infusion of new amounts of venture capital into new ventures and therefore we ought to have a long-term capital gains treatment for investment in new ventures in America; a partnership that requires a comprehensive and permanent research and development tax credit and significant housing incentives to revitalize the construction industry in this country; and more importantly, a partnership that requires us to make a comprehensive long-term commitment to the education and training of all of our people and to creating a climate in this country that supports the development of new technologies, supports the revitalization of our manufacturing sector, supports and strengthens our effort to promote small business. "

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New York City to Sell 'Mini Bonds'

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
New York City is going to the little guy again. It announced yesterday its second offering of "mini bonds" meant for small investors.
The bonds, which will be sold in October, have face values of just $5,000. The first sale in February was very successful, with the city eventually selling $100 million worth, twice what it had planned to offer. This October's goal is $75 million, but that could rise. 
 In the Treasury market yesterday, prices fell across the board, except for the 10-year note, which was in such strong demand that traders said a "squeeze" was in play. A squeeze occurs when demand far outstrips supply, forcing some investors to pay high premiums for the securities they want.
The Treasury sold $10.3 billion in three-month bills yesterday at an average discount rate of 2.91 percent, up from 2.89 percent last week, and $10.3 billion in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 2.93 percent, up from 2.90 percent last week.
The downward pressure on the market was coming from the normal selling ahead of a Treasury auction -- the two-year note today -- and the uncertainty surrounding the first use of a new Treasury auction procedure in the sale today.
 
Advertising Planned
 To encourage the sale of the mini bonds, the city is planning to spend around a half of million dollars on advertising. There is also an "800" telephone number investors can use to ask questions about the sale and even indicate interest in buying bonds. If they do, investors will receive information in the mail and will be able to complete the purchase when the bonds are priced and sold during the week of Oct. 19. The number is 800-874-3645.
 
Regular City Sale
 The sale of the mini bonds is part of the city's regular quarterly trip to the bond market to raise funds. The city intends to sell about $1 billion of various types of securities with a broad range of maturities, according to Darcy Bradbury, the Deputy City Comptroller for Finance. The sale will include both tax-exempt and taxable bonds, and the variable-rate bonds that are the basis of New York City tax-exempt money market funds.
The mini bonds are zero-coupon bonds, which pay no regular interest but are sold at a deep discount to their face value. The discount is based on the earnings from the assumed interest rate over the term of the bond. When the bond matures, the investor reaps the gains from the interest by being paid the face value of the bond.
Mini bond maturities will range from 5 to 20 years. A 10-year bond, for example, based on current market interest rates, would have a rate of around 5.95 percent. This means the price of a $5,000 bond would be $2,794, with the full $5,000 paid to the investor in October 2002.
 
Not for All Investors
 Ms. Bradury of the comptroller's office said that mini bonds were not for everyone. She said retirees, for example, who need current income, would probably find more suitable investments elsewhere, as would investors with few other assets. Such investors might have to cash in mini bonds before maturity, she said, and face possible losses because mini's are volatile and can be difficult to sell quickly at a good price.
According to a poll done by the comptroller's office of those who bought the city's first issue of mini bonds in February, 62 percent said they bought the bonds to pay future education costs or for their retirement funds.
 
Municipal Prices Off
 In the municipal bond market yesterday, prices were off from 1/8 to 1/4 point. Stephen C. Leslie, a senior vice president at M. R. Beal & Company in New York, said that the market was being weighed down by the large amount of municipal offerings scheduled for this week.
He said that just the top 10 issuers this week could sell up $5.5 billion in new securities. But he said that the soft condition of the market might make some of the issues delay their sales, which happened last week.
 
Treasury Market
 In secondary market trading, the 7.25 percent 30-year Treasury bond was down 9/32 to 98 26/32 to yield 7.34 percent, up from 7.32 percent on Friday.
In the preauction or when-issued market, yields rose sharply on both the two-year and five year notes. The yield on the five-year note, which will be auctioned tomorrow, jumped sharply, to 5.46 percent, and the yield on the two-year note was up to 3.93 percent.
But the 10-year note finished up 1/32, to yield 6.40 percent. Traders said the note was in great demand, in part because many dealers have used it to hedge against their exposures in the corporate, mortgage and municipal markets.
One measure of the demand for the 10-year note was the cost of borrowing the securities. This cost is measured by how little in interest a dealer can earn on the cash given in exchange for borrowing the securities. The closer this figure is to zero, the more demand there is and the bigger the squeeze, or cost, for investors or dealers who need the security. Yesterday, this interest rate fell to four-tenths of 1 percent.
 
New Auction System
 There were several forces pushing down the prices of other notes and bonds. One was today's trial run of a new Treasury auction system being tested over the next year. Currently, the securities in an auction are awarded at a variety of prices, depending on the range of bids. In the test, all the securities will be awarded at one price, the lowest of the accepted bids.
The purpose is to get dealers to make more aggressive bids because they know that they will get the lowest price in the end. In the current system, one dealer may pay more than another.
The uncertainty surrounding the exact working of the new system is making dealers more cautious, traders said.
In addition, dealers yesterday may have been trying to push the price of the two- and the five-year notes down to raise the yield and win what they call a concession in the auction. This means they can buy the notes cheaper and have a better chance for a profit later.
The very narrow yes vote in France Sunday on the referendum on European unity may also have had an impact. It meant that it is less likely that interest rates there will be cut soon, which means United States rates will not fall as fast as they have been.
Following are the results of yesterday's sale of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Board in California Approves Scholarship Fund for Whites

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 21

 BODY:
The governing body of the University of California has unanimously accepted a bequest from a school teacher that will provide scholarships for poor whites only.
The donation, estimated at $513,842, comes from the estate of Marguerite E. Hornbeck, an alumna of the University of California at Berkeley who never forgot her impoverished childhood. 
 When she died at the age of 87 in March 1990, Ms. Hornbeck left the university property in Hawaii and San Francisco, as well as miscellaneous belongings, but attached the stipulation that all proceeds from her estate "be used to finance a university scholarship there for very poor American Caucasian" students. Ms. Hornbeck, who was white, alluded to the hardships she endured while growing up but did not say why she chose to help only white students.
Robert Sanders, a spokesman for the University of California at Berkeley, said that the 10-campus University of California system has several scholarships for students of specific national, racial and even geographic origins, but he added that this would be the first limited to Caucasians.
 
'Person Was Well-Intentioned'
 University policy allows donors to establish scholarships for students on the basis of race, color, national origin, religion or sex as long as enough unrestricted funds are available to provide equivalent support for other students.
Jeremiah Hallisey is one of the University of California's 18 regents, and he voted with the board on Friday to accept Ms. Hornbeck's gift. "I had a question about it, but it was couched in terms of poor Caucasian students, and I don't think the donative intent was other than what it said," he said. "I think the person was well-intentioned."
Nonetheless, the restrictions included in the scholarship have led some people in the university community to voice concern.
"One reason this issue is so politically and economically charged is that it is taking place in a context of declining financial aid and rising college costs," said Jerome Karabel, an associate professor of sociology at Berkeley who wrote a report that set the university's admissions policy.
 
Recounting Hardships
 Two years before she died, Ms. Hornbeck wrote the university's Office of Trusts and Bequests and told of her intention to establish the fellowship.
She also provided a short autobiography in which she said that her father had died when she was a young girl, forcing her to work six days a week as a telephone operator, for which she earned $15 dollars. She wrote that her mother and her sister, Jonette Distensa Ensign, also had to work. The scholarship financed by the bequest is to be named the Ensign-Hornbeck scholarship for the donor and her sister.
"My early life has made me very concerned about the very very poor American Caucasian students who are struggling to get a university education," Ms. Hornbeck wrote.
After graduating from Berkeley, she worked as public school teacher in San Francisco, saving and investing in real estate. At the time she wrote to the Office of Trusts and Bequests in March 1989 she explained that she had outlived all immediate family members and so could not donate the money immediately.
"I have no one to lean on financially if I get a long-term illness," she wrote, adding that she did not expect to suffer such an infirmity because her only complaint was a minor one: "old-age arthritis."

HEADLINE: Status Quo in Haiti Slips Into Mere Stagnation

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 18

 BODY:
When 18 international human-rights observers began arriving here this month, many Haitians welcomed what they hoped would be the mission's calming effect after the year of fear and violence that followed the overthrow of the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
But with the deployment of the team from the Organization of American States, few in Haiti, be they the President's supporters or his bitter foes, expressed faith that diplomacy alone could bring a return to democracy. 
 For Father Aristide's enemies, bolstered by their successes in surviving an embargo declared 11 months ago, the mission was seen as a small concession to the outside world, one they hoped would soon return Haiti's international relations to normal. Failing that, many said, they are prepared to continue defying pressures for the deposed President's return.
"Nothing much is going to change, because we will just keep hanging in there, whatever it takes," said a businessman who, like many among a small moneyed class, is violently opposed to the President's return.
Conceived months ago as a mission of 500 people or more who would help prepare the President's return by deterring violence and reinforcing the justice system, the deployment has been limited to 18 people by the country's military-backed Government.
"This is truly negligible," said Rene Theodore, the leader of Haiti's small Communist Party, who has been selected by Father Aristide as a compromise choice for Prime Minister.
Diplomats associated with the mediation effort are split: Some express skepticism that Haiti's military leadership and the civilian Government it installed can be brought to seriously negotiate Father Aristide's return; others, while acknowledging long odds, still hold out hope.
"I think that eventually they will consider the President's return and that Aristide will again be back in the picture," said one diplomat.
Other diplomats said that with responsibility for hundreds of deaths on their hands, and the deposed President's insistence that they be punished, no amount of talking is likely to make Haiti's army leaders resign. Moreover, they said, many in the army have grown rich in a contraband market that has flourished under the international embargo.
Close supporters of the provisional Prime Minister, Marc L. Bazin, say the world should work with his Government to rebuild the economy and professionalize the armed forces. With progress, they say, the elected President might be able to return.
"I don't think that if Aristide ever returns to this country it will be because of the international community," a close adviser to Mr. Bazin said. "If he returns it will either be through revolution, or through working quietly to establish a climate of peace and reconciliation, and that would be a very positive thing for this country."
But even as they worried that international measures to secure his return would prove insufficient, supporters of Father Aristide said there was no reason to take such talk of reconciliation seriously.
"If we have learned one thing," said Wesner Emmanuel, a Senator whose party endorsed Father Aristide, "it is that for all of those involved in supporting the coup, the return of Aristide signifies a total failure."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Finances;
Angry at Bush, Republican Contributors Are Helping Clinton

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Kathryn G. Thompson was a precinct worker for Barry Goldwater in 1964, a staunch supporter of Ronald Reagan in the 1980's, a Bush delegate at the 1988 Republican National Convention and a member of Team 100, the elite contributors to the Republican Party who each gave more than $100,000.
Last Thursday Ms. Thompson gave a luncheon in Costa Mesa, Calif., for 800 mostly Republican women to raise nearly $100,000 for the Presidential campaign and to honor a woman that Ms. Thompson has come to admire: Hillary Clinton. 
 Ms. Thompson, the head of a large California real estate development company that bears her name, is hardly alone. Gov. Bill Clinton's highly successful fund-raising drive has been collecting millions of dollars from a growing cadre of Wall Street bankers and corporate executives who, until this year, had been dyed-in-the-wool supporters of Republicans.
And today, at a news conference in Chicago, the Clinton-Gore campaign made public a list of about 400 corporate executives who have endorsed the Democratic ticket. Accompanying Mr. Clinton to the news conference were 100 representatives of big, medium and small businesses, and about a third of them identified themselves as Republicans who had previously supported Mr. Bush.
 
Gains in Fund Raising
 
 
Mr. Clinton has tapped into a well of Republican financial and political support that other Democratic Presidential candidates have not been able to touch, and it stretches from the conservative citadel of Orange County, Calif., to the investment houses of lower Manhattan. In the last few months he has courted discontented Republicans, and it is now beginning to pay off.
Largely with their financial help, Mr. Clinton's fund-raising machine believes it has surged well ahead of the Bush-Quayle campaign's. Democratic officials say they will have completed virtually all of their fund raising in the next two weeks, surpassing Michael S. Dukakis's $53 million general election drive of four years ago.
Mr. Bush's finance officials say they have fewer of their larger contributors than in 1988 and are far off their anticipated revenue, but are hoping to have a strong fund-raising month in October.
Donald R. Sweitzer, a Clinton fund raiser who was the finance director for the Democratic National Committee in 1988, said: "A lot of the fresh money this year is coming from Republican business-types. Some don't agree philosophically with all of Clinton's views, but they believe Bush's policies have failed and that he has betrayed them."
For Ms. Thompson, whose California company constructs 1,000 homes in good years but has built only about 300 this year, her unhappiness with the President has "been building up for almost four years," she said.
"As the recession came upon us and we had numerous meetings with the President and his staff," she said, "we got a lack of acknowledgement of the recession. Last October, at a Team 100 meeting, we urged the President to come out strongly to deal with it. But there was a continuous denial."
"I made my final decision after the Republican convention," Ms. Thompson continued. "I couldn't listen anymore to the intolerance, to the hate, that was coming out of the convention. And when the President, the leader of the party, said he hadn't read the party's platform, I thought that was outrageous."
The executives who have come out for Mr. Clinton publicly include the heads of Apple Computer, Hewlett-Packard, Sara Lee and Xerox.
 
Coming Out for Democrats
 Kenneth Brody, who heads Mr. Clinton's fund-raising efforts in New York, supported Republican Presidential candidates until last year, when he started to raise money for the Arkansas Governor. Mr. Brody, a limited partner at the Wall Street firm of Goldman Sachs, has helped raise more than $6 million for the primaries and the general election.
"It's not easy for C.E.O.'s to come out for Democrats," Mr. Brody said. "Most of the people they deal with are Republicans. Their boards are Republicans. When I first got involved in this I did some research and found that no Democrat had ever got the support of a really large group of C.E.O.'s. Now it is happening in spades. People are willing to step up."
Almost uniformly, the Republican stalwarts who have switched allegiances describe a deep disillusionment with the economic and social policies of the Bush Presidency and a concern that their party has moved too far to the right.
"I decided that President Bush shouldn't have a second term in view of his record in the first one," said David O. Maxwell, who retired last year as the head of the Federal National Mortgage Association and was a senior official in the Nixon Administration.
"The Administration has not been notably successful in managing the economy, and as a consequence the deficit has increased," he said. "I am strongly pro-choice, and the Clarence Thomas hearing was upsetting. Even worse was the Administration's position against fetal tissue research, which became tremendously ideological."
In the Chicago news conference today, Mr. Clinton said the business people supported him "not because they agree with me on everything, not because they think I have all the answers, but because I have pledged to them to listen, to work and to make progress."
"Clinton has convinced me that he is a different kind of a Democrat," said Roger W. Johnson, chairman and chief executive of the Western Digital Corporation, a manufacturer of computer parts in Irvine, Calif. He voted for Dwight D. Eisenhower and has voted for every Republican Presidential nominee since then. But this year he is raising money for Mr. Clinton.
"When I met him, I asked him to talk about economic affairs, health care and women's issues, and I liked what I heard," Mr. Johnson said of the Arkansas Governor. "He understands the depth and complexity of problems but doesn't throw his hand up. I'm afraid my own party thinks the problems will just fix themselves."
Mr. Johnson said he is not relishing the prospect of paying higher taxes under a Clinton administration, but many of the other converts say they are not troubled by such increases because they believe the Democrats stand a better chance of turning the economy around.
"It can't be all financial," said Roy Furman, president of the Wall Street investment house of Furman, Selz Inc., who voted for Mr. Bush and Mr. Reagan and this year has been the host for several fund-raising dinners in New York for Mr. Clinton. "It can't be just because one guy saves you a dollar he's better. You have to ask, 'Is it worth paying more money in taxes if you will revitalize the country?' "

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 6.22 in Light, Cautious Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market closed lower yesterday in light, cautious trading dominated by uncertainty over Europe's proposed monetary union.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down by nearly 16 points early in the session, recouped the earlier losses, closing down 6.22 points at 3,320.83. Stock markets in London and Tokyo also posted small losses yesterday. 
 Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 10 to 7 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was light, with 153.9 million shares changing hands, down from 237.4 million in the previous session.
With no new economic reports during the session, stock market participants closely followed trends in the currency and bond markets after the French on Sunday narrowly endorsed the Maastricht treaty.
The pact is designed to unite the 12-nation European Community in economic, foreign and military policies and a single currency by 1999. Expectations of the possible "no" vote by the French contributed to last week's chaos in the currency markets.
Passage of the referendum steadied currency prices but sent United States Treasury bond prices lower, said Alfred Goldman, vice president of A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis.
"Until the currency situation is clarified and economic news emerges, the market will remain in this narrow trading range," said Dick Stein, chief technical analyst for the MKI Securities Corporation.
 
Technical Force Depresses Stocks
 A key technical force also depressed stock prices -- the expiration on Friday of stock options and index futures contracts, known as the "triple witching." Mr. Stein said stock prices generally retreat a session after advancing because of the technical effects of an options expiration.
Buyouts and takeovers accounted for heavy trading in several companies. The Travelers Corporation of Hartford was up 3 1/8 at 20 5/8 in active trading after it agreed to sell a 27 percent stake to the Primerica Corporation for $550 million.
The First Union Corporation, the Charlotte, N.C., banking company, fell 1, to 37, after it disclosed an agreement to buy Dominion Bankshares. The Virginia-based banking company was up 3 1/4 at 19 5/8 in active over-the-counter trading.
In over-the-counter trading, Rasterops of Santa Clara, Calif., was off 3 1/2 at 5 3/4, a decline of nearly 61 percent, after the technology company said sales would be off significantly in the third quarter.
Earnings reports also inspired trading. Nike gained 3/4, to 76 3/8, after reporting earnings rose only 7.4 percent in its first fiscal quarter from the period a year before. General Mills was delayed for trading because of an imbalance of buy and sell orders after it reported a 12 percent increase in first-quarter earnings. The stock did not resume trading for the day and the last price indication was 68 1/4. The stock closed at 72 3/4 on Friday.
Chrysler, up 3/4, to 24, led the active list on the Big Board, with analysts saying the buying was linked to introduction of the car marker's new LH automobiles. Other active issues on the Big Board included Merck , down 3/4, to 46 5/8; GTE Corporation, up 1/4, to 33 1/2; and the Chemical Banking Corporation, down 1/4, to 30 3/4.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index closed down 0.50 point at 231.89. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 2.78 points, to 382.72.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Surge in Natural-Gas Prices Takes Them to 7-Year High

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The month-old surge in natural-gas prices continued yesterday as prices registered one of their biggest one-day advances in the futures market, with the contract for October delivery rising 12.4 cents to settle at $2.452 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Gas prices have now risen 60 cents, or 33 percent, since Hurricane Andrew tore through prime gas-production fields in the Gulf of Mexico four weeks ago, temporarily knocking out 5 percent of the nation's daily gas output. 
 Gas in the spot market has not traded above $2.40 in the month of September for more than seven years, and has averaged less than $2 since 1985, when the average was $2.51.
Traders and analysts said that prices were pushed higher yesterday in part by the Government's report Friday that about one billion cubic feet of lost production would not be fully restored until December. Another billion cubic feet of lost output has been restored.
The report, by the Minerals Management Service, came after the close of trading Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analysts said that gas purchasers were still rebuilding storage levels that were behind schedule for the winter heating season a month ago.
 
'Bullish Psychology'
 "The market has had another dramatic increase on an extremely bullish psychology," said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. He said that many producers had reported selling gas in the cash market for between $2.35 and $2.40.
Buying patterns in the futures market indicated that gas prices could be trading at higher levels for several months. The average price for 12 monthly contracts through September 1993 was $2.063, the highest since trading in gas futures contracts began on the New York Mercantile Exchange in April 1990. The previous record was $2.05 in early December 1990.
In Texas, which produces 27 percent of the nation's gas, regulators said Friday that they had sharply increased output volumes for October, in part to enable producers to make up for any shortfall from shuttered wells in the Gulf of Mexico.
Most major producers, cheered by the higher gas prices, said that they were producing at close to their capacity and that they did not expect to fall behind on winter deliveries.
The ARCO Oil and Gas Company, which had opposed the new output laws now in effect in the Southwest, said that its Texas output had risen and that its Oklahoma production had fallen by less than 1 percent of its total domestic output.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower In Wake of Vote in France

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower yesterday in trading in the wake of France's favorable vote on the Maastricht treaty.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $347.50 a troy ounce, down $3.70 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $3.50 an ounce to a late bid price of $347.50. 
 Dealers said the French vote narrowly favoring closer European monetary and political ties eased much of the turmoil that has gripped currency markets.
The British pound continued to be driven sharply lower. In London, the pound fell to $1.7130, from $1.7375 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.7085 to buy one pound, cheaper than Friday's $1.7345. A few weeks ago the pound was trading at around $2.
 
Speculation on British Move
 Traders said speculation was rife that Britain would lower interest rates this week. Since suspending its link to the other leading European currencies, Britain "does not have to be as committed to defending the value of the pound and can concentrate on getting its economy going," said Mike Faust, an analyst with MMS International. Lower interest rates help stimulate growth by making borrowing more attractive.
Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said that despite the pressure on Germany to lower interest rates, the Bundesbank was likely to wait a few weeks before modestly easing rates.
Meanwhile, relatively little fresh economic data are expected to be released this week that would influence the dollar. Traders said the spotlight would remain on developments in Europe.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124 yen, down 0.33 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 123.70 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 123.75 yen, down from 124.55 yen on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.4835 German marks, down from 1.5035; 1.3030 Swiss francs, down from 1.3075; 5.0750 French francs, down from 5.1445; 1,254.00 Italian lire, down from 1,258.00, and 1.2321 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2168.
