HEADLINE: Trade's Long March;
Current U.S. Talks With China a Step On a Journey Expected to Take Years

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 20

 BODY:
As the United States and China prepare for what are likely to be nonstop negotiations to conclude a trade pact by Oct. 10, economists and Government officials say that this is only the beginning of years of tough talks for China as its trading partners demand it open its highly protected economy.
Now that China has emerged from decades of near-isolation to become a trading power, the United States is demanding in effect that it hasten the process of dismantling a huge apparatus of protection for its industries, most of it informal and all but impenetrable to outsiders. 
 The battling, the experts and officials said, is really over the fundamental character of the Chinese economy -- a process that is not very different from the unending trade clashes Washington has had with Japan and other Asian countries.
 
Others Have Also Complained
 The United States is not alone. Japan, South Korea and the European Community have at various times filed trade charges against China, complaining that it was dumping products into foreign markets at unfairly low prices.
China has tried over the last decade to transform its socialist economy from within, at its own pace. Now it is under pressure from outside to speed up the process considerably, and to adopt the West's rules.
"Nobody thinks that even if the Chinese agreed to everything being demanded here that this would be the end," said Nicholas R. Lardy, a professor at the University of Washington and an expert on the Chinese economy. "There are a series of problems."
Clyde Prestowitz, a senior trade official in the Reagan Administration and now president of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington, added: "This is just the opening shot. Now that the cold war is gone, there's less reason for the U.S. to hold back. They will push this to the limit."
Some Chinese officials acknowledge that beyond the current demand for broad reductions in barriers to imports, a number of other issues remain, like the removal of barriers against specific products and the ending of various price subsidies that make foreign products uncompetitive.
In a sign of how difficult and bitter these negotiations could become, a Government official was quoted today as saying that American trade demands might force China to cancel a recent $130 million agreement to purchase American autos.
 
Car Deal Called Uncertain
 The China Daily said in a front-page article that trade officials here were uncertain whether they would go through with what would be the largest Chinese acquisition of American-made cars. The deal was with General Motors, Ford and Chrysler. Earlier, Chinese newspapers quoted officials as saying China might halt purchases of American wheat.
When American negotiators announced on Aug. 21 a list of $3.9 billion of imports from China that could be hit with punitive tariffs if a deal was not reached by the Oct. 10 deadline set by Washington, the Chinese offered their own list of American-made products on which they would slap punitive tariffs.
Adding to the tension is President Bush's recent decision to sell 150 F-16 jet fighters to Taiwan, which China views as a rebel province.
Each of China's tough responses in the negotiation process has only underscored the potential that the continuing trade demands have for creating strains in the relationship between Beijing and Washington.
China has a great deal at stake. In the span of a decade, it has gone from being a relative economic hermit to become a global trading power. Trade now accounts for more than 32 percent of the swiftly expanding Chinese economy, compared with 9.9 percent in 1978, and it is expected to import and export $165 billion worth of goods this year.
What has brought Washington's ire is that China's trade surplus with the United States has soared. It was $12.7 billion last year and is expected to be as much as $19 billion this year.
Foreign products are increasingly finding their way into Chinese department stores or into industrial plants these days. But those are usually in carefully selected industries where the Chinese feel they can open up without harming essential domestic industries, experts say.
Mr. Lardy said one of the greatest problems China faced in making broader changes was that it tended to use administrative and other informal barriers to imports rather than tariffs.
Most imports, in other words, are blocked by bureaucratic decree. Not only are those decrees difficult to reverse, but once they are removed it means China will have no rational system in place to exercise control over its trade.
"They know they have a big apparatus to enforce these arbitrary rules," Mr. Lardy commented. "They know they're vulnerable."
He added: "They're in a terrible situation, because if they ever really did remove the administrative barriers, they'd be flooded with imports. They're in for a tough transition."

HEADLINE: Lessons From a Hurricane: It Pays Not to Gouge

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
The price of a sheet of exterior plywood -- a coveted commodity for patching up hurricane-battered houses -- was actually reduced on Sept. 14 at Home Depot stores supplying south Dade County, where Hurricane Andrew destroyed or damaged more than 75,000 homes. And since the hurricane struck on Aug. 24, the price of plywood at Home Depot stores in South Florida has increased only about half as much as the market price for plywood. 
 Executives from Home Depot, the largest building-materials retailer in the area, and Georgia-Pacific, the nation's biggest plywood producer, explain this price restraint as an act of collective corporate responsibility, forgoing millions of dollars in profit rather than benefiting from human misery.
 
A Half-Truth?
 Such magnanimity is a half-truth at best, economists reply. In post-disaster situations, they say, "fairness constraints" limit how much companies raise prices on scarce goods, even when suppliers are guided purely by self-interest. The principle is part of a subfield of a dismal science called behavioral economics, which, among other things, tries to decipher how the attitudes of consumers and regulators influence companies to refrain from capitalism's natural impulse -- pricing goods at whatever the market will bear.
The explanation is that consumers remember price-gouging suppliers and will avoid, or even boycott, them once shortages subside. Government agencies can also prod companies into line by threatening penalties against companies that appear to exceed the bounds of fair play.
"People will punish firms that behave unfairly," said Richard Thaler, an economist at the Cornell University business school. Mr. Thaler was one of three authors of a minor classic of behavioral economics, "Fairness as a Constraint on Profit-Seeking," in the American Economic Review in 1986.
The article by Mr. Thaler; Daniel Kahneman, a psychologist at the University of California at Berkeley, and Jack Knetsch, an economist at Simon Fraser University in Vancouver, British Columbia, was based on hundreds of survey questions asked consumers seeking to determine "norms of fairness." An example: a hardware store, which had been charging $15 each for snow shovels, raises the price to $20 the morning after a big snowstorm. Eighty two percent of those polled replied that the price rise was unfair.
The three academics found that in general, people do not believe that scarcity is a good reason for a supplier to raise prices -- precisely the situation in South Florida after Hurricane Andrew.
What happened in the plywood market here after the storm is a classic example of fairness constraints at work. Home Depot, big producers like Georgia-Pacific and Louisiana-Pacific, government agencies and public opinion all played their scripted roles.
The big companies performed far differently than the price-gougers selling ice, water and lumber from the back of pickup trucks at wildly inflated prices in the first week after the hurricane hit. Classic economic theory, of course, defends these unrestrained entrepreneurs as utilitarian opportunists, encouraged by high profits to increase supplies of scarce goods. But unlike the carpetbagging vendors, who drove away at sunset, the big companies have a long-term stake in the South Florida market.
For them, the good will of local customers and government officials is a valuable asset. And for them, ignoring the fairness constraints could be costly. In short, the companies were presented the opportunity to do well by doing good, pleasing the shareholders and the communities where they do business.
"It is perfectly sensible for profit-maximizing firms to exercise price restraint in a situation like the aftermath of Hurricane Andrew," said Lawrence Katz, a Harvard economist.
The problems in the plywood market started to loom even before the storm arrived. With forecasters saying the hurricane was heading toward the Miami area, the Home Depot stores in South Florida were jammed on the weekend before the storm hit on Aug. 24. "People were clamoring for plywood," said Bruce Berg, president of Home Depot's southeast division. "There was a full-scale panic in Miami."
The 19 Home Depot stores in southeast Florida, Mr. Berg said, sold more 4-foot-by-8-foot sheets of exterior plywood in those two days than they usually sold in two weeks, emptying the company's distribution centers in Tampa and Atlanta. Besides, he adds, inventories were low after the peak summer building season and supplies were tight nationally because some lands in the Pacific Northwest had been placed off-limits for logging for environmental reasons.
After the storm hit, things got worse. In the first few days, Home Depot held its prices on plywood at pre-hurricane levels, but it was seeing its prices from suppliers jump sharply, up more than 30 percent on some daily quotes.
"You can argue the ethics of it, but it has happened many, many times before," Mr. Berg said of such scarcity-related price spikes. The market price of plywood soared after Hurricane Hugo hit South Carolina in 1989, for example.
 
Policy Is Announced
 On Friday, Aug. 28, Home Depot announced its policy for four storm-related building materials: exterior plywood, roofing shingles, roofing felt and polyethylene sheeting. The Atlanta-based retailer said it would sell those products at its delivered cost plus freight, thus taking no profit. There would also be quantity limits, like 25 sheets of plywood per customer. The rationing was to prevent unscrupulous operators from buying large quantities from Home Depot and reselling the items at inflated prices.
Home Depot, which buys directly from producers, was also negotiating with its big suppliers like Louisiana-Pacific and Georgia-Pacific to try to roll back plywood prices. Louisiana-Pacific agreed to freeze prices at pre-hurricane levels in the South Florida market on Aug. 28, while Georgia-Pacific followed on Sept. 4. The price curbs will last through September, and Georgia-Pacific has frozen plywood prices nationally for a month at the level reached at the end of August.
For its part, Georgia-Pacific has 16 mills and distribution centers in Florida and owns about 500,000 acres of timberland in Florida. "We're there for the long term and this seemed to be the responsible thing to do," said David Mortensen, a Georgia-Pacific executive vice president.
Still, the price rollbacks did come after the Florida attorney general's office issued subpoenas on Aug. 26 seeking pricing information from nine plywood suppliers including Georgia-Pacific and Louisiana-Pacific. The subpoenas were a response to local contractors' complaints that their plywood prices had doubled in a week's time. Florida's Attorney General, Robert A. Butterworth, colorfully declared that the only difference between a looter and a price-gouger was that "the price-gouger may wear a suit and tie."
The producers vigorously denied trying to take advantage of the shortages, noting that local contractors typically bought from wholesalers. Yet the prices producers charge customers in the Southeast have increased 28 percent, from $258 per 1,000 square feet before the hurricane to $330 on Sept. 18, according to Random Lengths, a weekly newsletter in Eugene, Ore.
Still, the moves by Georgia-Pacific and Louisiana-Pacific have helped Home Depot curb price increases, from $8.65 for a standard half-inch-thick sheet of exterior plywood before Hurricane Andrew to $10.15. The price was cut on Sept. 14 from $10.65, reflecting the recent settling in producer prices.
The companies that have helped cool the plywood-price spiral are receiving praise from many quarters. Philip Bloom, a contractor, says Home Depot and major producers "did a great job holding the line." Les Garringer, director of the Florida Attorney General's economic-crimes unit, commended Georgia-Pacific and Louisiana-Pacific for their "responsible behavior." And, he said:"We're very pleased with Home Depot's actions. They were the first to step forward to hold prices down."
Kerry L. Herndon, an ornamental flower grower in Homestead, marveled at the "unbelievably cheap" price on the sheets of plywood he bought from Home Depot. "If they had spent $50 million on advertising, they couldn't have bought the good will they got by doing this," he said.
In Kendall, on the northern edge of the hard-hit portion of south Dade County, Jeff Barrington is managing a makeshift Home Depot under a tent beside one of the company's storm-damaged stores. In shorts, baseball cap and an orange Home Depot apron, Mr. Barrington recognizes that the company's fair-play pricing policy was a shrewd business decision.
"This will pay us back -- people will remember," he said. Nearby, a small table has been set up for hiring. The plan is to add 75 people to the 130-member staff of the 80,000-square-foot store. "There is obviously going to be a lot of rebuilding around here soon, and the business here is really going to take off," he said.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The Mothball Era In Arms Industry

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE Lockheed Corporation's factory complex in Burbank, Calif., is nearly empty now. With military work declining in the post-cold-war era, Lockheed shifted warplane production to newer plants to keep them busy. The most talked-about activity at the nearly deserted Burbank complex takes place in a corner of an otherwise unused building: a group of companies -- potential parts suppliers for a future electric car -- have borrowed floor space to assemble the sort of car they would like to help manufacture.
Across America, weapons factories stand empty or partly empty. Some, like the Lockheed complex in Burbank, date back to World War II and are no longer suitable for conversion to modern production of civilian products. But others are new, like the $100 million California plant that the Rockwell International Corporation built to produce the B1-B bomber, which has been canceled. Together with thousands of former employees, the old and the new are in effect mothballed. 
 "Easily one-third if not more of the military industry's production capacity is down now," said Greg Bischak, executive director of the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, a Washington organization.
Sam F. Iacobellis, chief operating officer of Rockwell International, does not challenge such data. "All military contractors have excess facilities," he said. "We had no reason to believe that the Berlin wall would come down or that the Soviet Union would break apart, and we overexpanded."
Most military contractors want the Federal Government to prevent the industry from shrinking much further. Congress should put a floor under military spending cuts so that the United States can maintain its role as a superpower, they argue. Others, outside the industry, counter that Pentagon spending should be channeled instead into converting military plants to civilian production. The Government would be the chief customer in these hard times, given the reluctance of the private sector to buy the products already available from commercial companies.
Shipyards now dedicated to making Navy warships, for example, could produce a new generation of supertankers with double hulls to protect against oil spills. Tank and aircraft factories could make pipes, electronic equipment, rail cars and other goods for public-works projects. Such spending, the argument goes, will create more jobs than the same dollars devoted to weaponry.
But while this debate proceeds, the huge military industry keeps shrinking, and the idled factories and lost jobs -- more than 300,000 since 1989 -- seem to be inflicting permanent damage on the American economy, now suffering from prolonged stagnation. The story of Barry Beggs, a 31-year-old systems engineer, and his colleagues illustrates the damage.
Mr. Beggs, educated in California, became a specialist in designing the systems that make fighter planes work. After three years at the Grumman Corporation, he joined the General Dynamics Corporation in Fort Worth to help design systems for the A12 fighter. But that project was canceled and Mr. Beggs was laid off early last year, along with 1,200 other engineers.
Twenty percent of that group have left engineering and are trying to get jobs in other fields, according to a survey conducted by a Fort Worth engineers association. The nation has lost them as trained engineers. Another 16 percent migrated to military jobs in other cities, often at lower pay. "They still see their future in military work," Mr. Beggs said. "It is very difficult for an engineer to send a resume listing a military background. There seems to be a bias against us."
Still, Mr. Beggs, like most of his jobless colleagues, sent out such resumes -- with mixed results. Losing his General Dynamics salary of $42,000, he was unemployed for seven months, finally getting work with a newly formed Fort Worth company that designs software for personal computers. The job paid $30,000 and lasted three months; the company then ran short of money.
Leaving Fort Worth, Mr. Beggs ended up in Durham, N.C., where a company called Analysts International has obtained contract work for him, currently at Northern Telecom Inc., where he designs data bases. The pay is a bit higher than at General Dynamics, but that is offset by the lack of benefits; the work is quite different from designing warplane systems.
By most estimates, at least 20 percent of the nation's scientists and engineers are employed in military work. That represents a huge potential loss of highly skilled people as military spending shrinks. So far, few programs exist to retrain engineers like Mr. Beggs to save them for commercial work. "I have had to acquire new skills on my own," Mr. Beggs said. "If Analysts International has a job and I have my skills up, they'll place me, and if I don't keep up my skills, they won't place me."

HEADLINE: After 17 Years, NASA Prepares for a Return Trip to Mars

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
SEVENTEEN years after the last American flights to Mars, a spacecraft is set to depart on a $900 million mission of renewed exploration of the one other world in the solar system where humans might conceivably make a home away from Earth.
"America is going back to Mars," said Dr. Wesley T. Huntress, director of solar system exploration for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, putting the simplest interpretation on the importance of the new mission. 
 Elaborating on the mission's scientific context, Dr. Arden L. Albee of the California Institute of Technology, the chief project scientist, said: "Previous missions have dispelled much of the mystery that's surrounded Mars. Mars is alive and complex, much like Earth. We have explored it and are now going back to observe it."
The agent of this new round of planetary investigation is the 5,700-pound spacecraft Mars Observer, which is to be launched Friday at Cape Canaveral, Fla., by a Titan 3 rocket with a powerful new upper-stage booster.
Anxiety is running high among scientists and spacecraft engineers, who have not waited out a countdown for flights to Mars since 1975. This time there is only one craft, with no backup. And they must get it going by Oct. 13, or else face a costly delay of two years until Mars is again in proper alignment with Earth.
Nine days of the launching opportunity were squandered when workers recently discovered metal flakes, paint chips and other contamination all over the spacecraft and had to haul it back to the hangar for a thorough cleaning. Some officials said this added to the vague unease that haunts the final days of any countdown and may be more worrisome this time because Mars Observer, built by the General Electric Company under the direction of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., had encountered so many development troubles.
If all goes well, though, Mars Observer will embark on an 11-month voyage, then swing into an orbit of Mars. From an altitude of 242 miles, the craft will cross both poles once every 117 minutes and return more data about the red planet than were transmitted by all previous missions to Mars.
Mariner 9 was the first spacecraft to orbit Mars, in 1971 and 1972, producing the first maps of another planet based on almost complete photographic coverage and demolishing forever legends of Martians who left a network of canals irrigating their dying civilization. Two Viking spacecraft, launched in 1975, reached Mars a year later for the first successful landings and automated experiments examining Martian soil for signs of biological activity -- and finding none. The most recent probes to Mars were two Russian spacecraft launched in 1988; one failed en route, the other shortly after reaching Mars.
Scientists hope that at the least Mars Observer will photograph the entire planet in finer detail than ever before and will be able to report on seasonal changes through an entire Martian year, which lasts 687 Earth days. The spacecraft is equipped with cameras and remote-sensing instruments to conduct the most thorough survey yet of the planet's topography, magnetism, mineral wealth, global wind storms and generally frigid weather and of the role water played in its past and could play in its future.
Even if those canals were figments of human imagination, one of the most intriguing questions about Mars -- was there ever life there? -- hinges on the matter of water in the planet's past. The question is raised because of clear evidence of widespread dry river valleys and other scars of erosion indicating global flooding on Mars in its early years. So scientists think it is possible that in those wetter times, when the climate of Mars was probably more like Earth's, life could have evolved briefly and left some fossil traces that future explorers might search for.
The other question is, where did the water go? Much of it undoubtedly evaporated into space, but previous spacecraft have detected large amounts of frozen water in the polar ice caps and have hinted at the existence of even more water trapped underground as a thick layer of permafrost extending over much of the higher latitudes. These residues of water, scientists reason, are the most promising places to search for pockets of existing microbial life or fossils of extinct organisms from the Martian past.
 
Potential for Major Discoveries
 Dr. Michael H. Carr, a planetary geologists with the United States Geological Survey who is a member of the Mars Observer science team, said: "We know that life started on Earth. We don't know what happened on Mars, and so we want to go back in time and look at, particularly, water-associated deposits."
The spacecraft's seven scientific instruments give the mission the potential for a wide range of discoveries beyond the water question.
Mineral prospecting will be conducted by the gamma ray spectrometer. High-energy gamma radiation is produced by the natural decay of radioactive elements and by cosmic rays interacting with the atmosphere and surface. By observing these gamma rays, the spectrometer should be able to determine the chemical composition of the surface.
The same instrument also includes a detector for measuring neutrons created by cosmic-ray impacts on the surface. The neutron detector is especially sensitive to the presence of hydrogen and carbon in Martian soil.
"With the neutron data we will be able to map out planetwide the water content in the top meter of Martian soil and search for carbonate minerals that could indicate the previous existence of life on Mars," said Dr. Bill Feldman, the physicist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico who developed the neutron detector.
Minerals will also be identified by the thermal emission spectrometer, designed to measure telltale infrared emissions from the Martian surface. Another instrument, the pressure modulator infrared radiometer, will monitor the atmosphere by determining temperature, water vapor and dust from near the surface to altitudes of 50 miles.
A magnetometer will search for evidence of a magnetic field now or in the past. Mars is the only planet, aside from Pluto, for which a planetary magnetic field has not yet been observed.
"Mars ought to have on," Dr. Albee said. "If it doesn't, did it have one in the past? If it did have one in the past, when did it quit having a magnetic field, and why?"
Scientists say the Mars Observer's narrow-angle camera is expected to take the most detailed pictures ever made of the planet, discerning objects as small as 10 feet across. The two wide-angle cameras can produce a complete color image of the entire planet every day.
A laser altimeter will be used to measure the distance from the spacecraft to the surface with the precision of several feet. From these measurements, scientists will produce more exact relief maps of Mars and learn something of the geologic forces shaping the planet's crust.
Dr. Huntress said that Mars Observer was a prerequisite to human flights to Mars because it should "provide a global data base and map where to send humans and what it is they are to do once they get there."
Although President Bush has said human flights to Mars should be the ultimate goal of the American space program, there are no such firm plans and, in the current economic climate, are not likely to be any for some years. But there are plans to accelerate and broaden robotic exploration of the planet by both the United States and Russia, and all will be depending on Mars Observer.
As Mars Observer is completing its primary mission covering one Martian year, a Russian spacecraft to be launched in 1994 would be delivering two or more small landers with scientific instruments to the surface of the planet. In addition, two "penetrators" would be deployed to drill into the surface for geological studies.
Russian scientists are counting on Mars Observer maps to help them select the most promising landing sites. And the American craft will also be carrying a French radio to relay transmissions from the Russian landers and penetrators to control stations on Earth. This should insure a greater return of data than could be handled by Russian transmissions alone.
If Mars Observer is still active in 1997, it will be asked to perform the same relay service for a planned Russian-European mission, launched in 1996, that is to deploy a roving vehicle on the Martian surface and a French balloon in the planet's thin carbon-dioxide atmosphere.
Dr. Carr, a member of a joint working group of American and Russian planetary scientists, said that despite political and economic turmoil in the former Soviet Union, the Russian Mars projects for 1994 and 1996 appeared to retain financial support, with French help, and to remain on schedule. But scientists worried that the slightest setback could derail the programs.
On the drawing boards is an even more comprehensive program of exploration to follow Mars Observer. As outlined by mission planners at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, NASA's next Mars mission would be called Pathfinder, a landing craft to be sent to the planet in 1996 carrying a small roving vehicle. Scientists said they were fairly optimistic that the project would be approved.
Pathfinder would be a test run for the much more ambitious Mars Environmental Survey, or Mesur, a 10-year program that would deliver 16 small automated science stations to the planet's surface, beginning in 1999. The network will concentrate on geological studies, weather measurements and seismic monitoring to learn something of the Martian crust and deep interior. Some stations will have mini-rovers for going out and collecting rock samples and making other observations.
Daniel S. Goldin, the NASA administrator, is pressing for such expanded exploration of Mars. The Mesur landers, he said, "will head for some of the more interesting areas of Mars -- such as the polar regions and canyons -- seeking possible human landing sites where the potential for water and signs of life or fossils may be greatest."

The southern polar cap (photo at left) is composed of carbon dioxide frost and is very different from the northern polar region. The dry channel in the photo at right suggests that water once flowed on the surface.

HEADLINE: A Strategy to Survey The Vast Unknowns Of Life on the Earth

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
SCIENTISTS have explored the physical world from the nucleus of atoms to the far stretches of galaxies, yet the realm of living things on earth remains so unexplored that biologists are "close to traveling blind," argues Dr. Edward O. Wilson of Harvard University.
About 1.4 million species of plants, animals and microorganisms have been given scientific names, Dr. Wilson estimates. How many species live on earth? Scientists have no idea, he writes: "The number could be close to 10 million or as high as 100 million." 
 A leading biologist, Dr. Wilson has done his best to chart the unknown. In his laboratory in Cambridge, Mass., he is describing, classifying and drawing 4,000 pictures of 600 species of ants that he and associates have collected, all belonging to a single genus. But even this labor will hardly roll back the veil of ignorance.
As part of a new book about the diversity of life, Dr. Wilson lays out a grand strategy for discovering and classifying the species of the living kingdoms before it is too late.
 
New Worlds, Close to Home
 Because of the destruction of tropical forests and other habitats, uncounted species are becoming extinct before scientists can even name and study them for their scientific and economic value. An effort to survey all these "unmined riches," Dr. Wilson says, is at least as important as mapping the human genome or cataloguing the heavens, since it involves the living fabric on which human survival depends.
For anyone looking for new worlds to explore, "this is where the action is going to be," he said, adding: "It's not going to be on the outer planets. It's going to be right here in the exploration of biodiversity."
It is not clear how much effort and money have been expended in such explorations, but little scientific or governmental attention has been paid to warnings like Dr. Wilson's until recently.
Dr. Wilson says that by spending $100 million a year, using presently available manpower, the United States could make a substantial contribution to a global biodiversity survey. In comparison, the project to map the entire human genetic structure will cost about $200 million a year for 15 years, and a manned mission to Mars would cost $10 billion to $15 billion a year for 30 years.
Dr. Wilson has been singing some verses of this song for a while, but many scientists believe that the time may now be ripe for the exploratory strategy he proposes, and that his stature will give it special weight and visibility.
"There's no question that the scientific interest in biodiversity today, compared to 10 or 20 years ago, is much greater," said Dr. Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences. "Wilson is a world-class scientist, and some other world-class scientists have expressed concern about this, so you have to take them seriously."
 
Growing Encyclopedia of Life
 Dr. Wilson worked out his proposed strategy for the exploration of biological diversity, an overall framework rather than a detailed plan, with Dr. Peter Raven, director of the Missouri Botanical Garden. As outlined in "The Diversity of Life," to be published Oct. 6 by Harvard University Press, it envisions three tiers of activity.
The first is an emergency assessment of immediately threatened regional ecosystems thought to harbor especially rich and diverse assortments of species -- "brush fires of extinction." This quick assessment would focus on clusters of large, familiar organisms like flowering plants, mammals, reptiles, birds, fishes and butterflies that can provide a rough gauge of diversity. Areas where high diversity is confirmed could then be the focus of intense conservation efforts.
Beyond this assessment, Dr. Wilson and Dr. Raven propose an intermediate effort aimed at a more systematic exploration of threatened areas that are especially rich in species, like tropical rain forests. More complete inventories would be made, taking in smaller, more prevalent creatures like ants, beetles and fungi, along with close studies of environmental factors like rainfall and temperature. Insects and other arthropods are so vital to the overall functioning of life, Dr. Wilson writes, that "humanity probably could not last more than a few months" if they were to disappear.
Finally, a global biodiversity survey would combine the first two studies with more conventional long-term explorations. The survey would be broadened to include the tiniest creatures like protozoa and bacteria. This growing encyclopedia of life would provide, over decades and even centuries, a description of the living world that gradually coalesced "to create a fine-grained image of global biodiversity."
Eventually, national biodiversity centers would be established as bases for exploration and repositories of accumulated knowledge. Dr. Wilson cites the example of Costa Rica's three-year-old National Institute of Biodiversity, whose aim is "nothing less than to account for all the plants and animals of this small Central American country."
Some biologists and conservationists welcome the Wilson proposal in principle while not necessarily agreeing with all the details. "It's a framework institutions like ours can buy into," said Dr. Adrian Forsyth, director of conservation biology of Conservation International, which has pioneered emergency assessment of biodiversity in the tropics. "Until someone lays out the agenda, we'll continue to work in a scattered, haphazard way. Wilson lays out an agenda."
The recommendation "is not going to be a panacea," said Dr. Gary Hartshorn, a tropical forest ecologist and vice president of the World Wildlife Fund, but he added: "He's at least pointing us in the right direction. The fact that he's taken this on and proposed it will mean a lot to the biological, ecological and conservation communities both here and elsewhere."
Galvanizing Federal support for a concept of this magnitude will not be easy, said Dr. Forsyth, a former student of Dr. Wilson's, even though other scientific areas greatly outstrip biodiversity in getting funds. "The amount of money that goes into recombinant DNA work, for example, just vastly dwarfs the whole 40 years of funding that's gone into understanding biodiversity," he said.
If the exploration of the biological world lags in funds, it lags also in performance, says Dr. Wilson. "In the realm of physical measurement," he writes in the new book, "evolutionary biology is far behind the rest of the natural sciences."
The smaller the biological scale, the deeper the level of ignorance. "The biologist starts with a big piece of forest and determines the larger organisms," Dr. Wilson said. "He draws in closer. Now he's looking at a bit of soil, a rotting log, a clump of leaves, and in that is a microwilderness, with the whole complex of biodiversity all over again. He looks more closely, down to a tiny fleck of rotting wood or the edge of a leaf, and there is yet a whole other world of complexity composed mostly of fungi and bacteria and protozoa."
At those smaller scales, he said, the prospects for exploration are "virtually unlimited; a single gram of soil contains as many as 4,000 or 5,000 species of bacteria, virtually all of them unknown." Bacteria, he writes, "await biologists as the black hole of taxonomy." Some of this diversity "stares us in the face but goes unrecognized."
It is very likely, Dr. Wilson said, "that the average person carries a few new species of bacteria on his shoes."

HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
New Treasury Bidding Rule Costly for U.S. in Note Sale

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The first test of the Treasury's new auction system yesterday did not go well for the Government, according to bidders, analysts and the auction details released by the Treasury. Despite a record low yield for the two-year note of 4 percent, the Treasury may still have paid more than it had to.
But some traders argued that the Treasury could be expected to pay a premium, considering the uncertainty surrounding the test. They said that the Treasury was likely to benefit in the long run after dealers and traders get used to the system. 
 As it turned out, traders said, yesterday was not the best day to try the system, in which securities are awarded at a single price. The bond market was down sharply across the board, with the 30-year bond off almost a point and a half and the yield leaping to 7.46 percent.
A surprisingly strong jump in housing starts, some selling of Treasury securities to hedge against large corporate and municipal issues yesterday and the possibility of some central bank selling of notes in the afternoon all contributed to the tumble, dealers said.
The new bidding system will be used for a year in the two- and five-year note auctions. The five-year note auction is today.
The test is a response to the Salomon Brothers scandal a year ago in which the firm admitted to illegal bidding. The goal is to encourage more aggressive bidding and to increase participation, which could open the system and make collusion less likely.
In the single-price Dutch auction being tested, all securities are awarded at the lowest price, or highest yield. This means that bidders, who are mostly the 39 primary dealers in the Treasury market, do not have to worry about paying more than their competitors. Under the system still being used at all other auctions, it is possible to pay too much, since securities are awarded to multiple bidders according to a scale of rising yields and declining prices until all are sold.
Not long before the 1 P.M. bidding deadline in yesterday's auction, John Costas, managing director of trading and sales at the First Boston Corporation, gathered with his fellow bond traders and salesmen around the desk of the two-year note specialist, Tony Zizzamia.
They discussed the sales they had made to customers; they tried to gauge demand, and they looked at rows of computer screens as the yield on the two-year note moved in the preauction, or when-issued, market. But most of all, they were trying to figure out how to bid in the new system.
"This is the first time, and we have nothing in experience to base anyone's behavior on," said Mr. Costas, who was wondering how the other 38 primary dealers were handling the same unknowns. A lot of the skill in bidding in Treasury auctions involves dealers figuring out what other dealers are doing so that they can get the amount of securities they need at the best prices, which, under the system being tested, is assured.
When the bidding deadline passed, Mr. Costas concluded that the new system had made him a little more aggressive than he would have been in last month's auction. He bid one basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, more than he might have under the other system. He could afford to be more aggressive because, under the new rules, First Boston would not have to pay more -- the winner's curse -- if it was more aggressive.
And that would be good for the Treasury if most dealers followed suit, because their aggressive bidding would bring higher prices and lower yields, which reduces Treasury borrowing costs.
But the overall results, at least in this first test, seemed to show that the Treasury did not get the benefit of the aggressive bidding of First Boston and the even more aggressive bidding other primary dealers.
The $14.5 billion of two-year notes was awarded at a yield of 4.00 percent, well below the 4.30 percent in the August auction. But that yield was higher than the aggressive bid by First Boston. (Mr. Costas did not want to reveal his exact bids.)
More important, the median bid was 3.98 percent, with 50 percent of the bids at this level or lower. Five percent of the bids were at 3.93 percent or lower, and one dealer said that a customer of his bid as low as 3.75 percent. When the yield is lower, dealers pay the Treasury more, saving the Government interest costs.
In addition, demand turned out to be very high compared with recent auctions, which is a situation in which the Treasury can usually get its best results. But in yesterday's case, while a vast majority of the bids were under the 4.00 percent level, the whole issue was sold at the lower price that comes with the higher yield.
"Over time, I believe there will be a savings for the Treasury, but I don't think the saving was realized today," Mr. Costas said.
 
Concentrated Demand
 Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., said that while there was stronger demand than average for the auction, most of it seemed to be concentrated among the 39 primary dealers in New York. This was shown by the fact that 94.8 percent of the bids yesterday where made through the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Yet one of the Treasury's goals is to increase participation outside of the dealer community. However, yesterday's test may not be a good measure because a lot of potential bidders stayed away until they saw how the system worked, traders said.
Jerome H. Powell, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Finance, declined to comment on the specifics of the auction. But he said in an interview: "It is important to remember that this is a yearlong experiment and any claims of success or failure are premature.
"Theory would suggest that a more aggressive pattern of bidding would emerge in a single-price auction, and we are conducting this experiment to test that theory."
 
Treasury Market
 The fall in the Treasury market started overseas when the German central bank announced a surge in its money supply growth in August. That lessened chances for an interest rate cut there and, in turn, in the United States.
But the market then fell dramatically in the early morning after the Commerce Department reported that housing starts surged 10.4 percent in August, the strongest monthly gain in 18 months.
Although many analysts expect the pace to level off, the report was a real surprise because forecasts for the August figure were for around 3 percent growth. The high actual growth figure shook the bond market because it could mean an upturn in economic growth, rising inflation and higher interest rates.
The further fall in the afternoon, traders said, was related to rumors of central bank selling of Treasury notes and breaking of key price levels, after which investors sold in order to protect profits already made.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of two-year Treasury notes under the single-price system:

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Head Scolds U.S. And Bonn for Deficits

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Laying out an economic rationale for the politically difficult step of cutting budget deficits, the head of the International Monetary Fund scolded the United States and Germany today, saying their large budget deficits hurt world growth.
Opening the formal sessions of the annual meeting of the monetary fund and the World Bank, Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, used the moral suasion of his office to press Washington and Bonn to cut their deficits. He said the move would improve investor confidence, ease inflationary pressures and reduce long-term interest rates. 
 If Germany cut its budget deficit, Mr. Camdessus said, that would give that nation's central bank more latitude to lower its high interest rates, which the United States and Britain repeatedly criticized last week. The Bundesbank has pushed its rates to over 9 percent to offset the inflationary pressures caused by the deficit, and those high rates helped fuel last week's currency tensions in Europe.
 
Defying Conventional Wisdom
 In a hotel ballroom packed with finance ministers and central bankers from 172 countries, Mr. Camdessus defied the wisdom of most economists and said the United States and other nations should cut their deficits now, even though the world was mired in a protracted slump. While the conventional wisdom is that cutting deficits during an economic downturn would further weaken fragile economies, Mr. Camdessus said, "Each postponement of long overdue fiscal action adds to the severity of the problem."
"Any further postponement" of deficit reduction "out of concern for possible short-tem effects on activity would contribute to a worse environment rather than a better one," Mr. Camdessus added. He did not address the short-term political pain that would be exacted by the spending cuts or tax increases needed to cut deficits.
Mr. Camdessus spoke on a day when financial markets remained tense, with the French franc and several other European currencies slipping to near the minimum level to which they are allowed to fall under the European monetary system, an 11-nation arrangement of fixed exchange rates.
As financial officials and journalists milled about, the halls of the Sheraton-Washington Hotel were filled with rumors that there might be further devaluations in Europe. Finance Minister Theo Waigel of Germany was so wrapped up in meetings that he canceled a long-scheduled lunch with journalists.
Sounding like a lecturing schoolmaster, Mr. Camdessus praised Japan, saying prudent budget policies had allowed Tokyo to "announce a welcome economic package" to stimulate its economy.
 
Scolds the United States
 But he spoke of the United States as a wayward pupil, suggesting that its budget deficit had made it difficult for Washington to use fiscal stimulus to escape its protracted slowdown. Instead, the United States has relied on monetary policy in the form of low interest rates to spur the economy.
On Monday, Finance Minister Carlos Solchaga of Spain, the chairman of the monetary fund's main policy-making committee, said that American rates were too low and German rates too high, and that the gap between the two countries' rates had caused Europe's currency crisis. The gap encouraged many money managers to shun American investments in favor of high-yield German assets. That strengthened the mark so much that it forced Britain, Italy and Spain to devalue their currencies last week.
Mr. Camdessus weighed in against lower American rates today, saying it would be imprudent for the Federal Reserve to cut rates further. In remarks clearly aimed at the United States, he said: "Some will tell you that it could be safe now to relax monetary discipline and so give a boost to activity, because inflation has been subdued, if not quite defeated. But this would be the most serious mistake we could make today."
In brief remarks to open the meeting, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady rejected the idea that American rates should be higher. He said, "When interest rates remain high for whatever reason," that hurts growth by discouraging businesses from borrowing to expand.
 
Third-World Perspective
 Speaking for the developing world, Mohammed Berrada, the head of Morocco's central bank and chairman of the I.M.F.-World Bank meeting, chided the United States and other industrial nations for their budget deficits. He said the deficits reduced the global pool of investment money that the developing world and former Communist countries could use to build their economies. He added that deficits pushed up long-term interest rates, increasing the third world's debt burden.
Mr. Berrada said, "It is more crucial than ever for government policies to display a consistent and overarching vision that takes account of the repercussions of such policies on other countries."
Regarding the former Communist countries, Mr. Camdessus said their transition to a market economy "is urgent and daunting." He noted that there have been setbacks, most notably inflationary pressures, and even the threat of prices increases of more than 1,000 percent a year.
Despite the pain that market-oriented reforms are causing, he urged a full-speed-ahead approach. "Full transformation will take time," he said, "but that is a good reason to start immediately, and to take advantage of the dynamism and enthusiasm of the present period to create, irreversibly, the basic structures of a market economy."

HEADLINE: Stocks Decline Broadly, Led by Auto Issues

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market declined broadly yesterday as investors sold auto stocks and executed computerized selling strategies to siphon profits from blue-chip companies.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 39.98 points, or 1.2 percent, to 3,280.85. Volume on the Big Board grew to 187 million shares from 153.9 million Monday. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by 12 to 5. 
 Walter Murphy, senior international market specialist for Merrill Lynch, said declines of this nature "are kind of reflective of the uncertainty in the market."
In recent weeks, analysts have expressed worries about an array of economic and political events that have clouded the investment horizon.
Stocks fell slightly after the opening bell, but prices plunged in heavy computerized selling after an analyst for Wertheim Schroder issued negative comments on major auto makers, predicting slow sales because of the distressed economy. In addition, General Motors pared its forecast of fourth-quarter output by about 27,000 vehicles because of sluggish demand.
Chrysler, the most actively traded issue on the Big Board, eased 5/8, to 23 3/8, while G.M. was off 1 1/4, to 33, and Ford Motor sank 2 3/8, to 40 1/4.
Eugene Peroni, analyst for Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia, said prices of auto stocks had been slowly rising in recent months, which created a selling opportunity for some traders.
 
Cashing In the Blue Chips
 Profit taking also hit other blue chips. Coca-Cola, among the most actives, drppped 2 1/2, to 42 1/4, in heavy trading after managers told analysts they expect slow growth.
Other stocks among the Dow Jones industrials were also struck: Allied- Signal, off 2 at 52 3/4, and I.B.M., down 1 1/8 at 83 1/4. Investors are starting to shift funds into cyclical issues, companies whose fortunes closely track economic cycles, Mr. Peroni said.
The selling came despite a relatively positive domestic economic development: The Commerce Department said housing starts rose 10.4 percent in August, the sharpest increase in 18 months. Analysts found a sour tone in the upbeat report -- applications for building permits, a key indicator of future construction activity, fell 1.6 percent, to a 1.06 million annual rate.
The strong housing report unnerved the Treasury bond market, which interpreted the figures as a sign the Government would be less inclined to cut interest rates further.
The Treasury's 30-year issue was off 1 3/8 points while the yield rose to 7.46 percent, from 7.34 percent late Monday. Bonds' decline was another factor in the stock market's retreat, Mr. Peroni said.

HEADLINE: Recycling Facing Test in Poorer Areas

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Hector Valentin eagerly lifted the lid of a blue bin in the parking lot of the St. Nicholas Houses in Harlem. He peered inside, hoping to discover a 1990's kind of valuable: recyclable cans, bottles and plastics. But it was empty.
A few days after New York City expanded its recycling program to all of Manhattan, the 2,500 tenants of the housing project at 215 West 127th Street had not begun using the blue containers. And Mr. Valentin, the superintendent of the project, said he could not predict when pilgrimages to the bins would become as much a part of residents' daily rituals as checking their mailboxes or brushing their teeth. 
 How will New York City's new recycling initiative, the most aggressive in the nation, fare in neighborhoods like Harlem, where many residents may be struggling with more pressing issues, like crime, poverty or unemployment? Amid so many worries, will people find the time and energy to sort their trash?
"It's going to be very difficult in poorer neighborhoods," said Steven M. Polan, a former New York City Sanitation Commissioner. "People who have incredible pressure from the basics of daily existence are obviously going to be less interested in recycling. But I don't want to broadbrush either. There have been success stories in poor neighborhoods as well."
 
Expanding to 5 Boroughs
 After years of halting efforts, the city's recycling program entered high gear last week when all Manhattan residents were required to sort their trash for six materials: newspapers, magazines, corrugated cardboard, glass, metals and foils, and plastics. The program, which began in Manhattan on Sept. 14 and was already under way on Staten Island, will expand to the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens by September 1993.
As part of a new solid-waste management plan that includes construction of a controversial incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the city hopes to be recycling 42 percent of its trash by the year 2000. Currently, it recycles about 13 percent. The city has mandated a six-month grace period during which it will not fine recycling violators.
City officials acknowledge that the new initiative will fare better in some areas than others, but they insist that even in a neighborhood like central Harlem, where 41 percent of the population receives some form of public assistance, income level is only one factor in determining whether people will recycle.
They emphasize that residents of poor areas often face serious sanitation problems, like garbage strewn across sidewalks and abandoned lots, so they may be more sensitive to recycling. For example, Community District 10, which encompasses central Harlem, says only 54 percent of its streets were acceptably clean in 1990, compared with the city average of 82 percent.
 
Degrees of Cooperation
 "Our experience is not that rich people recycle and poor people don't," said Emily Lloyd, the city's Sanitation Commissioner. "We have blocks or buildings that are very affluent and we have had a hard time getting them going and we've had blocks and buildings that are not affluent and are very enthusiastic. You can't just predict it on that basis at all."
Along 125th Street in Harlem the other day, many people said they had heard of the new recycling requirements from news reports. They expressed optimism that the new initiative would take hold, but they also said that success would depend on whether tenants in buildings banded together.
"Everybody has to participate for it to work," said Edythe Reyes, a 29-year-old student who lives in a city-owned building housing project at 242 West 112th Street near Frederick Douglass Boulevard. "But it will really be a struggle. This is a really drug-infested neighborhood. The drug addicts, all they care about is their next high. They don't care about recycling."
As she relaxed in the plaza of the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building, Candee Hueston-Ogiamien said assumptions about recycling problems in neighborhoods like Harlem failed to consider the variety of housing. In high-rise projects, she said, tenants might skirt the rules because superintendents usually cannot identify who did not sort their trash. But in smaller buildings, like her 10-unit brownstone at 2113 Fifth Avenue near 130th Street, there is more pressure to comply.
 
Facing Other Concerns
 "In our building, we know each other by first name," said Ms. Hueston-Ogiamien, a 43-year-old graduate student. "We have a family atmosphere and everybody looks after each other. So if Lorenzo does not separate his trash, we say, 'Lorenzo, get down here and take care of this!' "
But Jack J. Mobley, who publishes a monthly community newsletter called Uptown, said too many residents in the neighborhood were alienated from government to care about recycling. And he wondered why the city was planning to spend so much money on the new initiative -- up to $300 million by 1996 -- when other worries, like unemployment, were eating away at Harlem.
"A lot of people are not going to be that concerned because they have other things on their minds," said Mr. Mobley, 44. "Times are tough. You have to alleviate the basic problems before you start concentrating on cleaning up the trash. How do you expect people to pay attention when they have no jobs?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: New York City's new recycling initiative is off to a slow start. Hector Valentin, the superintendent of the St. Nicholas Houses project in Harlem, stood next to a brand new bin that has yet to be used. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dan Lacey, Editor, Is Dead at 42; Analyzed Unemployment Trends

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Dan Lacey, an authority on changes in the American work force, especially on the wave of cutbacks made by companies in recent years, died on Monday in Westlake, Ohio. He was 42 years old.
Mr. Lacey died of a heart attack, said his wife, Margaret. 
 Mr. Lacey, the editor of the Workplace Trends newsletter, monitored and compiled the numbers of layoffs, early retirement programs and other work-force cuts at American corporations using a method that was more timely and comprehensive than Government statistics. Mr. Lacey found that in the latter months of 1991, for example, staff cuts reached the pace of 2,600 for each working day, a widely quoted statistic that emphasized the magnitude of job losses.
Beyond tracking the phenomenon, Mr. Lacey also studied the causes of the labor cutbacks. He was often interviewed as a labor-market expert by network television news programs, newspapers and magazines.
In the current issue of Time magazine, Mr. Lacey was one of the several experts assembled by the magazine to offer their views on the state of the American economy and the outlook. He was also a consultant to corporations on personnel issues.
An advocate of the need for worker training, Mr. Lacey believed that one of the reasons for the widespread staff cutbacks by American companies was that neither the government nor companies had provided many workers with the skills necessary to compete in an advanced economy open to foreign rivals.
 
Self-Trained Analyst
 Mr. Lacey was a self-trained analyst of trends in the United States economy. He studied at Ohio State University, but did not hold a bachelor's degree. He began his career as a newspaper reporter, starting at 18 years old as a copy boy for The Times-Leader in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., his hometown. He later worked as a reporter for Scranton Times in Scranton, Pa., The Miami Herald and The Cleveland Press until it went out of business.
In 1988, Mr. Lacey founded the newsletter Workplace Trends, which is published six times a year. He was the author of three books, "The Paycheck Disruption: Finding Success in the Workplace of the '90's," "The Essential Immigrant" and "Your Rights in the Workplace." He was an editor of "Work in the 21st Century."
In addition to his wife, Mr. Lacey is survived by his parents, Harold and Florence, of Wilkes-Barre; his sister, Cynthia Silverman of York, Pa., and his brother, Harold Jr., of Hershey, Pa.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
With Sales Flat, Coke Has Clear Plan

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Against the backdrop of a gloomy third-quarter sales forecast made to analysts yesterday in New York, the Coca-Cola Company is going New Age.
Following a host of competitors, Coke announced plans yesterday to sell Nordic Mist, a flavored sparkling water. 
 The announcement, however, was overshadowed by Coke's disclosure that its worldwide case sales would be flat for the third quarter. Analysts had been expecting volume to be up by 5 percent, and Coke's stock fell $2.50 to close at $42.25 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Coca-Cola's news is not encouraging," Michael J. Branca, an analyst with County NatWest USA, said of the company's sales forecast. The company blamed the weak economies of Brazil and Britain for the softness of its overseas shipments in the quarter ending this month.
In addition, the cold, rainy summer in the United States and Japan also held down third-quarter sales.
Coke officials said volume in the United States would likely be flat or up only slightly for the first nine months of the year. Still, the company said its earnings per share would grow by 18 percent to 20 percent for the year.
George Thompson, an analyst with Prudential Securities, said Coke would make up for volume weakness overseas by cutting marketing expenditures.
With slow sales domestically, Coke and Pepsi are increasingly willing to enter niches they would have ignored as too small in the past. In addition to so-called New Age drinks, which accounts for only about $1 billion in sales in the $48 billion soft-drink market, both Coke and Pepsi are also pursing ice tea and sports drinks.
Although soft drink sales have been sluggish, the demand for fruity, clear drinks -- New Age beverages in industry-speak -- exploded last year. Sales of the drinks jumped by 18 percent in 1991, making them the fastest growing type of drink, said Hellen Berry, vice president of marketing for the Beverage Marketing Corporation.
"This is a growth area, and we are going to be there," said Pierre Ferrari, senior vice president of marketing for Coca-Cola USA.
The growth has attracted a lot of competition. Pepsi recently introduced several, a clear cola, Crystal Pepsi, and H2oH!, a flavored sparkling water. Seagram's recently introduced Quest, a low-calorie sparkling water.
The big beverage makers were attracted by the success of the Clearly Canadian Beverage Company, which sells a popular line of sparkling fruit drinks. The stock of Clearly Canadian, which is facing an increasingly crowded field of bigger and bigger competitors, fell 37.5 cents, to $11.625, in over-the-counter trading.
Nordic Mist will initially be introduced in New York, Philadelphia, Boston and Pittsburgh, and will be in most of the country by next summer. The drink will come in five fruit flavors. It is sweetened and caffeine free. An 11-ounce bottle will cost about $1 in delicatessans and other stores.
Based on its ingredients and caloric content, Nordic Mist is closer to a traditional soft drink than a sparkling water. A 12-ounce Coke has 144 calories, while an 11-ounce bottle of Nordic Mist has 112 calories.
Absent caramel coloring, its ingredients -- high-fructose corn syrup, citric acid and potassium benzoate -- are similar to the raw materials of a cola or other sugared soft drinks.
"It's soft drinks in disguise," Jack Trout of Trout & Ries, a marketing firm in Greenwich, Conn., said of New Age beverages.
Mr. Branca, the analyst with County NatWest, said a more accurate name was "fruit-flavored soft drinks," He added, "New age is a baloney kind of phrase."
 
Saturation Marketing
 The interest of the cola giants, Coke and Pepsi, gives the category a certain legitimacy and is likely to make the growth rate accelerate. Distribution muscle is the key to success in the beverage industry and other than Pepsi, competitors cannot match Coke's extensive reach.
Gatorade is experiencing first-hand Coke's ability to saturate a market. Powerade, Coke's new sports drink, is being introduced in different cities around the country. Over the weekend, for example, Coke representatives stocked the drink in stores in New Orleans.
"On Monday morning, our competitor woke up to discover that we had 36 percent of the shelf space," in stores in New Orleans, said M. Douglas Ivestor, president of Coca-Cola U.S.A.
The Nordic Mist name is supposed to evoke, healthful pure images. Although several people have said they think the name sounds like a perfume, some marketing experts said the Nordic Mist name was likely to attract consumers. "I think of tall, lithesome, gorgeous blondes cavorting in the snow," said Kenneth Love, a partner with Anspach, Grossman, & Portugal, an identity consulting firm.
While Coke has demonstrated an ability to manage its profits, investors are increasingly concerned that the company will have trouble meeting its long-term overseas growth target of 10 percent a year on average.

HEADLINE: Bank Money Market Yields And C.D. Rates Off in Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit fell in the latest reporting week, which ended today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication that tracks interest rates.
Analysts at the publication said, however, that the decline was not as sharp as in the previous weeks. They said one explanation could be that banks believed the Federal Reserve might have placed further rate cuts on hold. 
 Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said bank deposit rates and loan rates were set based on expectations.
 
Treasury Bills Up
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills Monday, rates rose as prices came under pressure from uncertainty in the market, caused in part by the turmoil in Europe.
The Treasury auction is regarded as a reliable barometer of how banks could eventually set deposit rates in the weeks ahead. On Monday the average rate at the auction for a three-month bill was 2.91 percent, up three basis points from last week. The six-month bill rose to 2.93 percent, up three basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
The overall average New York-area yield on money market accounts fell a basis point, to 2.91 percent, in the reporting week and the rate on three-month and six-month certificates of deposit fell 2 basis points each, to 2.93 percent and 3.10 percent, respectively.
At commercial banks, yields of money market accounts and three-month certificates each fell a basis point, to 2.74 percent and 2.79 percent, respectively. Six-month certificates of deposit at commercial banks remained unchanged, at 2.93 percent.
 
Savings Rates Off
 At savings banks, three-month certificates declined 3 basis points, to 3.08 percent, and six-month certificates fell 4 basis points, to 3.27 percent. Money market accounts at savings banks lost one basis point, to 3.08 percent.
The largest yield adjustments in the New York area in the week were at First Fidelity in New Jersey, which dropped its money market account by 15 basis points, to 3 percent. Dime Savings and Fleet Bank in Connecticut both cut their certificate rates by 16 basis points. The Dime's three-month certificate is now at 2.90 percent, and Fleet's six-month certificate is at 3.14 percent.
Outside the New York area, yields at 20 large banks surveyed were also down, with money market accounts and six-month certificates both off 2 basis points, to 2.77 percent and 2.95 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Merck as a Benchmark;
Taking the Measure Of the Biotech Field

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The youthful biotech industry continues to expand at a clip most businesses can only envy in 1992's slow growth economy. But it is still several years away from profitability, according to an annual survey released yesterday by the accounting firm Ernst & Young.
G. Steven Burrill and Kenneth B. Lee Jr., the San Francisco-based authors of the survey, said the total number of biotech companies grew 11 percent, to 1,231, in the year ending June 30. Industry employment expanded to 79,000, an increase of 13 percent. 
 Total revenues, including royalties and contract research payments, increased 28 percent, to $8.1 billion, while product sales grew 35 percent, to $5.9 billion. Net losses were also up, climbing 32 percent, to $3.4 billion, a reflection of the continual heavy investment required for building new businesses.
Mr. Burrill and Mr. Lee, employing a benchmark popular among biotech analysts, included a comparison of the entire fledgling industry with Merck & Company, the prototype of the successful, multinational pharmaceutical enterprise that many of the biotech companies dream of becoming.
Merck's 1991 sales of $8.6 billion were slightly higher than the biotech industry's, and the $2.1 billion in profits was an obvious contrast. But in terms of the market value of stock shares, Merck's $60 billion (based on prices this summer) was reasonably close to the $50 billion combined market value of the 225 publicly traded biotech companies.
By this measure, many analysts feel that it is the money-losing biotech companies, not Merck, that are undervalued. They ask which is likely to produce higher earnings growth in the future -- a biotech industry that last year spent $4.9 billion on research and development and has hundreds of products in the pipeline, or Merck, which spent $988 million and has a more modest new-product portfolio under development?
Of course, Merck has a few valuable weapons in its arsenal, like experience and marketing muscle -- not to mention the financial clout to acquire plenty of products that it does not invent itself.

HEADLINE: Japanese G.N.P. Gains A Scant 0.3% in Quarter

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 22

 BODY:
In a sign that Japan's recession is biting, the nation's economy grew a paltry three-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter of this year, the Government reported today.
But the weak economic report did not stop the Japanese yen from strengthening today against the dollar and European currencies. Tokyo trading closed with the dollar worth 122.67 yen, down 1.33 yen from Monday's close. 
 [In New York trading, the dollar fell to a record low against the yen, settling at 121.02 yen, down from 123.75 on Monday. In earlier trading in London, the dollar closed at 121.45 yen.]
Traders said the yen was being viewed as a safe haven for traders wanting to flee the turmoil in European currencies. They also said the yen was being bolstered by the uncertain outlook for the American economy and by speculation about additional cuts in interest rates in the United States and Germany.
 
Stock Market Advances
 As for the stock market here, today's weak economic report did not keep share prices from rising. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 216.48 points. or 1.2 percent, to close at 18,282.72. Financial markets will be closed here on Wednesday for Autumnal Equinox Day, a national holiday.
The quarterly rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in the gross national product translates to an annual rate of 1.1 percent a year and represents a sharp drop from the first quarter, when the G.N.P. grew 1.1 percent, or at an annual rate of 4.3 percent.
While in most countries a recession means an actual shrinkage in the economy, Japan's economy has generally continued to grow through the economic slump, but at far lower levels than normal.
But the figures for the second quarter, which ended in June, show virtually no growth. Consumer spending was unchanged from the previous quarter while corporate investment continued to decline, according to the Economic Planning Agency.
The latest G.N.P. figure will make it virtually impossible for Japan to meet the Government's official target of 3.5 percent growth this year, a goal that private economists had long since dismissed as unrealistic.
 
Rescue Package in Place
 But officials of the Economic Planning Agency said today that they thought that the second quarter would prove to be the worst for the economy, in part because an economic rescue package announced last month would soon begin to take effect.
The $86 billion pump-priming package, the largest such effort in the nation's history, will try to revive growth by increasing public-works spending and providing incentives for business investment.
But many economists say the effects of the plan will not really be felt until 1993. And while public-works spending can help the economy, they say, true recovery will not come until corporations finish cutting excess inventories and manpower and see their profits rise again, allowing them to increase their capital spending. That corporate healing process might take a year.
Some Government officials are already saying that if last month's rescue package fails to achieve the targeted growth rate, additional measures will have to be considered. These will probably include a cut in income taxes, a move that is already being called for by some business groups. Further increases in public spending may also be considered, even if that means a national budget deficit.
 
Slump in Auto Industry

In another piece of bad economic news, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today that domestic production of cars fell 11.2 percent in August from a year earlier while overall vehicle production, including trucks and buses, fell 12.7 percent. Domestic sales of vehicles plunged 15.3 percent from a year earlier and exports fell 5 percent.
While vehicle production and domestic demand have been falling all year, the August drop was particularly steep. Most major auto companies have cut back to one shift a day at many of their factories.
