HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
A Diamond-Coated Tool Etches the Tortuous Path of New Technologies

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Last spring, the Kingsbury Corporation had an unhappy customer. The metal-cutting machinery Kingsbury had built for an Alabama maker of brass water-meter housings had failed to perform as well as the company had promised.
"The brass just chewed up the carbide tools the machinery used," recalled James L. Koontz, president and chief executive of Kingsbury, a Keene, N.H., machine tool company. 
 In the end, Kingsbury cobbled together a setup the customer could live with by adding new cutting tools and holders and changing the way the parts were fed into the machinery. But Mr. Koontz recalls the incident as an exercise in frustration rather than a triumph of ingenuity. His first choice would have been simply to insert a new type of diamond-coated tool that he had obtained for testing from the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences.
 
 
Technologies Without Support
 "It cut through the brass like butter," he said. Unfortunately, no suppliers are producing the new cutter in the commercial quantities needed by Mr. Koontz's customers. Kingsbury's inability to exploit the technology cost the company time and about $50,000, and left its customer with a less productive machine than it wanted.
The episode is hardly without precedent in today's manufacturing circles, where niche technologies often go begging for development dollars, and even those that easily attract investment tend to mature slower than their champions had hoped. Each delay in the adoption of a new technology may be no more than an economic pinprick, but the cumulative effect saps the nation's competitiveness, manufacturing experts say.
"The Japanese deploy advanced technology 400 percent faster than we do," said Edward A. Miller, executive director of the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences, a five-year-old cooperative research organization based in Ann Arbor, Mich.
 
 
A Speedup Isn't Easy
 A look at why Kingsbury -- or General Motors, for that matter -- cannot yet buy such tools reveals that there are no simple ways to speed the process of creating technologies and converting them into commercial products.
Indeed, the diamond-coated tools that captured Mr. Koontz's interest are actually on a development fast track, having moved in three years from concept to large-scale testing this fall at G.M. and Chrysler. Industrial use of thin films of synthetic diamonds has been a hot area of research in recent years, as everyone from microchip makers to optics companies are searching for new ways to exploit the diamonds' extraordinary combination of hardness, heat conduction, slickness, transparency and electrical resistance.
Diamond-coated tools were singled out in 1989 for attention by the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences. The center, which relies on Government and private-sector financing, provided more than $1 million for a development program that brought together potential customers, tool suppliers and companies with expertise in making diamond films.
The center was tackling a problem that had already absorbed tens of millions of dollars in research and development investment for some 40 years in the Soviet Union, Japan and the United States. The center decided to focus on a narrow but particularly difficult challenge: finding a way to apply thin films of diamonds to tungsten carbide tools -- the strongest tools in widespread use.
Metal-cutting shops can already buy such carbide tools tipped with polycrystalline diamonds. But these P.C.D. tools, as they are known, are expensive -- between $50 and $100 each, compared with a few dollars for a noncoated carbide tool tip. The polycrystalline versions, of course, are intended to be used many more times before they need to be replaced.
The synthetic diamonds are "grown" in small sizes at high temperatures and pressures and then brazed onto the part of the tool, known as the insert, that goes into the toolholder on the cutting machine.
An alternative marketed by a handful of Japanese tool companies and by Norton Inc., an American subsidiary of Compagnie de Saint-Gobain of France, is made at much lower cost. These toolmakers create coated tools in small gas chambers. They use microwaves or other energy sources to create chemical reactions in methane or similar gases that result in films of diamond forming on the surfaces of the metal tool inserts.
But the chemical vapor deposition, or C.V.D., processes used by these companies have the annoying drawback of producing films that tend to chip away easily, say Mr. Koontz and others in the industry. That is because most carbide-based tools include up to 15 percent cobalt to make them less brittle. The cobalt tends to interfere with the bonding of diamonds to the surface in ways that are not yet fully understood.
The research sponsored by the manufacturing sciences center appears to have overcome the adhesion problem using C.V.D. technology developed by Crystallume Inc., a start-up company in Menlo Park, Calif. (Crystallume declines to describe its technique until a patent is issued.)
In tests conducted by Elmer Harbert, senior manufacturing engineer at the Allison Gas Turbine division of General Motors in Indianapolis, Crystallume's C.V.D. diamond-coated carbide blade made 21 eight-inch-long cuts in a high-strength aluminum compound used in engine blocks before wearing out. Other C.V.D. diamond-coated carbides cracked in less that two passes, he said, and carbide tools with other coatings failed to complete a single cut.
The aluminum-390, as the compound is known, contains enough silicon, the basic element of sand, to make it extremely abrasive. "Aluminum-390 normally eats tools for breakfast, lunch and dinner," Mr. Harbert said
Despite the success at Allison Gas Turbine and the enthusiasm of potential users like Mr. Koontz, no tool company has rushed to make the relatively modest investment of $8 million or so that it will take to mass-produce the new cutting tools, which are expected to sell for perhaps $25 to $50 each.
So far, the only potential supplier to commit itself publicly to moving forward is Crystallume. The agreement with the manufacturing sciences center prevents Crystallume from selling the technology to foreign manufacturers, but it does allow the company to sell coated products to them.
Crystallume plans to build clones of its prototype diamond-coating chamber in sufficient numbers to allow production of "tens of thousands" of coated tools by next year, said Laurie Conner, vice president of marketing and sales. But Crystallume is at least two years away from building its own large-scale manufacturing operation, and the manufacturing sciences center's negotiations to license established toolmakers have yet to result in any announced competition.
Experts in technology development say it is no surprise that established toolmakers are moving cautiously. Every new technology raises questions about performance and cost and where it will fit into each supplier's product strategy. Technologies that look like clear home runs in every respect are extremely rare.
One common barrier to commercialization of new technologies is that some potential suppliers may believe that other approaches that are as good or better are in the wings. That is a leading reason Kennametal Inc., the largest domestic machine toolmaker, has stayed out of the group organized by the manufacturing sciences center and is not ready to embrace its results.
"We have been looking at three different processes for depositing diamond on tools," said David Arnold, chief technical officer of Kennametal. "It wasn't clear that theirs would justify dropping what we are working on, and I can't afford a fourth project."
 
'Real Practical Problems'
 More fundamentally, most technologies require further development work even after promising test results are in hand.
"No one's holding back in this case, but there are real practical problems," said Deepak Baht, manager of advanced coatings development at GTE Valenite, a toolmaker in Troy, Mich., that is a unit of the GTE Corporation and part of the manufacturing sciences group. "The how-to of adhesion is now well known, but we still don't know exactly why it works. That makes scaling up to commercial production hard."
Teledyne Firth Sterling, a smaller toolmaker based in La Vergne, Tenn., has also been part of the consortium and also wants to see more tests before committing to commercial production.
 
 
Patent Uncertainties
 Currently, Crystallume's process can simultaneously coat up to six inserts over 24 hours. But toolmakers will have to coat hundreds of inserts at once for the process to be economically attractive, said Jerry Reimann, the center's project manager for diamond research.
Patent uncertainties and questions about the size of the potential market also affect the pace of investment in many technologies, including diamond films. Executives of toolmakers say the market for diamond-coated cutting inserts may be only about $50 million a year, although the extension of the technology beyond cutting devices to drilling tools is likely, meaning a potentially larger market.
Mr. Harbert expects the momentum to pick up this autumn after G.M. and Chrysler complete two months of production line tests of tools made with the Crystallume process. "That," Mr. Harbert said, "should prove the market exists."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A Market That's Educated, Affluent and Homosexual

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
AFTER listening to Republican Party attacks on homosexuals as having made "a wrong choice," many of America's largest marketers are making a different choice. Rather than being daunted by the campaign rhetoric, they are instead accelerating efforts at aiming sales messages at gay and lesbian consumers.
Blue-chip companies like Benetton, CBS, Hiram Walker, Philip Morris, Seagram and Time Warner are pursuing that unconventional strategy for the same reason that polls indicate few voters appear interested in Republican appeals to "family values" -- the economy. 
 "For a lot of people, the main concern right now is surviving in a tough economic climate," said Doug Alligood, vice president of special markets at BBDO New York. "When that happens, people get liberal in a hurry."
So if consumer product companies "find a market that's educated, affluent and can be reached through targeted media," Mr. Alligood continued, "there's no reason to be concerned about the politics."
Stephanie K. Blackwood, president at Blackwood & Friends, a New York public relations firm specializing in gay and lesbian marketing, said, "Rhetoric is one thing and recessions are another."
The affluence of homosexuals -- their annual earnings are estimated at $514 billion by Overlooked Opinions, a Chicago research firm -- "is the reason why Hiram Walker is interested in that market," she added. In Boston, Miami and New York, the company is testing a comprehensive marketing campaign aimed at homosexuals, for six brands including Courvoisier, Drambuie and Opal Nera.
As widespread as such efforts are becoming, they are, of course, by no means universal. Hundreds of major marketers still omit homosexuals from their plans, in important product categories like automobiles, fast food and soft drinks.
And some companies involved in the market are reticent about discussing the topic. Asked about Seagram's decision to advertise Somers gin, a test brand, in Out, a magazine for homosexuals, a spokeswoman in New York said that while "the gay market is an influential and trend-setting market," it is but "one factor in the overall audience, which is a very diverse audience."
And others involved in the market, like Gap Inc., refuse to discuss it. Mainstream advertising for its Gap retail chain mixes gay celebrities like the actor Ian McKellen with straight stars. And for its Banana Republic retail chain, ads in mainstream magazines and posters in stores include pairs of young men amid romantic couples.
One executive who has always been outspoken on the subject is Michel Roux, president and chief executive at Carillon Importers Ltd. in Teaneck, N.J., which markets brands like Absolut vodka.
He described himself as "not really worried about" attacks on homosexuals or on companies that market to them.
"Let me tell you something," he said. "I'm sure there are a lot of Republicans who are gay, too."
For gay men and lesbians of whatever political persuasion, Carillon is for the first time creating print advertisements specifically for a publication for homosexuals; previously, Carillon has used its mainstream ads in such publications.
In the Oct. 6 issue of The Advocate, celebrating the magazine's 25th anniversary, Carillon will sponsor "Absolut Symbols," a 16-page portfolio of works by gay and lesbian artists. Among the images: a gay marriage, a gay-pride parade -- even the 1969 Stonewall riots, considered the start of the modern homosexual-rights movement.
The Advocate's current issue is carrying ads from a first-time advertiser, CBS, promoting "The Kids in the Hall," a new late-night comedy series.
The network is not concerned about the "rhetorical warfare" over homosexuals, said George F. Schweitzer, senior vice president of CBS marketing and communications in New York, adding, "It clearly does not dictate our advertising positions."
Buying ad space in a homosexual publication "is not a political statement," he said. "It's an advertising strategy."
Another giant company eschewing a political motive for its entry into the market is Philip Morris U.S.A., which is including a smoker survey in Direct Male, a new direct-mail promotion being sent to 50,000 affluent gay male households. That follows a decision to include Genre, a magazine for homosexuals, among 58 publications in which ads appear for the company's new cigarette, Benson & Hedges Special Kings.
"Our market is adults who smoke," said a Philip Morris spokeswoman in New York, "and smokers come from all walks of life."
Among the other mainstream sponsors of Direct Male, produced by Winmark Concepts in Washington, are Berlitz International, the Conde Nast Collection, Time Warner's Quality Paperback Book Club, Warner-Lambert, and Interview and Men's Health magazines.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Reaches Record Low Against the Yen in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined sharply against the yen yesterday, hitting its lowest closing level ever against the Japanese currency, but settled mixed against the other currencies.
Gold prices settled mostly higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $348.80 an ounce, up $1.30 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold was up $1.10 an ounce, to $348.60. 
 Analysts said the dollar got off to a choppy start after the release of stronger-than-expected money supply figures in Germany. That led traders to speculate that the German central bank would not cut interest rates, and they sold the dollar.
But soon after, the Commerce Department said housing starts in the United States rose a robust 10.4 percent in August, the sharpest increase in 18 months. That, coupled with the continued turmoil among the European currencies, produced a wave of dollar-buying as dealers sought a safe haven, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA.
The dollar put in its worst performance against the yen. Many large Japanese investors are sheddding their holdings of European currencies and putting their money back into yen.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 122.67 yen, down 1.33 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 121.45 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.02 yen, down from 123.75 on Monday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7045, from $1.7130 late Monday. In New York, it cost $1.6965 to buy a pound, down from $1.7085 on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.4935 German marks, up from 1.4835; 1.3025 Swiss francs, down from 1.3030; 5.1045 French francs, up from 5.0750; 1,254.00 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.2358 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2321.
Silver prices rose worldwide. On the Comex in New York, silver settled at $3.822 an ounce, compared with $3.807 on Monday. In London, silver rose to $3.84, from $3.81.

HEADLINE: Kinark Will Take a Charge

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., Sept. 22

 BODY:
The Kinark Corporation, a chemical company, said today that it would write off the balance of a note receivable on a hotel it sold last year, resulting in a charge of $1.14 million, or 31 cents a share, in the third quarter.
Kinark, which sold the 350-room Tulsa-based Camelot Inn for $1.25 million in January 1991, said it had decided to write off the balance of the note because of the property's poor operating performance. 
 "The cash flow was just not there," a Kinark spokeswoman said. "The hotel economy in this part of the country just isn't very good."
For the third quarter a year ago, the company posted net income of $1.9 million, or 42 cents a share, on revenue of $8.7 million.
The company's shares hit a a 52-week low on the American Stock today, falling 50 cents, to $4.50.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Esther B. Fein

 BODY:

Salman Rushdie
When bookstores and libraries around the country begin observing Banned Book Week on Saturday, a week of activities and attention focusing on censorship around the world and through the ages, one of the most well-known modern writers on the list of unfortunately celebrated authors will be Salman Rushdie. Mr. Rushdie has lived in nomadic secrecy since February 1989, when his novel "The Satanic Verses" was declared blasphemous to Islam by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran and a multi-million dollar reward was offered for his execution.
Mr. Rushdie is venturing into the public more and more these days, doing impromptu readings at bookstores, addressing conventions on freedom of expression and human rights, conferring with Government officials in various countries. But everywhere he goes, he is surrounded by an elaborate security net and every public appearance, say the British authorities in charge of protecting him, poses a true threat to his life. 
 After the bounty on Mr. Rushdie's head was raised in June, and the Iranian foundation posting the reward offered to "cover expenses for the extermination of the cursed writer," in addition to having the bounty itself increased, Mr. Rushdie and the people who three years ago formed the Rushdie Defense Committee decided that they had to act more aggressively and openly to force Iran to end the execution decree.
"We can no longer use channels of quiet diplomacy," Mr. Rushdie said recently in a telephone interview. "We have to get sympathetic Governments to threaten Iran with economic sanctions and with being brought before the International Court of Justice in the Hague. Subtlety has been ineffective."
Frances D'Souza, the director of Article 19, a London-based international organization devoted to fighting censorship, said the relative impunity with which Iran has succeeded in "terrorizing Mr. Rushdie and others associated with the book" has led to a rise in censorship in other Islamic countries and in some countries in Africa and Southeast Asia.
As a founder of the Rushdie Defense Committee, she has set a goal of raising a million dollars by the end of this year, to finance the research and traveling necessary to accelerate the campaign to encourage Governments to pressure Iran to withdraw the decree against Mr. Rushdie.
"Do you realize that February will be four years since I was condemned," Mr. Rushdie said. "I am not resigned to living the rest of my life as fugitive for exercising my right to speak and write freely."
 
Howard Fast
 Howard Fast was never threatened with death for anything he wrote, but he was blacklisted in the 1950's by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after the House Committee on Un-American Activities accused him of writing Communist propaganda. At the time, he says now, he felt that the authorities might just as well have strangled him.
"It was sheer hell," said Mr. Fast, who had written a critically acclaimed autobiographical novel, "Citizen Tom Paine," before he was blacklisted, "Taking away a man's right to practice his art is nothing short of killing him."
Soon after he was blacklisted, Mr. Fast tried to publish his novel "Spartacus," the book upon which the film would be based, but no publisher would get involved with him. He finally decided to publish it himself, and the book became a best seller. Mr. Fast went on to publish books by other banned artists -- painters, poets, novelists -- but after hovering near what he described as "devastating poverty and near-bankruptcy," he got out of the self-publishing business and tried to return to writing full time.
He wrote a novel called "Sylvia," about a woman who escapes her impoverished childhood and becomes a successful member of high society whose millionaire fiance hires a private investigator to find out her history. But still, nobody would publish him. His agent, Paul Reynolds, finally suggested that he publish the novel under a pseudonym and as soon as he became E. V. Cunningham, the novel was published and then turned into the movie.
Mr. Fast went on to write 20 books under the pseudonym, though in France, where the F.B.I. blacklist didn't matter, each book came out under his real name. But through the years, "Sylvia" remained his favorite book, he said, and his anonymous connection to it became more painful.
"It was monstrous to see the book and not have my name associated with it," said Mr. Fast, who is now 78 years old, "and to know that no one would ever remember it as my work."
He said this one day at lunch with Hillel Black, the editor in chief of Carol Publishing, and last month the company's Birch Lane Press division published "Sylvia." For the first time the author was listed as Howard Fast.
"I feel relieved and redeemed," he said. "But it frightens me to know that our country is still not free of censorship when freedom of expression is an absolute necessity to any free society."
 
End Notes
 Dorothy Cannell begins her latest mystery, "Femmes Fatal" (Bantam), with a witty variation on the classic stereotype of a bad novel's opening line: "He was a dark and stormy knight." . . . The Rock Bottom Remainders, a band of best-selling authors who performed at the American Booksellers Convention in May in Anaheim, Calif., to raise money for literacy projects, are releasing a video of their musical performance. The band, which features among its members Stephen King, Amy Tan, Robert Fulghum, Dave Barry and Matt Groening, has boasted, "We play music as well as Metallica writes novels," but the amateur fun and enthusiasm is infectious. The 40-minute video, which is being released through BMG Video, includes performances of "Bye, Bye Love," "Teen Angel" and "Sea of Love," along with interviews of the authors and behind-the-scenes clips. Royalties are to benefit the Literacy Volunteers of America, the Homeless Coalition of Los Angeles and the Right to Rock Network. The video will be available in mid-October and will be sold through music and video stores. . . . Eight American writers will talk about the fate and the status of the novel at a panel discussion at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Town Hall Theater in midtown Manhattan. The authors who are to participate are Norman Mailer, Harold Brodkey, Michael Cunningham, Paule Marshall, Oscar Hijuelos, Norman Rush, Mona Simpson and Barbara Probst Solomon. The evening is sponsored by the Lannan Foundation, a private arts organization in Los Angeles, which as part of its literary program gives annual grants to writers of fiction, nonfiction and poetry.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
EXABYTE'S STOCK PLUNGES ON EARNINGS ESTIMATE

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The shares of the Exabyte Corporation, a Boulder, Colo., computer company, plunged more than 38 percent yesterday after it announced that third-quarter results would fall well below analysts' expectations. The company blamed the continued worldwide recession in the computer-systems market for its weak results. Exabyte was the most active issue in all trading yesterday, with volume of about 9.5 million shares, and it was the second-biggest percentage decliner in over-the-counter trading, closing off 38.4 percent, or $9.125, at $14.625. 
 Exabyte said it expects to post third-quarter earnings of 20 to 25 cents a share on revenue of $75 million to $78 million. In the period a year earlier, Exabyte's net income was about $8.6 million, or 40 cents a share, on revenue of $58.6 million. Analysts' estimates for the quarter ending Sept. 30 were between 48 cents and 57 cents a share on revenue of between $75 million and $78 million.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Appalled by the Execution Of A.I.D. Employee in the Sudan

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Relations between Washington and the Sudan, once an important American ally in Africa, have steadily deteriorated since the coming to power of Muslim fundamentalists in 1989. But the execution of a Sudanese employee of the United States' foreign aid agency appears to have shocked American diplomats already familiar with wide-ranging rights abuses by the Sudanese.
Donald Peterson, the United States Ambassador in Khartoum, said today that Andrew Tombe, 34 years old, a 10-year employee of the Agency for International Development in the southern regional capital of Juba, had been convicted of treason by a military court and executed about 10 days ago. Mr. Tombe was accused of working for a rebel group dominated by Christians and animists that is trying to wrest control of the south from the northern, Muslim-dominated government. 
 Embassy officials had been rebuffed in their requests for permission to go to Juba to see Mr. Tombe after his arrest in August, and again after his conviction, Mr. Peterson said.
The Ambassador said he had not been formally notified by the Government that Mr. Tombe had been executed. But he received a letter last Friday saying it was too late for the head of state, Lieut. Gen. Omar al-Bashir, to intervene in the A.I.D. employee's case.
He said he learned of Mr. Tombe's death through indirect channels.
Robert G. Houdek, now a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said that in 30 years as an American diplomat in Africa, he had never known of a local employee of a United States embassy being put to death.
Mr. Houdek said that the Sudanese Finance Minister, Abdul Rahim Hamdi, who is in Washington for an International Monetary Fund meeting, and another Sudanese official, a member of the allied National Islamic Front, would be called to the State Department on Wednesday.
"We plan to do some things but I'm not at liberty to say what," Mr. Houdek said. "I will communicate it to them at that time."
American options in the Sudan appear to be limited. All economic and military assistance were cut off after the Islamic fundamentalists came to power.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Kissinger Remarks on P.O.W.'s: Congress 'Undercut' Nixon

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony today by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger before the Senate Select Committee on P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs, including responses to some questions posed by the committee chairman, Senator John F. Kerry:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
With respect to the missing: There is really, as I see it, only one difference between us. Nobody ever questioned that the accounting for the missing was unsatisfactory. We raised it at least 60 times during 1973. 
 The only difference is that we did not know of confirmed prisoners. And had we known it, we would have taken the most drastic steps.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Mr. Chairman and gentlemen of the committee, 23 years ago the President of the United States did me the great honor of asking me to be the principal negotiator for ending the war in Vietnam. I might add, there were not too many applicants for that position.
When the Administration in which I served entered office, it found 550,000 soldiers in Vietnam; 31,000 had already died there. We faced a ruthless enemy without any regard for human life, or elementary principles of treatment of the captured.
From the day we entered office, we had no more consistent goal than the release of the brave Americans held prisoner throughout Indochina, and a full accounting of their missing colleagues.
The negotiating record makes clear that this matter was insistently raised with the Vietnamese. Despite Hanoi's protestations, we demanded that Hanoi guarantee the release of American P.O.W.'s in Laos and Cambodia, and assist in accounting for M.I.A.'s. There was no issue on which American officials from the President on down were more adamant . . .
After nearly four years of grueling negotiations, it was my privilege on Jan. 23, 1973, to initial the agreement to end the war that required the return of all prisoners throughout Indochina and an accounting for the missing. I am proud of what my associates and I accomplished. . . .
Here we are, 20 years later, being pilloried in leaks, without a shred of evidence, for the unforgivable libel that we knowingly abandoned the very group whose suffering was the biggest single incentive for our exertion.
The Paris accords were a major diplomatic accomplishment for America. As part of the accords, we demanded and finally received from Hanoi agreements which specifically made the withdrawal of American forces dependent on the release of our prisoners and assurances of Hanoi's assistance in the accounting for our missing.
 
Incentives and Penalties
Monday morning quarterbacks can argue that the Paris accords were not perfect. I agree. To me the ideal outcome would have been an American victory. But, Mr. Chairman, we had to deal with the war in the specific circumstances we faced. . . .
For example, just as I was leaving for the final negotiations in January 1973, the House and Senate Democratic caucuses each passed, by very large margins, resolutions calling for legislation to cut off all funds for the war.
I challenge those flaunting their 20-20 hindsight to say how they could have gotten better terms in that charged political atmosphere. What, precisely, would they have been willing to do to achieve what particular changes and at what cost?
Moreover, since Congress removed both incentives and penalties for Hanoi's compliance, how exactly would any achievable amendment have changed Hanoi's behavior?

 	 	 		. . .	 	I am amazed to see press stories hinting darkly about prisoners abandoned by their own Government. There has been talk of conspiracy extending through five Administrations. Leaks assert that when President Nixon announced that all prisoners were on their way home, he or his aides knew that many were left behind.
That allegation is a flat-out lie. What has happened to this country that a Congressional committee could be asked to inquire whether any American official of whatever Administration would fail to move heaven and earth to fight for the release of American P.O.W.'s and an accounting of the missing?

 	 	 		. . .	 	While I was in office, we did receive some reports alleging that live Americans were still in Indochina. I can assure you that all those reports were taken seriously. No confirmed report of living American prisoners ever crossed my desk, although I am not saying they did not exist.
At the time, returning prisoners stated that they believed that all prisoners had been released.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Favored Military Retaliation
 There is, of course, the question of what more we could have done. During this period, as I have reported in detail in my memoirs, and as I explained during my deposition, I favored military retaliation against Hanoi's repeated violation. . . .
President Nixon felt that on balance it was better to have one more negotiating round. And from the overall point of view, I had no reason to disagree with his judgment, nor do I today.
Certainly there was little support in the United States for stronger measures. Most commentators, I would say all commentators, congressional or media, opposed any effort to stand up to Hanoi, arguing that the United States had no right to retaliate at all against the North's blatant violation. . . . Nor did the Congress offer support needed to resist Hanoi's violation.
We made no secret of our outrage with Hanoi's violations. During 1973, we delivered at least 30 separate public statements or private messages to that effect. . .
Unfortunately, it was also no secret that these efforts to pin Hanoi down amounted to firing empty cannon.
In theory we had three sources of leverage available -- bombing the north, offering economic aid to Hanoi, and giving military and economic aid to Saigon to deprive Hanoi of the hope of military victory.
The Congress took all three levers away, denying us both the carrot and the stick. When the Congress eliminated our leverage, we were trapped in the classic nightmare of every statesman. We had nothing to back up our tough words. But more tough words.
Under such conditions, we had no bargaining position left. . . . I challenge critics of the accord to say precisely how they would have achieved a better outcome under these circumstances.

 	 	 		. . .	 	So let us stop torturing ourselves. . . The United States Government kept faith with those who served their country and suffered for it. If servicemen were kept by our enemy, there is one villain, and one villain only: the cold-hearted rulers in Hanoi.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. Mr. Secretary, lightly and nicely, let me say to you, this is the longest war in American history. In 1968, President Nixon came, and that was the year I was in Vietnam fighting, came with a program for peace, supposedly. In point of fact, what you wound up with in 1973 was extraordinarily close to the program tabled in 1969.
A. Absolutely not.
Q. Very close.
A. Not even remotely.
Q. Very close. I've read it word for word. But you suggest to me that those who oppose the war somehow took away options from you. I mean, you know, that's totally turning logic on -- I mean, the war ----
A. Mr. Chairman, it just -- what you are repeating here is the liturgy that one reads all the time that happens to be totally wrong. I don't happen to believe that this dialogue is very helpful, because it refights the Vietnam War.
 
U.S. Leverage
Q. . . . You were the first person here to suggest today that somehow it is inappropriate for me to ask a question because I represented a view that denied you these things.
Now, I don't believe I denied you anything.
A. No, all I'm saying is that the people who, in good faith, were opposed to continuation of military operations, cannot now say -- I do not in the slightest question your good faith -- cannot now say you didn't get what you only could have gotten by continuing military operations. That is all.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. The question is whether we got the full accounting and if we didn't, why. The question is did we move heaven and earth, as you said we would. Were we brutal in our response, as you told the families we would be? The answer is no.
Now, I've suggested that perhaps the reason is not that you were perfidious but that the Presidency crumbled, that there was not a capacity. If you think it's otherwise, I'd love to know.
 
'You Go Picking'
 A. Yes, I think it's otherwise, Mr. Chairman. First of all, Mr. Chairman, it is no great achievement. If you go picking through bureaucratic documents and use one sentence to prove what the motive was, nobody can believe --
Q. Sir, this is not a bureaucratic document. This is an American serviceman who was held as a prisoner in Vietnam.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Where Debate Was to Be, Clinton Shows Up for Rally

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 22

 BODY:
In the face of mounting Republican attacks on his character and record in Arkansas, Gov. Bill Clinton today used a rally at the site of what was to have been the first Presidential debate to say that President Bush is "ducking" the debates because he cannot defend his record.
"I showed up here to debate today," he told several thousand students at Michigan State University. 
 Mr. Clinton said Mr. Bush objected to the debate format because "he'd have a harder time with his politics of diversion, division and denial."
The Bush campaign, meanwhile, stuck by its position and rejected efforts by the debate commission to start discussions about the possibility of a debate next Tuesday.
The Clinton planners had been looking forward to using appearances in Michigan to paint Mr. Bush as an indifferent President who would prefer not to meet Mr. Clinton at the same site. A sign posted behind Mr. Clinton today read: "Bill Clinton. There's no debate about it."
"I guess I can't blame him," he said. "If I had the worst record of any President in 50 years, I wouldn't want to defend my record either."
 
Sharpening the Attack
 Mr. Clinton said the President would prefer to stay in "splendid isolation" rather than debate.
"Why didn't he show up today?" Mr. Clinton said. "I'll tell you why. He is not ducking this debate because he's a bad debater. As a matter of fact, he's won most of his national debates when there is a properly controlled format in which he's allowed to dump on his opponents and attack the press."
Mr. Clinton added: "After four years of broken promises, trickle-down economics, higher taxes on the middle class and fewer jobs all around, the President who will say anything to get elected but does nothing after he gets elected -- after four years of that, it's time for a change."
Mr. Clinton has spent portions of each of the last few days preparing for debates with Mr. Bush. As public and private polls have begun to show that many voters think the President is ducking the meetings, he has sharpened his criticism.
"He doesn't want to talk about the real lives of real people and what would happen on the day after the election," Mr. Clinton said.
 
Another Bush Rejection
 The Commission on Presidential Debates attempted to find middle ground between the Democratic and Republican camps today by offering to meet with Mr. Clinton's campaign chairman, Mickey Kantor, and his counterpart in the Bush organization, Robert M. Teeter, on a revised debating schedule. But the Bush camp again rejected the proposal.
The Clinton campaign accepted the suggestion that the two sides meet to discuss debating next Tuesday in Louisville and turn the proposed Oct. 4 debate in San Diego into a meeting between the two major Vice-Presidential candidates instead. Under this plan, the final debate would be held Oct. 15 in Richmond.
Mr. Kantor accepted the commission's tentative recommendation and agreed to meet, but Mr. Teeter rejected it. The Republicans have said debate talks should be conducted without the commission as an intermediary.
Publicly, the Bush campaign reacted little to today's developments. The President, speaking at a series of airport rallies vaguely promised some sort of Presidential debates.
"The other side says they're eager to debate," he said in Shreveport, La. "I've debated every time we've had elections, and we'll probably have debates. We're not going to do it on his terms alone, but we'll have debates."
But Mr. Clinton told the students at Michigan State and reporters on his plane that Mr. Bush was searching for the most superficial format.
"I'm not surprised that instead of coming up here today to make the case that the next four years ought to be like the last four, Mr. Bush has instead been flying to states all around my native state to tell them what a bad Governor I've been," he said.
Republicans acting on Mr. Bush's behalf were in East Lansing holding a news conference to make points similar to those the President was making on his six-state tour. On that tour Mr. Bush was dogged at the rallies by protesters calling attention to his refusal so far to debate.
Dressed as chickens, some protesters held signs that read, "Chicken George" and "Read My Beak." One, referring to Mr. Bush's most famous and ill-fated promise of the last election, said, "Chickens Have no Lips."
In Greenville, Miss., a chicken-protester bearing a sign that said, "No debate about it. It's Chicken George," was forced to leave the airport hanger by the police and Bush campaign officials before Mr. Bush was to speak.
Amid the tit-for-tat campaign attacks today, the Clinton campaign released its own version of what it said were Mr. Bush's flip flops, complete with a note from the President to Mr. Clinton in 1989 in which Mr. Bush praised the "great job" the Arkansas Governor's did on an education conference.
"I guess partisan politics will strain some relationships in '90," Mr. Bush wrote. "But I really want to keep education reform out there above the fray."

HEADLINE: BUSH VETOES BILL MAKING EMPLOYERS GIVE FAMILY LEAVE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
President Bush tonight issued an unusual late-night veto of a politically contentious bill that would require larger companies to grant at least 12 weeks of unpaid leave to any employee to deal with a birth or adoption, a parent's or spouse's sickness, or other family emergencies.
Nearing the end of 15 hours of campaigning, Mr. Bush said in a written statement that he supported the concept of family leave but was rejecting the legislation because the financial burden it would impose on business would further dampen the growth of the economy and new jobs. 
 The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, said he would quickly schedule a vote on overriding the veto.
 
Bush Hasn't Lost a Veto
 Mr. Bush has yet to lose a veto battle with the Democrats who control Congress, and there is little suggestion that this legislation, which was passed earlier this month by a 241-to-161 margin in the House, well short of the two-thirds needed to override a veto, would break that pattern. The bill passed the Senate on a voice vote in August.
But the political battle over the legislation is far more intense than that in Congress, and the timing of Mr. Bush's veto -- hours after the network television news programs had been broadcast -- suggested that the White House was seeking as little publicity for its action as possible.
Laura Melillo, a White House spokeswoman traveling with the President's campaign, said later that she was unsure why the veto message was issued so late, at 9 P.M., and said she could surmise only that the lateness was caused by the President's being on the road for the campaign.
 
Another Contentious Measure
 Congress earlier today sent Mr. Bush another contentious measure, one that would regulate soaring cable television prices, and dared him to carry through on his veto threat. On that bill, the two houses appeared to have enough votes to override a Bush veto for the first time. [Page D1.]
Mr. Bush has asserted that the Congress passed the family-leave bill at the peak of the campaign season, knowing that it would be vetoed, in an attempt to make him appear insensitive to the concerns of families and especially of women. Mr. Bush's Democratic opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton, favors the legislation.
In his veto message, Mr. Bush said, "I want to strongly reiterate that I have always supported employer policies to give time off for a child's birth or adoption or for family illness and believe it is important that employers offer these benefits. I object however, to the Federal Government mandating leave policies for American's employers and work force."
He suggested that Federal policies like the leave bill would stifle the creation of new jobs or result in the elimination of existing jobs.
In his veto message, the President called on Congress "to establish an alternative, flexible family-leave plan that will encourage small- and medium-size businesses to provide family leave for their employees" based on a refundable tax credit.
Mr. Bush formulated his proposal soon after the House passed the Democratic measure, and White House officials have acknowledged that there was little chance it would receive any real consideration, much less actual passage, before Election Day.
When the President vetoed a family leave measure in 1990, saying he opposed the idea of requiring businesses to provide leaves, he did not offer an alternative bill.
Tonight, Mr. Mitchell referred to the tax-credit proposal, saying: "The last time we heard such an interest in a family-leave tax credit was in the fall of 1988, when then-Vice President Bush promised during a political campaign to put forward such a proposal. Now, four years later, we are just learning the details of that proposal. This is a fig leaf to cover up the failed policies of the Bush Administration."
As to the timing of the veto announcement, Mr. Clinton said tonight: "Well, I expected it, but I'm still disappointed. I'm disappointed he did it late at night. I think he made a bad mistake. I think it's bad for America's families, bad for America's work places. That's another reason why I think people will vote for me Nov. 3, because I would sign such a law.
"I want to make these tough decisions in broad daylight when people can ask me about them. I'll have to make some tough decisions. When I do, I want to do it at a time where I can be held accountable for it."
The bill passed by Congress is broadly similar to one Mr. Bush vetoed in 1990. It requires companies with 50 or more workers to grant employees unpaid leave, to care for a sick child, parent or spouse, or for their own medical needs, like pregnancy, as well as requiring that employees' health insurance remain in force during such a leave.
It would not apply to employees who work fewer than 25 hours a weekly and would allow employers to exclude from the requirement workers in the top 10 percent of the pay scale. Those restrictions limit the bill's coverage mostly to the largest employers, about 5 percent of companies, employing roughly half of the nation's workers.
 
Bush's Alternative Tax Credit

Mr. Bush said last week in New Jersey that he believed family leave was an idea whose time was nigh. But he contended that most large companies already offered family leave to their workers and that the legislation would place an undue regulatory burden on those that did not. That would cost money, slow employment growth and eventually hurt some families the bill sought to help, he argued Friday.
Equally important, he said last week, the bill ignores the 50 to 60 percent of workers employed by small businesses that have no leave policies and, he said, cannot afford them without some form of assistance.
The Administration's new proposal would not require businesses to grant leaves but instead would offer a tax credit to any company, large or small, that chose to give its employees time off for family emergencies and medical problems.
The proposed credit, $20 a day for each employee up to 60 days leave, for an annual total of $1,200 a worker, would cost the Federal Government up to $400 million in lost tax revenues each year, the White House has estimated. Mr. Bush has said he will find the money by cutting elsewhere in the budget but has not specified what would be cut.

HEADLINE: Senate Fails to Override Veto Of Bill on Voter Registration

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The Senate today failed to override President Bush's veto of a bill that sought to increase voter turnout among the poor and the elderly by allowing citizens to register as they renew their driver's licenses or apply for welfare, unemployment, disability or Social Security benefits.
The President vetoed the bill nearly three months ago, but Democratic leaders decided to wait until the middle of the Presidential campaign to challenge Mr. Bush on it in order to maximize the political effect of their action. Democrats accused Mr. Bush of seeking to restrict the political power of those who most need Government help. 
 The Senate voted 62 to 38 in favor of overriding the veto, five votes short of the necessary two-thirds majority. The vote came down mostly along party lines, with 56 Democrats and 6 Republicans voting to override the veto and 37 Republicans joined by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, voting to sustain it.
The measure, known in Congress as the "motor voter" bill, was approved by the Senate in May, 61 to 38, with 6 Republicans joining the majority. The House approved an identical bill in June, 268 to 153, with 28 Republicans siding with the majority.
Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, the Senate Democratic whip who wrote the bill, said Mr. Bush's veto "reveals his shallow commitment to expanding democracy."
The measure would have simplified registration nationwide by adopting measures already in effect in 30 states. But the White House and most Republicans in Congress said a provision to encourage same-day registration would invite fraud in some areas.
"This is a solution in search of a problem," said Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky. "We estimate that it could cost up to $200 million in mandated costs that we would be imposing on the states, and there is no indication that throwing more people on the rolls makes them more likely to vote."
Richard Cloward, executive director of Human Serve, a voter registration group, disagreed. "This is a partisan effort to restrict democracy pure and simple," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From Bush's Speech on Clinton's Record

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an address by President Bush in Springfield, Mo.:
 
Civil Rights
 Let me begin with an issue of concern to every American, every fair-minded American, civil rights. Governor Clinton says, and I quote, "Everybody knows I have the best civil rights record" -- his words. His modesty overwhelms me. But how does his record stand? 
 Some of you may know that in 1968 when I was a Congressman from Texas I supported the Fair Housing Act, and it wasn't popular with some of my constituents. And times have changed, of course. And nowadays 41 states have laws banning housing discrimination -- 41. But Arkansas is not one of them, and even though my opponent has been Governor for 12 years. Forty-six states have human relations agencies that safeguard citizens against discrimination. But not Arkansas under his leadership. Forty-eight states have basic civil rights laws that ban discrimination and guarantee equal opportunity, but not Arkansas. And that's right. Arkansas is only one of two states in America without a civil rights statute.
Candidate Clinton likes to talk about my 1990 veto of the Democratic Congress's quota bill. And I did veto that bill, and I'll veto any other quota bill that the liberals cook up.
I am for civil rights, and I am against quotas. And that is not a contradiction.
And so last year, after tough negotiations with Congress and beating back two attempts to ram down my throat and the people's throat a quota bill, I did sign, proudly sign, a major civil rights bill without resorting to quotas.
And in addition, I fought for the Americans With Disabilities Act, the most sweeping civil rights legislation in 30 years that brings those with disabilities into the mainstream and gives them a shot at the American dream.
And I'm proud of it.
And what about Governor Clinton? Even though his party enjoys overwhelming control of the Arkansas Legislature, Governor Clinton has still not brought a civil rights bill to the people of Arkansas.
And so when you hear the Candidate Clinton's rhetoric all across this country about civil rights, Governor Clinton's record just does not stand up.
 
Taxes
 Now, consider another issue -- economic fairness. You know, Candidate Clinton is playing the old games that liberals love to play, class warfare, divide Americans rich from poor, one group from another. He's good at it. Candidate Clinton is very good at that, using the same tired, twisted partisan statistics to explain how the poor can only get richer if the rich get poorer.
According to Candidate Clinton, the last 10 years have been a nightmare. Well, I've got news for him: it is not true. The Urban Institute back in Washington is not usually sympathetic to me. But listen to what they had to say about the 1980's. "When one follows individuals, rather than statistical groups defined by income, one finds that on average, the rich got a little richer, and the poor got much richer." Now that's the truth. Our policies of cutting taxes have spurred growth for all Americans.
Yes, we've got tough times now, but it's fair to look at the whole record. And Candidate Clinton doesn't think this is a fair result. He doesn't think it's fair, and it's maybe because Governor Clinton doesn't have much experience with tax fairness in his own state.
Governor Clinton has more than doubled -- you want a horror story, listen to this -- he has more than doubled Arkansas state spending since 1983, and he has paid for it by raising the taxes that hurt poor and working families the most. My opponent has raised and extended his sales tax repeatedly, and he has opposed removing that tax from groceries.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Crime
 Another issue, one near and dear to the hearts of every American, rural or urban, and that's crime.
Candidate Clinton -- Candidate Clinton, meet Governor Clinton. During the 1980's, the nation's overall crime rate, during the 80's, actually declined, but not in Arkansas. In fact, Governor Clinton's state had the biggest increase in overall crime rate in the entire nation. Nearly 28 percent.
And again, this is not fair to the good people of Arkansas. What about violent crimes? Arkansas's violent crime rate went up more than 58 percent, one of the worst records in the entire nation.
Why? Well, I've got a few hunches. Arkansas ranks near rock bottom in every per capita law-enforcement expenditure. For prisons, 46th. For judicial and legal systems, 50th. And when it comes to spending for police officers, Arkansas ranks 49th. And in Arkansas, when the prison door slams shut on a convicted criminal, he knows it won't be long before it opens up again.
As incredible as it sounds, as incredible as it sounds, most inmates in Arkansas serve less than one-fifth, one-fifth of their sentence behind bars. That's the worst record in the entire nation.
And the people of Arkansas deserve to walk their streets without fearing that some crazy convict is going to ruin their lives, some guy let out of jail far too early.
Now contrast the situation in Arkansas with what we've been doing on the Federal level. Most Federal inmates serve at least 85 percent of their full sentence. And I think it's pretty simple. If you take liberties with the law, you're going to lose your own liberties for a long, long time.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

 BODY:

GOV. BILL CLINTON
In a speech yesterday at Michigan State University at East Lansing.
 "I'm not surprised that instead of showing up here today to make the case that the next four years ought to be like the last four, Mr. Bush is instead flying to states all around my native state to tell them what a bad Governor I've been. I'll tell you what: I bet you anything he won't point out that Arkansas ranks first in the country in job growth this year. 
 He sent his Secretary of Labor to my state, and she had to admit that the job growth in Arkansas has been enormous. We've created more manufacturing jobs in my state in the last four years than have been created in the whole country under the Bush policies, because he has no economic strategy.
 I'll bet you anything he won't tell them that we've got the second lowest tax burden in the country, or that U.S. News & World Report says that we have the third best overall economic performance in America. I'll bet George Bush conceals that from the people he's talking to today, because he doesn't want to talk about the real lives of real people, and what will happen on the day after the election. It's all about diversion, denial and division. We can do better than that.
This debate is not about George Bush or Bill Clinton. It's about you and what kind of future you're going to have."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Encircling Arkansas, Bush Opens Harsh Attack on Clinton's Record

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 22

 BODY:
Trailing in polls around the nation, President Bush today unleashed a harsh critique of Bill Clinton's record as Governor of Arkansas and depicted him as a man who could not be trusted to lead the country.
A combative, sometimes strident Mr. Bush derided Mr. Clinton as a "man who has the gall to go around America and promise the moon, when on issue after issue, the sky has fallen in his own backyard." 
 "He talks one way around the nation; he delivers misery at home," Mr. Bush said. "We've all heard what Candidate Clinton can do for America, but that's very different from what Governor Clinton has done to Arkansas. The record of Governor Clinton proves that it doesn't matter what the candidate will say to anyone, because he won't deliver." [Excerpts, page A20.]
 
A Tactic Renewed
 To lend emphasis to the argument, Mr. Bush staged an elaborate game of political encirclement, with Air Force One touching down more than six times in a single day in the states bordering the one his opponent has governed for five terms.
Reprising a tactic from the 1988 Presidential campaign, Mr. Bush laid out a broad, highly detailed attack on Mr. Clinton's record, accusing him in unusually harsh language of a wide array of failures in leadership in areas like the economy, the environment, crime, civil rights and health care.
Although statistically the President was on solid ground in his criticism of the Governor's record, a closer examination shows that Mr. Clinton has accomplished much in his state and that the statistics must be put into context to be fully understood. [News analysis, page A20.]
In his stops today, a day that had once been set aside for a televised debate between the candidates, Mr. Bush spoke of Mr. Clinton as someone who believes he can win election "only by tearing down America," as one who is "playing that old game liberals love to play -- class warfare," as the sort of Governor who "coddles criminals" and wants to "raise taxes that will kill jobs."
But, in apparent recognition of Mr. Clinton's determinedly middle-of-the-road persona, Mr. Bush also attacked from the left, criticizing the Governor for his environmental record and his state's care of children and its record on civil rights legislation.
The President's tactics seemed to draw in part on those he used four years ago, when he stripped Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of his political appeal by depicting the Massachusetts Governor as a spendthrift who had done a poor job at home.
Bush advisers said today that the President emphasized he was returning Mr. Clinton's attacks on him, because he did not want to be seen as the first candidate to go on the offensive. Now that the fight has been joined, however, Mr. Bush may stick to his tough tone, a senior aide said, even though classic political strategy calls for a return to a more positive tone just before Election Day.
"He's going to go out and say it and keep on saying it, because it's time for our principal to get into the fight," the aide said.
 
Difficult Straits for Bush
 In the past, Mr. Bush has preferred to stay above personal attacks, letting surrogates handle them. It is perhaps a measure of the difficulty he faces with only six weeks until Election Day that he is now handling the job himself, and in states that, by recent history's guide, should have already been safely in the Republican column.
"We've got to get this in the mix," a second Bush adviser said, speaking on a condition of anonymity. "But at the same time, and in almost the same proportion, we've got to give people a reason to be for George Bush."
The President said: "For month after month, Governor Clinton has persisted in attacks on me -- persistent, unrelenting and many very personal in nature. Frankly, he has distorted my record, and his campaign chairman even called me a racist. And this week, the Governor unveiled for the first time in this Presidential race negative campaigning, negative television advertising.
"So far, right up to today in Springfield, I have resisted the urge focus on Governor Clinton's record. But I must tell you, I am very tired of the distortions, tired of the half-truths. And the stakes are too high to let America be deceived by a negative campaign.
"So today, I have chosen to lay it on the line, talk about my opponent's record, talk facts, talk about the record in Arkansas, the Governor's record. And that means explaining the Grand Canyon that separates his rhetoric from the reality of his record."
In tone and particulars, Mr. Bush's speeches at rallies in Missouri, Oklahoma, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Tennessee recalled his attacks on Mr. Dukakis as a left-leaning, blame-America-first, soft-on-crime liberal.
 
Trying the Canine Analogy
 In Tulsa, Okla., the President said Mr. Clinton had "talked a lot, but done nothing," on civil rights. Later, in Longview, Tex., he charged his opponent with having a "sorry record, by any Texas standard," on health care and of taking such poor care of the Arkansas environment that "the rivers are so polluted the fish glow in the dark."
Then, in Shreveport, La., he said he wished that the tough-on-crime Candidate Clinton -- "the Doberman pinscher," he called him -- could meet "Governor Clinton, the Chihuahua on crime," whom he accused of having "the worst record in the entire nation, when it comes to keeping criminals behind bars."
Mr. Bush's attack rested heavily on what his strategists see as Mr. Clinton's great weakness, that many voters do not fully trust his character. The President thus spoke of Mr. Clinton as "slippery when wet" and made glancing references to his rival's much-publicized difficulty in explaining why he did not serve in the military during the Vietnam War.
In Longview, Mr. Bush pointed to a World War II warplane parked in front of him at the airport and said: "That's the kind of torpedo bomber I flew. I'm proud that I served my nation in combat."
In Shreveport, a man listening to Mr. Bush's invitation-only rally at the airport yelled out a question about Mr. Clinton and the draft, prompting Mr,. Bush to reply: "No, I am not going to talk about the draft today. I'll let the American people make up their minds about that. All I will say is that I am proud I put on the uniform and fought for my country."
The Clinton campaign responded quickly to the attacks and accused Mr. Bush both of being afraid to make his charges directly to the Governor's face and of distorting his record.
"They obviously don't want to debate the Arkansas record face to face with Governor Clinton, as they turned down the debate that was scheduled to be held in Michigan today," the Clinton campaign's spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said. "And they obviously are afraid to go into Arkansas and try to say this, because in Arkansas people know that the Governor's record is one of progress, with per capita income going up, welfare reform working, schools getting better."
While the direction of attack that Mr. Bush took today is not new in general character -- "the failed Governor of a small state" has been a Republican line for some time -- the specific accusations were far sharper and more detailed and numerous than in the past.
On civil rights, Mr. Bush dismissed Mr. Clinton's claim of a good record by saying that, as Governor for 12 years, Mr. Clinton has failed to sign a civil rights law banning discrimination. "That's right," Mr. Bush said. "Arkansas is one of only two states in America without a civil rights statute."
On Mr. Clinton's taxing and spending record, Mr. Bush said, "If you want a horror story, listen to this: he has more than doubled Arkansas state spending since 1983, and he has paid for it by raising the taxes that hurt the poor working families the most." The Governor, he said, had doubled the state gasoline tax, raised the tax on beer, inititated taxes on mobile homes and "even taxed food stamps until the Federal Government made him stop."
On crime, Mr. Bush's charges sounded like a replay of the attacks his campaign leveled against Mr. Dukakis over a Massachusetts program that allowed a murderer serving a sentence of life without parole to escape while on a weekend furlough and then brutally attack a Maryland couple.
Mr. Bush said Arkansas under Mr. Clinton's stewardship had "the worst record in the entire nation," in terms of paroling inmates who had served only small parts of their sentences, with "most inmates serving less than one-fifth" of their sentences. Violent crime, he said, had increased more than 58 percent during Mr. Clinton's tenure.
Ms. Myers, the Clinton spokeswoman, said Mr. Bush's charges were in many cases distorted because the President omitted to say that Arkansas's tax burden was in fact extremely low, that Arkansas led the nation in job growth in 1992 and that the Clinton Administration's failure to enact civil rights measures had not been for lack of trying.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Truth's Several Sides;
Bush's Attack on the Clinton Record Is Accurate, at Least as Far as It Goes

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Much of President Bush's damning description today of Bill Clinton's record as Governor was accurate, but as with all things political, Mr. Bush's account gave only half the story.
There are countervailing figures and plausible explanations for many of the harsh statistics the President described, conditions borne of Arkansas's endemic poverty, its citizens' historical disdain for government and the sharp statutory limits the state places on its chief executive. 
 Still, it is true, as Mr. Bush declared, that Arkansas's per capita income, among the lowest in the nation for as long as statistics have been collected, has not risen under Mr. Clinton's rule. In fact, it has fallen back a bit.
It is true that taxes have risen, particularly for the poor and middle class. College-admissions test scores have fallen. Only three other states have fewer people covered by health insurance. And only one other state has not passed a civil rights law.
 
Some Things Left Out
 But even with all that, Mr. Bush left a lot out. His own record as President offers as many opportunities for statistical attack. Today, Mr. Clinton, berating the President for failing to agree to terms for a debate, proclaimed, "If I had the worst record of any President in 50 years, I wouldn't want to defend that record either."
In the end, the numbers illustrating Arkansas's low rank among the states are hard, making them easy to throw around to good effect. The explanations are soft, making them difficult to communicate with equal force. And those are the key ingredients of a potentially effective political attack.
But even a casual look at Mr. Clinton's record as Governor for most of the last 13 years would suggest that the voters of his state, at least, must believe he has accomplished something. He has served longer in that office than anyone else; the voters have elected him five times. By most accounts he remains quite popular, even as national statistics continue to rank the state near last in the nation by most measures of quality of life.
One explanation for this paradox lies in the particularly bleak expectations most Arkansas residents seem to have.
"It took us 150 years to get in this spot, and it might take us a good long time to get out of it," Mike Gauldin, Mr. Clinton's aide, likes to say.
 
Attacking Basic Problems
 By most accounts, much of the state does believe Mr. Clinton has, in fact, worked hard to attack some of Arkansas's fundamental problems -- below-average schools, a weak economic base, lagging social services.
"People really do believe we've been aggressive and progressive about trying to bring our folks along," said John E. Miller, a member of the Arkansas House for the last 34 years.
But while Mr. Clinton may have tried harder than many of his predecessors, the governers of other states were hard at work, too. And so, after more than a decade of effort that many in Arkansas describe as extraordinary for the state, by many measures the state has managed only to hold its place -- near the bottom.
Even with that, a closer look at some of the issues Mr. Bush used in his attack today shows that the problems are not nearly as stark or one-sided as the President suggested. For some other issues, Mr. Bush's own record includes vulnerabilities as well.
 
Both Clean and Dirty
 As Mr. Bush said, the Kings River in northwest Arkansas has grown badly polluted with fecal bacteria and other pollutants derived from poultry wastes that wash into the stream. Mr. Clinton has also been widely criticized for appointing a 27-member committee made up mostly of poultry industry executives and state agency heads to study the problem.
But it is also true that Arkansas remains one of only a handful of states that meets all Federal air quality standards, while about 82 percent of the state's rivers and streams are clean enough for fishing and swimming -- one of the highest percentages in the nation.
As the President correctly observed, only one other state, Alabama, has not enacted a civil rights law barring racial discrimination in hiring and promotion. Mr. Clinton promoted a civil rights bill before the Arkansas Legislature last year, and it was defeated. Even without that, more blacks and women have been appointed to state boards, commissions and government departments under Mr. Clinton than under any of his predecessors.
And as Mr. Clinton's campaign likes to point out, Mr. Bush's record on this issues has long been a subject of criticism. As an unsuccessful Senate candidate from Texas in 1964, Mr. Bush campaigned against the Civil Rights Act of that year, saying it was "bad legislation in that it transcends the Constitution."
 
Not That Simple
 As Mr. Bush pointed out, Mr. Clinton raised taxes "that hurt poor and working families the most." At the Governor's urging, Arkansas's Legislature raised the sales tax and extended it to some items, like used cars, that are most often purchased by people with low incomes. But Mr. Clinton did that only after the Legislature refused to raise the state income tax, the least regressive state tax.
Under Arkansas's Constitution, the income tax can be raised only if three-quarters of the Legislature approves -- a nearly impossible political burden. As a result, the income tax has been raised only once since 1928. But even with the other tax increases during Mr. Clinton's time in office, 41 states impose higher tax burdens on their citizens.
Since 1979, as Mr. Bush said, the cumulative test scores of Arkansas students have fallen from 20th to 25th among the 28 states that administer one popular college-admission exam. But that may be because far more students, taking advantage of new state aid programs, are applying to college now -- meaning that the pool of test-takers no longer includes just the cream of each year's senior class.
At the same time, at Mr. Clinton's urging, the state's schools have increased expenditures, broadened curriculums, set new academic standards, required comptency tests for teachers and slowed the drop-out rate. Over all, state officials note, Arkansas now devotes a larger percentage of its budget to education than all but two other states -- a striking increase over the last decade.
Mr. Clinton's aides argue that the real effects of this increased commitment to education will not be felt until the generation of students that entered the schools in the mid- to late-1980's begins to graduate.
"We've laid a foundation," Bill Bowen, Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, said last spring. Now, he said, "It's a matter of waiting for things to come to fruition."

HEADLINE: Philadelphia Unions Facing Deadline Today on Contract

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Almost every day, Mayor Edward G. Rendell repeats a campaign pledge that he will endure a strike, if necessary, to make the city run efficiently and within its budget.
It may be necessary. 
 When Mr. Rendell came into office last November, Philadelphia had endured two years of political paralysis and fiscal crisis. To revive the city's economy, he vowed to set into motion a five-year plan to make the city run efficiently. The backbone of that plan included $1.1 billion in management and labor savings.
Now, after months of bargaining between city officials and the two unions representing all 15,000 non-uniformed municipal workers, a strike could occur as early as Thursday.
 
Threat of General Strike
 The Philadelphia A.F.L.-C.I.O. Council, which represents 250 local unions, including those for city employees, has also threatened a general strike by its 250,000 members in support of the city workers.
Matters came to a boil last Friday when Mr. Rendell presented the city's "last, best offer" at a news conference and said the unions, both districts of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, had until 5 P.M. Wednesday to accept it or have it imposed upon them.
"If you were a worker in the private sector and you were working for a company that suffered four straight years of substantial losses, you would view this contract proposal as a fair one," Mr. Rendell said.
By Monday night, the unions had rejected Mr. Rendell's offer. But informal talks continued today, leaving the possibility of a settlement. If no agreement is reached by 5 P.M. Wednesday, it is not certain what will happen.
"If the Mayor seeks to unilaterally implement this last offer, we will consider every option available to us, including lawsuits and a strike," said Deborah R. Willig, a lawyer representing the unions. Strikes by municipal employees are legal in Pennsylvania.
Ms. Willig said the unions could ask the Pennsylvania Labor Relations Board to rule that it is an unfair labor practice for the city to impose a final offer. The board ruled earlier this year that the Philadelphia Housing Authority was unfair when it imposed a final offer on its employees, but that ruling is being appealed.
Such a ruling by the board would not immediately prevent the city from imposing its final offer. But the dispute could drag on for several months.
The unions have already filed a charge of unfair labor practices , asserting that Mr. Rendell illegally presented his final offer at a news conference instead of at the bargaining table. State law prohibits employers from dealing directly with employees as opposed to union negotiators.
 
Getting the Public Ready
 Despite raising the ire of municipal unions, Mr. Rendell has, in the view of political analysts here, managed public opinion wisely since he was elected last November with 68 percent of the vote.
"He's been getting people used to the idea of a strike for months, saying something bad's going to happen, but something good will come out of it for everybody," said Randall M. Miller, a professor of political science at St. Joseph's University. "But it's hard to maintain this public readiness, so he is bringing it to a crisis for financial and political reasons."
Many fiscal experts say the city's survival depends on reducing its labor costs, which represent nearly 60 percent of the city's $2.3 billion budget.
"This negotiation is a make-it or break-it issue for the financial health and credibility of Philadelphia," said Diane E. Reed, executive director of the Pennsylvania Economy League, a nonprofit research organization.
 
Doing Well by Comparison
 Ms. Reed said Mr. Rendell's offer was "completely appropriate." She said Philadelphia's employees get higher pay and benefits than employees in nine other large cities in the nation.
The unions dispute the league' figures, but add that the disagreement is largely over benefits, job security and the union's role in the workplace. "Mr. Mayor is mistaken if he thinks the union is going to negotiate itself out of existence," said Dwight Kirk, a spokesman for one city local.
Mr. Rendell, saying he was seeking the same kinds of management flexibility that a dozen other major cities had obtained in recent years, says the city must "regain the right to manage its affairs like any business."
He said the city could not raise taxes or cut services, since it has done both repeatedly over the last decade.
 
Better Than First Offery
 The Mayor's last offer is apparently about 25 percent better than his first, which was made this spring, before the contracts expired on June 30. But the new offer still calls for $450 million in labor savings over the next four years. The contracts for the police and firefighters are settled by binding arbitration.
Under the Mayor's proposal, workers would receive no increase for two years, a 2 percent increase in 1995 and a 3 percent increase in 1996. The city would take over administration of health plans from the unions and require workers to pay a share of their medical expenses. Holidays and sick leave would be reduced.
The city has little room to negotiate since it has already incorporated the anticipated labor savings in its five-year recovery plan. The plan calls for obtaining the labor savings or, failing that, laying off enough workers to balance the budget each year. The plan, backed by the City Council, was the basis for the city's obtaining state help in raising $475 million in bonds on Wall Street earlier this year to cover deficits and capital improvements.
Last year, the State Legislature created an authority to oversee the city's finances and sell bonds on the city's behalf. If the city does not balance its budget, the authority can withhold proceeds of its bond sales and most assistance, said Ronald G. Henry, the authority's executive director. "Rendell has to stand his ground," he said.
