HEADLINE: Yawning at The Bomb

 BODY:
It has taken the Senate 14 months to begin consideration of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. Yet what do some resistant Republicans want to do? Filibuster, further delaying ratification. That's the latest example of Washington's remarkably diffident attitude toward the large and potentially dangerous array of nuclear arms that remain in the former Soviet Union.
Soviet disunion catapulted three republics into the ranks of nuclear powers overnight. If the U.S. is to prevent instant proliferation, it needs to take several urgent steps: 
 Coax Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus to get rid of their remaining nuclear-tipped missiles. Codify the agreement on far deeper reductions concluded with Russia in June. Induce Russia to dismantle nuclear warheads faster. Buy all the nuclear material removed. And post international inspectors at storage sites in the meantime.
For both sides to get on with these tasks, the Start treaty needs to be ratified. Any sign of hesitation would only play into the hands of nuclear nationalists in the former Soviet republics. Yet a handful of recalcitrant Republicans opposed to any arms control would do just that.
Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus all pledged in May to surrender their nuclear missiles in seven years. But today's regimes may not be around to deliver on that promise. Already Ukrainian nationalists are talking openly about reneging. Yet there's little sense of urgency in Washington: the U.S. official responsible for getting the nuclear republics to dispose of their arms is a part-time employee. Washington can use economic leverage to push disarmament by the republics.
Washington's lethargy extends to deeper cuts negotiated with Moscow. The cuts could induce the other nuclear republics to disarm. Yet the Government has not vigorously pressed to formalize the June agreement so that it can be ratified and carried out. What are we waiting for?
Russia has begun methodically dismantling some nuclear warheads but it could easily go faster. The U.S., or allies like Japan, might offer an inducement: so many millions in aid for, say, going twice as fast.
To its credit, the Administration has concluded a deal to buy Russian uranium removed from the dismantled warheads. But it has made no provision for monitoring the dismantling to insure that material stays out of the hands of nuclear wannabes. That may require reciprocal inspections in the U.S., which the Departments of Energy and Defense resist with startling shortsightedness.
The U.S., let alone the world, has an overriding interest in preventing instant proliferation. But no one would guess that from the backward-looking filibuster and the bureaucrats' sluggish Start.

HEADLINE: Women's Household Labor Goes Unrewarded

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The denial of women's labor is a curious phenomenon. Why is it that a woman is thought to be either "at work" or "at home," and that working at home means performing office tasks? Why isn't child raising considered to be the difficult, albeit rewarding job that it is?
It was mentioned repeatedly at the Republican Convention and in your Sept. 2 news article on mothers' roles that a woman was either "at work" or had chosen to stay "at home." "At home" had the connotation of being invisible. As Anna Quindlen has written: "When men do dishes, it is called helping. When women do dishes, it is called life" ("Abhors a Vacuum," column, Sept. 9). 
 It seems that in a patriarchal world only men's work is considered real work. Women are not paid for the services of the home. They are not part of the economy. It is convenient to think of women's work as insignificant and unworthy. If the work is unacknowledged and denied, then no one has to be directly responsible for it, certainly not men. Working men don't have to feel guilty about not sharing housework and child care, especially if they don't exist.
As an artist and mother I have worked at home and in my studio. It seems it is time to recognize that women who are "at home" are also "at work." If child raising and housework were considered valuable, there would be untold rewards and jobs for everyone.
 
ELIZABETH ENDERS
New York, Sept. 11, 1992

HEADLINE: Cable Bill Approved By Senate

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Congress sent President Bush a controversial bill today to regulate soaring cable television prices, daring him to carry through on his veto threat in the face of large votes for the measure in both the House and Senate.
The Senate approved the measure today, 74 to 25, an unexpectedly wide margin that included a majority of the Senate's Republicans. The approval came despite intense lobbying against the measure by cable television companies, Hollywood movie studios and the White House. [Roll-call, page D2.] 
 The House of Representatives had approved the same bill on Thursday by a wide margin, making it likely that President Bush would lose any veto battle on the issue. The President so far has not had any of his vetoes overridden by Congress.
 
Monthly Bill May Not Change
 Consumers are unlikely to notice an immediate change in their monthly cable bills, since the measure would primarily affect only a bare-bones package of programming consisting of local over-the-air television stations.
The bill would require the Federal Communications Commission to establish a "reasonable" price for such a basic package of cable programs and would authorize more limited regulation of the expanded packages that include such offerings as MTV, movies and sports channels.
But the measure also has a lucrative provision for broadcasters and includes some features ardently sought by companies that distribute television over satellite and microwave radio channels. The cable companies say those provisions will cable prices up.
 
Finance and Politics
 So, what started as an effort to pass a rather tame consumer bill three years ago has evolved into a high-stakes showdown on two stages. On one stage is the battle between huge competing industries: cable television companies and Hollywood studios versus over-the-air broadcasters and their allies.
On a second stage is the election-year battle between Congressional Democrats bent on passing what they see as a major consumer bill and President Bush, who has staked out his position as an opponent of "unnecessary and burdensome" regulations. The regulatory provisions in this bill are much tougher than the ones in a bill that nearly passed Congress in 1990, and rate increases are likely to be slowed considerably.
Today's vote came amid an intense blitz of lobbying and advertising from both sides of the issue. Cable companies have put a barrage of ads on cable networks, supplemented by leaflets stuffed into customers' bills, arguing that the bill would make rates go up, instead of down. The most familiar ad shows a man under an umbrella that leaks from numerous holes, intended to depict the bill's special-interest provisions. The ad warns consumers not to "get soaked."
The bill could become a significant issue in the Presidential campaign. Senator Al Gore Jr. of Tennessee, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, is a co-sponsor of the bill and he is scheduled to make a speech on Thursday in Morganton, N.C., where city officials have fought bitterly with the local cable company over price increases.
Cable television prices have risen over 50 percent, more than three times the rate of inflation, since they were deregulated five years ago under a law passed in 1984. In some cities, rates for basic service have more than doubled.
The bill being sent to President Bush would largely reverse the 1984 law, which was intended to give impetus to what was then a nascent cable industry. Cable television has grown spectacularly in recent years, from a fledgling industry with $2.5 billion in sales in 1980 to nearly $20 billion today. The number of channels available has steadily risen, from about a dozen in the early 1980's to as many as 75 in some cities and 150 in a showcase system in Queens, owned by Time-Warner Inc.
The consumer issues have emerged because cable companies continue to enjoy exclusive franchises in all but a few dozen communities. Competition from new technologies, like satellites that beam signals directly to houses, has yet to materialize.
Supporters of the bill were ecstatic about the lopsided vote. "It's a big boost," said Gene Kimmelman, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America. "It's a clear signal to President Bush that there is overwhelming support in the House and Senate to do something about the cable industry's excesses. He's got a lot of votes to change."
James P. Mooney, president of the National Cable Television Association, said he would continue to fight for a successful veto. "This is obviously a tough fight, and it isn't over," he said in a brief statement today.
 
Broadcasters Return Fire
 The National Association of Broadcasters has struck back at the cable companies' ads, blanketing both the radio and television airwaves in some cities with counter-ads. The broadcasters have provided most of the muscle in support of the bill, because it includes a provision that would allow them to demand royalties from cable companies for the right to retransmit their programming.
Some of the heaviest activity, however, has come from Hollywood movie producers who oppose the provision on retransmission rights because they fear it will leave them out of a valuable new stream of royalties. Jack Valenti, head of the Motion Picture Association of America, made personal visits to five Senators on Monday, according to one of his allies, and studio chiefs in California spent much of the last week urging lawmakers to vote against the bill. Among these were Michael Eisner, chief executive officer of the Walt Disney Company and Robert Daly, chief executive of Warner Brothers.
Both supporters and opponents had predicted that the vote would be close in terms of getting the fragile two-thirds majority needed to override a veto. The Senate approved a similar bill in January by a vote of 73 to 18, but many Republicans and a few Democrats loyal to Hollywood were considered likely to change their votes.
That did not happen. Only 18 Republicans voted against the bill today, while 24 voted in favor of it. Among the Republicans who had been considered candidates for switching their votes but did not do so were stalwart conservatives like Orrin Hatch of Utah and Alan Simpson of Wyoming, as well as moderates like Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania who face serious election challenges in November.
 
A Senator's Struggle
 "I don't think either side is right," said Senator Hatch, adding that his name had been mentioned in some television ads by local broadcasters and that he had almost voted against the bill in protest of that. Senator Hatch said he had voted in favor of the legislation in January and had overcome his concerns about re-regulation in part to remain consistent. Asked whether he would switch sides to support President Bush if a veto is put to an override test, he said he would "certainly look at it."
The leading Democratic opponent of the bill, Senator Tim Wirth of Colorado, whose state is home to Tele-Communications Inc., said today: "I'm surprised the Republicans didn't get more votes on this. They usually have better discipline than this. The President has got to be concerned about whether he has the votes. It's a stretch."
Senator John C. Danforth, the Missouri Republican who co-sponsored the legislation, said it would be premature to assume that President Bush would be defeated in a veto test. "This is a stronger vote than I had expected, but veto fights are tough," Mr. Danforth said. "They'll turn some votes around."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 25, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Wednesday showing the possible impact of cable television legislation misstated the royalties that broadcasters are expected to receive from cable companies. The highest estimate has been $1 billion, not $3 billion.


GRAPHIC: Backers of the cable bill call it a major consumer initiative that will curb soaring prices, while the cable industry says the measure is loaded with special-interest giveaways that will raise rates.
 
How The Bill Would Push Rates Down:
 
Rates
Chart: "The Cable Television Bill Debate"
The F.C.C. would set guidelines for prices for basic service, roughly pegged to the prices charged in the few markets where a cable system has a direct competitor. It estimates that prices are about 20 percent lower in these cases.
 
Competition
 Large companies that both own systems and produce popular programming, such as HBO, would have to license products to new rivals, thus increasing competition from new satellite services and "wireless cable" systems.
 
Equipment
 Prices for converter boxes and remote control devices would be regulated. Consumers could buy their own equipment.
 
How It Would Push Rates Up:
 
New broadcaster fees
 Over-the-air stations and the networks could demand that cable companies pay royalties to retransmit their programming, at a cost to the industry of up to $3 billion.
 
New technologies
 Within 10 years, customers would be able to buy only channels they want, rather than entire packages. Cable industry says the technology to make this possible will cost $4 billion.
 
The Bottom Line:
 Most consumers are not likely to notice any difference in their monthly bills. (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
BUSH SAYS CLINTON IMPERILS BUSINESS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
President Bush continued his political assault on Gov. Bill Clinton today, using his first television attack ad and two pointed speeches to broaden his profile of Mr. Clinton as a tax-and-spend liberal.
Mr. Bush said at a morning rally in Greensboro, N.C., that Mr. Clinton's plans for higher business taxes would wipe out tens of thousands of jobs in that state alone and millions of businesses nationwide. Later, at Pennsylvania State University, he told a roaring crowd of students that his rival was "taxing everything he can get his hands on" as Arkansas Governor.
 
$20 Billion Tax-Cut Plan
 
 By contrast, Mr. Bush proposed in Greensboro to cut small-business taxes by $20 billion in a second term, something he said would create new businesses and jobs in "the backbone of the economy."
By Administration estimates, that brought to $165 billion over five years the total of tax cuts that Mr. Bush had pledged to seek since his campaign began. [News analysis, page A22.]
Criss-crossing Georgia by bus, Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, responded by attacking Mr. Bush's economic record. The Democrats also gained new ammunition when organizers of a debate set for Tuesday in Louisville canceled it today because of Mr. Bush's objection to the format.
In Columbus, Ga., Mr. Clinton accused Mr. Bush of squandering billions of dollars in military spending cuts made possible by the collapse of Communism. He said Mr. Bush had poured that money "into a looming budget deficit to pay for the S.& L. crisis and ballooning health-care costs." And Mr. Gore lambasted Mr. Bush for what he called "the worst economic performance since the Great Depression."
"Unemployment under Bush and Quayle is up," he said. "New housing starts are down. Poverty is up. Personal income is down. Bankruptcies are up. Consumer confidence is down. Everything that should be down is up; everything that should be up is down. They've got it upside down. We want to turn it right-side up."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton have traded punches before. But today's campaigning seemed to mark the full emergence of the President's negative political strategy, weeks after the Clinton campaign began a daily pounding of Mr. Bush's record as President.
Today in Fort Worth, Vice President Dan Quayle stepped up the Republican attack on Mr. Clinton's trustworthiness by providing a "top 10 list of Bill Clinton flip-flops" on issues like abortion and welfare reform. "They reflect a fundamental element of Governor Clinton's character, the triumph of expediency over principle, of convenience over truth," he said.
A senior Bush campaign official said the race was moving toward a new stage in which the President, having in his advisers' view set out a plausible economic policy and rebuilt some lost credibility, would start reminding voters of Mr. Clinton's liabilities.
"A big chunk of his lead is pretty soft -- over a third of it -- and they know it," said the official, who would speak only if not named.
 
Attacking on Fast-Forward
 Moving to claim that chunk, Mr. Bush's advisers summoned reporters to the Washington campaign headquarters today to view a 30-second commercial that combines humor with a biting attack on Mr. Clinton's taxation record as Arkansas Governor.
The advertisement intersperses speeded-up videotape of Mr. Clinton signing legislation with a recitation of his state's tax increases on groceries, beer, mobile homes, consumer goods, tourism and cable television. It concludes by noting that Mr. Clinton wants to raise Federal spending by $220 billion if elected and asks: "Guess where he'll get the money?"
The Bush campaign made it clear that the commercial is the first of many negative advertisements. "The fact is, Bill Clinton has been a big taxer in Arkansas," said the campaign's senior political adviser, Charles Black. "We're simply raising the legitimate point that you have to judge what's likely to happen with taxes on his record."
The Clinton campaign's communications director, George Stephanopoulos, called the commercial misleading. "It's interesting to see George Bush talking about spending when he is on this pander parade," Mr. Stephanopoulos said, referring to Mr. Bush's recent trips around the nation to distribute Federal disaster relief and contracts to build aircraft.
He added: "It's hard to imagine anybody with less credibility on taxes than George Bush, a man who says 'read my lips' about taxes. It's time to reach for your wallet and check the facts."
The Clinton campaign unleashed a negative commercial of its own in Mr. Bush's adopted home state, Texas. Like earlier ones, it focuses on the high unemployment rate, using a close-up shot of Mr. Bush's lips as background for the complaint: "Bush promised 30 million jobs in eight years. He's 29 million short."
It concludes by asking, "Can Texans really afford four more years of this?"
 
Heckling Over Debate
 By some measures, it was one of Mr. Bush's better days, with sharp speeches and lively crowds, while Mr. Clinton drew subdued audiences. But the President was dogged by questions about his refusal to debate Mr. Clinton until both campaigns have negotiated a format and locales. Mr. Clinton has agreed to a series of debates proposed by an independent, bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates.
That group today scrapped plans for what would have been a second debate, set for Tuesday in Louisville, because Mr. Bush had not agreed to the format of having a single moderator rather than a panel of questioners. The first debate, scheduled for East Lansing, Mich., earlier this week, was canceled for the same reason.
At a rally in State College, Pa., Mr. Bush was loudly heckled on the matter. "I want a debate," he asserted, "over issues, and an argument over ideas, and I will stand on my record. And I won't let that Arkansas Governor run away from his record either."
The Clinton campaign chairman, Mickey Kantor, said his candidate would be in Louisville on Tuesday whether or not Mr. Bush showed up. "We keep accepting," he said. "They keep rejecting. They are missing in action."
On the road in North Carolina, Mr. Bush maintained that millions of small businesses would be ruined by Mr. Clinton's tax proposals, which include $150 billion in new personal and corporate income taxes, a 1.5 percent tax on payrolls and a health-care plan that would require an additional 7 percent payroll tax.
"If you're like the typical small business, you operate with a profit margin of about 2 percent," Mr. Bush said. "His payroll taxes alone amount to 4 percent to 5 percent of your operating expenses. That's your profit margin, and then some. So here's your choice: you can board up the windows or you can get out the pink slips."
Mr. Bush unveiled his own business plan, combining tax and policy changes costing $28.1 billion over five years. The plan mixed new proposals with some that have been languishing for months in Congress.
Bush aides said legislation to carry out the program had not been drafted. Nor was it likely that a Democrat-dominated Congress would pass the program, they conceded.
Mr. Clinton said that his campaign was "competitive all across the South, and we intend to press them" through the fall. He also sought to assure residents of Georgia, a state of big military bases and sprawling defense plants.
Standing on stages draped in flags, Mr. Clinton supported both the defense establishment and retraining programs for workers displaced by Pentagon cuts. He appeared with Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, who said Mr. Clinton would be "a Commander in Chief we can trust" and likened him to Thomas Jefferson. "You've been accused of everything that Thomas Jefferson was accused of, except being raised on cornbread," Mr. Nunn said. "And I'm waiting for that one, because that's going to help us right here in the South."

HEADLINE: Germany Tells the U.N. It Wants A Permanent Seat on the Council

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Germany told the United Nations General Assembly for the first time today that it would like a permanent seat on the Security Council and promised to revise its Constitution so that German soldiers could take part in United Nations military operations.
The German statement, made by Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel in an address to the Assembly, was widely viewed as a sign that two years after reunification Germany is ready to take a role in world political affairs commensurate with its economic strength.
 
Japan Also Wants a Seat
 
 Mr. Kinkel made clear that Germany was still unwilling to go on the offensive in seeking a permanent seat on the 15-nation Council, the body charged with preserving world peace, saying, "We will not take the initiative in this respect."
But he noted that a debate on enlarging the Security Council was under way and that "if a change in the Council's composition is actually considered we, too, shall seek a permanent seat."
Mr. Kinkel's comments came one day after the Japanese Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, dropped a broad hint, as he did in his speech last year, that Japan also believes its economic importance merits permanent Security Council membership by 1995, when the United Nations celebrates its 50th anniversary.
In the past, the United States has supported the principle of Council membership for Japan and, since reunification in October 1990, for Germany as well. But it has also quietly discouraged both countries from pressing openly for permanent membership, fearing that any attempt to amend the United Nations Charter risks unleashing pressures for more far-reaching organizational changes. Now that Germany and Japan are becoming more explicit about their wishes, Washington may have to decide whether to come out publicly in favor of or against their membership.
At present, permanent membership is restricted to the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China, the five World War II victors, who also have a veto on decisions. The 10 rotating members serve two-year terms.
Many countries consider that this no longer reflects the realities of the modern era. Pressure to expand or change the membership is growing among the poor populous countries in the United Nations and popular sentiment to join the Council is also thought to be building in Japan and Germany.
 
May Be Years Away
 Mr. Kinkel said today that the "efficiency and credibility" of the Council were important if it was to serve as a guardian of international peace. German officials say that the pressures will force the United Nations to reconsider the Council's membership in the next few years and that Germany will seek permanent a seat then.
Changes in the Council's membership are almost certain to be accompanied with complications and disputes. Many third world countries resent the privileged position of the present Permanent Five, as they are called, and want greater representation for the world's populous poorer nations.
This week Brazil's Foreign Minister, Celso Lafer, has sought support for what has come to be called the Brazilian plan, under which Germany and Japan would get permanent seats without a veto, along with such countries as Brazil, India, Egypt and Nigeria.
But the addition of five or six more permanent members would bring pressure for more rotating seats as well, raising the Council's membership to 25 or so, which some diplomats fear would make decisions harder to reach.
German officials say the Government decided that the time was right to press more openly for permanent Council membership because of a feeling that Britain and France would never agree to an alternative plan under which they would merge their national seats into a single permanent seat representing the European Community.
The German Foreign Minister also sought to deal with one of the major arguments against giving Germany permanent Security Council membership today -- the Government's contention that a constitutional ban against sending German soldiers outside the NATO area prevents it from taking part in peacekeeping operations.
Mr. Kinkel said the ruling coalition of Christian Democrats and Free Democrats was committed "to make our armed forces available to the United Nations, with the approval of Parliament, for peacekeeping and peacemaking assignments." German officials said this phrase was meant to include both classic peacekeeping operations and military enforcement action against aggressors authorized by the Security Council.
 
In Supporting Roles
 In fact, German armed forces have played supporting roles in several United Nations peacekeeping operations recently in what German officials here say is a calculated policy of preparing German public opinion for a larger role. A German army field hospital is now deployed in Cambodia, for instance.
Not all German legal experts agree that the Constitution bars Germany from taking part in United Nations peacekeeping operations. But the Government wants Parliament to approve a constitutional amendment giving it an unambiguous right to send forces abroad on United Nations business. However, it has been unable to assemble the necessary majority because of deep-seated objections by the left wing of the opposition Social Democrats.
 
Salvadoran Notes Advances
 President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador told the General Assembly today that the agreement ending his country's long and bitter civil war was moving ahead and that the demobilization of the rebel forces would be completed by the Oct. 31 target date.
Mr. Cristiani also received the report of an independent three-man commission inquiring into human rights abuses and corruption together with its recommendations, which he must comply with within 60 days. He refused to disclose details and said they would be dealt with confidentially.
At a news conference later, Mr. Cristiani said the cost of returning El Salvador to normalcy after 12 years of fighting would be $1.8 billion, including redistributing land, establishing a new civil police force and repairing the country's damaged infrastructure.
The Presidents of Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina signed a new friendship agreement today under which they will coordinate their defense efforts against the Serbian authorities in Belgrade.
The two Presidents said they would join their efforts both to defend themselves against Serbian attack and to seek an end to the Security Council's arms embargo against all the republics of the former Yugoslav federation.
President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia also said that since full civil rights had now been extended to the Serbian minority living in his country under United Nations protection, the peacekeeping force should be withdrawn next year when its mandate expires.

HEADLINE: 'Safety Net' for Anchorage Homeless Is Seen as Both a Lifesaver and a Trap

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE

 BODY:
This city is a showcase to social progress of a sort, though it is measured in the slumped forms of the homeless men and women who sleep on a cavernous shelter floor.
It is progress because few homeless people in Anchorage die, despite the city's large population of street alcoholics and the long, hard winters that used to kill many of them. 
 While many cities have taken a hostile view of their homeless, Anchorage is emerging from a decade in which the fortification of a safety net has become a matter of civic pride.
 
Praise for Generosity
 "People are just incredibly generous here," said Hilary Morgan, a social worker at the Brother Francis Shelter, the city's largest, who moved to Anchorage last year after living in Hawaii and New York City.
But the civic dynamics of homelessness are changing in a way that could imperil hundreds of the city's dispossessed this winter and that illustrates what a confounding problem homelessness in America has become.
After a decade of expanding services, a city report issued in July said the system "only exacerbates the problems of the persistently poor." This brought even to a laboratory of generosity like Anchorage an echo of arguments heard elsewhere, that efforts to help some homeless people can inadvertently hurt them.
In New York, Philadelphia, Washington and elsewhere, some officials have argued that the guarantee of shelter simply leads addicts to spend more money on liquor or drugs. Some academic researchers have reached the same conclusion.
 
Closing of a Shelter
 Making the same argument, Anchorage officials have now closed an emergency shelter for alcoholics who were too drunk to be admitted to Brother Francis. In turn, they have opened 10 new detoxification beds and begun talking about rehabilitation.
"All we had was stronger, healthier drunks," said Jewel Jones, the director of social services.
But some advocates for the homeless here view the development with alarm. They say the beds are too few and that the new system may drive the hardest drinkers, unwilling to seek treatment, back into the bushes and the abandoned buildings where they used to freeze to death.
The average winter low in Anchorage is seven degrees, and even Ms. Jones confesses that she does not know how well street people will fare under the new policies. "We're going forward with our fingers crossed," she said, "hoping no one dies."
Anchorage's history of generosity dates to a May afternoon in 1983 when an encampment of homeless people were evicted from Federal railroad land. With coaxing from the Roman Catholic Archbishop, Francis Hurley, two lay members of a religious order, Bob Eaton and Dave Sifferman, led about 100 of them into a downtown park, where they pitched tents to dramatize their condition.
Area residents protested, and John Franklin, then the public safety commissioner, arrived in angry mood, planning another eviction. But he was stopped, he said, by the look on Mr. Sifferman's face.
"I remember, he said -- eyes full of compassion -- 'John, these people have no place to go,' " Mr. Franklin said.
As a recovering alcoholic himself, Mr. Franklin said he even recognized a few of the encamped men from his own days, 15 years earlier, as back-alley drinker. He stayed the eviction and reported to the Mayor, Tony Knowles, a Democrat, who asked him to help the advocates find a permanent shelter.
They picked a city warehouse, used a $700,000 Federal grant to rehabilitate it and opened the Brother Francis shelter in October of 1983. The city pays about $100,000 a year in maintenance and utility bills, and the archdiocese, through Catholic Social Services, meets the $460,000 operating budget."
Mr. Franklin, who has since retired, said he got up to speak at the dedication but "burst into tears."
 
'Nobody Has to Freeze to Death'
 'About all I could say is, 'Thank God, at least nobody has to freeze to death in Anchorage anymore," he said.
But business at the shelter, to everyone's regret, has continued to boom. In its first year, the shelter never had more than 180 clients a night. Last winter, it topped off at 320, and the area has now grown into what has been called the homeless "campus."
When the shelter closes at 7 A.M., many of its residents simply cross the parking lot to Bean's Cafe, a soup kitchen run by a separate nonprofit group. It provides three meals and a place to spend the day.
Another key to the city's success is an emergency van service that patrols the streets for alcoholics in danger of freezing to death. It is operated by a private company, with a $400,000 city contract.
The city does not collect statistics on the deaths of homeless people, but government officials say that before Brother Francis Shelter was opened, as many as a dozen a year would die in the cold. Now Mr. Eaton, the advocate who founded the shelter, said, "We lose one or two a year."
Alcoholism is not the only cause of homelessness in Anchorage, where the rental market rocketed in the 1980's, displacing many low-income families. But it is the leading cause, especially among the single men and women who roam the streets and give homelessness its public face.
A city study published in July estimates that substance abuse accounted for 46 percent of the city's homeless. Other reasons included mental illness, 17 percent; economic dislocation, 16 percent; physical illness, 9 percent; "apparent deadbeats," 6 percent; "noncitizens" looking for work 4 percent, and abused women, 2 percent.
Even in August, when many homeless people sleep outside, Brother Francis Shelter has the ragged feel of a Civil War army in retreat. At 8 o'clock on a recent night, about 150 men and women gathered to eat paper platefuls of chili, watch television, smoke or sleep. A woman held up a copy of a Harlequin romance novel and insisted the man on its cover was her long-lost brother. A couple tried to fight, but their drunken blows landed only on the night air, amid an outpouring of epithets.
Roy Willock, 33 years old, told a common story about a journey from rural Alaska to Anchorage, fueled by thirst. He said he left his village, Kotzebue, four years ago when voters approved a ban on bars and liquor stores and has been living at the shelter intermittently ever since.
Asked how often he drinks, Mr. Willock said, "Fluently, every other day." Without the Brother Francis Shelter, he said, "I'd probably go back home in Kotzebue, where I have family that would take care of me."
 
Support From Public
 Despite a clientele with more grunge than glamour, those who serve the homeless have received an unusual amount of public support. Donors to the Anchorage United Way give more money to Bean's Cafe than to any other organization, and Catholic Social Services, which runs Brother Francis Shelter, ranks second.
Some advocates even say they prefer the private support to government money. "We're not adding to the Federal deficit by asking for money for what we see as a local problem," said Mr. Eaton, whose work has drawn praise in many corners of the city.
Area stores support the kitchen by selling packages of bean soup. And when Bean's was constructing a new building, the Arco oil company even lent a manager, Rob McCormick, to serve as interim director, paying his $45,000 salary for eight months and presenting television commercials lauding his work.
At The Anchorage Daily News, several top editors are married to advocates for the homeless. Among them is Howard Weaver, the newspaper's top editor, who describes its coverage as something of a crusade. "We're not exactly disinterested, and I don't think we should be," he said. "I'm rather proud of the way Anchorage has responded on the basic question of 'Are you going to freeze to death?' "
But with homelessness at record highs, city officials now argue that the safety net grew more snug than intended. Even Brother Francis Shelter has set a nightly limit of 240, both for the safety of the residents and because the staff thinks some people could afford to make other arrangements.
"We're getting a little tougher here," said Mr. Eaton, who is resigning this year after a decade of exhausting work.
A Republican Mayor, Tom Fink, was elected in 1986, and his aides now argue that city policy has "enabled" alcoholics to keep drinking. They argue that with vans to transport them, kitchens to feed them and shelters to keep them from the cold, public inebriates had no motivation to change. A June memorandum signed by Mr. Fink argues that the policy allowed alcoholics not only to continue their drinking but "perhaps even to increase it."
Emphasizing the goal of self-sufficiency, the city in July closed the emergency sleep-off center that provided 30 beds for people too drunk to stay at Brother Francis. Instead it has substituted a bedless waiting room where alcoholics can spend the night in hard plastic chairs, and opened an additional 10 beds for those willing to enter a detoxification program.
But some advocates warn that the policy may just drive street alcoholics back into the bushes, a possibility that Ms. Jones, the social services director, calls real.
Mr. Franklin, the former public safety commissioner, said the talk of "enabling" alcoholics to keep drinking is just a rationale for saving money, one that ignores the fact that alcoholics have "no control." "We're not enabling alcoholism," he said, "we're enabling the alcoholics to stay alive."
Mr. Eaton, proud of the city's record in saving lives, also views ambitious talk of rehabilitation warily. Allowing himself a rare sardonic moment, he said, "I'm a big believer that you can't rehabilitate a dead person."

The population at the Brother Francis shelter, the city's largest, has grown steadily since itopened in 1983. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Plan to Destroy Toxic Weapons Polarizes a City

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANNISTON, Ala. Sept. 18

 BODY:
Each day for more than 32 years, Curtis Penny's job took him into the concrete, earth-covered igloos that dot acre after acre of the Anniston Army Depot, like so many grassy hummocks.
The tools of his trade included protective clothing, a gas mask and a syringe full of atropine, the heart and muscle stimulant he would have injected at a moment's notice if any of the thousands of containers he was charged with maintaining had leaked their deadly contents: nerve gas that had been stored for up to 30 years. 
 In that time neither Mr. Penny nor hundreds of other civilian employees who tended the stockpile of chemical weapons talked much about their work to neighbors in this city of 30,000. Even so, he and others insisted that everybody must have known of the chemicals stored there; they just didn't like to think about them.
 
Awakening to Danger
 Suddenly Anniston is forced to confront the perils in its midst: Sarin a topical poison that interrupts breathing and destroys vision and muscle control; VX, a substance that produces similar symptoms when vaporized and inhaled; mustard agents that cause skin eruptions, blistering and lesions while destroying the eyes and lungs. Unlike modern binary chemical weapons, which require two components to be mixed before becoming lethal, these substances are so-called unitary chemicals, fully potent and deadly in their aging containers.
Last spring, the U. S. Army announced that it was working on plans to build a $600 million incinerator at the depot to destroy Anniston's stockpiles over a four-year period. In one of the cruel paradoxes of the cold war's end, residents here could no longer ignore their dangerous secret.
For years the depot and Fort McClelland, a center for research of chemical and biological weapons, have formed part of the economic bedrock of Anniston and surrounding Calhoun County, and people here have grown to trust and depend on the Army. Lately Fort McClelland has been on, then off, the list of military bases to be closed. But whatever the depot's future, its contents must be destroyed as part of the Pentagon's program to eradicate chemical weapons.
Residents' responses to the incinerator plan have been ambivalent. In recent months a group called Families Concerned About Nerve Gas Incineration has been formed to fight the plan, arguing for an 18-month delay while alternatives are researched. The group fears that incomplete burning of the chemicals could fill the air over Anniston with poisons, some of which were designed to be deadly in vapor form.
On the other side, a group called S.P.R.I.N.G., for Supporting Proven Reliable Incineration of Nerve Gas, supports building the incinerator as soon as possible. They argue that many of the chemical containers, including weapons canisters and drums, are deteriorating and represent a greater danger than incineration.
 
Perilous Choices
 "Everyone supports the army depot and wants to see it stay open," Jeri Higginbotham, a teacher at a nearby college, said as she left the meeting of opposition group. "But we have a tough choice: Do we live next door to a toxic-materials storage facility, or next door to a toxic-waste incinerator." She said she also planned to attend the next meeting of the supporters' group.
For Mr. Penny, the choice is clear. Over the years, he said, he had watched the slow deterioration of the containers holding the chemical weapons, and he had supervised periodic cleanups, neutralizations and disposals of small amounts of chemicals that had leaked. He said his neighbors would be "scared to death" if they knew how toxic the chemicals were and how rapidly they could spread.
The Anniston depot is one of eight storage sites around the country for obsolete chemical weapons developed as far back as World War II. At a ninth site in the Pacific Ocean on Johnston Atoll, just south of Honolulu, the Pentagon also stores chemicals and operates an incinerator.
The Pentagon does not discuss the size of the stockpile of chemical and nerve agents, but critics who have studied the incineration program estimate the total at between 60 million and 70 million pounds. The bulk of the chemicals, 42 percent, are stored at the isolated Tooele Army Depot in north central Utah. About 7.1 percent, or as much as 5 million pounds, are stored at Anniston, where close to 100,000 people live within a 30-mile radius of the depot.
 
Alternatives Under Study
 The Pentagon, arguing that the chemicals are too dangerous to transport, plans to build incinerators at each storage site, then destroy them after the chemicals have been burned. An incinerator is nearing completion at the Utah facility, and site preparation has been completed here while the Army awaits final state approval. But Congress has delayed construction at the six other mainland sites while researchers study alternatives, like rendering the agents safer by mixing them with neutralizing chemicals.
Many here doubt the Pentagon's pledge to destroy the incinerator once the Anniston stockpile is gone.
"If you build it, it will stay," predicted Ben Haskell, one of the organizers of the opponents' group. Envisioning a field of nightmares, Mr. Haskell and other opponents fear that instead of being decommissioned, an incinerator would be used to destroy stockpiles in Kentucky, Maryland and Indiana.
Rudy Noll, a retired Army colonel and one of the organizers of S.P.R.I.N.G., said that trucking chemical weapons from other sites would unify supporters and opponents of the incinerator. Other supporters agreed, but they said they trusted the military to demolish the facility.
Marilyn Tischbin, a spokeswoman for the Army's chemical disposal program, said tests have shown that burning the agents is safe. She repeated the military's pledge to tear down the Anniston plant as soon as the Anniston-based agents were destroyed.
Among those who doubt that pledge is Craig Williams, a member of the Kentucky Environmental Foundation and one of the founders of a group in Richmond, Ky., that succeeded in blocking construction of an incinerator to burn the stockpiles at the Lexington Blue Grass Army Depot.
Mr. Williams, who came to Anniston to help the local opposition get started, said that in the last several months new international treaty negotiations on chemical and nerve agents have included broadening the categories that would have to be destroyed. His group estimates that future treaties could force the destruction of items stored at 200 military sites in 37 states, increasing the pressure on the Pentagon to keep existing incinerators open and perhaps even build scores more.
Such scenarios leave many residents wondering if Anniston, after living with chemical weapons for more than three decades, could survive an incinerator.
"So many people would just leave if this thing is built," said Brenda Lindell, a member of the opponents' group. "Who would want to move here? I think the community would just die."

GRAPHIC: Photo: While the residents of Anniston, Ala., argue over what should be done with the stockpile of chemical weapons stored there, the answer is clear to Curtis Penny, who worked at the army depot for 32 years. At a public meeting, he took the floor to warn that they must be destroyed as soon as possible. (Mike Clemmer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Rates Back Near 7.5%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates, which fell sharply after the Federal Reserve cut short-term rates last summer, are rising again because of economic and political uncertainties at home and abroad. Some see the higher rates as a threat to the already sluggish economic recovery.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond inched back up toward 7.5 percent yesterday in very volatile trading. The yield has leaped more than a quarter of a percentage point in just two weeks, to 7.48 percent yesterday, as a host of negative factors have beset the market, including the dollar's fall yesterday to a new low against the Japanese yen. [D21.] 
 The surge in yields, several traders and analysts said, marks the end for now of the rally that had pushed the yield on the 30-year bond down from 7.74 percent on July 1 to a six-year low of 7.21 percent on Sept. 8. That could not have come at a worse time for the economy, and, probably, the re-election hopes of President Bush.
 
Responding to the Fed
 Short-term interest rates are at their lowest level in nearly 30 years because they are the ones most directly affected by the Fed's action in cutting its Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other on short-term borrowings, to 3 percent.
But long-term interest rates, even at their recent lows, did not come down enough to satisfy economic policy makers or to give key sectors of the economy, like housing and construction, the lift that might have sparked a broader recovery.
"A near-term backup in long-term yields will add to the doubts about the strength of growth in the coming quarters," John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said.
 
Blow to Homeowners
 The end of the rally for now may also be a blow to homeowners who had been planning to refinance their mortgages to take advantage of the sharp drop in rates in the last two months. The savings in lower monthly mortgage payments from such refinancing could help spur consumer spending, although that apparently did not happen after the wave of refinancings at the beginning of the year.
Lawrence Waldorf, a bond portfolio manager for the First Investors Management Company, said he had given up hope for now of a 7 percent yield on the Treasury bond and sold the last $25 million of his Treasury securities yesterday. Just six weeks ago, he was predicting 7 percent by the end of the year.
"The dream is gone until at least the first quarter of 1993," he said. "It is now a no-win situation for bond investors," he added, arguing that even the kind of bad economic news that usually lifts the bond market -- like higher unemployment or sluggish retail sales -- would have little impact in the face of other uncertainties.
Among the dream slayers are the upheaval in the currency markets in Europe; the growing attractiveness of foreign bond markets because of the expectation of falling interest rates abroad; the uncertainty of the Presidential election; a growing belief that Gov. Bill Clinton could win, and the fear of a large economic stimulus package that could reignite inflation.
The external problems are overwhelming the economic fundamentals of slow growth and low inflation that are good for the bond market, although many analysts, including Mr. Lipsky, think these fundamentals can still bring yields back down again.
"For now, market participants have become more concerned about near-term uncertainties like politics at home and turmoil in markets abroad," he said.
 
Falling Out of Favor
 Norman Robertson, chief economist for the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said, "The United States is suddenly not the favorite of international investors, who stand to reap more benefits from falling interest rates in their own countries."
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, is not worried about inflation. But he sees why some investors might be.
"Fundamentally, please, inflation is not a threat right now," he argued. "But if you want to assume that you are going to have a fiscal stimulus package and that Congress is going to overdo it, you might think there is going to be some inflationary pressure."
For the rally to revive now, William Pike, the managing director who runs Chemical Securities, said the economy would have to start a new move downward, which he does not expect.
"With Clinton, the market expects a heavy dose of fiscal stimulus," he said. "And with long yields back near 7.5 percent, it is a long way to 7 percent. So I don't see that happening in the near future."
 
Treasury Market
 In late trading in the secondary market, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was offered at 978/32 , down 4/32 , to yield 7.48 percent, its highest yield since late July. The prices of Treasury notes also fell.
While yesterday's decline in the price of the 30-year bond was modest, the bond was off almost a point and a half on Tuesday, in part because of the unexpectedly strong increase in housing starts in August. In two days, the yield jumped from 7.32 percent to 7.48 percent.
Also yesterday, the Treasury held the second test of a new auction system in its sale of five-year notes. The results, traders said, were far worse for the Treasury than in the trial at the two-year note sale Tuesday.
Under the system being tested, all securities are awarded to dealers at the lowest price or the highest yield. Under the system still being used in other auctions, the awards are based on the dealer bids, which means one dealer can pay more than another. The purpose of the single-price system is to encourage aggressive bidding because dealers do not have to fear paying too much.
In yesterday's auction of $10.5 billion of five-year notes, demand was very light and the yield was 5.54 percent. But at the time of the bidding deadline, 1 P.M., the yield in the pre-auction or when-issued market was just below 5.51 percent, which means the cost for the Treasury was much higher than the market sentiment at the time the bids were submitted.
Some traders said it appeared that after one day of practice with the new system, bidders were worried that all dealers might be too aggressive in their bidding and that in the end, they would actually pay more than they wanted.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of five-year notes:

HEADLINE: OVERRIDE VOTE SET ON FAMILY LEAVE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Reacting to President Bush's late-night veto of family-leave legislation, Democratic leaders in the Senate today scheduled an override vote on the politically contentious bill for Thursday.
The legislation would require larger companies to grant at least 12 weeks of unpaid leave to any employee to deal with a birth or adoption or family emergencies like a parent's or spouse's sickness. 
 Democrats criticized Mr. Bush's veto as a betrayal of the family values theme the Republican ticket has been espousing in the Presidential campaign. Congressional Republicans, on the other hand, went on the defensive by pressing for the alternative Mr. Bush has proposed: a tax credit for employers who let workers have unpaid time off in family emergencies.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the veto would be overridden "if enough Republican members of Congress support the needs of working parents struggling to deal with their dual responsibility to their families and their jobs."
Mr. Bush has yet to lose a veto battle with the Democrats who control Congress, and there is little suggestion that this legislation, which was passed earlier this month by vote of 241 to 161 that is well short of the two-thirds needed to override a veto, would break that pattern. The bill passed the Senate on a voice vote in August.
 
Late-Night Timing
 The battle over the legislation is far more intense in the world of Presidential politics than it is in Congress, and the timing of Mr. Bush's veto on Tuesday night -- hours after the network television news programs had been broadcast -- suggested that the White House was seeking as little publicity for its action as possible.
In a written statement issued about 9 P.M. Tuesday near the end of 15 hours of campaigning, Mr. Bush said he supported the concept of family leave but rejected the legislation because the financial burden it would impose on business would further dampen the growth of the economy and new jobs.
Today, Mr. Bush worked a defense of his veto into a campaign day devoted to depicting his opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton, as an advocate of governmental social engineering programs that would hurt business.
Mr. Bush said he supported the concept of businesses giving unpaid leave to workers who needed time off for medical reasons or the birth of a child, but he added: "I'm not going to do what the liberal Congress wants me to do, slap another mandate on business's back. I am not going to do that.
"I believe in family leave, and I believe our approach to facilitate family leave through tax credits is a far better way than putting new mandates on a guy who is struggling to make ends meet."
 
Little Chance of Action Soon
 Mr. Bush formulated his tax credit proposal soon after the House passed the Democratic measure, and White House officials have acknowledged that there was little chance it wouldreceive any real consideration, much less actual passage, before Election Day.
When the President vetoed a family-leave measure in 1990, saying he opposed the idea of requiring businesses to provide leaves, he did not offer an alternative bill.
The timing of the veto announcement was criticized by Mr. Clinton on Tuesday night, and he attacked the veto again today on a campaign bus tour in Georgia, saying: "Seventy-two countries have a family- and medical-leave act. We're being told by this President we can't. I was taught to believe that America was the we-can country."
The bill passed by Congress is broadly similar to the one Mr. Bush vetoed in 1990. It requires companies with 50 or more workers to grant employees unpaid leave to care for a sick child, parent or spouse, or for their own medical needs, like pregnancy, as well as requiring that employees' health insurance remain in force during such a leave.
It would not apply to employees who work fewer than 25 hours a week and would allow the exclusion of workers in the top 10 percent of the pay scale. Those restrictions limit the bill's coverage mostly to the largest employers, about 5 percent of companies, employing roughly half of the nation's workers.
 
Bush's Argument
 Mr. Bush said last week in New Jersey that he believed family leave was an idea whose time was nigh. But he contended that most large companies already offered family leave to their workers and that the legislation would place an undue regulatory burden on those that did not. That would cost money, slow employment growth and eventually hurt some families the bill sought to help, he said then.
He also argued that the legislation might lead companies to break the law by practicing job discrimination against women, even though the legislation applies equally to men and to women.
"Think of the impact mandated family leave has on hiring decisions," he told a meeting of A.T. &T. employees and women service organizations on Friday. "I know it's not supposed to happen, but how many employers will think, why not hire a man instead of a woman? He won't leave to care for a child. He won't leave to care for his family. And this is illegal, and we must enforce the law. But mandated family leave could encourage this subtle kind of discrimination."

HEADLINE: Fed Study Finds Modest Economic Upturn

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve today issued a modestly upbeat assessment of business conditions around the country, stating, "Economic activity has been improving slowly in most of the nation."
The report, the Fed's last summary of regional economies before the election, found weakening conditions only in the areas covered by its San Francisco and Chicago district banks. 
 "Cleveland, Dallas, Kansas City, Philadelphia and Richmond report modestly improved conditions in their districts," said the report, known as the "beige book" for the color of its cover.
"The remaining districts generally reported a continuation of slowly expanding activity," it said.
Although today's report included cautions -- such as "the pace of recovery has been uneven across many regions and sectors" -- it was slightly more positive than the last beige book, released on Aug. 5.
"Retail sales are reported steady or slightly higher by most districts, but auto sales are lackluster," it said. "Manufacturing activity has weakened in autos, aerospace, and defense-related industries. Outside these sectors, however, improvement is noted in orders, production and sales."
The Fed report was compiled from information gathered by its 12 regional banks, based on interviews with business people conducted before Sept. 15. It will be used by monetary policy makers when they meet on Oct. 6 to review their interest-rate polices.
Today's report also noted that farming conditions were good in most areas and that housing construction "appears to be improving slowly . . . particularly in low to mid-priced housing." It said nonresidential construction remained weak.
It said Hurricane Andrew probably would stimulate construction and other economic activity in Florida and Louisiana. The storm has put little upward pressure on prices, except for lumber and natural gas, it said.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Extend Losing Streak

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks extended their losing streak to three sessions yesterday as investors found plenty of reasons to stay on the defensive.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 2.16 points to close at 3,278.69. Decliners outnumbered gainers, 950 to 767, on active volume of 205.4 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Concerns over corporate financial results, Presidential politics, world interest rates and crumbling European economic unity combined to deter buyers, analysts said.
The dollar dropped to a new low against the Japanese yen in early trading, but by the end of the dayit had recovered some ground.
The Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey said the economy was improving slowly but at an uneven pace, a report that provided little fresh insight for the markets.
"We're just not seeing any response," said Alice Sadlo, a first vice president at McDonald & Company. "I don't sense any urgency to get involved."
She said the strong responses to the earnings forecasts of individual companies indicated that "people are starting to look at the bottom line again."
 
Downturn of Prized Issues
 Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers, detected a breakdown in stocks that were previously prized as issues unlikely to be hurt by an economic downturn.
Coca-Cola is a prime example, he said. "That seemed to be impervious to market jitters, but it has broken down," he said. "Coke has been one of the flagship growth stocks."
Coca-Cola lost 1 1/2, to 40 3/4, continuing a decline after the company said Tuesday that its third-quarter sales would be dampened by weak overseas markets.
Investors were also keeping a watch on the Presidential election, which has been clouded once again by the Texas billionaire Ross Perot, who has indicated that he will take a more active role in the election after bowing out of the race.
Video Lottery Technologies dropped 10, to 14, a plunge of 41 percent. Several analysts cut their ratings on the maker of video lottery systems after it lost its license in Australia.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.30, to 417.44. The American Stock Exchange index lost 1.08, to 379.91. The Nasdaq index lost 0.04, to 582.96.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sales of U.S.-Built Cars and Light Trucks Off 3.1%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks, burdened by weak results at the General Motors Corporation, fell 3.1 percent in mid-September, according to company reports released today.
Car sales alone by the Big Three and Japanese companies with American operations dropped 7.3 percent, to 134,283, while light-truck sales, which include sales of mini-vans, sports-utility vehicles and pickups, rose 3.4 percent, to 98,005. Overall sales of domestically built cars and light trucks totaled 232,288. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 6.1 million, compared with 6 million in early September and 6.4 million last year at this time.
Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco, called the sales disappointing. Mr. Glantz said an informal survey of dealers suggested that showroom traffic had been fairly strong, but the rate of closed deals among prospective buyers had been poor. "People are uneasy over economic prospects," he said.
G.M.'s car sales were off 13.6 percent in the 10-day period that ended on Sept. 20, to 58,221, and the company's light-truck sales were down 5.8 percent, to 36,447 for the period.
Antonette Simonetti, a G.M. spokeswoman, said the auto maker had intentionally curtailed incentives to daily-rental companies on car models. "But our retail sales" to individuals "are steady," she said.
An important reason for G.M.'s overall weakness has been continuing soft sales by Chevrolet, the company's biggest division. Chevy's car sales were off 28.8 percent in mid-September; its light-truck sales were off 10.9 percent.
Selling fewer cars to daily-rental fleets appears to be only part of Chevy's problem. Dealers have complained that Chevrolet's car models are dated. Thomas Castriota, general manager of Castriota Chevrolet Geo in Pittsburgh, said: "The Cavalier came out in 1982. Some of the cars Lumina competes against have been updated."
 
Signs of Growth Are Seen
 Jim Perkins, general manager of Chevrolet/Geo, said, "We see some signs of growth, but no volcanic eruption." Speaking at an introduction of 1993 Chevrolet models in Rochester Hills, Mich., Mr. Perkins introduced a new Geo Prizm, which is based on the Toyota Corolla, and showed slides of redesigned Chevy car and truck models to be introduced during the next year.
The Ford Motor Company, meanwhile, once more gained market share by bucking the industry's weak sales trend. Sales of Ford's domestic car models rose 11.3 percent, to 40,006, and sales of Ford's light trucks rose 12.4 percent, to 34,669.
The Chrysler Corporation's sales of cars were estimated by Ward's Automotive Reports at 11,900, down 13.6 percent, and the company's light-truck sales were put at 19,900, down five-tenths of 1 percent. Chrysler reports its sales only on a monthly basis.
The Honda Motor Company, feeling the effects of a stronger yen and resulting higher prices, posted a 25.9 percent drop in car sales, to 11,900. The Toyota Motor Corporation, however, showed a 21.1 percent gain in car sales, to 6,761; Toyota, in its first year of domestic light-truck production, reported sales of 2,001 for the period.
The Nissan Motor Company's car sales rose 12.2 percent, to 2,642; Nissan's light-truck sales fell 21.5 percent, to 2,982.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Bush and Bounty

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Today, President Bush offered a $20 billion tax break to small businesses. Last week, it was $500 million a year to companies that give workers time off in family emergencies. Before that, it was a 1 percentage point across-the-board reduction in tax rates for individuals.
And these are just the tax cuts Mr. Bush has proposed since the White House published its mid-year budget review in July. All told, the tax breaks he has put forth in his election campaign would cost the Government about $165 billion in lost revenue over the next five years. 
 That does not count the tax credits and deductions Mr. Bush would allow so that people could get medical insurance, a cost that could easily reach $20 billion a year. Nor does it count the tens of billions more he says he would spend for job training and for tuition payments for students in private schools.
It is not unusual for Presidential candidates to make generous promises as the election approaches. But Mr. Bush does so in the same breath that he advocates a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget and at a time when the Federal deficit is about $350 billion, the highest ever.
 
Clinton Promises, Too
 Mr. Bush's Democratic opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton, also makes big promises: $20 billion a year for public works, medical care for all, an expanded student loan program, tax cuts for the middle class, continued spending on popular weapons programs. And some of the Governor's arithmetic is almost as shaky as Mr. Bush's. But Mr. Clinton does talk about both the specific taxes he would raise and much deeper reductions in military spending than the President wants.
And Mr. Clinton does not promise to balance the budget, only to cut the deficit in half over four years.
Mr. Bush, of course, is sworn against tax increases. He says merely that his tax cuts would be balanced by spending reductions; he almost never says which ones. He did not say today, for example, how the country could afford $20 billion in tax relief for small businesses.
A senior White House official said the new tax proposal would be more than offset by $132 billion in spending cuts that Mr. Bush has recommended over the years and that have been rejected by Congress.
 
Cut What? and Where?
 There are several problems with that figure:
The first is that the White House and the Bush campaign have no list of programs that are included in the $132 billion total. Only $72 billion of the cuts are in the budget for the next fiscal year, of which $38 billion results from an accounting gimmick.
The second problem is that Mr. Bush no longer advocates some cuts he favored early in his Administration that are presumably included in the $132 billion. For example, two years ago, he recommended cutting price-support payments to farmers by $20 billion. Congress approved about $15 billion, but less than $1 billion of the remaining cuts are included in next year's budget.
Finally, and perhaps most important, the President's staff uses the same $132 billion figure to show how they would pay for tax cuts, how they would reduce the budget deficit and how they would finance such election-year plums as the reconstruction of Homestead Air Force Base in South Florida.
But this is not the full extent of Mr. Bush's budgetary sleight of hand. He said he favors putting a cap on all mandatory spending programs except Social Security so they could rise no more than the rate of inflation and the rate of increase in the eligible population. Such a cap, he said, would save the Government $294 billion over the next five years.
 
Shrinking Mandatory Programs
 Mandatory programs, also called entitlements, are those like Medicare, Medicaid, veterans benefits, food stamps and agricultural price supports that pay benefits automatically to everyone who is eligible. They make up about three-fifths of the Federal budget, and almost all economists think that they somehow should be reined in.
But here is the rub with Mr. Bush's plan: He offers no clue how it would work, nothing that would give any voter any indication that a favored benefit might be sliced.
Mr. Bush has never said, for example, whether the cap would apply to the total of all mandatory programs or to each individually. If it is the total he is talking about, then the unanswered question is, "Which programs would be permitted to grow and which ones would shrink?" If each program would be individually capped, who would become ineligible and whose benefits would be reduced? Would the Government simply stop writing checks part way through the year? Mr. Bush never says.
Medicare and Medicaid, by far the largest mandatory programs besides Social Security, have been growing at about 13 percent a year, more than three times the rate of inflation. Does Mr. Bush have some plan he has not announced to lower medical costs? Or would the elderly and the poor find that some of their medical bills were not covered?
 
No Time for Bad News
 Mr. Clinton's accounting is also open to question. His pledge to cut the budget deficit in half over the next four years is based largely on the optimistic assumption that the economy will grow somewhat faster than Congressional authorities and most private economists anticipate. A promise to collect more taxes from foreign corporations based in the United States is probably more smoke than substance. And promises to save billions by cutting administrative costs throughout the Government and improving management of the savings and loan bailout are probably not realistic.
Like most other politicians, Mr. Clinton almost never delivers bad news. In the Middle West, he says he will continue generous farm subsidies. In Florida, he promises no cuts in Social Security or Medicare. And when he arrives in a community where weapons systems are built, he becomes outright hawkish.
He tells voters in Michigan and Ohio, for instance, that he would continue to build the M1-A1 tank. He tells those in Fort Worth that he supports continued production of the V-22 Osprey, the troubled craft that takes off like a helicopter and flies like an airplane. And he says in Connecticut that he supports building the Seawolf nuclear submarine.
The biggest gap in Mr. Clinton's calculations involves medical insurance. He calls medical care "a right, not a privilege," and he promises an insurance package that includes coverage for nursing-home care and prescription drugs for every American.
Mr. Clinton says the price to the Government, perhaps $30 billion or $40 billion a year, would be offset by controlling medical costs, but he has not offered a fully developed cost-control plan. His staff says that if the health-care plan proved to be too expensive, it might have to be phased in over several years, a caveat that Mr. Clinton himself does not make in his stump speeches.
But that said, Mr. Clinton has put out the most complete tax and spending figures of any recent Presidential challenger. If they do not add up, they are not nearly so far off as President Bush's.

LENGTH: 656 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

PRESIDENT BUSH
In a speech yesterday at Penn State University in University Park, Pa.
"And, yes, I want a debate. I want a debate over issues and an argument over ideas, and I will stand on my record, and I won't let that Arkansas Governor run away from his record, either.
You know, I think the American people have a right to know what they're buying into because, remember, if you buy what candidate Clinton is selling, there's no refund, there's no rebate. Actually it's more like a permanent payment plan, and I don't think we need that for the United States of America.
On one issue, and I think it's the fundamental issue in this campaign, my opponent and I have just agreed to disagree. It's a question of how our economy grows and how our country works, and it's kind of like 'Jeopardy.' It all comes down to how you ask the question. And my opponent asks, what makes the economy grow? And his answer, and look at his program, is government planners and projects and programs.
And I ask, who makes this country grow? And my answer is you, the individual working men and women, building and buying a freedom of the market."
 
GOV. BILL CLINTON
In a speech yesterday in Columbus, Ga.
"There are people like that all over the world who are struggling to develop the capacity to have nuclear technology; to be able to drop chemical weapons; to be able to drop biological weapons on their people, on other people.
We cannot risk that happening. So there are significant challenges to us in the world we are living in. What does that mean? I conclude that it means we need not so many people in uniform as we used to have. We need not so many people in Europe as we used to have, because the Europeans don't face the imminent threat of a large Soviet Army marching across Eastern Europe into Western Europe. We need not so much money spent on the space-based portion of 'Star Wars,' but we do need to focus on greater training and mobility of our forces, on land, in the air and on the sea; and on maintaining the enormous technological lead we have in the development of both tactical defenses and defensive weapons.
Which means we have to maintain a strong infrastructure of technology in this country. And we have to continue to train, equip, and work with our military forces at a smaller level to make sure they are still the strongest, the best, and now the most mobile in the world, hopefully being able always to be used in cooperation with our allies.
That is the defense plan I have put forward to the American people in this election. It will require us to spend less money that we are now spending. But I think it will give us a stronger national defense than Mr. Bush's proposed budget."
 
VICE PRESIDENT DAN QUAYLE
In a speech at a rally yesterday in Fort Worth, Tex.
 "As the case of military service makes most clear, these differing positions are, in fact, more than mere flip-flops. They reflect a fundamental element of Governor Clinton's character: the triumph of expediency over principle, of convenience over truth. Governor Clinton says he is the candidate of change, but he truly is the changing candidate.
Don't get me wrong. If you are in public life, sooner or later some variation will creep into the record. Sometimes, leaders genuinely change their minds or they may alter course in the best interest of the nation. It's one thing to take a political risk in the hope of helping your country. But it's another matter to change your position to avoid political risk in the hope of helping yourself.
One lesson we've learned over the past two centuries is the need for strong character in our Presidents. This country has prevailed in rough times when our leaders have adhered firmly to principle and truth. But when our Presidents have vacillated or lied or attempted to be all things to all people, then we have lost national confidence and steered toward crisis."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Loss Seen For Bon-Ton; Stock Drops

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Shares of Bon-Ton Stores Inc. lost more than a third of their value yesterday after the retailer painted a bleak picture of its third-quarter earnings prospects and announced the departure of its president.
The company said aggressive cost-cutting to clear excessive inventory, coupled with sluggish sales during the back-to school season, would probably result in a loss per share of 12 to 18 cents. 
 The stock closed down $2.50, at $4.75, a loss of 34.5 percent. The percentage decline was the second largest on the Nasdaq national system.
 
 
Executive Stepping Aside
 Bon-Ton also said E. Herbert Ross, the president and chief operating officer, who has been in charge of merchandising and marketing, would step aside on Friday.
M. Thomas Grumbacher, the company's vice chairman and chief executive and a member of the family that founded Bon-Ton, will assume Mr. Ross's responsibilities for merchandising, marketing and stores.
While Bon-Ton has worked to pare its expenses and has few direct competitors in the markets where it operates, as a department store it still has higher overhead costs than competing mass merchants and specialty shops. The Northeast's weak economy has also buffeted its 34 stores scattered in Maryland, West Virginia, western New York and Pennsylvania.
 
 
Analysts Surprised
 The handful of analysts who follow the company, which went public in October, said they knew Bon-Ton's business had been slow in the third quarter and expected earnings of about 3 cents a share. But all of them said they thought the company had worked its way through the deep inventory it had accumulated in anticipation of stronger summer sales.
"We went into the first quarter of 1992 with more inventory than we should have from the holidays and had already committed to an aggressive spring and summer," said Michael L. Gleim, senior executive vice president and chief administrative officer. "As it turned out, there wasn't any spring or summer for us ."
He said the company had planned conservatively for the fourth quarter but expected a tough battle for profits. "The holiday season is going to be fiercely competitive this year, -- more so than usual," Mr. Gleim said.
 Robert Buchanan, a retail analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., cut his earnings estimates to 35 cents a share for the current year, from 70 cents, and reduced his 1993 estimates to 62 cents a share, from 95 cents.
