HEADLINE: For Burned-Out Businesses, More Hope Than Help;
Bronx Merchants Say They Have Seen City Agencies' Promises, Too, Turn to Ashes

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
On a sunny day last July, Stanley Bell stood helplessly outside his electronics shop and watched a business he had built up over 40 years vanish amid a swirl of flames and smoke. A scrappy businessman, he vowed to rebuild, determined to stay put in the central Bronx neighborhood that nurtured his company, Belco Distributors.
He was reassured by a procession of city officials who convened meetings and pledged help with loans, building improvements and cutting through red tape in his dealings with city agencies. He was heartened that his store was salvageable and its inventory largely intact. 
 But two and a half months after a five-alarm fire that started accidentally in a pile of rubbish swept through several businesses on East Tremont Avenue, Mr. Bell is foundering on a bureaucratic odyssey of frustration and promises unkept.
His business was a small one -- just himself and five employees. But his struggles, and those of his neighbors, show how long and hard the road back can be for merchants -- especially those in low- and moderate-income neighborhoods -- hit by catastrophic events.
Mr. Bell is no closer to rebuilding than he was on that July day, and his employees remain unemployed. His insurance company has yet to settle his claim. He and other merchants say city agencies have done little since the initial rush of meetings.
And each day his hopes grow dimmer. Vandals have repeatedly dropped in through a gaping hole in the store's roof, stripping the place of air-conditioners, fixtures and even its aluminum storefront. His customers, hundreds of livery-cab drivers to whom he sold two-way radios, have defected to his competitors, who privately gloat at his misfortune.
"I don't want anything for nothing, I just want to get started," he said, standing outside what remained of his store at 418 East Tremont Avenue. "It takes a lot of heart out of you because it takes so long."
While resources are available from the government, wresting them from the bureaucratic maze can be another matter, said Ron Shiffman, a member of the city's Planning Commission and director of the Pratt Center for Community and Environmental Development, in Brooklyn. The city, he said, has yet to perfect a rapid response to disasters like the East Tremont fire.
"After the initial hype, unless you have people on the front lines who expedite the situation and follow through, it tends to fall to the wayside," Mr. Shiffman said.
The commissioner of the city's Department of Business Services, Wallace L. Ford 2d, insisted that the experience of the Tremont merchants was not typical. But he said he was in the midst of coordinating the efforts of agencies involved with business development, a process he called difficult and time consuming.
"You're talking about a $29 billion corporation with over 40 different agencies," he said of the city government. "It is a major reorientation task that we're talking here."
Before the fire, the block was one of the area's most stable and vibrant, a tidy strip that included a hardware store, restaurant, blueprint service and Belco Distributors. While other stores farther east on Tremont never quite rebounded from the looting after the 1977 blackout, Mr. Bell's block survived untouched. Business was so good that on some days, double-parked delivery trucks and livery cabs clogged traffic.
"It looked like we were giving out free cheese," joked Americo Torres, the manager of Belco Distributors.
Almost immediately after the fire, Mr. Bell and the others decided to rebuild. Officials from the Department of Business Services, the Economic Development Corporation and the Bronx Borough President's Office assuaged their fears the day after the fire and met with them twice in the next two weeks.
 
Many Agencies
 Francisco Gonzalez of the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation said the meetings were to coordinate city offers of technical assistance, street and facade improvements and applications for tax abatements and low-interest loans. He added that the strip was targeted for a pilot program to create a streamlined look for the new storefronts.
The Department of Business Services, recently reorganized to serve businesses better, Mr. Ford said, was helping to run interference. Barbara Wolff, the assistant commissioner, said her agency had helped insure that the police paid attention to the block in the weeks after the fire.
But Mr. Bell said that the police attention waned after three weeks, leaving his store vulnerable to the looters who struck. What irritates him even more is that the looting could have been prevented and the rebuilding begun if the promised city assistance had come through.
Although Mr. Bell has hired a contractor to clear debris and seal the hole in the roof, the contractor said that she has been lost in a thicket of city forms and requirements. When he and other store owners reported to a late August hearing on the buildings' status, they found that no meeting had been scheduled, and the representative from the city's Buildings Department was on vacation. The meeting has not been rescheduled.
 
Insurance Problems, Too
 In the meantime, Mr. Bell has been haggling with his insurer, Aetna Casualty and Surety Company, which last week offered a $108,000 settlement on a policy with a full value of $200,000. Mr. Bell said he needed $220,000 to rebuild and $10,000 to replace damaged merchandise.
Myra Packman, a lawyer advising Mr. Bell, said his situation is not uncommon among small-business owners.
Stephen Wasdick, a spokesman for Aetna, said there had been problems communicating with the adjuster hired by Mr. Bell to expedite his claim. He cited a delay getting copies of Mr. Bell's tax returns.
Mr. Wasdick said the settlement offer was less than the policy's full value because the building was not completely destroyed. He said he was optimistic of a quick settlement following recent meetings with Mr. Bell.
Jesus Rodriguez, the co-owner of Tremont and Webster Hardware, a thriving business burned beyond recognition, is not so concerned about his insurance settlement, which he thinks will cover the $400,000 in lost inventory. He is more worried about rebuilding the gutted store.
He is relying on a low-interest city loan, since a commercial loan, if he could get one, would come with prohibitive terms. Both Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Bell said they were assured by Craig Hazel of the Economic Development Corporation that such loans were available. At a meeting in late July, Mr. Rodriguez said Mr. Hazel advised him to put together his tax returns and other financial statements to begin the application process for a $250,000 loan. Mr. Rodriguez complied within a week, but he said Mr. Hazel had yet to return his phone calls.
Mr. Bell, who decided to apply for a $50,000 loan, said he got through to Mr. Hazel after calling for two months. He said he was promised an application form, but none was delivered. He finally got it last week from Elvis Herrera of the Bathgate Industrial Park Local Development Corporation, who several merchants said was one of the few people who has consistently offered help.
 
Official Responds
 Mr. Hazel denied that he had advised anyone to apply for a loan of more than $50,000, the maximum the program offers, and said he had told the merchants early on that they did not qualify because they needed more than that maximum. He said Mr. Bell adjusted his request downward after being told of the limit but has not submitted an application.
He said that the state's Urban Development Corporation could provide funding for major rebuilding if the merchants applied as a group. Steven Vitoff, a spokesman for the state agency, said there have been some exchanges of information that could lead to loans or grants.
"The city truly wants to help these people," said Joy Taylor, the Economic Development Corporation's senior vice president for lending programs. "But the program is not going to create a stir in reopening when all you do is add to their problems if you lend them money that is not sufficient."
She said the merchants had not been able to reach her agency because the phones were being upgraded.
Mr. Rodriguez said talk is all he's gotten from the city since the fire. His finances are strained, house payments are becoming burdensome and his wife has been forced to return to work. Luckily, he said, he continues to work in a Washington Heights hardware store in which he is a partner, and he has helped his former employees find work at other businesses owned by his relatives.
 
Help From Other Owners
 About the only people he said had helped him were, oddly enough, other hardware-store owners in the area, who promised to supply him with materials for rebuilding.
He laughed when he remembered the early meetings with city officials at which they told him and the other merchants that the government was 100 percent behind them. He wonders when he'll be able to reopen.
"I can understand maybe we were not knocking on doors every day," he said. "Maybe it's our fault. But who do I have to talk to to get my store? It's not my fault I lost my business."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Looks Into 'Squeeze' In Treasuries

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The "squeeze" on the Treasury's seven- and 10-year notes has become tight enough to prompt the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to collect information on dealer positions and study the dynamics of the shortage of securities.
A squeeze, which forces some traders to pay very high premiums to borrow the securities they want, is not necessarily illegal. But it can be if there is collusion involved in creating a shortage of securities. 
 The Federal Reserve Bank, which is collecting the data as part of the broadened market surveillance effort that was started after the Treasury auction scandal involving Salomon Brothers in August 1991, confirmed the special request to dealers for information yesterday.
 
Hedging Operations
 Several dealers said yesterday that they saw nothing happening beyond a normal squeeze on the 10-year note. There is a shortage of the securities because so many dealers have sold them, without actually owning them, as part of hedging operations against large holdings of corporate issues that have been difficult to sell to customers recently.
Two traders, who asked not to be identified, said Yamaichi International, a primary dealer, was at the center of the shortage of seven-year notes.
But Scott E. Pardee, co-chairman of Yamaichi, dismissed the accusations as finger-pointing. "There has been a tendency on the part of people in the center to point fingers at people who are not in the center, so I am not surprised that they are trying to point the finger at us," he said.
Mr. Pardee, a former Federal Reserve official, said traders had done similar finger-pointing at Yamaichi earlier this year in connection with a squeeze of 10-year notes, so his firm was being "scrupulously careful in this." He said the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in earlier situations, "has done a good job in making sure that no one is sitting on the bonds."
The measure of a squeeze or shortage of notes or bonds is in the repurchase market, where these securities are borrowed. In normal circumstances, a dealer swaps cash for the securities. He lends the cash to the holder of the securities at daily market rates, which are around 3 percent.
But when there is a shortage, the dealer must "pay" by lending that cash at lower than market rates, a move that benefits the dealer who has the securities. Yesterday, the rate on 10-year notes was at zero, while the rate on seven-year notes was around 1/8 of a percent.
 
Involvement of the Fed
 The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has gathered such data on seven other issues this year, including the five-year note that was auctioned in July, said a spokesman, Peter Bakstansky. "We are tying to better understand the positions in the market and the market dynamics," he said.
In similar instances earlier this year, the information gathered has gone to the interagency working group for Treasury market surveillance, which includes the Treasury, the Fed and the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Under the changes made after the Salomon bidding scandal, the Treasury said it would use its power to make additional securities available to the market to end any acute shortage or squeeze in the market. Although this weapon has not been used, the increased surveillance is part of the first step that would lead to a decision on whether to break up a squeeze.
 
Treasury Market
 Prices of bonds and notes rose yesterday, spurred by some sluggish employment figures and comments from a Federal Reserve Board governor, Wayne D. Angell.
In late trading in the secondary market, the 7.5 percent 30-year bond was offered at 981/32 , up 23/32 , to yield 7.41 percent, down from a yield of 7.48 percent on Wednesday.
"We're now in a trading range bound by the bottom yesterday and the top earlier this month," said Terrence Crowe, vice president at Nikko Securities. He was referring to the recent high yield on the 30-year bond of 7.48 percent, which was hit Wednesday, and the 7.21 percent low, which was touched on Sept. 8.
Another trader noted: "People are buying into weakness and selling into strength. So we're probably into some kind of wide trading range."
The focus of the market has already turned to the September employment report, which is to be released next Friday and will be the last such report before the Presidential election. Mr. Angell made this clear yesterday when he said in a speech in Kansas City, Mo., that the unemployment rate for this month would be higher than the consensus forecast, which is around 7.7 percent to 7.8 percent.
When the comment was reported in the afternoon, prices of bonds and notes moved higher. In the morning, the market got its first lift, when the Government reported that initial claims for unemployment compensation had risen by 15,000, to 414,000, in the week ending Sept. 12.
If the employment report is surprisingly negative, the bond market, which has fallen sharply over the last several weeks, could get a lift because investors would expect the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates again -- if not before the election, then sometime before the end of the year.

HEADLINE: Pacts Elude New York City And Unions

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
A year after most of New York City's contracts with municipal labor unions expired, contract negotiations are stalled, union officials and mayoral advisers say.
Each side blames the other for the failure to make progress in the talks, whose outcome could have a major impact both on the city's fiscal standing and on the mayoral election next year. 
 The city is projecting a budget gap of $1.3 billion for the fiscal year that begins next July, and the ability of Mayor David N. Dinkins to keep the city's finances stable will depend significantly on the size and shape of the labor settlements.
The bargaining could also play a role in the Mayor's re-election effort. Support from many municipal labor unions was critical to Mr. Dinkins's election in 1989, and at least one union official has already suggested that she might not back him next year if she remains dissatisfied with the contract talks.
 
No Move From Positions
 The major issue in the contract talks is the city's insistence that its fiscal distress is so severe that the only way it can give municipal workers a raise is through productivity savings or other union concessions. The city has not budged from its position, and neither have the unions, which say they will discuss concessions only after the Dinkins administration first puts some money on the table.
The Dinkins administration has been negotiating intermittently for months with dozens of unions, some of which have formed a large coalition for bargaining while others are negotiating on their own.
The latest round of talks with the major coalition -- a group of 15 unions that includes District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, by far the largest municipal union -- began with some fanfare in June. Since then, leaders of the coalition have met with city negotiators only twice, according to labor leaders and mayoral advisers.
"There hasn't been a whole lot of progress being made," a senior mayoral aide said. Some city officials speculate that the coalition may be waiting for the city to settle first with the teachers, although those talks, too, are languishing. In turn, some union leaders who say the teachers may have the best case for a raise speculate that the city is reluctant to settle first with the teachers.
Some small progress has been made by one of the coalition's bargaining subcommittees on a proposal for an early retirement program that could reduce the city's work force, a labor negotiator said.
And the sanitation workers agreed in principle to help finance a raise in part through concessions, as the administration has demanded, but a specific agreement eluded negotiators. In a contract reached last March, the city gave the sanitation workers a one-year raise of 3.5 percent. Both sides then said they would reach an agreement within a month that would require the trash haulers to work a more complete workday by extending their collection routes.
The route extensions in a sample collection district were then to serve as a model for achieving similar productivity gains within a year for each of New York's 59 trash-collection districts.
But the city and the union have still not reached the initial accord, and the matter is in arbitration.
Money, of course, remains at the core of the city's impasse with most of its unions. A 1 percent raise for all of the city's more than 200,000 workers would cost about $150 million a year. So a wage increase that kept pace with inflation, about 3.5 percent, that would cost the city more than $500 million a year. A three-year contract -- city officials say they are looking for a long-term deal -- would cost between $1.5 billion and $1.8 billion a year in the third year, city officials say.
The recession and the city's budget strains make such a wage increase impossible, the Mayor and his aides contend. "The traditional rules of bargaining do not apply," said one of the Mayor's advisers. "They have to work with us to help find solutions."
But many labor leaders insist that there is some flexibility in the city's $29.5 billion budget. They also contend that their workers deserve a raise and that the city has deliberately hidden money in its budget for an anticipated raise.
"The workers who run this city do a hell of a job, and they need to be treated with respect and dignity," said Stanley Hill, the executive director of District Council 37 of American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
But finances are only part of the reason for the impasse. In the private, complex world of city labor relations, there are many other forces at work that complicate the talks and make progress elusive.
City officials believe that the slow pace of the talks with Mr. Hill's coalition shows that the unions want the city first to make a deal with the United Federation of Teachers. The teachers, who contend that they are paid less than teachers in other parts of the region, may have the best argument for a significant raise.
In 1990, the city settled first with the teachers, granting a 5.5 percent increase, which Mr. Dinkins's critics contended was too much. The agreement made it difficult for other union leaders to settle for substantially less than the teachers' pact.
This year, the city's talks with the teachers are also stalled. Many labor experts suspect that the Mayor does not want to have the teachers set the standard again. At the request of the teachers union, a state mediator recently began talking with each side.
But if the Mayor thinks it is in his interest to settle first with the large coalition -- which represents more than half of the municipal work force -- he has several major hurdles to overcome. Some labor experts believe that, even if the city were to soften its posture and offer a small raise, Mr. Hill would find it very difficult then to negotiate productivity savings or other concessions.
District Council 37 is itself a huge coalition of very diverse locals. What might be a reasonable concession for city social workers, for example, might not be seen as reasonable by city hospital workers.
Complicating the talks are administrative charges filed last week against Barry Feinstein, the president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. City officials say they fear that the accusations involving union expenditures -- which are not criminal charges but which could result in his expulsion from the union -- will distract him.
Mr. Feinstein, who heads the union bargaining coalition with Mr. Hill, is a leading labor official and would ordinarily be central to any contract.
City officials say they are hopeful that a tentative agreement reached two weeks ago with the firefighters union could invigorate the other negotiations. The 30-month contract, nearly all of which is retroactive, calls for a 4.5 percent raise -- roughly the same as many of the unions won in 1990, but for a term twice as long as the other unions' 15-month deals.
Some mayoral advisers argue that the firefighters essentially settled for two 15-month contracts, the second at no raise. They suggest that the firefighters' willingness to accept no raise should be matched by the other unions, but labor leaders say they will have none of that. "I'm not going to use the firefighters as a model," Mr. Hill said.
Some city officials speculate that Mr. Hill's coalition and many of the other unions, including those representing teachers and police officers, are in no rush to make a deal. The union leaders may be hoping that, as next year's mayoral election approaches, the pressure will mount on Mr. Dinkins, forcing him to grant raises to win union endorsements.
But Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, said that if that is the labor leaders' strategy, they will be disappointed.
"The Mayor has made it clear that he has got to do the right thing for the city," Mr. Steisel said.

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
In Quayle's home state, a lawyer and ex-backer doesn't like the Republican attacks on the bar.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

DATELINE: LEBANON, Ind.

 BODY:
Among the otherwise forgettable ad hoc groups supporting this year's Presidential tickets, one seems particularly odd. In fact, it could be called "Masochists for Bush-Quayle," for it is made up of what have become the Republicans' favorite whipping boys and girls: lawyers.
On Sept. 15 the Bush campaign unveiled the names of the 100-member steering committee of Lawyers for Bush/Quayle '92. These practitioners are alike in several ways. If, as their favorite candidates contend, America has too many lawyers, none considers himself to be among the surplus. None of them have ever filed a frivolous lawsuit or harmed American competitiveness. All firmly believe that when the President and Vice President chastise lawyers, they are clearly talking about someone else. 
 But there is a dissenter on the committee, and in the unlikeliest of venues: here where Dan Quayle lived as a young boy.
Earlier this year, when Peter Obremskey of Lebanon was asked to join the steering committee, he casually agreed, then quickly forgot about it. After all, Mr. Obremskey was a lifelong Republican who cast his first vote in a Presidential election for Barry Goldwater, liked President Bush all right and knew Mr. Quayle, with whom he had played golf several times at the Ulen Country Club, a stone's throw from the house where Mr. Quayle's grandmother once lived. So his name appears on the list -- with Lebanon misspelled.
But the 56-year-old Mr. Obremskey is a trial lawyer -- one of the tassled-shoes set who, after the committee's formation, became a scourge of the Republican National Convention, along with liberals and homosexuals. Much of his livelihood comes from representing accident victims, and he is past president of the Indiana Trial Lawyers Association, which represents those representatives.
So furious is Mr. Obremskey over the Bush-Quayle bar-bashing that on Tuesday, after a reporter's call reminded him of his presence on the list, he quit the steering committee. And come November, he says, he is contemplating something even more radical: casting his first vote ever for a Democratic Presidential candidate.
Mr. Obremskey, a starting forward on the 1958 Hoosier basketball team that won the Big Ten, says his outrage is not a function of hurt feelings, wounded professional pride or economic self-interest. Instead, he says, by making scapegoats of lawyers the Bush-Quayle campaign is poisoning public perceptions of the profession, polluting jury pools and perverting the judicial process, all to score some cheap and ultimately ephemeral political points.
"It's bad for the Republican Party, it's bad for the legal profession and it's bad for the population of this country, because it impacts on the poor bastards I represent," he said.
Truth be told, few on the steering committee actually like the anti-lawyer fulminations. "They were painting with a broader brush than they needed to," said John C. Shepherd of St. Louis, a past president of the American Bar Association.
Another in the association's huge stable of former presidents, Eugene Thomas of Boise, Idaho, said the Republican standard-bearers had been "misadvised."
To Mr. Obremskey, these lawyers represent fat cats -- the fat cats at the receiving end of personal injury lawsuits -- and can afford to be forgiving. "They don't deal with people who get run over and maimed," he said. "It's the little guy who's affected by this anti-lawyer propaganda."
His partner and fellow trial lawyer, Kent Frandsen, says he feels the same way, though for him the subject is more painful. Mr. Frandsen's late father, G. Kent Frandsen, a one-time judge and director of admissions at the Indiana University Law School in Indianapolis, officiated at the Quayles' wedding ceremony. And it was the senior Mr. Frandsen who had to field the barrage of questions about just how someone with the mediocre grades and low test scores of Mr. Quayle got into law school. The experience was so stressful, his son believes, that it led his father, a healthy 61-year-old, to suffer a fatal heart attack within days of the 1988 election.
He "always had a special place in our hearts," says the handwritten note from the Vice President hanging on Kent Frandsen's office wall. But the younger Mr. Frandsen said his father would be "disappointed" to hear Dan Quayle engaging in anti-lawyer diatribes. Mr. Obremskey was more blunt: "He'd turn over in his grave."
Mr. Obremskey said he still liked Mr. Quayle and did not think he actually believed everything he said. He suggests that the Vice President, like the caddies on the Ulen links, is carrying someone else's clubs.
"By upbringing and because he was born with a silver spoon in his mouth, Dan Quayle's natural inclination is ultra-conservative," Mr. Obremskey said. "But he's just a puppy dog. He's become a tool of the far right and a pawn of big business."

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Sues 18 in Motel 6 Insider Case

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission sued a public relations executive of Motel 6 and 17 other people yesterday, accusing them of illegal insider trading in the takeover of the economy motel chain in 1990.
The suit, filed in Federal court in Manhattan, seeks repayment of $4.5 million in reportedly illegal profits and penalties of three times that amount. The civil suit also names the brokerage firm Gorman Commodities and Securities Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif. 
 The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan also filed criminal charges against two of the people who traded on the Motel 6 takeover tips.
 Dallas-based Motel 6, a nationwide chain of economy motels, was acquired by Accor, a French hotel and tourism company, in August 1990. Before the takeover, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company had owned a majority stake of Motel 6 through various partnerships.
On July 12, 1990, Accor announced it would buy Motel 6 for $22.50 a share, almost $6 a share higher than the previous day's closing price on the New York Stock Exchange.
The S.E.C. charged that Hugh Thrasher, executive vice president in charge of corporate communications at Motel 6, had told his close friend Carl Harris about the planned deal. Mr. Thrasher, who retains his position at the company, reportedly was financially supporting Mr. Harris at the time.
The suit contends that Mr. Thrasher told Mr. Harris about the deal to bestow a gift" upon him. Mr. Harris has since died.
 
Charge Is Vigorously Denied
 Charles Stillman, Mr. Thrasher's lawyer, said his client denied the charges.
"Mr. Thrasher did not trade on Motel 6 securities and he made no profits directly or indirectly on trading by others," Mr. Stillman said. "He did not tip anyone and intends to defend the S.E.C. action vigorously."
Motel 6 said in a statement that it had cooperated fully with the S.E.C. It said it was "obviously distressed" about the allegations against Mr. Thrasher, a longtime key executive, but felt it improper to comment further while the suit was pending.
In its suit, the S.E.C. is asking the court to order Mr. Thrasher to repay at least $227,939 representing illegal trading profits made by others.
The S.E.C. contended that Mr. Harris had tipped two relatives, his two roommates and numerous friends, most of whom traded on the information.
Some of those individuals paid Mr. Harris a percentage of their profits in exchange for the information and also passed the tip to others, the commission said.
Jeffery Sanker, one of Mr. Harris's roommates, and Gregg Shawzin, one of Mr. Harris's friends, were named in separate criminal charges. Both live in Beverly Hills, Calif.
The criminal charges contend that Mr. Sanker, 36 years old, who was a Los Angeles nightclub promoter, received $20,000 for tips he gave to others, which resulted in more than $480,000 in illegal profits. He is also charged with perjury.
If convicted, he faces a possible maximum prison term of 10 years and fines of more than $500,000.
Mr. Shawzin, 33, the owner of Futures Link Inc., a Beverly Hills commodities firm, reportedly made more than $550,000 from his own trades. If convicted he faces a possible maximum prison term of five years and fines of $250,000.
Of the 18 individuals named in the S.E.C. complaint, four have settled by agreeing to repay illegal profits.

HEADLINE: Economic Consensus Is Elusive

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
After a week in which currency speculation bore more fruit than international economic cooperation, finance ministers and central bankers from 172 countries left here saying that more cooperation would get the global economy moving again.
Even before high-level meetings began in Washington a week ago, the economic officials were unhappy about forecasts that the global economy would grow by a feeble 1 percent this year. Now they fear that Europe's currency crisis will make things even worse. 
 "Global prospects provide little cheer," Manmohan Singh, president of India's central bank, told the ministers. "Exchange rate volatility in the major industrial countries has added to the instability."
 
Officials Propose Solutions
 At session after session of the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, official after official insisted that there were solutions: more international economic cooperation would unlock world growth and calm frenzied currency markets, deficit cuts by big-deficit industrial nations would increase buisness confidence and reduce long-term rates, and lower trade barriers would spur growth by increasing investment.
Dozens of ministers called on the United States, Britain, Germany and Italy to adopt strong plans to reduce their deficits over the next three to five years, a move they said would go far toward easing foreign exchange tensions.
 
Accepting Their Own Advice
 "I find it somewhat ironic," said John Dawkins, the head of Australia's central bank, "that many of the developed countries have not willingly adopted the policies they have urged and, in some cases forced, upon the developing world."
Most ministers also urgently called for concluding the 108-nation Uruguay Round of talks that aim to reduce trade barriers.
Despite all the appeals for greater international cooperation, few analysts expect the major industrial powers to join hands overnight on coordinating policies. Leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations are too preoccupied with their own political and economic woes, economists said.
"Political leadership in the industrial world has weakened," said Henry Kaufman, head of an economics consulting firm. "Where are the one or two political leaders in the industrial world that can marshal resources and opinion to forge a cooperative economic effort?"
Take interest rates. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady took the lead in campaigning for Germany and other countries to lower interest rates, saying that this would give growth a shot in the arm. Privately, American officials asserted that Germany's stratospheric rates were a major drag on world growth.
Displaying the sharp tensions within the Group of Seven, German officials huffily rebuffed such pleas, saying their central bank needed to keep their rates high to cut inflation to 2 percent from 3.5 percent.
Much of the talk in the meeting rooms and in the hallways was about how problems in the three largest industrial nations -- the United States, Germany and Japan -- were dragging down everyone else in the world's increasingly interdependent economy. The economic big three are all suffering from problems undermining growth, and no one expects instant turnarounds that would allow any of the three to be a locomotive for the stalled global economy.
"The recovery is going to be less rapid than from past postwar recessions, because there's no strong driving force," said Lawrence H. Summers, the World Bank's chief economist. "Nineteen ninety-one was one of the worst years for the world economy since the war, and 1992 will be somewhat better, but not good enough."
The United States is so weighed down by low consumer confidence, a $320 billion budget deficit and heavy consumer and business debt burdens that many economists see continued sluggishness for months to come.
Germany's weak growth is not likely to pick up anytime soon because the German central bank seems intent on keeping interest rates high to bring down inflation. The Bundesbank's high rates are tugging down growth throughout Europe.
As for Japan, that much-envied dynamo, its economy slid close to recession in the second quarter because the stock market and real estate values plummeted and its banks are in shaky condition. Japan's new stimulus program of more than $86 billion provides perhaps the brightest ray of hope for heating up the world economy.
"Although Japan is the world's second-largest economy, the spillover from Japan to other countries will be fairly modest," said John Williamson, an economist with the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based research group. "The big problem is that while we expect some recovery eventually, there's nothing that will really catapult the world economy."
Michael Mussa, the International Monetary Fund's chief economists, said the world economy would gradually pick up steam, reaching a respectable 3 percent growth rate next year. He said interest rate cuts in the United States and elsewhere were already stimulating economies, adding that consumer spending and confidence should pick up as consumers worked down their debt loads.
The I.M.F.-World Bank meeting is normally the developing nations' day in the sun, but this year Europe's currency crisis completely overshadowed their concerns, making many third-world ministers complain that the rich were neglecting the poor. At the meetings, many officials fretted that Europe's currency tensions would push up long-term interest rates, push down stock prices and hurt business confidence -- in developed and developing country alike.
 
Global Interdependence Stressed
 Emphasizing how interdependent the global economy is, Lewis T. Preston, president of the World Bank, said in a closing news conference today, "The developing countries, whose prosperity depends on their exports, will suffer if these events lead to a further slowing of growth in the industrial economies."
He implored the industrial nations to do more to spur growth to help the developing world. He said that if the rich nations recovered quickly from the current slump, that would increase the third world's exports by nearly $50 billion a year. That sum, he noted, is almost equal to the foreign aid that developing nations receive each year.
If there was any good news at the meeting, it was the unexpected turnaround of the developing nations. In the past, when the industrial world caught cold, the developing world came down with pneumonia, but during the current slump, the poor outperformed the rich.
The developing world is expected to grow by more than 6 percent this year, largely because many countries in Asia and Latin America have adopted reforms aimed at speeding growth. These reforms include slashing inflation, privatizing industry and bringing budget deficits under control.
"We have the feeling that we know what are the good methods, the good recipes for this good cuisine," Michel Camdessus, the monetary fund's managing director, said in a news conference today. "We have pressed hard in this direction, and I was impressed that this now appears to be common wisdom."

HEADLINE: Short Sales Outstanding Rise Again on Nasdaq

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Furthering a trend that has persisted throughout the year, the number of shares sold short and not yet covered of all over-the-counter stocks rose between mid-August and mid-September for the eighth straight month, the National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday.
The latest monthly figures reflect trades that took place on the Nasdaq system reported as of Sept. 6 and settled as of Sept. 13. They are a widely watched gauge of investor sentiment, since they reflect the activities of a large contingent of professional sellers who specialize in ferreting out overvalued companies. 
 By borrowing the stocks of those companies and selling them at high prices, the investors are betting they will be able to buy the shares back on the cheap and keep the difference.
The mid-August through mid-September period was a difficult one for professional short-sellers, however, because Nasdaq's broad market averages moved higher, not lower.
"Despite the fact that some over-the-counter stocks had spectacular implosions, this was not a good month for short-sellers," said Steve Kibbey, a vice president at Centurion Capital in La Jolla, Calif.
Nevertheless, the market's lofty price levels, as well as continued nervousness about the economy and the Presidential election led to a 4 percent increase in outstanding short interest on Nasdaq, to 440.7 million shares, from 423.6 million in August.
Harry Strunk, an investment consultant in Palm Beach, Fla., said individual investors, and not professionals, were largely responsible for the rise last month.
"The professional short-sellers are being very cautious," he said. "They are not contributing to these numbers. In fact, they are only about 60 percent to 70 percent invested, which from those guys is pretty bullish."
Short interest in the more than 2,600 over-the-counter issues that trade on Nasdaq's National Market System amounted to 416.2 million shares, up from 399.8 million in the period of mid-July to mid-August.
Meanwhile, short interest in the 979 small-capitalization Nasdaq issues rose to 24.5 million shares, from 23.7 million in the previous month.
Among the issues showing big increases in short interest during the month was Gensia Pharmaceuticals Inc. Outstanding short positions in its stock increased more than 29 percent, to 2.2 million shares.
Those who shorted the issue then are smiling now, because earlier this week Gensia stock lost more than a third of its market value after the company said results of yearlong tests on a drug to be used in cardiac bypass surgery did not conclusively prove its effectiveness.
But those who continued to sell shares of Outback Steakhouse short are licking their wounds.
Short interest in Outback increased by 7 percent, despite the fact that the stock, which was trading around $32 a share in mid-August, has risen to more than $48 a share.

PUB-DATE: September 25, 1992

SECTION: Section D; Page 3; Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 662 words

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Insurance Stocks Surge Except for Continental

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Insurance company stocks surged yesterday on the expectation that the high losses from Hurricanes Andrew and Iniki would finally force property-casualty insurers to raise their prices on business insurance.
The rally in a host of highly regarded insurance stocks came after an announcement by the Continental Insurance Company that it had suffered losses totaling $200 million. Continental, which also said it was lowering its dividend for the first time since 1853, did not share in the rally and its stock price plunged by $6.125, to $24. 
 Just the day before, Prudential Insurance quadrupled its gross loss estimates to more than $1 billion, indicating higher overall losses to the insurance industry from Andrew than previously thought. Industry experts, still uncertain of how much the Florida toll will come to, say it may well top $10 billion.
 
Bad News Is Good News
 As strange as it sounds, such bad news could be good news to property-casualty insurers. A serious enough blow, experts say, could end the aggressive price cutting that has reduced business insurance premiums by as much as 40 percent over the last five years. Wall Street has been awaiting a turnaround in the pricing cycle.
The shares of some bellwether insurance stocks rose sharply, including, American International Group, up by $7.125, to $101.625, and the Marsh & McLennan Companies, up $5.50, to $89.
Others that rose included General Reinsurance, which jumped $8.125, to $102.50; Chubb up $4.50, to $79.25; the St. Paul Companies, up $3.375, to $72, and CNA Financial, up $3.875 to 91, as well as Cigna, up $3.25, to $50.75; Aetna, up $1.50, to $40.875, and Travelers, up 75 cents, to $22.125.
 "Its a phenomenal rally," said Orin Kramer, an economist and insurance company consultant in Fort Lee, N.J.
John H. Snyder, the senior vice president of the Property Casualty Department of A. M. Best, an insurance rating agency in Oldwick, N.J., said that it would take months to be certain that the much-awaited turn in the pricing cycle was going to take place. But, he said, it was clear that Wall Street believed it was getting close.
"The news from Prudential, from Continental means that the damage is greater than anyone imagined," Mr. Snyder said. "If there is a turn in the pricing cycle, people will want to buy just these types of stocks."
 
Leaving Reinsurance
 John P. Mascotte, chairman and chief executive of Continental, said yesterday that the company's pretax loss from Hurricane Iniki in Hawaii would total $55 million. The company had previously estimated its losses from Hurricane Andrew would come to $55 million and together with the cost of buying more catastrophe reinsurance coverage, the storm-related costs will result in a $200 million charge for the third quarter.
The company also announced it was withdrawing from the reinsurance business and from its modest international operations to concentrate capital on core businesses. That move will result in an additional $120 million charge for the quarter. Mr. Mascotte said the company was lowering its quarterly common stock dividend to 25 cents from 65 cents a share.
Continental, a New York company with $1.8 billion in capitalization or so-called consolidated surplus, writes commercial and personal insurance and has about $5 billion in annual revenues.
"This action is necessary in order to keep our business healthy," Mr. Mascotte said. "We remain confident in the soundness of our strategy, the quality of our people and the prospects for our future success."
The company also announced that its president and chief operating officer, William E. Thiele, would leave the company on Dec. 31. Mr. Mascotte will assume those positions.
Lowering the dividend was a particularly harsh move for Continental. The stock was widely held because of its high dividends and because it was one of a handful of companies that could boast it had not lowered its dividends in this century.

PUB-DATE: September 25, 1992

SECTION: Section D; Page 12; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 312 words

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in a Slow Day With Little Economic News

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in unhurried trading yesterday with no significant economic news to push it around.
In New York, the dollar closed at 120.55 yen, up from 120.15 yen late Wednesday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 120.25 Japanese yen from 122.67 yen at Tuesday's close. Tokyo markets were closed Wednesday for a national holiday. Later, in London, the dollar rose to 120.60 yen. 
 The dollar closed at 1.4850 German marks in New York, down from 1.5005 late Wednesday. In late dollar trading in Europe, the dollar hit 1.4835 German marks, down from 1.4990 late Wednesday.
 
Yen Gets Stronger
 On Wednesday, the dollar fell to a new low against the Japanese yen as investors sought a haven from the turmoil that has plagued the European currencies.
Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer for the Bank Leumi Trust Company, said the dollar traded in a narrow range yesterday during the calm that followed that battering.
"There is no economic news on which to give the dollar any strength," Mr. Waxman said. "We are sort of stuck here."
Mr. Waxman said the next possible impetus to the foreign currency market would be the German central bank meeting next week, and whether it acted on the mark.
"I think the market just doesn't know where it wants to go" without some indications, Mr. Waxman said.
In London, the British pound was unchanged at $1.7085. Later in New York it cost $1.7060 to buy one pound, less than late Wednesday's $1.7095.
 
New York Rates
 Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late rates, included: 1.3045 Swiss francs, down from 1.3095; 5.0405 French francs, down from 5.1140; 1,249.5 Italian lire, down from 1,258.00, and 1.24175 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2403.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.4835 German marks, down from 1.4990.
